webTitle: More of a sea view for Free Willy star

fields.headline: More of a sea view for Free Willy star
fields.trailText: Keiko, the killer whale that starred in the 1993 film Free Willy, swam out of his pen into a bigger enclosure in a remote Icelandic bay yesterday morning, to the delight of a nature group which hopes he can return fully to the wild this year.
fields.body:
Keiko, the killer whale that starred in the 1993 film Free Willy, swam out of his pen into a bigger enclosure in a remote Icelandic bay yesterday morning, to the delight of a nature group which hopes he can return fully to the wild this year.

The five-tonne whale poked his nose through an underwater cage, and moved into a pool of water that opens on to an enclosed area of Klettsvik bay in the Westman Islands off Iceland's south coast. This will allow the black and white orca to roam about an area more than 20 times bigger than his current home, though he will still need to be fed fish.

"It's been just a terrific day," said Charles Vinick, executive vice-president of Ocean Futures, which is rehabilitating Keiko, told Reuters by phone. This is the first attempt to return a killer whale to the wild.

Keiko was captured off Iceland in 1979 aged about two, and was the star attraction at a Mexico City amusement park before rising to fame in the film, in which a boy befriends a killer whale in a theme park and helps him escape.

His stardom drew attention to poor conditions in the park and triggered an international campaign to save him. He was taken back to Iceland in 1998.

webTitle: Waugh's winning ways finally go west

fields.headline: Waugh's winning ways finally go west
fields.trailText: After seven Test victories on the trot and an unparalleled 14 one-day internationals without defeat, it had to end sometime. Australia's apparent invincibility was finally broken yesterday by the unlikeliest of heroes when New Zealand's rookie wicketkeeper Chris Nevin hit 74 to propel the Kiwis to a seven-wicket win in the sixth and final one-day international at Auckland.
fields.body:
After seven Test victories on the trot and an unparalleled 14 one-day internationals without defeat, it had to end sometime. Australia's apparent invincibility was finally broken yesterday by the unlikeliest of heroes when New Zealand's rookie wicketkeeper Chris Nevin hit 74 to propel the Kiwis to a seven-wicket win in the sixth and final one-day international at Auckland.

The Australia captain Steve Waugh caused a surprise by tampering with his winning side, dropping the in-form openers Mark Waugh and Adam Gilchrist down the order and opening with Matthew Hayden and Damien Martyn.

Martyn carried his bat for a dogged 116, thus securing his initial position for the forthcoming three-Test series, but the plan backfired as Australia were shot out for 191, Chris Cairns taking three for 33.

New Zealand needed just 41 overs to knock off the target for the loss of three wickets, the captain Stephen Fleming supporting Nevin with an unbeaten 60. "We knew we had to play out of our skins," Fleming said afterwards. "It was very nice to break the sequence of a very good side."

Meanwhile South Africa are on target to break India's run of 13 years without losing a Test series at home as Gary Kirsten and the nightwatchman Nicky Boje put them in command of the second and final Test at Bangalore. The pair added 161 for the second wicket as the tourists, who already lead the series 1-0, ended the day on 254 for three in reply to India's 158.

Boje, the left-arm spinner playing in just his second Test, drove India's slow bowlers with ease. He hit nine boundaries in his 85 before being bowled by Anil Kumble, who has taken all three wickets.

Kirsten passed 4000 Test runs during his 79 before popping up a catch to Wasim Jaffer at short leg. Daryll Cullinan, returning to the side from injury, and Jacques Kallis consolidated South Africa's advantage by hitting out boldly in the final session.

fields.headline: We're all going to Web-ley
fields.trailText: If you are looking for a career in IT, then Wembley may be the place to kick-off your job-search on Tuesday and Wednesday.
fields.body:
If you are looking for a career in IT, then Wembley may be the place to kick-off your job-search on Tuesday and Wednesday.

Graduates in IT takes place twice a year at Wembley Conference and Exhibition Centre and is one of the biggest graduate recruitment exhibitions for graduates who are looking for a career in IT.

The two-day event is attended by more than 30 blue chip employers, offering hundreds of job opportunities for talented and ambitious would-be IT professionals.

Last year's exhibitors, for example included Admiral Computing, Allied Domecq, British Airways, CSC, Daimler Chrysler Aerospace, Dell, Deutsche Bank, Easynet, Elan Computing, Enron, Euler Trade Indemnity, GCHQ, Hewlett Packard, HSBC and IBM.

Although not essential, graduates with degree backgrounds that include computing, computer science, mathematics, statistics, business studies and engineering tend to be the most sought after by employers at the fair.

To help graduates and students attend, the organisers are offering free coach travel for groups of 20 or more students from any UK university - arrangements have been made to collect students from pick up points, take them to the event and return them on the same day.

Other attractions over the two open days include CV clinics where your current CV can be overhauled and fine-tuned free of charge; an internet

cafe where you can surf the web for job openings; career seminars and 30 minute company presenta tions where employers will discuss the job opportunities they have available.

Graduates in IT Fair, 8 and 9, 2000, Wembley Conference & Exhibition Centre, London. For more information contact the exhibitions team on 01442 289700 or see the Graduates in IT website at www.graduates-in-it.co.uk

webTitle: You don't have to be a high-tech wizard to work here...

fields.headline: You don't have to be a high-tech wizard to work here...
fields.standfirst: Ten myths that stand between you and a magic job
fields.trailText: The world of information technology may be shaking off its nerdish image, yet many graduates are still unsure of what an IT career might actually entail. So, to help those considering a first job in IT, we've asked a panel of industry experts to nominate their favourite myth before dispelling it:
fields.body:
The world of information technology may be shaking off its nerdish image, yet many graduates are still unsure of what an IT career might actually entail. So, to help those considering a first job in IT, we've asked a panel of industry experts to nominate their favourite myth before dispelling it:

Myth No.1: To work in IT you have to be a wizard at science and maths

"Possibly the oldest myth, perhaps because originally it was true," says Andrew Franklin, commercial director at Chase. "But now, the IT industry offers well paid, challenging jobs with excellent career prospects for people with a wide range of skills.

"The skills you are likely to need include communication, teamwork, problem-solving, initiative, organisation and adaptability. A strong technical background is not necessary for a successful career in IT - all you need is the appropriate aptitude and ability."

"Customers want answers and these need to be explained in clear terms so graduates don't have to be technical wizards to guarantee getting a job," says David Plummer, managing director of Triage Consulting, an IT and telecomms recruitment consultancy.

"Any qualification that is electronic/or IT-based will stand graduates in good stead when going for that 'elusive' first job. But because of the current skills shortage graduates should not feel that they will be ignored if they have arts degrees. Most companies have training programmes - it is in their interests to have ultra- competent staff so they will teach employees what they need to know.

"It's no longer the case that a technical person can 'hide in the corner' and do their job; they need to be able to explain the problem in layman terms - so graduates with what is perceived to be a more rounded arts degree may well find themselves being sought after.

"But graduates need to be prepared to continue learning - the IT sector is fast moving and companies that refuse to adapt will fail, so the onus is on graduates to show initiative and willingness to learn."

Myth No.2: Jobs in IT always involve staring at a screen

"In fact, screen work is probably the minor activity in IT," claims Tim Illingworth, managing director for UK operations at Matra Datavision. "Much more time is spent defining the problem and then developing a solution will meet the goals of both the users and the business.

"All this involves good communication skills, the ability to analyse situations and a commitment to deploying really effective solutions."

Myth No.3: A job in IT is a job for life

"Some people believe that the IT industry offers job security because no one understands it and therefore leave the IT experts to get on with things," says David Plummer. "But this is not true. Many jobs are awarded on a project basis so security only lasts as long as the job itself."

Myth No.4: If you work with IT you don't work with people

"Business is about people and business is about computers," says Andrew Wilder, director at Software Business Network. "The truth is, virtually all IT activities must relate to people, either in serving their needs, as a customer interface or to produce information sought by an individual."

Myth No.5: IT does not offer any career opportunities for women

Simply not true, says Wendy Mason, human resources director at ICL. "Because it offers flexible hours and work locations, a career in IT can be especially attractive to women, as many firms accommodate part-time, work from home and work-share arrangements."

Myth No.6: You have to be an anorak

"This industry is about being hot, and when you're hot, you don't wear an anorak," says Tim Conway of CP Research. "To work in the IT industry you have to be much more than a 'techie' - you need good business skills, the ability to convert concepts to action and market your ideas."

Myth No.7: There is no career structure in IT

"The rise of e-business means IT is now part of everyone's job and is just as much a profession and part of the business community as accounting or law," maintains John Pocock, chief executive of IT management consultancy Druid.

Myth No.8: You have to start at an early age

"People can be trained in IT at virtually any age, from any background. Current technologies are user friendly and there are large number of IT trainers who offer career change courses," says Trish Boag, director of Kuorum International

Myth No.9: You must have all the latest skills

Not necessarily, says Suzy Frith, chairman of Citigate Technology. "While it is important to keep up to date and most employers invest heavily in staff training to ensure this, it is not crucial, as many IT systems last decades and require regular support.

"Many employers want people with a consistent skill set and long-term experience to solve problems in existing systems."

Myth No.10: Computers cost people jobs

"In fact, more people now work in the software and services industry than the coal mining industry at its peak," says John Higgins, director general at the Computer Services and Software Association.

webTitle: Been there, done that, got the degree certificate ...

fields.headline: Been there, done that, got the degree certificate ...
fields.standfirst: But have you got the right skills?
fields.trailText: Postgraduate courses, like evening classes, often seem like a good idea at the time. Somehow we hope that the act of signing up for a year or more and handing over a significant wad of cash will provide a sufficient boost to our career prospects, making the hours of hard graft to gain the qualification worthwhile.
fields.body:
Postgraduate courses, like evening classes, often seem like a good idea at the time. Somehow we hope that the act of signing up for a year or more and handing over a significant wad of cash will provide a sufficient boost to our career prospects, making the hours of hard graft to gain the qualification worthwhile.

For some graduates it can be little more than a delaying tactic, putting off the evil day when they have to decide what they will do with their working lives. But in most cases a good postgraduate qualification will enhance your development and skills, building on those you have already gained at either undergraduate level or through your work and life experiences. It will stand you in good stead whatever you decide to do in the future and can only enhance your career prospects.

In recent years there has been a proliferation of courses designed to prepare graduates for specific job market. Courses with more academic or theoretical emphasis tend to be masters programmes; those with a more applied or practical bent often lead to postgraduate diplomas.

In particular the demand from the IT industry for suitably qualified and skilled graduates has seen a rapid development of computing-related postgraduate degrees.

London Guildhall University, for example offers postgraduate qualifications in computing, information systems and multimedia as well as an MSc in information systems development.

Applicants are usually expected to have an honours degree with a substantial computing component. However, the university says graduates with an appropriate industry or business background may also be considered and in "certain exceptional circumstances", those with extensive experience in a relevant area may also be considered eligible.

The LGU teaching programme aims to develop an understanding of the core skills of systems development. The university says it provides graduates with the knowledge and skills required to prepare them to work on the analysis, design and implementation of information systems in a commercial context.

The structure of the courses is modular, making it more accessible for those in work and where possible, the modules have also been designed to be free-standing to allow students an even greater measure of flexibility.

According to the university, many of its students go on to work in areas such as database applications programming, systems administration and analysis, design and development, or systems research in industrial R&D environments.

The LGU also offers an MSc in IT consultancy, providing graduates with an opportunity to study the latest developments in IT applications, acquire skills and develop an understanding of the issues affecting individuals, organisations and society.

The MSc is based on an inter- disciplinary approach and aimed primarily at people who wish to work in a freelance capacity, possibly on short-term or long-term contracts, or in IT-related project work in their own companies.

There are plenty of IT conversion courses on offer which concentrate on computing and the business applications of IT, but Heriot-Watt University in Edinburgh claims its MSc and Diploma in information technology have a unique emphasis.

The aim of its courses, says the university is to provide a broad-based introduction to IT, with options in business, systems or human computer interaction. Heriot-Watt says the course has been taken successfully by students from a wide range of disciplines but stresses that it is "not suitable for graduates in the arts". No previous computing experience is required, but the university expects applicants to have at least a first or second class honours degree in science, mathematics, non-electrical engineering or business studies - including at least a course in probability or statistics.

webTitle: A school career has its attractions after all

fields.headline: A school career has its attractions after all
fields.standfirst: Teaching can be "intellectually challenging and fun"
fields.trailText: The days of rock-bottom morale and low pay are finally over, making teaching a more attractive career move than it has been for years.
fields.body:
No one forgets a good teacher, runs the now infamous line. From Tony Blair downwards, celebrities virtually queued up to name the man or woman who had inspired them at their alma mater. Whether you believed them or not didn't matter - for the first time teaching suddenly became sexy.

This year the Teacher Training Agency (TTA) is looking to recruit around 25,000 trainees to the profession and, more than likely, many of those applicants will be switching from other careers, tempted by the chance to make a difference - not to mention the long holidays.

If you'd talked to most teachers five years ago, you'd have found morale at rock bottom. Pay and conditions were way behind equivalent professionals jobs and vast numbers of staff were leaving the industry. So, what happened?

"Teaching has changed," says the TTA's new chief executive, Ralph Tabberer. "Traditionally people went into teaching as a life long career but as the employment market has changed, so we've had to. We're now selling the profession as one you no longer have to sign up to for life, but one in which you can learn transferable skills that other employers are looking for.

"Of course, we still want the people who will stay for the whole of their careers, but it's no longer a pre-requisite."

Certainly the profession has attempted to sort out one of the reasons that many left its ranks - pay. Today teachers with a couple of years' experience and who have also demonstrated competency in key areas are earning close to £30,000 - half of new teachers are expected to make this grade.

Also, newly-qualified graduates planning to teach maths, sciences or modern European languages are paid a £5,000 "golden hello" as a stepped bonus. Half is paid in two tranches as they go through the training and the remaining £2,500 once they take up a position at a state school.

Add to this TTA's new fast track graduate programme which will accelerate the top people through the ranks, and it's actually starting to look quite attractive.

Although the TTA is unable to say how many graduates have switched careers as a result of the "No one forgets" ad campaign, its enquiry line did receive 11,000 calls from those interested - up 20% on the year before. "There's certainly anecdotal evidence that a lot of graduates have switched from careers in areas such as banking or insurance and are already accelerating through the profession," says Tabberer.

One graduate who was partly inspired by the ad is Tamazin Steele. She is half way through her PGCE and currently on teaching practice at a school in East Croydon. "When I left college I thought about teaching but when it came to it, the idea went out of the window and I followed most of my friends into the City, partly lured by the money. I was working as an assistant manager for Gartmore Investment Management but I soon realised it wasn't me. I found I was pushing bits of paper around the office and, in the main, every day was the same.

"After finally deciding to leave and despite a couple of false starts, I left and went travelling for three months. I even went back to another job in the City before realising teaching was the right move. Now I'm here, I wish I'd done it earlier.

"Although the first day of teaching was terrifying, now I've settled down the level of job satisfaction is in a different league and every day is different, even though it's often the same children. The challenge is teaching classes of differing abilities and working out which ones need extra help at which stage."

Interestingly, Steele who is 25, reports that only half of the 25 people on her course have come straight from college, while the others have done everything else from being mothers to working in advertising.

One area she has been less than happy with is the problem of getting the local education authority to sort out student loans. "Lots of the group are still waiting for the money months after starting the course. I'm sure they'll be quicker to get in touch when we're qualified," she says.

Another graduate who has turned his back on the world of company cars is Nigel Fisher. When Rise caught up with him last week, he was preparing to take a class load of 17-year olds for the half-term ski trip to the French Alps. Fisher now works in a sixth form college in Brighton but was previously an environmental consultant.

"I was assessing the environmental impact of road schemes and power stations and enjoying it. I'd had quite a varied career, had worked abroad for a while and had risen to the dizzy heights of associate within the company. At that stage I thought I would be doing it forever and probably would have been had I not changed jobs. Within days of joining a new company it was re-organised and I was out before I had started."

He had also thought about teaching after leaving college but had dismissed it preferring to go and do something else first.

"Suddenly the time seemed right. I borrowed loads of money and sponged off my then girlfriend, now my wife and did the PGCE."

Fisher trained in a secondary school and now teaches A levels. He describes himself as having found his metier. "I really like working with this age group and I do feel I make a difference. One of the best things is seeing kids that you've helped go on to further education, who ten years ago probably wouldn't have.

"The other thing I've been surprised at is how much teamwork there is between teachers and how supportive of each other they are. It's also been intellectually challenging - and fun." And is he a better teacher for having done something else first? "Definitely. I would have been useless at 21."

For more details, contact the Teaching Information Line on 01245 454454.

"Of course, we still want the people who will stay for the whole of their careers, but it's no longer a pre-requisite." Certainly the profession has attempted to sort out one of the reasons that many left its ranks - pay. Today teachers with a couple of years' experience and who have also demonstrated competency in key areas are earning close to £30,000 - half of new teachers are expected to make this grade. Also, newly-qualified graduates planning to teach maths, sciences or modern European languages are paid a £5,000 "golden hello" as a stepped bonus. Half is paid in two tranches as they go through the training and the remaining £2,500 once they take up a position at a state school. Add to this TTA's new fast track graduate programme which will accelerate the top people through the ranks, and it's actually starting to look quite attractive. Although the TTA is unable to say how many graduates have switched careers as a result of the "No one forgets" ad campaign, its enquiry line did receive 11,000 calls from those interested - up 20% on the year before. "There's certainly anecdotal evidence that a lot of graduates have switched from careers in areas such as banking or insurance and are already accelerating through the profession," says Tabberer. One graduate who was partly inspired by the ad is Tamazin Steele. She is half way through her PGCE and currently on teaching practice at a school in East Croydon. "When I left college I thought about teaching but when it came to it, the idea went out of the window and I followed most of my friends into the City, partly lured by the money. I was working as an assistant manager for Gartmore Investment Management but I soon realised it wasn't me. I found I was pushing bits of paper around the office and, in the main, every day was the same. "After finally deciding to leave and despite a couple of false starts, I left and went travelling for three months. I even went back to another job in the City before realising teaching was the right move. Now I'm here, I wish I'd done it earlier. "Although the first day of teaching was terrifying, now I've settled down the level of job satisfaction is in a different league and every day is different, even though it's often the same children. The challenge is teaching classes of differing abilities and working out which ones need extra help at which stage." Interestingly, Steele who is 25, reports that only half of the 25 people on her course have come straight from college, while the others have done everything else from being mothers to working in advertising. One area she has been less than happy with is the problem of getting the local education authority to sort out student loans. "Lots of the group are still waiting for the money months after starting the course. I'm sure they'll be quicker to get in touch when we're qualified," she says. Another graduate who has turned his back on the world of company cars is Nigel Fisher. When Rise caught up with him last week, he was preparing to take a class load of 17-year olds for the half-term ski trip to the French Alps. Fisher now works in a sixth form college in Brighton but was previously an environmental consultant. "I was assessing the environmental impact of road schemes and power stations and enjoying it. I'd had quite a varied career, had worked abroad for a while and had risen to the dizzy heights of associate within the company. At that stage I thought I would be doing it forever and probably would have been had I not changed jobs. Within days of joining a new company it was re-organised and I was out before I had started." He had also thought about teaching after leaving college but had dismissed it preferring to go and do something else first. "Suddenly the time seemed right. I borrowed loads of money and sponged off my then girlfriend, now my wife and did the PGCE." Fisher trained in a secondary school and now teaches A levels. He describes himself as having found his metier. "I really like working with this age group and I do feel I make a difference. One of the best things is seeing kids that you've helped go on to further education, who ten years ago probably wouldn't have. "The other thing I've been surprised at is how much teamwork there is between teachers and how supportive of each other they are. It's also been intellectually challenging - and fun." And is he a better teacher for having done something else first? "Definitely. I would have been useless at 21." For more details, contact the Teaching Information Line on 01245 454454.

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: • Porterhouse blues: Universities face a new brain drain as the brightest graduates shun academic careers, according to new research published by Industrial Relations Services. One in three academics is over 50, and the next generation of researchers are choosing better paid jobs in the private sector and abroad.
fields.body:
 Porterhouse blues: Universities face a new brain drain as the brightest graduates shun academic careers, according to new research published by Industrial Relations Services. One in three academics is over 50, and the next generation of researchers are choosing better paid jobs in the private sector and abroad.

 Event of the Week: Graduate recruitment managers at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter could only watch in horror as Oxford University students exploited the generosity of their hosts, running up a bar bill of more than £8,000. The event descended into a drunken shambles when brawling broke out and the arguing factions were asked to leave the cafe.

 Book of the Week: Even successful young professionals like you can feel frustrated and bored. With a little help from Dilbert and Far Side cartoons, author John Clark suggests some ways of putting the enjoyment back into work. Published by Random House, The Money or Your Life can be ordered at the special price of £7.99 (plus p&p) from our Cultureshop on 0800 3166102.

 Moving pictures: Employers seeking to motivate their workers could do worse than show them a couple of films, say therapists in the US where movies are the hot new prescription. For example, a film like Shakespeare in Love , might cure an employee of cynicism about their work reckons John Hesley, a clinical psychologist in Arlington, Texas.

 Dressing up: Hoping to give the office-wear pendulum a push back toward the suit, the American menswear industry has formed a task force to promote Dress-up Thursday. Organisers say they haven't been able to find any empirical evidence to support their belief that "better dress means better production", but "we are planning a research project".

 Office foreplay: Impress your boss and colleagues with your golfing prowess in the Glenlivet Office Putting Championships where entrants are invited to create their very own putting green at work. The final will take place at Seagram's HQ in Hammersmith. Ring 0181250 1031 for more details.

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Pass the salt
fields.trailText: Lunch etiquette
fields.body: If a prospective employer offers to buy you lunch, enjoying a good meal is not the intent. Every move you make will be analysed says image consultant Melissa Stevens. Use price as a guideline in ordering, she suggests, as you want to appear gracious, not gluttonous. "Look at the highest and lowest in the price brackets. Then go for the middle range. Don't even think about having a cigarette." If the employer suggests a drink or a cigarette as a test, resist. "And don't salt and pepper until you've tasted your food. It could indicate you have a trust problem -like you don't trust the chef to season your food."

fields.headline: Cool companies: No 28. Redstone Telecom
fields.trailText: Redstone Telecom is not some kind of pinko telephone operator, but a thrusting young company aiming to be the champion of small and medium-sized firms. Just five-years old, it is fast coming of age as its national telecoms network takes on the might of BT, CWC and Energis in the business sector.
fields.body:
Redstone Telecom is not some kind of pinko telephone operator, but a thrusting young company aiming to be the champion of small and medium-sized firms. Just five-years old, it is fast coming of age as its national telecoms network takes on the might of BT, CWC and Energis in the business sector.

In that short space of time, it has developed from being a single product, indirect switch-based reseller to a direct facilities-based national network service provider with a broad product range and quality customer base by offering telecom capacity on a need-to-use basis. This way, it can undercut larger players in the regional business market and stick up for small and medium-sized companies which, it says, have largely missed out on the benefits of de-regulation and competition.

Redstone has adopted a business model based on US local exchange carriers, and intends to exploit opportunities from the opening of the 'local loop' - the final connection between the exchange and the home or office .

The idea is to build fibre-optic connections from its existing network to BT exchanges.

The company was granted its licence to run a public telephone network by the Department of Trade and Industry in 1995. The major part of its existing business is indirect access, personal numbering and various business telecom services such as freephone and local rate call service.

Thanks to its underlying national network and support infrastructure, Redstone has seen voice-based service revenues grow from £1.8m in 1996-97 to £23.2m in 1998-99. The flotation of Redstone in October 1999 raised further investment capital.

Moreover Oftel, the industry regulator, has recently confirmed that network operators such as Redstone will have access rights to BT's local copper-line network for higher bandwidth services.

Unified messaging is another growth area for the company -allowing voicemail, fax and email all to be stored in digitised form in a single message box which can then be accessed by a number of methods. This will be of particular value to Redstone's core customers. Small and medium-sized businesses, who find the proliferation of messages a particular problem will simply be able to locating a message box on a server in the Redstone network.

The company is also targeting business users travelling abroad. Its latest service, Callsure, offers savings of more than 70% when receiving calls on mobile phones overseas.

If you'd like to apply for a job with Redstone, send a full CV to Redstone Telecom, Premiere House, Elstree Way,Borehamwood, Herts WD6 1JH. Alternatively you can email your CV to
human.resources@redstone.co.uk. Don't forget to include a contact number, quoting Ref WP01 and the position you're interested in applying for.

fields.headline: Shock jock
fields.trailText: Gill Mills, TV and radio presenter
fields.body:
Name: Gill Mills

Status: TV and radio presenter

Past: Graduated from Glasgow University with an MA in film, TV and theatre studies, then set up her own video archive company which serviced theatre companies and Glasgow city council. Launched her TV career after taking a £50-a-week job as a runner on BBC's Big Country.

Present: Prolific presenter with an opinion slot on a political programme, a night-time show on Radio 1, a careers programme on digital channel BBC Knowledge and a review and entertainment show on Scottish TV.

Future: "I'd rather be a presenter than a personality. I want to be hired for my ability to communicate rather than because I look good in a frock."

Strengths: "I'm a good communicator and have a quick and incisive mind."

Weaknesses: "I tend to be overbearing in order to make a point."

Wisdom: "Be persistent, think laterally and get multi-skilled. And never think you're too good for a job."

References: www.bbc.co.uk/knowledge

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to career-limiting moves

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to career-limiting moves
fields.trailText: Developing a gloriously successful career often means compromising in other areas. We offer you three steps to career heaven and social hell.
fields.body:
A. Late availability

If you've decided you want a gloriously successful career and are determined not to let the pursuit of happiness stand in your way, you need to spot factors that could hold you back. Most employers are jealous masters reserving the richest rewards for those who show single-minded devotion. To hint there's something else you'd rather be doing calls into question your commitment. Availability at all times is vital.

B. Place your bid

Avoid developing a taste for extended travel. Most employers think six weeks holiday a year is more than generous - you need to be convincingly grateful for it. Learn to be flexible and adaptable; see advantage where advantage lies. Forget having principles and sticking up for them: that will leave you stranded on the moral high ground. Be careful where you choose to live, the nicest places are career black holes. If you're willing to move regularly or settle where no one else wants to be, there's less competition.

C. Care-free

Any form of emotional attachment is limiting. Falling in love with a person or a place is the surest way of creating your own glass ceiling. However, the most serious and lasting mistake you can make is having children. Family-friendly working policies may make life manageable for a lucky few, but generally look better on paper than they are in reality. Even if you do earn enough to pay someone else to love them, you'll be suspected of split loyalties.

webTitle: Lara calls time out for 'personal reasons'

fields.headline: Lara calls time out for 'personal reasons'
fields.trailText: Brian Lara, who sent seven million West Indians into shock a week ago by giving up the captaincy, yesterday induced haemorrhage by pulling out of the Test and one-day series against Zimbabwe and Pakistan that begins here in less than a fortnight.
fields.body:
Brian Lara, who sent seven million West Indians into shock a week ago by giving up the captaincy, yesterday induced haemorrhage by pulling out of the Test and one-day series against Zimbabwe and Pakistan that begins here in less than a fortnight. It is not yet clear whether he will be available to tour England this summer.

Lara wrote to the West Indies Cricket Board of Control advising that he had decided it was "essential for personal reasons" that he take "a break from cricket for a short period with immediate effect".

During his time away from the game, Lara said, he would seek help from "appropriate professionals to rebuild all facets" of his game and sustain the remainder of his career.

Lara's language, as it was last week, was carefully couched so as not to suggest any disagreement with the board but few West Indians believe his departure is due solely to the team's poor performance. The board's treatment of Lara's mentor, Sir Vivian Richards, can hardly have encouraged him to stay.

Richards stepped into the breach as team coach after the late Malcolm Marshall's illness forced his early retirement. Most West Indians assumed Richards would continue as coach but, during the disastrous New Zealand tour, the board advertised applications for his job and required minimum formal qualifications that Richards could not meet.

The subsequent appointment of Roger Harper to replace Richards and the board's manner of informing him - he was told by a junior official instead of the chief executive officer Stephen Camacho - led to demonstrations outside the board's offices in Antigua and an unequivocal public apology from Camacho.

Lara could not have been pleased, either, by the board's decision to begin a compulsory training camp on the weekend of the Trinidad Carnival, the island's biggest festival and one in which Lara is a highly visible participant.

The Trinidad board president Alloy Lequay said there was a long-standing understanding that Trinidadian players would be exempt from such activities at carnival time.

Should the board stick to its guns, though, even if Lara finds that he needs only a very short break from cricket, he will not be permitted to play in the Zimbabwe and Pakistan games.

fields.headline: In defence of Talk Radio
fields.standfirst: Amid all the clamour for the return of TMS, 16-year-old Chris Wilson argues that it's good to Talk
fields.trailText: In defence of Talk Radio.
fields.body:
It's Thursday 25th November at 8.30am. I am on my way to college, headphones on, heart throbbing in eager anticipation of the first Test between South Africa and England. For the first time I tune into 1089AM. It's Talk Radio (soon to become TalkSport), and I hear my favourite commentator Mark Nicholas describing the most awful start England have ever had (and surely will ever have). He screams and shouts with interruptions from Geoff Boycott and I am enthralled. The only shame is that I have to go into lessons.

It was the most exciting moment in sport since that semi-final and it was made all the better by the youthful, exuberant coverage of Talk Radio. Yet, in the next day's paper all I read about the coverage was that the poor journalists had been watching television while listening to Talk, while having to put up with a 30-second delay.

Oh dear. Most listeners were at work or in the car and were none the wiser of the delay, so what did it matter? Besides, there were important issues at stake: we did not hear about passing busses, nor did we hear Trevor 'The Boil' Bailey going on about the 1950s, and thank goodness, we did know what was "going off out there". Boycott called a spade a spade, the language of Nicholas was lucid and colourful, and together they brought us the full picture. It was not mindless screaming and it was not dull boredom: it was a brilliant mix of excitement and description.

Suddenly, though, everyone was longing for TMS. But as I said in an e-mail to TMS editor Peter Baxter, their coverage of the last South Africa tour in 1995 did not start until 9am. Had they had the rights this winter and started at the same time, the most dramatic start to a Test match in history would have been missed. In addition to this, we would have listened to the SABC commentary, which is more biased than Nigel Starmer-Smith commentating on England rugby internationals.

True, Regus.com was annoying, as was Jack Bannister at times, not to mention the adverts, but what a find Chris Cowdrey was. I hope we hear him during the summer on Channel 4. There was no shipping forecast, and the coverage continued after the close of play and during lunch, just like on the television. It was complete coverage revolutionising cricket on the radio and I do hope that they continue in the same vein during their county coverage this summer.

After March's WCM, I would like to give my marks out of ten for the Talk team:

Mark Nicholas - 9/10: as good on the radio as on the TV.
Geoff Boycott - 8/10: a spade is a spade.
Chris Cowdrey - 8/10: he's got a bright future.
Bob Woolmer - 7/10: when you can understand him he has brilliant insights
Graeme Pollock - 5/10: only there to provide balance, lacked humour and character.
Jack Bannister - 3/10: should stick to the Birmingham Evening Post.

Role on Pakistan and "Talk at the Test". Maybe the gnashing of teeth - simply because it's not the BBC - will have stopped by then. I hope so.

fields.headline: Lacey
fields.standfirst: Platini seasons his pie in the sky
fields.trailText: At least Michel Platini's scheme for a homogenised world football season lacks nothing in imagination. Now it is even easier to believe that a committee, asked to design a horse, would indeed come up with a camel or, if ordered to produce a ship of the desert, would attach caterpillar tracks to the Titanic.
fields.body:
At least Michel Platini's scheme for a homogenised world football season lacks nothing in imagination. Now it is even easier to believe that a committee, asked to design a horse, would indeed come up with a camel or, if ordered to produce a ship of the desert, would attach caterpillar tracks to the Titanic.

Platini, who is Fifa's technical adviser, envisages a global season running from February to November, with July and August given over to international tournaments, a month's break in December, and January used for pre-season training. This is about as likely to be accepted as the ban on tackling once proposed, in all seriousness, by the Platini-led Fifa task force.

As a player Platini has had few equals but as an ideas man he is beginning to recall Bob Newhart's imagined telephone conversation with Sir Walter Raleigh, who has just discovered tobacco. "What's that Wal? You roll up dried leaves... aha... then what Wal?... no, don't tell me... you stick 'em in your ear!"

Yet just as Raleigh's unhealthy idea caught on, so the spirit of Platini's proposals should not be laughed into oblivion as one more crackpot notion from the Fifa funny farm. The world's players are being asked to play too much football. For three years, from the start of the 1999-2000 season to the end of the 2002 World Cup, many will not get a meaningful break, and this can only endanger playing standards.

Platini's heart, then, is in the right place. The trouble with his plan is that it approaches the problem of overplaying from the wrong angle.

His scheme would give the world 76 days for football matches with 46 allocated to domestic league and cup competitions and the rest devoted to international tournaments at representative and club level. Just where the television schedules come in is unclear. Certainly the Sky people would be getting some long holidays.

The only way to reduce the number of competitive fixtures throughout the world is to reduce the number of competitions, but that would be fiercely resisted by the game's various national and international bodies.

Even if Fifa does approve the Platini plan, it will be rejected by Uefa, who would break away from the world body rather than turn the European season inside out. True, the Scandinavians and the Russians do already play summer football but for them that is a meteorological necessity.

The Football Association and the Premier League have been swift to declare their opposition to a scheme that, in theory, would see the FA Cup final played in November. Given the way the FA Cup has gone lately it is surprising this has not already occurred to Lancaster Gate but the police would probably have insisted on a Sunday morning kick-off because the clocks had gone back.

Platini's ideas struggle for rationality. Japan may play its national league in two phases but is hardly a template for the game as a whole. Setting aside July and August for the World Cup and European Championships may make more sense but still ignores the qualifying competitions.

Football needs fewer matches but that is not going to be achieved simply by juggling the calendar. By all means have a month's break but, if this is merely a ruse to accommodate the wretched Fifa World Club Championship on an annual basis, then forget it.

A fundamental change of attitude, from Fifa level right down to club boardrooms, will be needed before the game gets off the global treadmill. Fat chance, with the InterToto Cup no longer a summer irrelevance but an early route to the Uefa Cup, the European body set on a Nations Cup to replace international friendlies and a fully fledged European League virtually upon us.

For Platini's plan to work, no national league would comprise more than 18 clubs, yet in England only Manchester United and Arsenal have consistently been in favour of reducing the size of the Premiership. The rest would strongly object to the prospect of losing income by cutting two home matches from the fixture list. More than a few are finding it hard to meet the spiralling cost of players' wages as it is.

Old Trafford, now assured of crowds of around 60,000 for each home game, might welcome fewer Premiership matches and only this week Sir Alex Ferguson queried the size of the Champions League, which he reckons now involves too many games. But for a club such as Derby County, who so far this season have played 30 matches compared with Manchester United's 40, trimming the league would court disaster.

And what about the lower divisions? The bulk of the Nationwide clubs would go out of business if Platini had his way, and the pattern would be repeated across Europe.

In any case, where is the frozen fun in watching Oldham in June rather than January, and what would the Oldham squad think of reporting back for pre-season training in January rather than July?

No, Platini's calendar is designed principally for Fifa's administrative convenience and does not offer a practical means of easing the global game's workload. Platini must realise this, which may be why he did not turn up for the launch this week.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: This is the Saturday morning bible of the football connaisseur. And, biensur, you are one. OK, OK just read it, all right?
fields.body:
Good news at last for Clydebank - membership of their Isle of Wight supporters' club branch has topped the dozen mark. Fans at the Woodvale Hotel have clubbed together to send half-time tea and biscuits to the winless Scottish First Division club. The IoW Bankies, who began by sending faxes of support to the club, have yet to receive anything concrete in return - they asked for a match programme, but Clydebank cannot afford to produce one. However, they did elicit the understatement of the season from the coach Stephen Morrison, who commented: "The players have seen the faxes and it does give them all a lift, especially as things are not going our way on the pitch at the moment."

 It's going to be a long and quarrelsome road to the 2002 World Cup if the opening match is any guide. Today's visit of Netherlands Antilles to Trinidad and Tobago not only comes at a time of turmoil in T&T over the sacking of coach Bertille St Clair - a decision succinctly described by Dwight Yorke as "crap". Controversy also extends to the name of the venue. Fans in Port of Spain will be heading to the Hasely Crawford stadium. To Fifa, however, the ground is known as the "Havelange Center of Excellence".

 The week's most baffling opinion comes from Ingrid Tarrant, wife of DJ Chris, interviewed in Match Of The Day magazine.

"Q: Does Chris ever get all his mates round for a kick-about?

"A: If there's a major Man Utd game on, we get together with Errol Brown of Hot Chocolate and his wife. I get involved in the atmosphere, but I'm rooting with Chris rather than for the teams."

 High-minded indignation after Bayern Munich's 4-2 victory over Real Madrid this week. "The Real manager said before the match, Germans can't play," one Bayern player fumed. "Well, he knows better now, I guess. He should shut up, this Mr Camacho or Caramba or whatever his name is." (That's Vicente del Bosque to you.) Stereotypical German arrogance, you might think. Except that the player was the Brazilian Giovane Elber.

 The phones will have been running hot at Vodafone yesterday, after the announcement that Manchester United have agreed a deal for the formula one team Arrows to carry the club's website logo on their cars. After paying £30m to get their name on United's shirts, Vodafone will hardly relish the sight of the new orange Arrows cars. That's orange as in Orange.  Spare a thought for Liverpool's Sander Westerveld, mercilessly dragged from his bed to face Manchester United this morning. "I love to have a good sleep before a game," the Dutch giant admits on his personal website. "On Saturday, however, I will maybe have to wake up at 8.30 and have my pre-match meal half an hour later. You try eating spaghetti at nine o'clock in the morning!" It's the toughest league in the world, Sander.

webTitle: Vogts makes play for Celtic job

fields.headline: Vogts makes play for Celtic job
fields.trailText: Bertie Vogts, for reasons best known to himself, has applied for the job of Celtic manager. A World Cup winner as a player, if Vogts is appointed he will become the first German to take charge of a British side.
fields.body:
Bertie Vogts, for reasons best known to himself, has applied for the job of Celtic manager. A World Cup winner as a player, if Vogts is appointed he will become the first German to take charge of a British side.

His surprise application could be hard for the Glasgow club to turn down. It will certainly meet with the approval of fans who insisted that the appointment of such an inexperienced figure as John Barnes was a major error.

Vogts, who resigned as manager of his national side after the 1998 World Cup, has impeccable credentials and the matter may now rest with Kenny Dalglish, the club's director of football, whose willingness to team up with the German will be crucial.

Dalglish, in temporary charge of first-team affairs, confirmed Vogts' expression of interest but stressed there has been no contact beyond that.

Dalglish said: "Certainly somebody has put his name forward but we've not approached anybody. We're no further on than what we have been in our search for a head coach. That's basically it. Bertie Vogts' advisers have contacted us to say he would be interested in the post. End of story."

The possible appointment of the 53-year-old Vogts will be the talk of the plastic seats at Easter Road tomorrow night when Celtic take on Hibs. With an Old Firm game against Rangers looming on Wednesday, any indication that Celtic are to enlist a European coach would be a boost as a possible counterweight to Rangers' Dick Advocaat, a former manager of Holland.

The Vogts saga could add spice to the dramatic slog being played out in the Premier League where, with two thirds of the season gone, eight of the 10 clubs cannot rule out relegation.

Motherwell may well be third, a place that would earn them European football if they could hang on to it, but they are only nine points ahead of the fast-improving Aberdeen - who are currently in the relegation play-off position.

Motherwell have won only twice in their last 10 matches, one a cup replay. That spell coincides with the departure of the defender Shaun Teale after a contract dispute which ended with the club chairman John Boyle claiming that he had lost a yard of pace. Today they face Aberdeen at Fir Park.

Elsewhere Kilmarnock, improving like Aberdeen, play Dundee, a club in turmoil who already this week have conceded 13 goals to the Old Firm.

The only beneficiaries today would appear to be Rangers, who should comfortably beat St Johnstone and then rest up before next week's game against Celtic.

fields.headline: The World Cup starts today
fields.standfirst: Scramble for 2002 places kicks off amid Caribbean carnival: Around the world in 809 games
fields.trailText: The footballing wallahs at Fifa will be feeling a little smug today. The game's governing body could hardly have picked a more vibrant place to begin the marathon journey to the 2002 World Cup finals this evening than Port of Spain's Hasley Crawford National Stadium.
fields.byline: BC Pires in Port of Spain and Adam Sills
fields.body:
The footballing wallahs at Fifa will be feeling a little smug today. The game's governing body could hardly have picked a more vibrant place to begin the marathon journey to the 2002 World Cup finals this evening than Port of Spain's Hasley Crawford National Stadium. For it is carnival weekend in Trinidad and Tobago, and the party will be in full effect when the hosts take on Netherlands Antilles.

While Trinidad and Tobago's opener is merely the first of 809 games to decide who fills the remaining 29 places for World Cup 2002, the revellers in Port of Spain will view it as the moment the carnival goes into overdrive. Only the carnival cities of Brazil and New Orleans could possibly compete with the frenetic atmosphere - despite the fact that not everyone here will be dancing to the same beat.

After Trinidad and Tobago's recent Gold Cup disappointment, losing 1-0 to Canada in the semi-finals, their manager Bertille St Clair was sacked. Now the Manchester United striker Dwight Yorke, among others, has threatened not to play for his national side until St Clair is reinstated.

To be fair, Yorke would not have played tonight anyway, events at Old Trafford proving a weightier distraction. But the Trinidad football authorities will not be allowed to brush the matter under the carpet just because the carnival is in town.

For the rest of the world, the next 632 days of qualifying will see hopes dashed, dreams fulfilled and mismatches of the most humiliating kind. Indeed, such is the allure of Japan and South Korea in 2 years' time that only one of Fifa's 203 members withdrew from qualifying on account of a lack of skill: Papua New Guinea has instead prepared a development programme aimed at 2006. Three others, Burundi, Niger and Afghanistan, opted out due to political conflict and financial hardship; North Korea remains ambivalent towards its host neighbour.

They will not be joining the hosts and the holders France at the most commercially driven tournament of all, but for the 20 million who are expected to attend the qualifying matches from Macao to the Maldives, the motivations are the same.

There are up to 14 qualifying spots from Europe, four or five from South America, five from Africa, two or three from Asia (to go with Japan and South Korea), three from Concacaf (grouping the Caribbean, North and Central America) and one from Oceania, if its representative gets past a play-off.

As the Caribbean launches its challenge this weekend, hopes remain high for Trinidad and Tobago. Netherlands Antilles have never scored a goal against them in three World Cup matches and, despite the dismissal of St Clair, the home side are one of the favourites to shimmy their way to one of the Caribbean's three slots in the Concacaf qualifiers, where relative giants such as Mexico and the United States enter the fray.

There again this is Trinidad, where the Attorney General, a lifelong opponent of capital punishment, hanged nine men in a single weekend last year; and this is World Cup football, where anything can happen. You have got to expect a double measure of controversy, and the opening game in Port of Spain has it in spades.

St Clair led the national team to its best-ever performance in the Gold Cup, yet was sacked immediately upon his return. Understandably, not everyone in Trinidad and Tobago agreed with the three-man committee that dropped the axe.

"Canada was by far one of the weakest teams in the tournament," said the Trinidad and Tobago Football Federation special adviser Jack Warner of the eventual Gold Cup winners. "I have consistently said that in spite of our success and victories, I still find the team to be technically deficient in several areas, particularly our defence and midfield."

Shaka Hislop and Russell Latapy, Trinidad and Tobago's other leading players from British clubs, are also said to be extremely unhappy about the sacking, as are most callers to television and radio chat shows. Following the resignation of Trinidad's favourite son Brian Lara from the captaincy of the West Indies cricket team, sport has kept a heady profile here. There is talk of a boycott of today's game, but that will happen only if someone throws a massive free party on the other side of town at kick-off.

Whether or not St Clair is reinstated, the only thing that can prevent the stadium from being packed beyond fire safety regulations is if everyone wakes up too hung over from last night to be able to move before this evening. But that is extremely unlikely, given that most people will not even be going to sleep until next Wednesday.

 The Cayman Islands team, beefed up by a number of British-based players face a daunting opener in Havana where they take on Cuba tomorrow. Cuba, who played in the 1938 World Cup finals in France, has seen football overtaken in popularity by several sports, but still scored a 6-1 aggregate win over the Caymans in the qualifiers four years ago.

Number of 2002 World Cup qualifying matches to be played in each Fifa zone:

Europe 238

South America 90

Africa 149

Concacaf 124

Asia 162

Oceania 42

Intercontinental play-offs 4

Total 809

webTitle: Spurs tune up with boy band

fields.headline: Spurs tune up with boy band
fields.standfirst: George Graham hopes a fresh crop of young signings will bring success in the long term
fields.trailText: Over the past three months Tottenham have signed six youngsters ranging in age from 16 to 21. Two more are currently under scrutiny as part of the club's ambitious attempt to build a new, young team capable of competing with the best in the country a few years down the road. George Graham talks to Vivek Chaudhary about his rejuvenating plans.
fields.body:
The headlines may focus on Tottenham Hotspur's endless search for a new striker, but they do not tell the whole story. In fact, Spurs have been one of the Premiership's busiest transfer dealers in recent times - though with the ages of those involved, you could be forgiven for thinking that the chairman Alan Sugar is considering a move into the music business by forming his own boy band in London N17.

Over the past three months Tottenham have signed six youngsters ranging in age from 16 to 21. Two more are currently under scrutiny as part of the club's ambitious attempt to build a new, young team capable of competing with the best in the country a few years down the road.

"We have bought these youngsters but most are at least two years away from the first team," says the Spurs manager George Graham. "There's a lot of clubs who have spent more money than us and they are still not any nearer to the championship. If two of these players come off then that's good buying - it's good for the club, who have to be complimented for this policy. It's shrewd thinking.

"Unfortunately we have not had a group of young players ready to break into the first team from the existing youth team, so we are taking our chances on these young players."

The six in question are the former Peterborough pair Matthew Etherington, aged 18, and Simon Davies, 20 - both of whom had previously been invited to train with Manchester United - 19-year- old central defender Anthony Gardner from Port Vale; Dave McEwen, a 22-year-old striker from Dulwich Hamlet; the 17-year-old Swedish youth international Jonathan Partin, and an unnamed 16-year-old Icelandic midfielder.

Spurs also hope to complete the signing of England's highly rated under-16 goalkeeper Shaun Allaway from Reading, and are watching Leyton Orient's 18 year-old defender Simon Downer. Depending on how the players progress through the ranks, Tottenham's total outlay on the youngsters could top £5m.

Etherington, a talented winger dubbed the new David Ginola, is considered one of the finest players of his age group, and he and the midfielder Davies, recently selected for the Wales senior squad, are being fast-tracked for first-team action.

"They are advancing quicker than I expected," Graham admits. "If these lads come along well over the next six months then I will stick them in the first team. I proved that at Arsenal and Leeds. I want young, ambitious, homegrown players."

"Hopefully I'll be in the first team at Spurs within the next six to 12 months," Etherington says. "There's a lot of good youngsters at Spurs and it's good to see the club building foundations for the future."

In fact, the majority of the recent signings have been the work of David Pleat, Tottenham's director of football, and the reserve team coach Chris Hughton. Much has been made of the relationship between Pleat and Graham, but the areas of responsibility appear well defined, even if the two men do disagree fundamentally on how football should be played. Certainly, despite some inflammatory quotes attributed to Pleat which appeared in the press at the end of last year, there is little to suggest his relationship with Graham is a problematic one.

Graham's priority, of course, lies with the first team. And in the short term at least, he is treading a rocky road given his lack of high-profile first-team signings, the team's stuttering league progress and their exits from all cup competions before Christmas. "I have to put the first team on track," says Graham. "When I came here I knew it was not going to be a quick fix."

The Spurs manager keeps insisting he needs at least four "quality" first-team players, yet he has failed to sign even one. Spurs fans are growing impatient with a long-term youth policy which appears to preclude the signing of ready-made first-teamers. Those who have arrived during Graham's reign, such as Tim Sherwood and Steffen Freund, may have helped steady the ship, but they do not compare to signings made by the country's other major clubs and are unlikely to satisfy the demands of Tottenham fans.

To be fair to Graham, there have been few top-quality players available for sale during the season, but even in the close season with Uefa Cup football on offer following victory in the Worthington Cup last year, Tottenham were reticent about pursuing the quality players on offer. Graham's track record at Arsenal and Leeds suggests he has never been keen on big-name, expensive signings, and there is little to suggest things will be any different at Spurs.

The chairman, meanwhile, has a history of splashing out on players with very little reward on the pitch (the club claims to have spent £17m during Graham's reign). The current cautious approach to buying players suits manager and chairman alike.

Graham remains vague as to why not one of the four quality signings he claims he needs has failed to materialise at White Hart Lane. While insisting money is available, he does not reveal how much and hints it is not enough.

"There is money," he confirms. "The problem is I can't spend it on one player. There are problems with finances and the availability of players."

Graham also has the added headache of attempting to persuade his England internationals Sol Campbell and Darren Anderton to commit to new contracts. Graham says he cannot understand what the delay is about.

"The wages have not been a problem - we are up there with the best payers in the Premier League. fields.headline: Sodje pays for late return
fields.standfirst: The Nigerian defender finds himself an outcast at Luton
fields.trailText: Nigerian defender Efe Sodje finds himself an outcast at Luton after returning late from the African Nations Cup. Here he gives Jon Brodkin his side of the story.
fields.body:
Efe Sodje still had the plasters on his arms, a legacy of the blood tests he has undergone this week after fainting during training. Exhaustion, the doctors reckon. Hardly surprising, the mischief-makers will say, after all that late-night partying with Nwankwo Kanu and Celestine Babayaro after the African Nations Cup.

Sodje, like his more celebrated Nigeria team-mates, returned late from last month's extravaganza and the Luton Town defender has paid the price. Slapped on the transfer list and banished to the reserves, he has also been fined. "We hadn't seen or heard from him," said his club manager Lennie Lawrence. "God knows where he was."

A first-team regular before his departure with Nigeria in late December, Sodje now finds himself an outcast. "The manager was furious and I understand his point of view," he says. "But I don't want to leave Luton. I hope he can see the other side. I hope he calms down and gives me a chance."

What puzzles Lawrence is why Sodje failed to contact the club. The manager presumably finds it hard to believe that faxes and phones are impossible to come by. But Sodje says his attempts to contact the club came to naught.

"There are phones," he says, "but you can try phoning the house next door and you will not get through for two hours. That's how bad the communication is. It's hard."

Nor, he explains, is it just a case of picking up the receiver and calling England. Slots must be booked at telephone exchanges which have limited hours. Then there is always the danger of a power cut.

The 27-year-old is at pains to stress that it was official duties, not laziness or revelry, which held him and his team-mates back. But why, when he returned a week after the final, were Kanu and Babayaro even later? "They are more high-profile players than me," he suggests, "so maybe they had more duties to do."

Babayaro, he adds, was not helped by the civil unrest in his home city of Kaduna. "Hundreds of people have been dying. [Babayaro] said that was why he couldn't come out and no one believed him. Then you saw on the news everything burning. Who do they believe now?"

It is difficult to believe Sodje was living the high life. Slouched on a settee in traditional Nigerian dress and his trademark bandanna on Thursday he hardly looked a party animal.

"We saw in the papers that we were partying but that was rubbish," Sodje says. "You want to go out partying after losing the final? They might shoot you. People in Nigeria live for football, they don't care about anything apart from football. It's not like here where they give you some stick and you're a hero the next day. There they might stone you."

Nor, before it is suggested, was malaria the reason for his absence. Quite simply, when the president and your state governors come calling, snubbing them would be about as wise as refusing to travel to Old Trafford because you are changing nappies.

The governor of Sodje's state paid for hundreds of locals to stay in Lagos during the tournament and they turned up outside the team hotel to sing to the former Macclesfield Town player, the first member of the Urhobo tribe to represent his country.

"In Nigeria if you don't do something you are seen as big-headed and it will be the last time you are involved," he says. "People don't understand that. They don't understand the culture. If the president wants to see you, you are hardly going to say no. He wanted to thank us, 22 people out of 150 million, for honouring the call-up and representing the country."

Crucially, football is one of the few factors capable of uniting the people of Nigeria. Sodje, who was on the substitutes' bench throughout the Nations Cup, believes the players have an important public duty.

"The president said that when it comes to football you never have one tribe ask, 'What tribe are you from? Are you Christian or Muslim?' When you are in the stadium people are united. We want to show that, if football can bring you together, anything can."

Not that that unity was obvious after Nigeria's draw with Congo. "We were attacked going off the pitch," Sodje says. "And as we left the stadium the windows of the bus were smashed. We had to lie on the floor and that was a draw.

"Then we beat Morocco in the next match and the same people were using their shirts to clean the bus. They were dancing, shouting 'We are back.' There were banners saying, 'We are sorry.' It was fun but really serious business."

For Sodje, determined to find favour again at Luton, the serious business goes on.

fields.headline: Red revolution
fields.standfirst: Resurgent Liverpool seek morning glory at Old Trafford to spark an unlikely title challenge
fields.trailText: Liverpool could be on the verge of something big this morning. Quite how big remains to be seen. But Anfield boss Gerard Houllier and Kop legend Mark Lawrenson set their sights to long-term success. Even if Houllier would love it if they beat THEM now.
fields.body:
Back in the middle of August, on the second Saturday of the new football season, the telephone lines to Radio 5 Live's Six-O-Six show were white hot. Liverpool had just been beaten 1-0 at home by Watford and several irate callers were demanding that the Merseysiders' manager Gérard Houllier be removed from office at once.

"It was ridiculous," recalls Mark Lawrenson, the former Liverpool central defender turned television pundit. "Quite simply, Gérard Houllier is the best thing to have happened to Liverpool for many, many years. He is not a tub-thumper and nor is he demonstrative, but he has moved the club forward very swiftly. After so many years of mediocrity, finally there is light at the end of the tunnel."

Indeed, Liverpool's recent form has been so impressive that they are even talked of as potential Premiership champions this season. Such talk is far-fetched, requiring the darkest of horses to charge majestically from the pack (Liverpool are currently 12-1 for the title with Ladbrokes), but their challenge would gather credibility should they prevail in this morning's skirmish down the East Lancs Road at Old Trafford. Victory over Manchester United will move Houllier's side within seven points of the championship leaders with a game in hand. Their prospects are only improved by the news that Roy Keane and Paul Scholes are doubtful starters.

The more optimistic members of the Anfield clan make play of the fact that, of the current top five, only Liverpool are working free of the "burden" of involvement in some form of cup competition. They have 13 league games remaining and some ebullient people (most of them wearing shorts and driving big, expensive cars) believe Liverpool could just win the lot, thus fast-tracking a footballing institution fallen on barren times to the most improbable of championship triumphs.

Typically for a Frenchman who has wasted little time mastering the art of good, old-fashioned north-of-England bluntness, Houllier dismisses the idea out of hand. He is, nevertheless, apparently keen enough to take something from today's game to recall Michael Owen for his first competitive outing in six weeks.

"It is extremely unrealistic to suggest we can win the title," Houllier says. "Manchester United will win the Premiership title again - I am sure of that. I am sure it is already finished. They are too good a side to let it slip from the position they now find themselves in; they have far too many good and experienced players.

"Of course we would dearly love to win at Old Trafford, if only because that would move us a step closer to what has always been our primary objective: qualification for next season's Champions League. That is what we want, that is what we need."

Since assuming sole responsibility for Liverpool's fortunes a little more than 12 months ago, Houllier has wasted few words, always preferring to deliver an honest appraisal than attempt to appease those who struggle with home truths. The speed with which the awful blandness and under-achievement of recent seasons has been forgotten is such that Houllier seems to have been around for years, his fixed smile to the fore as he preaches his amiable Dumas-esque doctrine of all for one and one for all.

Only once after succeeding his one-time partner Roy Evans did he slip out of character, opting for a massive, calculated gamble by gathering together practically all the cash available to him and spending it with astonishing haste. Houllier's now famous player-a-week trawl through the civilised world netted no fewer than eight new players at a combined cost of almost £30m.

Some, most notably Vladimir Smicer, have still to settle but the portents are good. Having bought the bricks, Houllier then had to build the empire.

"The pairing of Sami Hyypia and Stéphane Henchoz at the centre of the defence has been key," says Lawrenson who, with his Match of the Day side-kick Alan Hansen, forged the finest centre-back partnership in Liverpool's history in the 80s.

"In the previous couple of seasons Liverpool's defence was unreliable and porous; it leaked goals. Now they have the meanest defence in the Premiership [21 goals from 25 games]. If you are building a new team, as Houllier has done, you must start at the back; get that right and it will buy you some time. It's so difficult to find the right men for the big job but Gérard may just have done it.

"When you see his team play you feel they are going about their business in a well-schooled and professional way. I do believe Liverpool are now ready to re-emerge as a genuine force. They have yet to master the necessary art of picking up points when they don't play well - as Manchester United and Arsenal have - but they are on their way back."

Managers and pundits do not always occupy common ground but on this occasion Houllier and Lawrenson sing loudly from the same song-sheet. "Yes, sorting out the defence was my priority," Houllier says. "We needed stability and reliability; we needed a rock-solid heart to the back four. There were other areas of the team which needed working on but you must have a good foundation upon which to build. Sami and Stéphane have done ever so well for us."

But for a shaky opening to the campaign, when the jigsaw puzzle refused to lock together, it is conceivable Liverpool would now be rubbing shoulders with United rather than treading on their coat-tails. "We picked up just 10 points from our opening eight games," Houllier continues, "but since the beginning of October our form has been championship form rather than Champions League qualification form. If the Premiership had started at the end of September we would be top but even so I'm pleased with our progress. I can see now the core of what could be called a 'coming' team. Rebuilding anything takes time."

And all this is despite having been able to play his preferred strike partnership of Owen and Robbie Fowler only once this season. While Owen will attempt another comeback today, Fowler is still struggling with a long-term ankle injury.

"We have suffered blows, some of them bad blows, in terms of injuries," Houllier says. "I look back at the season now and realise we haven't been able to field our strongest team on anything approaching a regular basis. But the team spirit and the work ethic at our club is fantastic."

The result has indeed been "championship form" since the end of September. But it is still difficult to disagree with Houllier's clinical assessment that this year's title is out of reach. Liverpool's time will surely come, but caution and patience must be the order of today.

webTitle: Liverpool close on Heskey with £12m bid

fields.headline: Liverpool close on Heskey with £12m bid
fields.standfirst: Houllier aims to land England striker next week after raising stakes
fields.trailText: The long-anticipated transfer of Emile Heskey between Leicester City and Liverpool could well happen early next week after the Merseyside club increased their bid to £12m.
fields.body:
The long-anticipated transfer of Emile Heskey between Leicester City and Liverpool could well happen early next week after the Merseyside club increased their bid to £12m.

It is now more than six months since the clubs struck a gentlemen's agreement designed to guarantee the 22-year-old England forward a move to Anfield for £10.75m at the end of the season, and Liverpool have been attempting to bring forward the deal for some time.

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier contacted his Leicester counterpart Martin O'Neill this week to increase his offer.

Houllier feared that Heskey's impressive performance against Argentina last week, coupled with Leicester's Worthington Cup success, would precipitate a higher bid from another club or prompt a change of heart by the player.

Since Sunday's Wembley victory O'Neill has - publicly at least - sought to persuade Heskey to extend a contract that has only 18 months left. On Thursday O'Neill offered to make Heskey the highest-paid player in Leicester's history with a weekly £25,000-plus wage.

Liverpool want to bring in Heskey because of doubts over the long-term fitness of their recognised strikers, Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler.

O'Neill said yesterday that he would have talks with Heskey tomorrow after Leicester's home game against Sunderland, hoping to have the striker sign a 12-month extension. "I can't read his mind at the moment," said O'Neill. "It will be up to him at the end of the day."

Meanwhile, Leicester's midfielder Robbie Savage has agreed a new three-year contract and he has secured the Boca Juniors forward Fernando Pasquinelli, 20, on loan.

 After more than four days of at times acrimonious negotiations, Arsenal's former England Under-21 midfielder Stephen Hughes has agreed to move to Everton.

The 22-year-old Hughes will join the Merseyside club in a deal which could ultimately be worth £3m after Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger informed him that he had no future in north London.

Hughes has yet to sign a four-year Everton contract but he will travel to the north-west today for a medical before completing his transfer on Monday morning. The deal has been held up by a wrangle over personal terms and the manner of payment.

Everton's veteran defender Richard Gough has agreed to sign a new two-year contract which will keep him at Goodison until he is 40.

 The Belgium striker Luc Nilis is due to have a medical at Aston Villa today and discuss terms for a summer move. Nilis, 32, who can leave PSV Eindhoven at the end of the season on a free transfer, is believed to prefer Villa to several other interested British clubs.

 West Ham's defender Neil Ruddock, out of the first team since January, has rejected a proposed loan to Portsmouth as he attempts to reclaim a senior place at Upton Park.
