fields.headline: Grammar school vote splits community
fields.standfirst: Campaign to end selection has led to bitterness and division in Yorkshire city where outcome of test-case poll is likely to be close
fields.trailText: Time stood still in Ripon this week, where the town hall's imposing Victorian clock has been stopped for ten days to be fitted with a modern, automatic winding mechanism. A welcoming signpost, meanwhile, urges tourists in one of Britain's smallest cities to "stay awhile amid its ancient charms".
fields.body:
Time stood still in Ripon this week, where the town hall's imposing Victorian clock has been stopped for ten days to be fitted with a modern, automatic winding mechanism. A welcoming signpost, meanwhile, urges tourists in one of Britain's smallest cities to "stay awhile amid its ancient charms".

The old-versus-new symbolism is not lost on local parents who are battling to close the North Yorkshire city's grammar school - the oldest in England - and convert it into a comprehensive. They will finally learn whether they have been successful next Friday evening, when the result of a vote among some 3,000 eligible parents who have children at the city's primary schools is announced by the Electoral Reform Society in a test case for the rest of the country. They are bracing themselves for defeat.

Ripon is the first area where anti-grammar campaigners have successfully forced a ballot under controversial legislation introduced by Labour in 1998 which allows parents to determine the fate of Britain's 166 surviving state-maintained grammar schools. The campaign is being led by the Ripon branch of the Campaign for State Education, which has been fighting for many years to end selection. It took the group around five months to secure the 20% of parental support - 587 signatures - to stage a ballot.

If it wins the vote, the school - founded in 1555 - would be required to scrap its 11-plus test from September 2002 and admit pupils of all abilities.

The North Yorkshire local education authority has been vague about what would replace the grammar school, although it has promised a review of secondary education which would lead to reorganisation. But if, as seems more likely, the vote is lost, the pro-comprehensive campaigners will have the opportunity to return to their cause in five years and force another ballot.

The issue has split Ripon, where the grammar school and Ripon College - the local comprehensive - face each other across a main road. But it has not divided the commu nity along the lines that might have been expected. The anti-grammar campaigners, for example, include grammar-educated parents whose children benefit from education at the grammar school, but who believe selection is divisive and limits potential.

This is well-heeled Conservative heartland, yet the pro-grammar campaigners include Labour and Liberal Democrat supporters as well as Tories. Some families have found themselves with one child at the grammar and one at Ripon College.

Emotions have been highly charged and came to a head earlier this week when a planned radio debate on BBC Radio York was cancelled after the pro-grammar school camp - known as the Ripon Secondary Schools Partnership - refused to take part. The Campaign for State Education was bitterly disappointed. It had hoped that a public airing of the issues might remind tardy parents to send off their voting forms before the ballot closes next week.

Meanwhile, the heads and teachers of the two schools - who are forbidden by law from taking a stand on the issue - have kept out of the limelight. But the heads are known to want to preserve the status quo.

Alan Jones, headmaster of the grammar school, said the message from both schools was that it was business as usual. "We've had to conduct business in distracting times, and I think our parents have appreciated that."

His school creams off the brightest 30% of local children, while the rest either attend Ripon College or are sent by bus to comprehensive schools outside the area. Ripon grammar school is one of three selective grammar schools in North Yorkshire which feature consistently at the top of the region's performance league tables. The school's academic record is impeccable - all its pupils pass at least five good GCSEs at grades A to C - while 96% of sixth-formers go on to university.

The debate has been compounded by the improving fortunes of the 470-pupil Ripon College. Under the headship of Paul Lowery, the number of pupils getting five GCSEs at grades A to C has risen from 8% to 20% per cent and is on target for 22% this year. The award of technology status last month brings new funding of £250,000 and £123 per student per year.

A partnership forged between Mr Jones and Mr Lowery means that for the first time this year sixth-formers from the two schools will share lessons and facilities.

The local Conservative MP, David Curry - a former Ripon grammar head boy - said: "It is not just about saving the grammar school. It is about making sure we get good quality secondary education which serves Ripon best. The two schools have strong individual identities and are working very well together - why throw that away?"

Debbie Atkins, who sent two of her three daughters to a comprehensive in Harrogate rather than enter them for the 11-plus, said: "Why should children feel they are on the scrapheap because they have failed?

"And is it fair that Ripon should suffer as a community because 35% of its children are being bussed out of the area?"

Pressure from Parents

Petitions to abolish selection in several other parts of the country are already under way - all involving much larger electorates than Ripon - although none has yet reached the required level of 20% of parental support.

The department for education said it had so far set the following thresholds for signatures as a result of requests from local parents:

London borough of Barnet: 7,209 signatures needed.

Birmingham: two groups of schools, one group requiring 4,441 signatures and the other 10,728.

Trafford in Greater Manchester: 8,518.

Kent: 45,959.

London borough of Sutton: 7,375.

In the London borough of Enfield the department has received a request for a threshold to be set in the case of the Latymer School.

Parents can get a more details from the department's publications centre by quoting ref.Gramguide. Tel: 0845-602 2260

fields.headline: Ski briefs
fields.trailText: • Options at Easter are limited. The holiday is late, running from April 21-24, and package tour operators will have already wound up their programmes to many of the lower resorts. Holidays are still available, however. Val d'Isère-Tignes is a good bet. Even if conditions are dodgy on the lower slopes, they should be passable further up - and there is always glacier skiing as a last resort. Ski Beat (01243 780405) has space left for the week beginning on Easter Saturday. Half-board packages cost £339. And for 18-40 year olds, Action Vacances is offering three-day deals from April 22-24, for £129. Le Ski (01484 548996) has chalets available, also in Val d'Isère, at £479 for the week starting April 22. Ski Lagrange (020-7371 6111) has self-drive deals to Tignes, Val d'Isère and Val Thorens from £93, £87 and £73 respectively, based on four sharing and including ferry crossings.

And for 18-40 year olds, Action Vacances is offering three-day deals from April 22-24, for £129. Le Ski (01484 548996) has chalets available, also in Val d'Isère, at £479 for the week starting April 22. Ski Lagrange (020-7371 6111) has self-drive deals to Tignes, Val d'Isère and Val Thorens from £93, £87 and £73 respectively, based on four sharing and including ferry crossings.

 After a season in which independent skiers have enjoyed a wealth of cut-price flights, their choices are about to be reduced. British Airways' low-cost subsidiary Go! is to axe its services from Stansted to Munich with the end of its winter schedules on March 25 because competition has proved too fierce. The airline has complained to the European Commission that Lufthansa has cut fares to unrealistic levels in order to force it off the route. The German airline has been offering return fares from around £80. One bright note is that while flights to the former will also end on March 25, the airline has just decided to extend Lyon services until April 18.

 Interhome (020-8891 1294) is offering free lift passes and ski hire for children under 10, to customers booking apartments in the second half of this month. The deal, which covers six days' skiing, is on offer in six French resorts : Les Arcs, La Plagne, La Norma, La Clusaz, Les Contamines of Samoens - which connects with Flaine. It applies to departures on March 18 and 25 and is available for up to two children (one per adult - each parent must buy a similar six-day pass).

 Packages to the British Snowboarding Championships in Mayrhofen, Austria (April 1-8) are on offer from Thomson via its web site. Deals start at £299, including coach travel, seven nights' bed and breakfast and a six-day lift-pass covering Mayrhofen and Hintertux . The price of air and self-drive packages start at £375 and £235 . Further information: www.board-X.com (championship organiser) or www.isf.net (International Snowboarding Federation).

fields.headline: Mike Nemesvary never travels without...
fields.trailText: People to help me | A hot bath | A teddy-bear
fields.body:
A necessity: People to help me. Because of my disability, I need someone to get me dressed, bathe me and help me get to bed everyday, as well as three or four teams to help with the logistics and navigation for my round-the-world trip.

A luxury: A hot bath. Although I can't feel 80% of my body from my chest upwards, I love the sensation of heat and a good bubble bath is a real treat.

A memento: I'll be taking Tripper, a teddy-bear that was made by the residents of an old people's home I met when I was working for the International Day of Older People.

fields.headline: Beauty and the beasts
fields.standfirst: Richard Branson's hotel in the Ulusaba Game Park is so luxurious that everything, including the wildlife, seems part of a Hollywood set. Perfect for a Hemingway fantasist such as Birds of a Feather scriptwriter  Laurence Marks
fields.trailText: Richard Branson's hotel in the Ulusaba Game Park is so luxurious that everything, including the wildlife, seems part of a Hollywood set. Perfect for a Hemingway fantasist such as Birds of a Feather scriptwriter Laurence Marks.
fields.body:
The message is crackling over the radio. It is spoken in Shangaan, the language of the rangers who guide the open-topped Land Rovers across the 600km of road around the Sabi Sands Game Park. A female leopard has been spotted (pun not intended), and she appears to be stalking something.

This is too good an opportunity to miss. We are told that even sighting a leopard is a remote possibility, as there are only six in the game park. A leopard making a "kill" had been seen only once by the park ranger.

It means going through the undergrowth of the park, and this could be very dangerous. There is a rule when out spotting big game that you should never break the shape of the Land Rover by standing up. Evidently, the animals think the Land Rover is another animal, and to break the shape is to warn some very dangerous ones that you are foe. They might charge - or worse.

We drive as fast as we can through the labyrinth of trees and bushes, which become more hazardous the deeper we enter. The radio sizzles into life again, informing us that the female leopard is still in position, and that she is definitely stalking something, although what it is no one can see. She won't stay for much longer and time for us is running out. We drive as fast as safety will allow.

And then we see her. My first sighting of a leopard. She is no more than 50ft from me. My God, she is huge! My God, she is beautiful.

There are five of us in the Land Rover. I am positioned in the passenger seat. Behind me sit Michael Thompson Noel and Nigel Dempster, the gossip columnist. Both look apprehensive as they stare into the eyes of this leopard. For Dempster, this is far removed from stalking celebrities.

As the Land Rover edges nearer, so we might have a close up of the "kill", there is a loud explosion as if someone has fired a high-powered rifle at us. The leopard is startled. A sharp tree stump has gone through the side wall of our front nearside tyre. The air whooshes out and the Land Rover has tipped to an angle of 45 degrees.

What are we to do? Dyke, our ranger, is asked to very carefully leave his car seat, move gingerly around to the rear of the Land Rover and release the spare tyre. It is getting dark. Dyke is plainly frightened.

Darren, our driver, then carefully stands up. "Where are you going?" I ask.

"I'm getting out to jack up the vehicle," he says.

"But what about the leopard?"

Darren takes the rifle from the dashboard of the car, loads three copper-tipped bullets and hands me the gun.

The leopard moves closer towards the two men, now out of the vehicle. Dyke and Darren have most definitely "broken the shape" and the leopard is aware of it. Whatever the leopard is stalking might not be as appetising and easy a target as our driver and ranger.

Darren instructs me: "If it comes any closer than 15ft, fire a bullet into the air. It should frighten her off. If she keeps on coming, then aim between her eyes. It would break my heart to shoot a leopard, but it's her or us."

The leopard is perfectly still, and then instead of coming any closer to us, she pounces on to the neck of a baby impala and a scream shrieks out into the twilight. I don't have to fire a shot. The Land Rover is jacked up. The tyre is changed. The blood returns to Dempster's face.

I suppose not all wild game adventures are as this one. How could they be? But isn't this what going on safari is all about?

I am staying at the Ulusaba Rock Lodge, situated on the cliff face of the Ulusaba mountain, 800ft above sea level, overlooking a wilderness below that is the size of Wales. From up here, I am able to look over a landscape that I had previously only ever imagined: bush as far as the eye can see, with light orange tracks that are the roads that will take us in search of wild game.

I consider that it is the size, the wide open space, the noise of the bush that made the British settle here in another time. But I mustn't overlook the unadulterated luxury of this marvellous hotel high above the game reserve, for I would not associate this level of luxury with the African bush.

Ulusaba Rock Lodge is perhaps best described as Hollywood in the Bush. This is really what Meryl Streep would expect before she started the morning's filming on Out Of Africa. This is the resort that makes you feel like a Hollywood star.

You see, Ulusaba Rock Lodge is one of an exclusive collection of unique hotels that have been personally selected by Richard Branson. When I am shown to my room, known as the Zulu Room, I ask why there isn't a picture of Stanley Baker or Michael Caine to be seen anywhere, But I have to admit that the Zulu Room did scream Africa at me, with the bed covered in a zebra-skin, furnishings by African Habitat, and above my four-poster bed, draped with a mosquito net, was a pair of horns from a, well, I don't know whence they came.

I wander around the grounds. Past the 11 air-conditioned rooms - which means that there will never be more than 22 people up at this Lodge at any one time - I am making the difficult decision as to whether I go on the walking bush trails, or to make the 4.30am start in the Land Rover. I am determined to see the Big Five, which Ulusaba promises can be done if you're very lucky: rhino, buffalo, lion, elephant and leopard. Well, I certainly saw a leopard.

No, it's the Land Rover for me. So it's to be an early dinner if I am to be up before the lark. Dinner is taken communally in the Rock Lodge's baronial dining room. All 22 guests dine together around a table laid with the most delicious salads, meats, fish, vegetables you could wish for. This "let's all muck in together" policy is a good one, for someone at table might be the person who saves your life when out in the bush - as Dempster will testify.

All of us sit in high-backed chairs, atop of each are matching antlers. I don't suppose Branson intends us to take this style - Jungle Baroque is what I name it - seriously. But then why should we? One doesn't come to Ulusaba to be serious. The wine list though is more than a little serious. I know my South African wines, and I can say without fear of contradiction that what is served at Ulusaba is the finest South Africa has to offer. But I must go easy, I have a 4.30am start in the morning.

After dinner, declining the ports and cognacs (which with food and wines are included in the price), I wander down the hill from Rock Lodge to Safari Lodge. Here I find a romantic, tree-house-style lodge nestling in the Riverine bush, under a canopy of trees. This lodge borders the Mabrak River, and stands almost next door to a watering hole (for the animals), so big game can be seen from the viewing deck. I give way to temptation as I sit down here with a glass of Veuve Cliquot, chewing Biltong, watching rhinos taking an early evening drink, and thinking this is all so surreal but all so wonderful.

The next morning I am in the bush by 5am, when the nocturnal animals are just returning home from their night shift. During this four-hour early morning ride around the park, I see and photograph a hyena, antelope, giraffe, warthog, cheetah, as well as the big four - winter is the wrong time of the year for buffalo, I am informed. I am so impressed by this safari that I put my name down for the early evening tour. On this, I sit for nearly 45 minutes and watch a white rhino, no further than 10ft from me, eating his evening meal. He sees me. I am no threat to him. He is beautiful. How sad that this species is being killed for its horn, and that in time the white rhino will be nothing more than a memory.

And it is as we are photographing this powerful beast that the message comes through on the radio that a female leopard has been sighted and the real African adventure is about to begin.

While here, I read JB Priestley, who writes: "A good holiday is one spent among people whose notions of time are vaguer than yours." And here at Ulusaba nobody seems to care about time. The staff are my type of people. Africa is my type of country. Ulusaba Rock Lodge is my type of resort. I don't care that everything seems as if we are in a Hollywood film set. Here I know I will eat well, drink well, be pampered and still feel as though I am Ernest Hemingway.

The practicals

Ulusaba Rock Lodge and Safari Lodge can be booked for individuals and parties, or for exclusive use. Prices start at £405 a day at Rock Lodge and £200 at Safari Lodge. Rates include accomodation, all meals and drinks, twice daily game viewing drives, use of gym, pool and tennis courts. Details from Limited Edition by Virgin (020 7313 6110) .

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Healthy option
fields.body:
Healthy option

Staying healthy on the road is as much about having the right attitude as getting the right jab. Best advice is to use your common sense, but every traveller should be concerned about their health if only because more than 50% will suffer from diarrhoea. Lonely Planet's new Healthy Travel Guidebooks, covering Asia & India; Africa; Central & South America; and Australia, NZ & the Pacific, cost £3.99. They are written by GPs and medical experts in travel and tropical diseases.

All in a good cause

There are lots of places to go and people to see listed in a new series of family guides, published in 10 regions, and which also raise money for charity. Let's Go With The Children guides are available from bookshops, newsagents, supermarkets and the publisher, on 01252 722761 or at www.cubepublications.co.uk They cost £2.99 each and cover most parts of Britain. In 1998/9 more than £7,000 was raised from sales of the guides for Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital. This year they aim to raise £10,000 and a further £3,500 to help buy a mobile X-ray unit.

Kids are all right

Staying on message is all the rage these days. Parents with children in the Mega Clubs run by Cosmos (0870 9084299) at their Mediterranean resorts can be fitted with bleepers this summer, should they wish, offering peace of mind while their offspring are at play.

Making tracks

Always fancied going to the British Grand Prix but never quite got round to organising it? Crystal (01235 824324) has put together a programme of British holidays including hotels and tickets for sporting events, theatres, theme parks, concerts and activity days.

High as a kite

Go fly a kite in the Hebrides. You could place money on there being enough wind for the first Western Isles Kite Week from Monday, May 29. There will be static kites, stunt kites and plenty of space on those big beaches for buggying and surfing, too. Log on to www.kite-hebrides.co.uk or The Western Isles Tourist Board on 01851 703088.

Plaza suite

Gable, Hemingway, Bogart and Bacall all stayed at the Le Plaza hotel in Brussels. Add your name to the list of those who have admired the trompe-l'oeil ceiling in the l'Estrelle bar and restaurant on a weekend of antique hunting. Around 150 dealers from all over Europe will be showing paintings, coins, objets d'art, clocks and sculptures at the yearly Brussels Eurantica fair. On the weekends of March 18 and 24, Short Breaks (020-8402 0007) has two-night breaks with entry to the fair for £159 per person.

fields.headline: Open up, Ma'am
fields.standfirst: The royal archives should be accessible to allFreedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: The farce of the missing letter from the Queen Mother in the Monckton papers, released this week, is a perfect example of how access to state archives is governed by a uniquely British mixture of privilege, secrecy and self-censorship.
fields.body:
The farce of the missing letter from the Queen Mother in the Monckton papers, released this week, is a perfect example of how access to state archives is governed by a uniquely British mixture of privilege, secrecy and self-censorship. The release of the papers at Oxford University's Bodleian library degenerated into an argument over whether the "crown jewels" in the Monckton collection had been removed, and once again the chance to address the continuing mystery surrounding the Duke of Windsor was lost. As long as the royal archives are accorded special privileges, sensationalism will be rife and the work of historians obstructed.

The letter, containing highly unflattering comments about the Duchess of Windsor, was weeded from hundreds of personal papers belonging to Walter Monckton, the Duke of Windsor's private lawyer and confidant. Buckingham Palace confirmed the document was given to the royal archives at Windsor by the Monckton papers' trustees when his literary estate was wound up in 1977. Sir Alastair Aird, the Queen Mother's private secretary, has told the Guardian that "since she was still alive it was better to keep it there". He added that it was "policy" to keep the former Queen's correspondence at Windsor.

The Windsor archives are the royal family's private property. Access to them is restricted to those suitably vetted by the Queen's private secretary, who also carries the title of keeper of the "Queen's Archives". Among those allowed to see the papers are authors of officially sanctioned biographies. One such is Philip Ziegler, author of the official biography of Edward VIII, published in 1990.

Ziegler was reported yesterday as say ing that he had indeed seen the letter from the then Queen, written in August 1940 in response to the Windsors' preoccupation with retrieving possessions from their house in occupied France at a time when Britain was fighting for its survival. "For sheer vulgarity it is hard to beat," she wrote, "and though it made us laugh, one's mind went automatically from pink sheets to our poor people spending nights in little tin shelters, and then going to work in the morning."

Ziegler said he did not quote it in his biography since it said nothing new about the duke. Nor did he quote another letter from the Queen Mother in which she described the duchess as "looked upon as the lowest of the low".

The historian Andrew Roberts, who first revealed this letter, says he got it from a friend who copied it from another personal archive which he refuses to identify.

Ziegler's dismissal of the significance of the letters - he concedes that they do no harm to the former Queen's reputation, far from it - misses the point. Almost all official documents relating to the abdication crisis have been withheld from the public record office at Kew, where it is assumed they will not be released until after the Queen Mother's death. They are officially closed until the year 2037, 100 years after the event. Why?

The Queen Mother's letter is not the only document missing from the Monckton papers. An unknown number of what Helen Langley, a senior Bodleian librarian, describes as "government papers" were withheld, weeded out over the past few weeks. They include 50 documents relating to the British fascist leader, Oswald Mosley. It is known that Mosley's friends and relations - some of them known as the "King's Party" - put pressure on Monckton to have Mosley released from internment.

Langley insisted they were withheld "according to public record office guidelines". The clear suggestion was that the PRO had offered advice. Yet the PRO is not responsible for weeding documents. This is done by Whitehall departments under statutory rules which allow papers to be withheld more or less at whim.

Section 3 (4) of the public records act baldly states: "Any records may be retained . . . if, in the opinion of the person responsible for them, they are required for administrative purposes or ought to be retained for any other special reason." The rules also enable records to be suppressed beyond the normal 30 years if they cause "substantial distress" to "persons affected by disclosure or their descendants".

Such broad-brush regulations have enabled the Whitehall establishment and its friends to hide a multitude of sins. Closed papers include those relating to Rudolf Hess, Hitler's former deputy, who flew to Britain in May 1941 in an apparent attempt to reach a peace agreement between Britain and Germany; Sir Roger Casement, who was hanged in 1916 for seeking German help for Irish independence; Britain's claims to Gibraltar and the Falklands; and the activities of the security and intelligence agencies.

The opening of the Monckton papers had been billed as a major event; press interest hadn't been this high in Oxford since the Archbishop of Canterbury was burnt at the stake in 1556. The assembled journalists were there for the startling revelation - "The duke's Nazi treachery" or "How the Queen Mother hated Edward" - but constitutional expert Vernon Bogdanor, speaking on behalf of the university, insisted there was none. The story that emerged - "The mysterious disappearance of the Queen Mother's letter" - helped no one.

Far from resolving the great questions about the duke - was he a Nazi sympathiser, was there a conspiracy to force him to abdicate, was he willing to support Hitler in 1940? - releasing an incomplete set of papers served only to confuse the issue.

Historians who have cast an eye over the brief reign and dissipated life of the Duke of Windsor have been relatively kind to him. Ziegler thought him well meaning but weak, and certainly no traitor. Frances Donaldson, who had access to the Monckton archive for her pioneering 1974 biography, was less tolerant but demurred from following those in George VI's circle who accused him of outright treachery.

But the questions remain. The subject demands another long, hard look, with full access to all the papers by a historian (with no disrespect to Ziegler) whose work does not have to be read by Buckingham Palace. It is time that state archives - royal papers at Windsor and official government papers at Kew - drawn up and preserved at public cost, were opened up to anyone who wants to see them, subject only to a genuine need to protect personal privacy.

Monckton's correspondence with the MCC was closed until more than 20 years after his death; who knows how long ordinary members of the public will be waiting to see that angry letter from the Queen Mother.

Ziegler was reported yesterday as say ing that he had indeed seen the letter from the then Queen, written in August 1940 in response to the Windsors' preoccupation with retrieving possessions from their house in occupied France at a time when Britain was fighting for its survival. "For sheer vulgarity it is hard to beat," she wrote, "and though it made us laugh, one's mind went automatically from pink sheets to our poor people spending nights in little tin shelters, and then going to work in the morning." Ziegler said he did not quote it in his biography since it said nothing new about the duke. Nor did he quote another letter from the Queen Mother in which she described the duchess as "looked upon as the lowest of the low". The historian Andrew Roberts, who first revealed this letter, says he got it from a friend who copied it from another personal archive which he refuses to identify. Ziegler's dismissal of the significance of the letters - he concedes that they do no harm to the former Queen's reputation, far from it - misses the point. Almost all official documents relating to the abdication crisis have been withheld from the public record office at Kew, where it is assumed they will not be released until after the Queen Mother's death. They are officially closed until the year 2037, 100 years after the event. Why? The Queen Mother's letter is not the only document missing from the Monckton papers. An unknown number of what Helen Langley, a senior Bodleian librarian, describes as "government papers" were withheld, weeded out over the past few weeks. They include 50 documents relating to the British fascist leader, Oswald Mosley. It is known that Mosley's friends and relations - some of them known as the "King's Party" - put pressure on Monckton to have Mosley released from internment. Langley insisted they were withheld "according to public record office guidelines". The clear suggestion was that the PRO had offered advice. Yet the PRO is not responsible for weeding documents. This is done by Whitehall departments under statutory rules which allow papers to be withheld more or less at whim. Section 3 (4) of the public records act baldly states: "Any records may be retained . . . if, in the opinion of the person responsible for them, they are required for administrative purposes or ought to be retained for any other special reason." The rules also enable records to be suppressed beyond the normal 30 years if they cause "substantial distress" to "persons affected by disclosure or their descendants". Such broad-brush regulations have enabled the Whitehall establishment and its friends to hide a multitude of sins. Closed papers include those relating to Rudolf Hess, Hitler's former deputy, who flew to Britain in May 1941 in an apparent attempt to reach a peace agreement between Britain and Germany; Sir Roger Casement, who was hanged in 1916 for seeking German help for Irish independence; Britain's claims to Gibraltar and the Falklands; and the activities of the security and intelligence agencies. The opening of the Monckton papers had been billed as a major event; press interest hadn't been this high in Oxford since the Archbishop of Canterbury was burnt at the stake in 1556. The assembled journalists were there for the startling revelation - "The duke's Nazi treachery" or "How the Queen Mother hated Edward" - but constitutional expert Vernon Bogdanor, speaking on behalf of the university, insisted there was none. The story that emerged - "The mysterious disappearance of the Queen Mother's letter" - helped no one. Far from resolving the great questions about the duke - was he a Nazi sympathiser, was there a conspiracy to force him to abdicate, was he willing to support Hitler in 1940? - releasing an incomplete set of papers served only to confuse the issue. Historians who have cast an eye over the brief reign and dissipated life of the Duke of Windsor have been relatively kind to him. Ziegler thought him well meaning but weak, and certainly no traitor. Frances Donaldson, who had access to the Monckton archive for her pioneering 1974 biography, was less tolerant but demurred from following those in George VI's circle who accused him of outright treachery. But the questions remain. The subject demands another long, hard look, with full access to all the papers by a historian (with no disrespect to Ziegler) whose work does not have to be read by Buckingham Palace. It is time that state archives - royal papers at Windsor and official government papers at Kew - drawn up and preserved at public cost, were opened up to anyone who wants to see them, subject only to a genuine need to protect personal privacy. Monckton's correspondence with the MCC was closed until more than 20 years after his death; who knows how long ordinary members of the public will be waiting to see that angry letter from the Queen Mother.

webTitle: Sikh officer fired for race hate mail

fields.headline: Sikh officer fired for race hate mail
fields.standfirst: >Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A Sikh police sergeant was dismissed yesterday for sending hate mail to himself and other black and Asian staff in west London, and covering his tracks by trying to incriminate a white colleague.
fields.body:
A Sikh police sergeant was dismissed yesterday for sending hate mail to himself and other black and Asian staff in west London, and covering his tracks by trying to incriminate a white colleague.

A Metropolitan police disciplinary hearing ruled that Gurpal Virdi, 41, targeted ethnic minority officers and civilian workers at Ealing and Hanwell stations in December 1997 and January 1998 after being turned down for promotion.

When he discovered the first batch of letters could be traced to his computer, he logged on using a woman constable's password to write another set of letters, the hearing was told.

Mr Virdi denied 11 charges relating to sending offensive mail and the alleged attempt to blame a fellow officer. He also denied charges of illegally possessing police documents.

He claimed he was not at Hanwell station when the first set of 13 letters was written and printed shortly before 4am on December 24, 1997, and maintained he was not responsible for the second batch of six sent four weeks later.

Discovery of the hate mail was a severe embarrassment to the force and led to an immediate investigation by Scotland Yard's complaints investigation branch. Mr Virdi was suspended on April 15, 1998, following a raid at his house near Heathrow. Detectives found envelopes identical to those used to post the letters.

The investigation revealed the first letter was written on a computer in Mr Virdi's office by someone logged on using his password. Independent computer experts were hired to verifiy the "audit trail", the tribunal chairman, Commander Richard Cullen, was told.

The A4 letter with a Met crest read: "Not wanted. Keep the police force white. Leave now or else." It was signed NF.

The tribunal sat for four weeks in private, being told Mr Virdi sent the second batch after learning the force could retrieve deleted files.

The complaints branch discovered that the second batch had been written on Mr Verdi's computer on January 18, 1998. This time it was logged on as a constable whose secret password was "George Clooney". Detectives believe she had been very indiscreet and had subsequently not bothered to change the password. While the second letter was written, she was logged on at another computer in the station, working on an application form. The second letter read: "You are ordered to leave. You have no right to be here. NF."

The investigators believe Mr Virdi, a father of two, also sent an anonymous letter to the division commander suggesting he investigate the woman, who has not been named, and another white officer.

Although there was no forensic evidence to incriminate Mr Virdi and no motive was given in evidence, the tribunal decided "beyond reasonable doubt"' he must have been responsible for the hate mail.

Deputy assistant commissioner Michael Todd, who co-ordinated the investigation, said: "The ruling is very fair when you look at the effect of what Sgt Virdi did on his victims, namely those officers who received hate mail and the female officer whom he effectively attempted to frame. Anyone who sends racist mail is doing something despicable. When it is sent to someone's colleagues, as in this case, it is all the worse."

Mr Virdi, who had 16 years' unblemished service, alleged he was framed for challenging white officers on race crime, threatening to expose fellow officers allegedly lacking zeal in investigating an attack in Hanwell. Last night he said he had been the victim of racism within the Met.

"An injustice has been done here today. We will lodge an immediate appeal; I intend to return one day to the Met. We would also like a public inquiry, because this whole thing stinks of corruption."

Det Insp David Michael, chairman of the Met Black Police Association, added: "We will be backing Sgt Virdi in his attempt to overturn findings that are not safe."

Mr Virdi can appeal to the Met commissioner and to the home secretary.

fields.headline: PC Plod learns PC
fields.standfirst: Black people care about language - but they care more about justiceRace issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The point that seems to be constantly missed is that we pay the police to do a job. Maybe there is some public sector job in which freedom to racially abuse is part of the terms of employment, but I can't think of one.
fields.body:
I 'm never sure how worthwhile it is to relate things that have appeared in the Daily Mail, but I have a morbid fascination with it. It is always breathtaking how "political correctness gone mad" is the phrase used to describe all things that are eminently reasonable. I am not referring solely to the letters, which often appear to be transcriptions of the mutterings of traumatised people in their sleep. "The other day a woman in the supermarket called me 'love' and yet when I expose myself in the park I am the one accused of sexism."

This week's star offering was not a letter but a vast piece championing a dismissed policeman who had called a detained teenage boy a "black bastard". It seems his sergeant immediately upbraided him, saying: "Language!" The constable apologised, firstly to his superior and then to others present. The writer of the piece observes: "How vividly this illustrates the highly sensitised post-Stephen Lawrence anxiety over racial gaffes."

I am not sure whether he considers racist language and inaction in a murder case to be mere gaffes. But he appears to think racial abuse is a slip of the tongue that comes from nowhere. Even if for some weird reason you believe it to be part of everyday discourse, the point that seems to be constantly missed is that we pay the police to do a job. Maybe there is some public sector job in which freedom to racially abuse is part of the terms of employment, but I can't think of one.

Policing is still discussed as though black people's sensitivities were the problem, as though Doreen Lawrence or Sukhdev Reel would be happier if the investigations of their sons' deaths had been cocked-up by officers who weren't white. On Thursday's Question Time, Steven Norris was again the only mayoral candidate to raise the police's relationship to ethnic communities but his approach says little for his view of the audience to which he was pitching his prospectus. He told us that, if you ask Londoners what their prime concerns are, black people say health and housing, and white people say crime. What then of all the black victims of crime who are protesting that police have done nothing, or, indeed, that police have committed the crime?

That is not what politicians mean by Crime. Uppercase Crime is the bogeyman who stalks the streets threatening our property, women and children. Crimes against ethnic minorities and deaths caused by police officers are just things people are upset about because of bad community relations.

Norris's line appears to be that we need more black police officers so that black people will respect the police and cooperate in a way that they now, presumably, don't. It follows from this that black people see policing in racial terms, that one cannot expect white officers to do their jobs and that it is up to black people to help the force to change. The latter proposition fits with the traditional police view that their failures are the fault of the public: no one came forward to tell us who did it and the culprit foolishly failed to give himself up.

And yet how furious the justice system, the Police Federation and the rightwing press get when members of the public take the initiative, approach Inquest about a death in custody, or seek the help of a lawyer or monitoring group to push forward the investigation of a crime. At Ricky Reel's inquest, the coroner asked his mother frequently why she had attended the Lawrence inquiry. He also asked her why she had approached the monitoring group in Southall, and referred to the "Suresh Grover factor". Suresh, chair of the monitoring group, had helped Mrs Reel when she found that the police were not taking her son's disappearance seriously.

Now the Daily Mail is attacking Suresh for responding to the McGowan family's request for help, or as the Mail puts it his "muscling in". That request came after Harold McGowan was found hanged in Telford. The family suspected local racists even then, before his nephew, Jason, died in the same way.

When it comes to Northern Ireland, where recruitment is again seen as the answer to the problem of lousy policing, it is small wonder that the family of Robert Hamill in Portadown receive so much support from people like Suresh Grover. It was when Robert's family approached the solicitor Rosemary Nelson, unhappy that RUC officers had failed to restrain or arrest a sectarian crowd who attacked their son 20 yards from a police Land Rover, that the attitude of the RUC changed towards them.

All any of these families have asked is that the police do their job and be held to account when they don't. But I suppose that would be policing correctness gone mad.

Jeremy Hardy appears with Ardal O'Hanlon and Jo Brand at a benefit for the Robert Hamill campaign at the Jazz Cafe, Camden, tomorrow. Information line: 0171-916 6060

fields.headline: Paperback non-fiction, 4 March
fields.trailText: A mass of detail that doesn't add up to much, plus Memories of a Catholic Girlhood
fields.body:
JFK, Reckless Youth
Nigel Hamilton
Pimlico, £15
Buy it at BOL

Carefully researched, carelessly written: Hamilton is in possession of many of President Kennedy's family facts, which he strings like beads on sentences spaced with speculations (as in his description of JFK's ma as "woefully ignorant about sex, with a penchant for pretty challis blouses and long woollen skirts"). Gives a false sense of being privy to what really happened in that privileged yet weird family; false because perhaps only a novelist could grasp the internal life, and therefore the motives, of the characters - Hamilton's accumulations of names and places and reported testimony about behaviour never allow you to inhabit their days...

Memories of a Catholic Girlhood
Mary McCarthy
Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

...whereas you can feel even the silences and absences within the family houses in this republication of the mother - the Mother Superior - of all memoirs. The romance of every chapter is deliberately undermined by McCarthy's long footnotes, in which she checks her narrative with the recollections of others present, only to discover that in almost every attempt at recording fact, she is plain wrong. But the sense of the modern US just coagulating out of 19th-century immigration, already preoccupied with physical appearance and identity through celebrity, explains the Kennedys as well as the McCarthys.

fields.headline: Paperback fiction, 4 March
fields.standfirst: An impressive first novel from Francine Stock, plus Horse Latitudes, The Funnies, Mizora
fields.trailText: An impressive first novel from Francine Stock, plus Horse Latitudes, The Funnies, Mizora
fields.body:
A Foreign Country
Francine Stock
Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Novels about journalism by journalists are rarely satisfying, but Stock's first novel works on every level. Daphne is a grandmother who lives for the present until her wartime role in interning Britain's Italian community is is uncovered. Her son Oliver, a TV journalist, is trying to make sense of a civil war in the former Soviet Union. Recording the present and unearthing the past are questions of interpretation. Daphne's War Office work looks morally dubious in hindsight and Oliver roams the capital of a newly independent state, pressured by filming schedules, trying to create clarity from confusion. A Foreign Country is a highly accomplished debut.

Horse Latitudes
Jay Merrick
Fourth Estate, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Walter studies fungal growths in the Delta - once Stansted airport - but he becomes drawn towards Freyn, a 106-year-old inhabitant of this packing-case colony. Back in the 30s Freyn was a drunk washed up in Roraima, a god-forsaken English outpost, until he was sent to meet Luchenne, the mad demi-god of the interior. Merrick re-creates the colonial story of fall and redemption with bravura, though the balancing act between Walter's stylishly imagined near future and Freyn's memories of the past tilts in favour of Freyn's more gripping tale. But this is a sophisticated debut and Freyn a compelling central character.

The Funnies
J Robert Lennon
Granta, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Better than your average dysfunctional-family narrative, The Funnies has a neat plot line and some fine descriptions of New Jersey living. Carl Mix has ruined his family by turning them into a cartoon strip of all-American cute, comic kids. The reality, of course, is that the Mixes are all mixed up and warped by their famous alter egos. After Mix's death his estate is divided between four of the children. Tim, the fifth, gets the poisoned chalice - give up his installation art and carry on the strip for Dad. Coming to terms with growing up, the family and the choice between selling out or staying credible and miserable is the backbone of this wry comedy.

Mizora, A World of Women
Mary E Bradley Lane
University of Nebraska Press, £6.95
Buy it at BOL

In 1880, when the Cincinnati Commercial newspaper serialised this feminist utopian novel, ideas such as universal free education, a world where class has no meaning and where women are freed from domestic labour were revolutionary. Much of the description of Mizora still sounds radical, though one might well blanch at blonde, blue-eyed maidens ruling the world and eating chemically created food. You can read it as a fun exercise from the genesis of the sci-fi genre, as a serious piece of feminist writing or as an historical curiosity whose central peculiarity is that its author kept her writing a secret from her husband.

fields.headline: Audio: Alan Bennett
fields.standfirst: Bennett weighs in with another offering for the true fans, plus  Facing Up
fields.trailText: Bennett weighs in with another offering for the true fans, plus Facing Up
fields.body:
Father! Father! Burning Bright
written and read by Alan Bennett (BBC Radio Collection, £8.99, 100 mn)
Buy it at BOL

A Bennett audiobook hits the market like nothing else. This isn't quite new - it is adapted from a 1982 TV play - and the print version is dialogue-heavy. But his fans can never have enough ludicrous banality from Bennett folk.

Downtrodden Midgley is keeping vigil at his father's hospital bed, determined he should not die alone. Alas, at the critical moment he finds himself in bed with the night nurse. It's flimsy, but the fans will not be disappointed.

Facing Up
written and read by Bear Grylls
Macmillan Audio, £8.99, 180 mn
Buy it at BOL

At 23, Bear became the 31st, and youngest Briton to climb Everest. His account makes clear this will never become a routine feat - one in seven climbers dies in the attempt. Abridgement befuddles the narrative and the prose relies too much on cliche, but Grylls's fresh, honest delivery transcends it all.

webTitle: Should prisoners be made to pay their way?

fields.headline: Should prisoners be made to pay their way?
fields.standfirst: The home office is currently considering proposals to allow prisoners to work in jail and earn a decent wage, which they could use to repay their debt to the victims of their crimes. But this amounts to a double punishment for inmates, first through deprivation of their freedom and then having to pay for their time inside. Read the debate and have your say
fields.trailText:
Dear Harry,
The impact of imprisonment should never be underestimated, but prisoners are excused most responsibilities as members of society. They can give nothing to their victims, their families or the community at large, because they earn only pocket money. Attempts to challenge this status quo in the past have foundered on bureaucracy and indifference. The home office is now considering new proposals on this matter.

Attempts to challenge this status quo in the past have foundered on bureaucracy and indifference. The home office is now considering new proposals on this matter.

All released prisoners need employment and sound domestic conditions to lead law-abiding lives. The prison service should enter into significant commercial contracts to provide work in prisons, so that prisoners can develop skills and earn significantly more than they do at present. Then, though it might be too expensive to administer deductions for board and lodging, three major conditions could be attached.

There could be a reparation tax, in the form of a compulsory payment to Victim Support, based on an agreed business plan with that organisation. Prisoners could be required to save a large part of their earnings for release, instead of buying non-essential goods inside. Finally, there should be a deduction towards the work of those groups which support the wives and families who currently struggle to maintain family ties.

Yours sincerely,
David Roddan,
General secretary
Prison Governors Association

Dear David,
I find it extremely difficult to support any notion of compulsory deductions, for bed and board and the like, for serving prisoners.

Taxing prisoners is far more complicated than it looks, for a number of reasons. At the moment, proposals are before the House of Commons to suspend all benefits for offenders who breach community orders; about 40,000 people will be affected each year.

Ministers argue that, by offending, this group has lost the right to taxpayers' money through the benefit system. By crude logic, this principle could be extended to argue that prisoners should be made to pay for their keep. But this smacks of double punishment: deprivation of liberty, with all that flows from it, and, effectively, fines. It does not seem very practical.

I would estimate that only around 2-3% of the current prison population of 67,000 is actually engaged in commercial work. The rest are involved in training, education or the internal prison market, earning anywhere between £5 and £16 per week. To deduct money from them would leave the prison service with a major control problem.

Prisons are not primarily about providing commercial work for inmates. Such projects are hard to come by; and if, by some chance, the prison service could manage to increase such contracts without causing unemployment outside, surely deductions from wages could only be on a voluntary basis? Would not deductions against those fortunate enough to be in work programmes be discriminatory?

The prison service should definitely encourage personal savings plans and donations to good causes - but compulsory deductions would take us back to earlier, darker times.

Yours,
Harry Fletcher,
Assistant general secretary
National association of probation officers

Dear Harry,
You go too far in suggesting that we are supporting a return to "earlier, darker times". Convicted prisoners are already required to work, or to attend training or education. If they are able to work but choose not to, they are penalised. This is not dissimilar to the vision the chancellor has: if work is available, you have to take it.

Prisoners would not be forced on to an enhanced wages scheme, but we anticipate that such schemes would be highly popular, even with prior knowledge of the deduction and savings rules. And on discrimination, we would have to ensure that individuals are not denied access on grounds of sex or race. But in order to deal with the offending behaviour of individuals, completion of appropriate courses would come before acceptance on such a scheme, placing great obligation on the prison service to provide adequate course places. There are proposals in the next business plan to do this.

We share your concerns about the suspension of benefits to offenders breaching court orders. But what else can you suggest, instead of committing such people to prison? If the original offence did not justify a prison sentence, we would not welcome a further increase to prison admissions if other ways could be found to ensure compliance with the original order.

Yours sincerely,
David

Dear David,
You make some persuasive points but I still find the notion of compulsory contributions from prisoners towards their keep reminiscent of Dickensian descriptions of debtors' jails. And where does the principle of paying for your incarceration end? Should people on probation, or community service, contribute towards their supervisors' wages?

I welcome your view that prisoners should not be forced into an enhanced wages scheme. But would it be a real choice if a prisoner had the option of earning £8 or £10 in the laundry or the library, or 10 times that in wages?

I would be most interested to hear how the prison service intends to increase the number of competitive work schemes, and how it will do this without costing jobs on the outside. Do you think prisoners who are not on the scheme should make contributions to their bed and board, in order to avoid discrimination against those who choose work? Might this not lead to the accumulation of huge debts and thus increased control problems in prisons? The people who failed to comply with community orders this year were fined, re-sentenced, given additional community service hours or, in a few cases, given a short period in prison.

Suspension of benefits is thus like paying for your stay in prison: a second punishment. Also, as you may be aware, one prisoner last year challenged the prison service's right to deduct money from his earnings as a contribution towards board. The high court found for the inmate, and a prison service instruction was issued warning governors about the practice. Might not the current proposals invite similar legal challenges?

Yours ever,
Harry

Dear Harry,
Your point about offenders serving community punishments actually strengthens the case for reparations from prisoners. Offenders on community service are visibly paying something back to society; for most of the community, including victims, offenders become invisible while in prison. Surely the opportunity to earn higher wages and pay the equivalent of tax can't be compared to the world of The Beggars' Opera?

As I said recently, my association does not want to see prisoners being released owing money to the state. But we see no reason why the prison service should not compete with commercial concerns to win business. We agree that board and lodging deductions for prisoners on normal prison wages of £10 would be impracticable.

We are aware of the high court ruling you mention. Now that there is a prisoners earnings act, the scheme of enhanced wages with deductions, set out in my first letter, needs to be seriously explored.

Yours sincerely,
David

Dear David,
Whatever the merits of compulsory deductions, the home office is a long way off being in any sort of position to implement it. If it were able to educate prisoners to a reasonable level and then gain lucrative outside contracts and pay competitive rates, the case would be stronger. In Japan, some prisoners who pose no risk to the public work in car accessory plants and earn competitive wages, though a prerequisite for this is Japan's policy of full employment. It's difficult to imagine moving towards this model in Britain.

There are fundamental issues that are hard to circumnavigate, including the risk of discrimination and double punishment, and the fact that prisons exist to rehabilitate, not to make money from inmates' activities. I do not want to be labelled a "force of conservatism", but I think there is merit in the principle enshrined in the prison act of 1952, that the cost of keeping prisoners should be defrayed by money set aside by parliament. Forty years after the act, the master of the rolls, Lord Donaldson, when dealing with a challenge from a prisoner who had been told to fund his own travel to a court hearing, said: "As the law stands, I can see no justification for a prisoner being asked to pay for the cost of, or to contribute to, his own imprisonment."

If new legislation is on the horizon, it must not discriminate, and individuals ought to have the opportunity to donate deductions to charity, instead of to the upkeep of the jail and the jailers' wages. We do not want to end up with the model used in some American states, where the logic of "paying for your time" has led to charges for healthcare and education.

Yours ever,
Harry

fields.headline: Bluffer's guide to Blairspeak
fields.standfirst:
New Labour, new language? Norman Fairclough charts New Labour's journey into the realms of advertising

No, same old story, says Ted Honderich
fields.trailText: New Labour, new language? Norman Fairclough charts New Labour's journey into the realms of advertising
fields.body:
New Labour, New Language?
Norman Fairclough
Routledge, £9.99, 192pp

Buy it at BOL
Read an extract

The main explicit claim of this book is that Tony Blair and New Labour are taking the marketing or merchandising of politics further than ever before; the main implicit claim is that this takes them - and our politics - further away from truth and honesty.

In the course of his researches, Norman Fairclough, professor of language in social life at Lancaster University, counts up the number of times particular words are used in a computerised corpus of speeches, manifestos, Green Papers and whatnot. Among his findings is the news - hardly earthshaking - that the word "values" turns up 64 times, but never in the collocation "socialist values".

We are enlightened about the populist use of the glottal stop; also about Blair's poetics, exemplified by his recollection of London's Gower Street transfigured by crowds as he made his way to Buckingham Palace after the 1997 election.

For much of the book we hear of New Labour's third way, and of a good deal else, as "discourse". But we are not to be so mundane as to take discourse to be a stretch of speaking or writing. It is, or it has to do with, a representation or vision of the world as it is and should be. Government is not only involved in discourse, but is itself discourse. It is only moderately reassuring to hear, late in the book, that when an army's artillery levels a village it is not just discourse.

It is pretty easy to put up with this advanced thinking because the book is also cogent. There are excellent reflections on Blair's rhetoric in his sincere and perfect words to Diana, Princess of Wales's sons after her death. Other reflections in the book also carry conviction. It is indeed a little crooked for New Labour to go on endlessly about how it will simultaneously achieve things that, in an ordinary understanding, cannot go together - the free market and social justice, for instance.

Our author does not tolerate the hypocritical pretence of this government, as of almost all governments, that what it wants is a necessity and that nothing else is possible. It isn't just political realism but also managerial politics to run together the inevitability of globalisation with the inevitability of neoliberal globalisation.

There is deception by omission in using such nouns as "global change" while leaving out the principal agents of that change, the multi-nationals. It's not forces and economic tides, but boards of directors making money, who are responsible for other people having McJobs.

Does this sort of thing establish that along with New Labour we have a new language - in the sense both that it has more to do with marketing than what went before and that it is further from truth and honesty?

New Labour has indeed been getting too close to the creativity of advertising, as against the intelligence of a good essay or a frank conversation. It is not as straight as Michael Foot. But for me it is no further into falsehood and lies than the governments that went before it.

Mrs Thatcher playing St Francis of Assisi comes to mind, as does the role in a lying election of her party chairman Chris Patten, now wonderfully rehabilitated. But it does seem more the case with New Labour than with its predecessors that its policies are talked into being in TV interviews and the like. Whether something becomes a commitment, or a commitment for a while, turns importantly on what it sounds like.

But there is some hope to be had in the fact that New Labour is no settled thing. The party may grow averse to going so much by the sounds of things: it can make you ratty at the despatch box, and it doesn't make for a good life, even with the chauffeurs. Clear truth can turn out to be worth something.

This is a real book, not written by a spin doctor. Read it and worry. Read it and hope.

 Ted Honderich is a professor of philosophy at University College, London.

fields.headline: Reel Love
fields.standfirst: On-set passion can make for great films, but disastrous marriages, as Luc Besson and Milla Jovovich discovered in making Joan Of Arc. John Patterson investigates
fields.trailText: On-set passion can make for great films, but disastrous marriages, as Luc Besson and Milla Jovovich discovered in making Joan Of Arc. John Patterson investigates
fields.body:
When it comes to the subject of husbands and wives working together as director and actress, one couldn't ask for a better place to start than the movie of that title Husbands And Wives starring Woody Allen and his longtime paramour Mia Farrow. At the time of its American release in 1992, given the circumstances then prevailing in the protagonists' lives, no film could have been more layered with dark ironies and unintended revelations and parallels.

Onscreen, Woody and Mia played a happily married couple, while Juliette Lewis played a 19-year-old student Woody gets the hots for. Meanwhile, in the media they were trading accusations of child-molestation, serial infidelity, commitment phobia and psychotic levels of New York neurosis. Woody was directing his own wife in a thinly fictionalised version of events that, unbeknownst to Mia, were then transpiring in his own life. By the time the film was in cinemas, Woody's relationship with Farrow's adopted teenage daughter Soon-Yi was public knowledge, and Mia and Woody were sundering their union in a war of writs, each marshalling entire PR companies to defame and belittle the other. It was the most spectacular celeb break-up of them all. It was magnificent, and it was instantly memorialised in a film-a-clef that went on to earn several Oscar nominations.

What is it with male movie directors and female movie stars? What special magic exists on movie sets that makes trousers drop and skirts rise? With Mia there were special circumstances that the amateur Freudian could dwell on for weeks. As a child she once caught her father, John Farrow, a movie director and a devout Roman Catholic, in frankly hypocritical flagrante delicto with a woman not his wife at one of his Hollywood parties, which must have been deeply disturbing and confusing for Mia (whose actorly persona rests on a foundation of fragility and vulnerability). After a series of marriages to much older men - André Previn, Frank Sinatra - she ended up with Woody, an older writer-director, a creator, an educator of his muse-like lover-stars. In short, a puppetmaster looking for an actress willing to play Daddy's Little Girl. Given Allen's propensity for casting lithe teenagers in his movies - everyone from Mariel Hemingway to Natalie Portman - and his habit of trading in his women for younger models (Louise Lasser to Diane Keaton to Mia to Soon-Yi), perhaps she should have seen it all coming.

But there was another side to the story, as there often is with directors and actresses in turbulent relationships: they made some great movies together, including Husbands And Wives and Crimes And Misdemeanors, two of Allen's finest moments. And if one looks at many other director-actress relationships, one can't help noticing the number of good films many of them have produced, whether by accident or design.

Peter Bogdanovich and Cybill Shepherd, for instance, made The Last Picture Show together. There was the long marriage and extremely productive partnership between John Cassavetes and Gena Rowlands. Claude Chabrol and his mesmerising Stéphane Audran made literally dozens of superb thrillers together. Then there are Jean-Luc Godard and Anna Karina, Carlos Saura and Geraldine Chaplin, Olivier Assayas and Maggie "the Cat" Cheung, and Zhang Yimou and Gong Li. Some of the world's great postwar cinema came out of the partnerships between Ingmar Bergman and Liv Ullmann, Federico Fellini and Giulietta Masina, and Roberto Rossellini and Ingrid Bergman, the last of whom had a love story as inspiring and romantic as any of the beautiful movies they made together. In fact, their daughter Isabella has been wife and artistic inspiration to both Martin Scorsese and David Lynch, which may say something about the hot-cold fission produced by Scandinavian and Italian genes.

When you look at the phenomenon closely, it's hard to deny that the issue of power lies at its heart. The director has the tangible power in a movie-making situation, particularly on a location, because he's the boss. He's quite literally the one calling all the shots. He is also by profession (and often by temperament) a manipulator of other people and an arranger of scenarios, both of which are necessary and useful skills in a dramatic context, but which become potentially exploitative when applied to the domestic sphere. Especially if he uses his movie sets as de facto dating agencies

The actress, by contrast, will more than likely be a lot younger than her director and, if she's a newcomer, a lot more vulnerable to the blandishments of a strong svengali figure who must suddenly give her his undivided attention, and who after all was probably the person who cast her in the first place (come on down Luc Besson and Milla Jovovich: married in Vegas shortly after wrapping The Fifth Element, divorced shortly after wrapping Joan Of Arc). And in the hothouse creative environment of a movie set or some far-flung three-month location shoot, when partners and spouses are far away and the working day can last up to 18 hours, the opportunities for falling into bed, if not in love, are legion.

But the director has his weak points too. As a species, movie directors are a geeky-looking, chinless, pointy-faced lot who've often (these days at least) wasted their entire adolescence in darkened rooms watching movies and eating junk food. Thus they often lack the requisite social skills to deal in a normal, healthy way with heart-breakingly beautiful young women, the likes of whom they've never encountered before. Had they not been movie directors, one doubts that Bogdanovich would ever have taken up with Shepherd, or that the nerdy William Friedkin would have married Jeanne Moreau.

If the director is primarily a manipulative force, he may need to beware of meeting his match. Any woman who's grown up cursed as well as blessed by great beauty will learn to know exactly what any look on a man's face means (and usually it only means one thing), with the result that she likely knows a man's thoughts better than the poor bovine bastard does himself. If one compounds that basic skill with, firstly, the ability to act (which for man or woman is a literal training in the arts of flattery and deception) and secondly, a strategic sense of one's own career trajectory, then the notion of embarking upon what's often euphemised as a "deeply creative collaboration" can seem like a canny move. It's good for business. It can help one avoid loneliness on location. It's a means of being at the heart of things and inside the creative loop, and - catnip to thespians of all ages and genders - it's the surest way of being the centre of attention.

I don't believe all or even most directors and actresses are necessarily this manipulative - I certainly can't picture Liv Ullmann taking much shit from anyone - but this is Hollywood, where all stereotypes take on flesh and blood. Nastassja Kinski was upfront about sleeping with most of her directors, including Roman Polanski on Tess. When it came to Cat People, remade by the pudgy-looking Paul Schrader in 1982, she was getting tired of it. "I sleep with all my directors," she told Schrader after the movie wrapped, "but with you Paul, it was hard."

In the main, though, the directors are the ones making all the running. An actress may use a director to achieve or enlarge her own star status, but some directors serially dispose of their actress-lovers in the way business executives trade up on a new car every year. The quintessential svengali was John Derek, who ran a stable of undertalented blonde trilbies for over 30 years. He started with Ursula Andress, moved on to Linda Evans, and finally hit the jackpot with his tawdry and endless exploitation of Bo Derek's unstinting commitment to onscreen shirtlessness.

The late Roger Vadim was Derek's French equivalent, degrading and idolising his wives and lovers in a series of throwaway movies. He's most closely associated with Brigitte Bardot, who was largely his creation, despite the title of their most notorious film Et Dieu Crea La Femme. Then he took up with Jane Fonda in her pre-political, bimbo years, and memorialised that period in her life with his lubricious sci-fi sex comedy Barbarella. He also had flings with Jeanne Moreau and a long relationship with Marie-Christine Barrault, but by the end of his life he was more famous for his womenfolk than for his films. His autobiography was called Bardot, Deneuve, Fonda: My Life With The Three Most Beautiful Women In The World, which really says it all.

In the end, however cynical one may be about the motives and methods of director-actress collaborations, the resulting movies often prove that the injection of sexual chemistry, or even a deep and abiding love between them, can make for some fantastic movies. Just a short and wonderfully varied list should suffice to convince us: The Last Picture Show, A Star Is Born (Vincente Minnelli and Judy Garland), Blue Velvet (Lynch, Rossellini), Juliet Of The Spirits (Fellini, Masina), Person and Cries And Whispers (Bergman, Ullmann), Bitter Moon (Roman Polanski, Emmanuelle Seigneur), The Americanisation Of Emily (Blake Edwards, Julie Andrews), In A Lonely Place (Nicholas Ray, Gloria Graeme), The Lady From Shanghai (Orson Welles, Rita Hayworth), A Woman Under The Influence (Cassavetes, Rowlands) and most of Godard's mid-60s work with Anna Karina. And let's not forget Beneath The Valley Of The Ultravixens, starring the cartoonishly well-stacked Kitten Natividad, and directed by the laureate of softcore mammophilia, Russ Meyer.

Exploitation? Obsession? True love and devotion? Whatever the magic chemistry was that caused them, movies like these are their own best defence.

 Joan Of Arc is out on Friday
