fields.headline: Spice up your history
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  enjoys Glies Milton's spicy tale of colonial history, Nathaniel's Nutmeg
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard enjoys Glies Milton's spicy tale of colonial history, Nathaniel's Nutmeg
fields.body:
Nathaniel's Nutmeg
Giles Milton
Sceptre, £6.99, 388pp

Buy it at BOL

This book has been marketed within an inch of its life. First, there is the not-so-modish title. (Captain Corelli's Old Hat.) The Nathaniel of the title is Nathaniel Courthope, whose story occupies about 8 per cent of this book, 30-odd pages before its end. Neither did Nathaniel have, trade, grow or even handle any nutmeg. He was holed up on the island of Run, besieged by the Dutch for 1,540 days, and while it is true that the whole fuss was about nutmeg, it could not, strictly speaking, be called his.

It gets worse. The book's subtitle is "How One Man's Courage Changed the Course of History". There is no doubting Courthope's courage. You don't hole up on an island against a superior fleet, with no natural water sources (he and his men had to drink their supplies with clenched teeth to keep the fauna out) and nothing to eat but sago without a good deal of the right stuff. But his courage did not change the course of history - it simply delayed it a bit.

If the course of history was changed, it was by Sir Thomas Dale (the same man who had brought Pocahontas back from America in 1616), who could have relieved the siege and driven the Dutch out of the spice islands for good, but who hesitated at the last minute and let the enemy regroup. But then "How One Man's Dithering Changed the Course of History" is not such an uplifting message, is it?

Now that we've got that out of the way, we can celebrate the book. Giles Milton doesn't make too much of a fuss about it, but we are talking about momentous history being decided here. Next time you contemplate the wealth and beauty of Amsterdam, or wonder how it is that the inhabitants of Manhattan speak English rather than Dutch - and then wonder if there might be any connection between the two facts - bear in mind that all the answers are here. In short, Manhattan was traded for the island of Run, a speck of land so obscure it now only appears on specialised maps.

As you'll have gathered, this is about the spice trade, about which we have some hazy notion ("ah yes, the spice trade") but which repays a closer look. One penn'orth of nutmeg in the East Indies went for 50 shillings in London - that's a 60,000 per cent mark-up, I think - so imagine the incentive for greed, treachery, freebooting and murder. The stories are terrific, and Milton has trawled through the records (primary research - maximum respect) to intoxicating effect. The East India Company used to be a turn-off at school but if they'd told us just how gloves-off this capitalism could be the kids' attention would have been guaranteed.

Read about William Hawkins's dealings with the psychotic and unpredictable Moghul Emperor Jehangir (endless piss-ups, gladiatorial competitions between people and lions); Captain William Keeling making his crew put on Hamlet (in Africa, in 1607, possibly the first amateur production); and the Massacre of Amboyna, where the Dutch tortured and then murdered the English inhabitants on trumped-up charges.

The English may have been thugs and pirates but at least the natives, when they had a choice, preferred us to the Dutch. In fact the Dutch come off appallingly: you can see how their settlers came up with such charming ideas as apartheid. Only the treaty of Westminster (1654) has stopped me from organising a punitive expedition against the perfidious Hollander - and even so I wouldn't rule out a sortie within the next few months, just to show them (a) who's boss and (b) that we haven't forgotten.

fields.headline: Pocket books
fields.trailText: David Newnham on the latest travel books
fields.body:
For Love And A Beetle - A Tale of Two Journeys, by Ivan Hodge with Petronella McGovern (New Holland, £9.99)

It was 1961, the year the Berlin Wall went up. Wide-eyed Kiwis Ivan and Beth Hodge had come to the end of a 14-month honeymoon in England and couldn't afford the air fare home. But at £439, a Gulf Blue VW Deluxe Saloon Beetle was just within their means. So they piled their shopping on the roof rack, took a ferry to Europe and drove to Calcutta, finally making it to Auckland by cargo boat.

Cut to contented family life, daughters, a career in insurance and a comfortable retirement, yes? Well, sort of. Except that the little car (cue in theme tune from The Love Bug) remained in the family, cared for by Ivan's parents. So when the idea of a second honeymoon came up 35 years later . . . You could probably write the rest yourself. Actually, Ivan got a Canberra-based scribe to help him with that bit - just in case you were wondering how Beth translates into Petronella.

A Traveller's History of Scotland, by Andrew Fisher (The Windrush Press, £8.99)

In 1995, Michael Forsyth took over at the Scottish Office and attempted to give the Tories a more acceptable face. And not just a face, either. For when the film Braveheart opened in Stirling, Forsyth turned up wearing a kilt. Before long, he was upbraiding Scottish youth for not knowing enough about the history of their own country. They hadn't, it seems, read the first edition of The Traveller's History of Scotland.

Perhaps they were misled by the title, which does rather suggest that this is a primer for foreigners and therefore not to be touched with a 12-foot pikestaff (see Battle of Bannockburn). In fact it's essential reading for anyone who can't see beyond the kilts and bagpipes of invented tradition, and all the more useful in this updated edition, which continues the story as far as the inauguration of the first Scottish parliament since 1707.

Big Snake, by Robert Twigger (Phoenix, £7.99)

How do you seek out a snake in the Malay jungle? Use your nose, of course. The smell you're after, says Twigger, is "a distillate or variant of the smell of the reptile house, muggy, frowsty, a hint of bad breath, meaty, sweaty, not pungent but there, heavily there".

And why look for a tubular reptile in the first place? The spur in Twigger's case was something he came across on the internet. The Roosevelt Prize for capturing a live snake longer than 30ft had not been claimed since 1912.

There was something else, too. Twigger was about to get married, and the man who had won a barrel of awards for his account of a year spent learning aikido with the Tokyo riot police needed a quick adventure. All sounds terribly macho, like one of those TV programmes where men in shorts wrestle with wild animals and shout a lot? Don't worry. Twigger is a poet. He wears spectacles and lives in Oxford. With his wife.

Kibbutz Volunteeer, by Victoria Pybus (Vacation Work, £10.99)

It was once described as "the purest form of communism". But the 21st-century kibbutz runs motels for tourists and floats its shares on the Tel Aviv stock market. So what happened to the ideals of common ownership, co-operation, equality and democracy?

Perhaps that's another book for another day. If you want to get out there and write it, or just escape for six months to what can still be a relatively-socialistic micro- culture (expect to work a six-day, 48-hour week), Kibbutz Volunteer is an invaluable jumping-off point. It actually doubles as a working traveller's guide to the whole of Israel, taking in the more capitalistic settlements known as moshavim , as well as archaeological digs, conservation, tourism and au pair work. A change is as good as a rest.

Secrets of the Stone Age, by Richard Rudgley (Century, £18.99)

History, says Rudgley, is just the tip of the iceberg. Delve down into the vastness of prehistory and you don't need intervention from Atlantis or outer space to explain the wonders of ancient Egypt. The pyramids were simply the product of a build-up of skills that began way back - "way back" being a lot further back than you or I were taught at school. For our Stone Age forebears weren't as primitive as we take them for, says Rudgley, and even ancestors of the Neanderthals went to sea on rafts.

Fascinating stuff, and what's more, the evidence is there for the traveller to see - megalithic temples in Malta, ice-age lunar calendars in Hungary and flint axes from Norfolk that demonstrate how, even in Paleolithic times, humans were fascinated by fossils. You saw it on TV, now here's the hardback.

On the Missionary Trail, by Tom Hiney (Chatto & Windus, £17.99)

The square-rigged whaler that slipped down the Thames and out to sea on the evening of the day that Napoleon died, was bound for Tahiti. The ship would be away for three years. Yet two of its passengers, a stout Yorkshire philanthropist and an Isle of Wight vicar, were away considerably longer. For these two Georgian gentleman had undertaken a task so perilous that the story of their odyssey reads more like fiction than fact. Their job was to report on the state of various Christian missions that had been sent from London to the far corners of the globe some years previously and had not been heard of since. Faith drove them to the other side of the world, and the things they found when they got there almost beggar belief.

Champagne, by Maggie McNie (Faber, £12.99)

It wasn't always bubbly - little more, really, than a greyish wine with a little gas trapped in it, on account of the fermentation continuing after bottling. A novelty brew - and a cloudy one, too, since that ongoing fermentation left a nasty yeast deposit. Who would have thought, in 1690, say, that this stuff would catch on? The story of how a downmarket little wine was painstakingly developed into the crystal-clear substance we know as Champagne has more twists and turns than a wine waiter's friend. In fact, given more stylistic latitude than this excellent series of Faber wine books permits, McNie could probably have written another Longitude. With blind monks, ingenious widows and any number of exploding bottles, she certainly has all the ingredients. As it is, her relatively sober retelling of the tale leads nicely into an exploration of the Champagne region - its people, its climate and, most important, its great vintages.

Fred Dibnah's Magnificent Monuments, by Fred Dibnah and David Hall (BBC, £11.99)

Easy money for BBC Worldwide, I thought. A straightforward spin-off from the TV series in which the bespecta cled, cloth-capped former steeplejack from Bolton ("Britain's favourite steeplejack", says the blurb, as if we have so many to choose from) gives us the low-down on a few buildings that take his fancy. In reality, though, this "guide to impressive buildings and monuments in the UK" turns out to be not such a bad idea after all, since it drives a welcome strimmer through the historical associations that can often obscure a structure like a bad case of ivy. There are more than 400 sites here, with an introduction to each category. It's a good selection, too, ranging from megalithic circles to the Millennium Dome, from the Ribblehead Viaduct to the Channel Tunnel, and from a Roman stronghold in Northumberland to the extraordinary artillery fort that the Victorians planted on the seabed one mile out from Portsmouth Harbour.

The Elusive Truffle, by Mirabel Osler (Black Swan, £6.99)

In Umbria, I once tasted an omelette made with eggs that had been in brief contact with minuscule slivers of truffle. Incredible! The stuff actually lived up to its hype. If only the same could be said for the subject of this book (it's not about truffles, silly). Osler has fond memories of Traditional French Cuisine - cooks who won't plan their menus until they have been to market, and so on. But these days, it's mostly microwave and boil-in-the-bag. There are exceptions, of course, and in this beautifully-written and illustrated book, Osler sniffs 'em out.

fields.headline: A home from Holmes
fields.standfirst: Daniel Stashower's new biography of Arthur Conan Doyle, Teller of Tales, still leaves John Mullan hankering after the release of his letters
fields.trailText: Daniel Stashower's new biography of Arthur Conan Doyle, Teller of Tales, still leaves John Mullan hankering after the release of his letters
fields.body:
Teller of Tales: The Life of Arthur Conan Doyle
Daniel Stashower
Allen Lane, £18.99, 496pp
Buy it at BOL

Daniel Stashower begins this biography where the spirit of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle might have wished, with his posthumous life. Five days after his death, on July 8 1930, over 6,000 people crammed into the Albert Hall in the hope that the famous author would communicate with them from beyond the grave.

On the only empty chair in the hall was a card that read "Sir Arthur Conan Doyle". The medium Estelle Roberts, an old associate of Conan Doyle, took the stage and embarked on a long, inspired monologue. At the climax of her performance, she cried "He is here! He is here!" All eyes fixed on that chair. She had a message from Arthur, she said, but apparently it was for his family only. As she murmured confidentially to them, his widow reportedly smiled serenely.

Arthur Conan Doyle claimed that he would most like to be remembered for his promotion of spiritualism. Sometimes perplexedly, Stashower tries to do justice to his subject's strange priorities. He has spent time "dutifully slogging", as he puts it, through Conan Doyle's copious writings on ectoplasm, "spirit communications" and the like.

It is sometimes droll, sometimes mad stuff. What this book lacks is a way of seeing Conan Doyle's obsession as a symptom of his age. Stashower vividly retells Conan Doyle's early flirtations with spiritualism as a Southsea GP, having lost his Catholic faith; yet he only glimpses that Conan Doyle is not untypical. Indeed, the Society of Psychical Research, to which Conan Doyle was to belong, was a haven for leading late-Victorian intellectuals; with religious belief damaged beyond repair by science, reason had to find something beyond the merely material.

Conan Doyle was himself puzzled as to why any intelligent reader would prefer a detective tale dashed off in a few days to one of his historical novels, composed by sequestering himself with works of scholarship. Stashower does not plead for the literary merits of, say, The White Company (the heroic deeds of English bowmen in the 14th century) or Micah Clarke (the autobiography of a 17th-century Puritan soldier). Sherlock Holmes dogged Conan Doyle, partly because the tales of detection that he wrote for The Strand Magazine were so lucrative that he could not abandon them.

The great sleuth, sent toppling over the Reichenbach Falls, had to return (gloriously, in 1901, in The Hound of the Baskervilles). Yet Conan Doyle was also an indefatigable campaigner and polemicist, penning pamphlets about miscarriages of justice and endless letters to newspapers about improvements to the armed services. After travelling to South Africa, he produced his 500-page The Great Boer War. It was as an energetic apologist for British actions that he was awarded his knighthood in 1902; later he wrote a five-volume history of the first world war.

His life beyond writing was full of unlikely achievements. He travelled on a whaler to the Arctic and on a cargo ship down the west coast of Africa. He was a founding member and goalkeeper of Portsmouth Football Club and played cricket for the MCC, once bowling out WG Grace and writing a poem about the encounter. (Stashower skates over the sporting achievements.) He was a pioneer of downhill skiing. He went ballooning and flying, and was one of the first people in Britain to be fined for speeding in a car.

He was also a great befriender of other writers: Robert Louis Stevenson, Kipling, JM Barrie, Bram Stoker. He had a "golden evening" with Oscar Wilde at the end of which he and Wilde agreed to write something for the editor who was paying for their dinner. Wilde's contribution was The Picture of Dorian Gray; Conan Doyle promised more adventures for a detective called Holmes, who had appeared once, in A Study in Scarlet.

Stashower gives a strong sense of Conan Doyle's commercial acumen as a writer, and of the ways in which this shaped his output. He was to spend much of his earnings on the cause of spiritualism, dedicating the last two decades of his life to polemicising for the cause. Latterly, his credibility was damaged by his support for two Yorkshire schoolgirls who famously produced photographs of themselves with fairies: Conan Doyle saw not cutouts, but proof of a population "only separated from us by some difference of vibrations". He wondered whether "psychic spectacles" might reveal the world of fairies to everyone.

There are undeniably rich materials here, pacily narrated by Stashower, although done scant justice by his carelessness about providing sources. Yet it is difficult to see that this life adds anything new to, say, Martin Booth's equally full and readable account published in 1997. Conan Doyle's eccentric descendants have long since denied access to to the piles of manuscripts (especially letters) they still own. He seems to have known everyone who was anyone; if his papers ever become available, it really will be worth writing his biography again.

fields.headline: Smells like teen reading
fields.trailText: Melvyn Burgess' Bloodtide is a savage story of war, plus Dosh, Kit's Wilderness, Holes and The Teenage Worrier's Worry Files
fields.body:
Never underestimate teenagers, or the books that are written for them. A notoriously hard group to keep interested in reading, it demands the greatest skill of a writer to get their attention and hold it without being patronising or crossing the boundaries of good taste that govern the adults who may still direct them.

Melvin Burgess's Bloodtide (Andersen, £14.99) is a savage story of war and its vast human cost. In a dysfunctional future which bears traces of our present social structure, King Val, ruler of the broken but still powerful London, makes a treaty with King Conor, master of the Outside, with its population of half-men and other genetically modified misfits. The price of the treaty? Signy, Val's daughter, given in marriage to his enemy: an old, old storyline that ends disastrously in betrayal and revenge.

Burgess skilfully weaves his futuristic world, fashioned from the ills of contemporary society along with strands of the Volsunga Saga's shape-changing characters and deep undercurrents of fate and vengeance. Told in the contrasting voices of Signy and her twin brother Siggy, Bloodtide shies from nothing, making it both cruel and magnificent.

Robert Swindells is also not frightened of shocking his readers. Winner of the Carnegie medal for Stone Cold, the story of a serial killer at large among the homeless, he tackles systematic and extreme bullying in Dosh (Hamish Hamilton, £10.99). For too long, the Push gang has dominated the lives of the children in Cottoncroft. Paying a proportion of their cash as protection money to the racket run by Flitcroft, a drug dealer and small-time crook, has almost become an accepted way of life. But then Passmore and his friends set up Pull, a new collective prepared to stand up to the bullies of Push and defeat them at their own game.

Swindells's schools, schoolchildren and their families are all convincing, and the excitement of the group response to intimidation is contagious. Sadly, the plot overreaches itself when Push's controllers are revealed as child pornographers and the children in Pull get trapped in an unsavoury scene of sexual abuse. That aside, this is an empowering book which never preaches, but encourages children to take control.

David Almond's first book Skellig showed what a sensitive writer he is. In Kit's Wilderness (Hodder Children's Books, £4.99) he uses the same light touch in a longer and more difficult novel about the loneliness of the outsider. Asquew is the leader of the boys who play the "game of death": there are shades of Lord of the Flies as the teenagers act out their private rituals on wasteland that was once a coalpit, but there is no underlying brutality, despite the privations of Asquew's background. Instead there is a fragile, mutual support.

Almond understands how teenagers relate to one another, their need to posture and test each other as well as their need for warmth and protection and, above all, recognition. Kit's Wilderness evokes a time in adolescence when loyalties become confused that many will identify with.

In Holes by Louis Sacher (Bloomsbury, £10.99) all the boys are outsiders: outside the law, at any rate. A camp for young offenders in the Texan desert is an unlikely setting for an exceptionally funny and generous book that is also a tightly plotted detective novel.

Sent there for a crime he did not commit, Stanley Yelnats accepts his fate placidly. Along with the other boys, he sets out every morning to dig his hole - five foot wide by five foot deep - in the dried-up bed of the lake. Digging holes is character-building, claims the Warden, but Stanley guesses there are other reasons. Stories from the past interweave with daily events at the camp; as Stanley discovers the secret behind the holes, the threads are unravelled. Without ever becoming mawkishly sentimental about the good within everyone, Sacher's young offenders are clearly more sinned against than sinning, and their developing relationships, fraught with hierarchy and petty jealousies, are minutely detailed and wholly absorbing.

Anyone who has sneaked a peek at a teenager's diary - or, more honourably, remembers writing their own - will feel completely at home in Ros Asquith's The Teenage Worrier's Worry Files (Corgi, £4.99). The fourth in the Teenage Worrier series (there are pocket guides as well) offers an update on the Worrier's family background, to make sure that new readers know where they are. No such guide is strictly necessary, as "Letty Chubb, authorene" writes so vividly that it is easy to pick up the threads.

Friendships, school, boyz, spotz and much else figure in Letty's outpourings, which are as funny as they are accurate. Despite constant expressions of "glume" and feelings of frustration that the world is against her, the Worrier comes through life remarkably well, giving hope to other teenagers - and their parents. Letty's style is a neat combination of the crude and the literary, with a far more sizeable vocabulary than is commonly found in the grunted exchanges of Harry Enfield and his friends.

fields.body:
Delia's place at the top of the table remains unassailable, but there are some dodgy characters creeping up on her - namely two stars of the Worldwide Wrestling Federation, Mankind and The Rock. Aficionados of this Cable TV cult "sport" have bought nearly 100,000 of the two books since they were released in the UK a month or so ago. Expect sales to rise in the run-up to the sell-out Insurrection contest at Earl's Court next month.

Another American import that is flying high is Tuesdays with Morrie - a heartwarmer about a young journalist imbibing wisdom at the knee of an old professor, and a bestseller in the US. Memoirs are always with us - Frank McCourt is apparently unstoppable, but not far behind him come Rabbi Hugo Gryn's recollections of Carpathia in the 30s, and Sir John Mills's priceless photographic autobiography. Where else could you see Laurence Olivier's bottom?

fields.headline: Onward for poetry
fields.trailText: • This year's Forward Prizes for Poetry, awarded in October, have kicked into action, with founder William Sieghart hosting a lunch for London's literary editors. Much of the table talk was concerned with the vexed question of how to boost poetry's profile with the reading public, with Andrew Motion in attendance to provide handy hints on how to display versifiers to maximum advantage.
fields.body:
 This year's Forward Prizes for Poetry, awarded in October, have kicked into action, with founder William Sieghart hosting a lunch for London's literary editors. Much of the table talk was concerned with the vexed question of how to boost poetry's profile with the reading public, with Andrew Motion in attendance to provide handy hints on how to display versifiers to maximum advantage.

Some might feel, however, that poets can be their worst enemy: Forward itself lost Midland Bank as its sponsors back in 1993, when they included a poem by Carol Ann Duffy in the collection that they published following the prize. Apparently, Duffy's use of the word "fuck" was a step too far for one teacher, who rang the Midland to complain, and rather put them off the idea of backing verse.

One hopes that the prize's current sponsors have a more relaxed attitude to language, or chair of the judges John Walsh - no stranger to the odd profanity, surely? - may find himself having to return poems to sender with naughty words blacked out.

 Authors are not always renowned for their Samaritan-like qualities, being rather too concerned with getting to the bar or to their next appearance on Start the Week to trouble themselves tending to hapless passers by. But there are always exceptions, as Picador publicist Camilla Elworthy had cause to note on a train back from Paris.

Afflicted with gastroenteritis, she was feeling distinctly seedy and rather unimpressed with Eurostar's provision for under-the-weather passengers. Her mood improved when a fellow passenger spoke to her solicitously and, on their arrival in London, offered to seek out a wheelchair. This kind gent was none other than Douglas Kennedy, author of The Big Picture, who may well have been feeling charitably disposed after moving publishers from Little, Brown to Hutchinson in a six-figure deal.

 The force is no longer with Dorling Kindersley, it seems, as the hapless publisher - which fell victim to over-optimism on a grand scale when it estimated sales figures of the latest Stars Wars tie-in - announced redundancies from its Covent Garden offices. Now Bertelsmann, WH Smith and Pearson are being touted as potential buyers for the troubled DK, although one might think that the German company had enough on its plate. With its UK book clubs operation, BCA, in the midst of taking over its biggest rivals, and with the planned public listing of bol.com's shares, how on earth will Bertelsmann work out how to shift several warehouses of The Phantom Menace?

 And now for a delightful tale of the writer's life, Stateside. Little did Dave Eggers know when he titled his family memoir A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius that so many people would agree with him. The book received a rave review in the New York Times and shot to number 16 in their bestsellers list.

It's also number seven on Amazon, with further sales helped along by the ecstatic nature of the readers' reviews. "If only every book on programming algorithms were as lucid, well-illustrated, and - yes - FUN as this one!" gushes one happy customer, while others were particularly pleased by its portrayal of an eccentric Southern family and yet others liked its description of rats trained to infiltrate and mend photocopiers.

Those who suspect a little harmless spoofery may be interested to know that Eggers presides over a satirical website called mcsweeneys.net, which contains in its archives the article "Actual reviews posted on Amazon.com by me, in utter slack-jawed ignorance of the books involved, and with grammatical errors intact".

fields.headline: The music of time
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi  welcomes back Gayl Jones's jazzy rhythms in The Healing
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi welcomes back Gayl Jones's jazzy rhythms in The Healing
fields.body:
The Healing
Gayl Jones
Serpent's Tail, £9.99, 284pp
Buy it at BOL

Gayl Jones's first novel, Corregidora (1975), was both shocking and ground-breaking in its probing of the psychological legacy of slavery and sexual ownership through the life of a Kentucky blues singer. Published when Jones was 26, it predated Alice Walker's The Color Purple and Toni Morrison's Beloved, revealing an unfinished emancipation and the power of historical memory to shape lives. It also marked a shift in African-American literature that made women, and relationships between black people, central.

Corregidora (to be reissued by Serpent's Tail in July) was followed by Eva's Man (1976), whose heroine kills and mutilates her abusive lover, and the short story collection White Rat (1976). Admirers included Morrison, who edited her, James Baldwin, Maya Angelou and John Updike, who praised her sense of "history in the blood".

But then she went silent. There was a hiatus of more than 20 years - during which she published only poetry and literary criticism - before she returned to fiction with The Healing. The novel was shortlisted for the National Book Award, but it also earned less welcome attention for a recluse who aspires to being known, "like JD Salinger", solely through her work.

Her privacy was shattered when US press reports on The Healing alerted the law to her fugitive husband, with whom she had left a professorship in Michigan to go on the run in Europe in the 80s and who was now living with her in Kentucky. Convicted in absentia of assault and staked out in their home, he stabbed himself to death, leaving his wife to spend three weeks in hospital for "psychiatric observation".

The new novel gives few clues either to Jones's spurning of fiction or to her embattled home life; its tone is lighter and more jocular than her early books (which she has rejected as "man done her wrong-type blues novels"). Still compelled by the southern speech and taut, sparring dialogue of the early fiction, it has a witty, savvy, sometimes cynical edge.

Its truculent, demotic narrator is Harlan Jane Eagleton, a healer and race-track gambler, former beautician and ex-manager of singer Joan Savage, who "mixes a little rap with her rock". The tale is told backwards, from Harlan's fame as a greyhound-racing healer to the violent event that began her life as a layer-on of hands.

Harlan, variously described as a "picarí" , "coloured-girl adventuress" and "alley cat", has left her medical anthropologist husband, Norvelle, in Africa. Deemed by his sister not to be a "wifeable woman", she takes up with a jockey named Paradise, an African-German race horse owner and Joan's ex-husband James - the source of incendiary friction with her client.

Though the two women share traits, Joan appears the more intellectual. Harlan reflects: "The type of romantic music I write she ridicules. She likes satire, wit, what she calls intelligent music." Yet a strong thread in the novel, which contains nods to Platonic philosophy, is about the difference between what people really are and the idea they, or others, have of them; what they are idealised - or underestimated - into being. James scorns Joan's career, thinking, as she puts it, "that I'm just another stereotype. Playing the Nigger Entertainer... How does he know I ain't playing myself? Maybe that's who some of us are. Maybe I'm the Archetypal Nigger Entertainer and not the Stereotypical Nigger Entertainer."

There is a self-consciousness to the tale, which includes a sceptics' chorus of the faithless and asides on aesthetics. Harlan says: "Lotta readers say they don't understand them flashback scenes... Seem to me anybody seen a modern movie, even them old-time modern movies, would understand a flashback scene. Or if you listen to jazz..."

Oral storytelling remains the vital source, just as Harlan's mother and grandmother, with their tales of Turtle women and of carnival, embody different ways of telling: "As soon as Grandmother turned her story into fantasy, Mother always brought it back to reality again."

As Harlan trawls black culture, Jones slyly combines folksy, vernacular wisdom with discursive flights. Into this fluid pastiche she mixes pop culture - Oprah, Denzel, Tina Turner - with allusions to Chaucer, Henry James, Ralph Ellison, Ishmael Reed.

Here is Harlan on chivalry: "Them women that don't wanna be on no pedestal... is kinda different from the women that ain't been on no pedestal." Or on French as the language of romance: "Course if you's Algerian during that war, or an Algerian in France after the war, you wouldn't think of that French as a lover's language."

Like Joan, Harlan is "simply wanting to be my own woman" rather than anyone else's idea of one. But redefining herself and her "own ideals or possibilities of womanhood" still leaves space for discovery - of "the last man in the world I expected to find. Or maybe the first man I'd hoped for."

The romantic plot, with its shadowy males and upbeat ending, its hint that "when you discover you can heal yourself... you soon discover you can heal others", is a far cry from Jones's fictional beginnings. But the novel's richness lies in its entertaining meandering, and the vitality of its spoken rhythms.

fields.headline: Motion: mild man, bullied child
fields.standfirst:
Poet laureate reveals boyhood beating in poem for campaign to help children
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Andrew Motion has been on the receiving end of several severe critical attacks since he was controversially made poet laureate last year. Now Motion has confessed that he was also bullied as a child.
fields.body:
Andrew Motion has been on the receiving end of several severe critical attacks since he was controversially made poet laureate last year. First there were sneers about his lines on the Paddington train crash, then he took another pasting in the "cash for couplets" affair over the sale of his millennium poem to a Sunday paper. Now Motion has confessed that he was also bullied as a child.

In a tender poem called The Game written for Esther Rantzen's ChildLine charity, Motion describes how he was tied to a tree at the bottom of a garden by bigger boys who whipped him with bamboo canes.

After his torturers, who were playing at being Japanese prisoner-of-war camp guards, had tired of whacking him on the back, he pulled up his dungarees and thanked them. "When they eventually let me go/I still did not know/what to say except 'Thank you' - softly, admittedly, but 'Thank you'/all the same."

The Game is undoubtedly his best public poem since he took on the difficult mantle of the laureateship in May.

The poem evokes parallels with the very public hidings the painfully polite poet and biographer has recently taken.

Only a few days ago Motion congratulated a rival biographer who attacked him for making up the main confession in his new fictionalised biography of the Regency poisoner Thomas Wainewright when one already existed in the archives. Motion said he was not aware of it and praised the scholarship of Marc Vaubert de Chantilly in finding it. Reviews of his book, Wainewright the Poisoner, have been lukewarm.

Valerie Howarth, ChildLine's chief executive, said she found The Game deeply moving. "It is obviously a very vivid personal memory of bullying. It is exceptionally valuable to have someone of Andrew Motion's distinction drawing attention to a problem which too often has been derided or dismissed as just a natural part of growing up."

Ms Rantzen, who chairs the charity, was equally pleased. "We felt we were chancing our arm a little when we asked the poet laureate to write a poem commemorating ChildLine helping its one millionth child," she said. "So when the poem turned up we were thrilled.

"The fact that he has chosen to write so vividly and movingly about bullying, a prob lem which tops the list of what children call us about, will greatly help us in our work. I believe it will speak to many of today's children and to their families, who are struggling with the despair that bullying can cause."

fields.headline: Once were warriors
fields.standfirst: Sidney and Beatrice Webb loved justice and each other. A fine biography of two socialist stars and what passes for a history of socialism
fields.trailText: Sidney and Beatrice Webb loved justice and each other. A fine biography of two socialist stars and what passes for a history of socialism
fields.body:
The Life and Times of Sidney and Beatrice Webb: 1858-1905, The Formative Years
Royden J Harrison
Macmillan Press, £50, 416pp
Buy it at BOL

A Strange Eventful History: Democratic Socialism in Britain
Edmund Dell
HarperCollins, £24.99, 640pp

Back in the 1960s, the Passfield Trustees for the estate of Sidney and Beatrice Webb invited Royden Harrison, a young left-wing historian, to the House of Commons and offered him their papers and cooperation if he would write a comprehensive biography of the Webbs. He agreed enthusiastically, though his project was immediately thwarted.

One trustee, the late Professor William Robson of the LSE, asked the historian to record all the great couple's comments about him. "This was a request that could not be met," explains Harrison. "Was I to tell him that Sidney regarded him as the most boring person on earth?"

More awkward problems soon arose. Other books about the Webbs were started or written with the permission of the Passfield trustees, who did not bother to tell the man they had hired to write the authorised biography.

Now at last the first volume is out, covering the years from 1858 to 1905. The publishers are surprisingly coy about it: repeated attempts to get a review copy proved futile. "Er, who exactly was Sidney Webb?" asked a Macmillan press officer. When I explained that he had been a minister in the first two Labour cabinets, she exclaimed: "Oh, no wonder the Guardian want to review it." The book never arrived, however, so I bought it myself. The price - £50 - seemed a little steep, but it is worth every penny.

Royden Harrison's books Before the Socialists, an account of the passing of the second Reform Act of 1867, and The English Defence of the Commune filled two glaring gaps in the history of British labour; his foray into biography is also a resounding success.

He begins with Sidney, son of a London hairdresser, who rapidly established himself as probably the most brilliant student of his generation. There was no language he could not master, no prize he could not win.

Within months of the death of Karl Marx, for instance, Webb was writing: "He utterly and repeatedly smashes, pulverises and destroys the absurd idea that money breeds money or that capital or machinery produce anything." However, he was not impressed by Marx's call to revolution; he was a founder of the Fabian society, and the historic Fabian essays gave their readers "a sense of socialism" diluted by "a certain distrust of the masses".

Here Harrison breaks off and traces the simultaneous development of a woman from a very different background: Beatrice Potter, eighth daughter of the plutocratic capitalist Richard Potter, born a year before Sidney in the vast Gloucestershire stately home of Standish. Beatrice's upper-class background and reforming instincts drew her to charitable works, chiefly as a rent collector in workers' houses round the London docks. In her early 30s she fell passionately in love with the radical Liberal politician Joseph Chamberlain.

Her sister warned her that marriage to him would be the "murder of your independent nature". The warning was compounded by the great dissenter himself, who turned out to be rather intolerant of dissent. "You don't allow any division of opinion in your household, Mr Chamberlain?" she asked him anxiously. His reply was first evasive and then plain. "I can't help people thinking differently from me." "But you don't allow the expression of difference?" "No." "That little word ended our intercourse," Beatrice concluded, though it did not end the sleepless nights endlessly churning her erotic imagination.

Two connected matters kept her safe from the great reformer after he married the daughter of the US secretary of state for war and drifted off into the Tory party. First came the working-class people of London's east end, whom Beatrice grew to admire much more than companions from her own class. "If we compare them with their brothers and sisters in the London Club and West End drawing room, we must admit that in one respect they are strikingly superior. The stern reality of ever-pressing starvation draws all together. Communism is a necessity of their life; they share all with one another, and as a class are quixotically generous. It is this virtue and the courage with which they face privation that lend a charm to life among them." She was fast moving away from the ruthless charity of the rent collector.

Second came Sidney Webb: short, bearded, ugly and brilliant. His periodic depressions vanished as he fell immediately in love with her. He would not say No, as Chamberlain had done, or take No for an answer either. Her family warned her not to marry beneath her station, but eventually she gave way. "If you lose at Deptford," she wrote to Sidney on the eve of his standing for election to the London County Council, "I shall spend the whole day kissing you." He won triumphantly, and the kissing probably went on anyway.

Two mighty books were the result of this momentous partnership - The History of Trade Unionism (1894) and Industrial Democracy (1897). The first is still indispensable to anyone interested in the long struggle of British workers to protect themselves from exploitation. The book was made possible by Beatrice's inexhaustible curiosity and her determination to root out information and records jealously protected by trade union officers.

Industrial Democracy is also supremely relevant today, if only because it deals with the central problem of representation in trade unions: the inevitable drift of the salaried official away from the aspirations of the rank and file. It informed and delighted people as far apart as Lenin and Edward Bernstein, father of German reformism.

Harrison is not a hagiographer. He can see the weaknesses in the Webbs as clearly as their strengths. He exposes their shifting priorities, and ties them firmly to the moods of the workers: rising high when the workers' struggles reached their peaks, as in the great dock strike of 1889, and plunging low into prime-ministerial dinner parties and shameless imperialism during the employers' counter-offensive at the turn of the century.

Anyone who believes in a law of progress should ponder the achievements of the Webbs, and what happened in the century that followed. Both were strong supporters of municipal enterprise. Sidney pointed out that every time a worker climbed on to a tram, drank a glass of water or turned on the gas, he or she was paying "tribute to a monopolist". Thanks largely to the work of the Webbs and to Clause Four of the Labour Party constitution, which Sidney wrote with Arthur Henderson, all these services were nationalised or municipalised. Now, they are back in the pockets of the monopolists.

My penalty for enjoying every sentence of this absorbing history, its deep historical understanding and its rich sense of humour, was to turn with a heavy heart to 600 lugubrious pages of what passes for history written by the former Labour minister and chairman of Guinness Peat, Edmund Dell.

Dell died last year soon after finishing this book, so I must be merciful. His thesis is simple: that democratic socialism is impossible in modern Britain and every attempt to achieve it must be patronised, abused or mocked. All the socialists in and out of the Labour Party who tried to take the side of workers' democracy against capitalist oligarchy were chasing a mirage.

Even Tony Blair and Gordon Brown don't go far enough for Dell, whose book ends thus: "New Labour will not fully have entered the modern world until it learns to love capitalism with all its warts."

These two books provide further evidence of that law of progress: the Webbs, who are normally and correctly associated with the right of the Labour Party, were a million miles to the left of the Rt Hon Edmund Dell and his fellow wart-worshippers in Millbank.

webTitle: Spice whirl casts shadow over Brit awards

fields.headline: Spice whirl casts shadow over Brit awards
fields.standfirst:
Fractious five reap award for outstanding contribution to pop as Travis win two top titles and Tom Jones collects best male artist garland

The Brit awardsThe Brit awards: special report
fields.trailText: Travis, a group of hairy, unreconstructed rockers, saw off a battery of techno-driven dance acts to take the two top Brit awards last night.
fields.body:
Travis, a group of hairy, unreconstructed rockers, saw off a battery of techno-driven dance acts to take the two top Brit awards last night.

They won best British group and the award for best British album.

But the struggle for the soul of British pop between the guitar bands and knob-twiddlers mattered not one iota to the legion of screaming teenagers who packed Earls Court in London. They were far more worked up about whether the five original Spice Girls would appear on stage for the first time since their acrimonious split to accept a special Brit for their "outstanding contribution to British pop music" award.

All eyes were on Geri Halliwell, Ginger Spice, who quit the group to become a UN ambassador, bestselling author and solo artist.

In the hours leading up to the ceremony, a spokesman for the four remaining Spices said that the achievement was for all five Spice Girls. He said that it was very much "up to Geri" whether they would appear together.

To add to the drama, she was also ranged against fellow Spice, Mel C, in the best British female solo artist category. In the event Beth Orton beat both of them.

The most popular winner of the night, however, was Tom Jones. Thirty-seven years after his first hit, Jones took the Brit for best male artist, much to the delight of Robbie Williams, one of several young British bucks on Jones's new album, Reload.

Having gained three awards himself last year, Williams won best single and best video with his hit She's the One.

Of the legion of dance bands nominated this year, only the Chemical Brothers - Tom Rowlands and Ed Simons - won anything. They collected the Brit for the best dance act.

The teen band phenomenon fared much better, led by S Club 7, who won the best British newcomers while Steps won the bestselling act Brit, and Five, the best pop act.

As predicted, the soul diva Macy Gray dominated the international section, winning best newcomer and best female artist. Beck won the male equivalent.

Despite wide expectation that Blur, who celebrated a decade together last year, would get at least one Brit from their two nominations for best group and best single for their gospel-edged Tender, Damon Albarn and co went home empty handed.

In the past only music industry insiders were allowed a vote in the traditionally quixotic Brits, although this year newspaper readers and radio listeners were allowed to have their say in a number of categories.

Rob Dickins, chairman of the BPI, the industry body which organises the awards, defended their decision to give the outstanding contribution award to the Spice Girls, the youngest recipients.

He said that in their own way they had done as much for British music as The Beatles had in the 60s. "They are known all over the globe and with their career still in its early years, they cause a sensation with every move. You cannot argue with that kind of popularity or their sales figures."

Although the victory of Travis as best band was hardly a surprise, the manner of the dance genre's defeat in all the crossover categories was.

The Chemical Brothers, Fatboy Slim and Basement Jaxx all had three nominations while Shanks & Bigfoot had two.

He said that it was very much "up to Geri" whether they would appear together. To add to the drama, she was also ranged against fellow Spice, Mel C, in the best British female solo artist category. In the event Beth Orton beat both of them. The most popular winner of the night, however, was Tom Jones. Thirty-seven years after his first hit, Jones took the Brit for best male artist, much to the delight of Robbie Williams, one of several young British bucks on Jones's new album, Reload. Having gained three awards himself last year, Williams won best single and best video with his hit She's the One. Of the legion of dance bands nominated this year, only the Chemical Brothers - Tom Rowlands and Ed Simons - won anything. They collected the Brit for the best dance act. The teen band phenomenon fared much better, led by S Club 7, who won the best British newcomers while Steps won the bestselling act Brit, and Five, the best pop act. As predicted, the soul diva Macy Gray dominated the international section, winning best newcomer and best female artist. Beck won the male equivalent. Despite wide expectation that Blur, who celebrated a decade together last year, would get at least one Brit from their two nominations for best group and best single for their gospel-edged Tender, Damon Albarn and co went home empty handed. In the past only music industry insiders were allowed a vote in the traditionally quixotic Brits, although this year newspaper readers and radio listeners were allowed to have their say in a number of categories. Rob Dickins, chairman of the BPI, the industry body which organises the awards, defended their decision to give the outstanding contribution award to the Spice Girls, the youngest recipients. He said that in their own way they had done as much for British music as The Beatles had in the 60s. "They are known all over the globe and with their career still in its early years, they cause a sensation with every move. You cannot argue with that kind of popularity or their sales figures." Although the victory of Travis as best band was hardly a surprise, the manner of the dance genre's defeat in all the crossover categories was. The Chemical Brothers, Fatboy Slim and Basement Jaxx all had three nominations while Shanks & Bigfoot had two.

fields.headline: Tree people face wildlife peril
fields.standfirst:
Venomous snakes and stinging insects have also sought refuge in the branches
Mozambique floods: special report
Disaster Relief - MOD site
Disasters Emergency Committee - Moazambique Floods Appeal
Department for International Development
fields.trailText: The first sign of life from one of the trees speckled across the vast new lake that is southern Mozambique was an arm thrust from among the leaves. The anonymous limb waved a cooking pot, not with any great vigour, for fear of upsetting the precarious balance of life under the foliage. But it was enough to catch the South African pilot's eye.
fields.body:
The first sign of life from one of the trees speckled across the vast new lake that is southern Mozambique was an arm thrust from among the leaves. The anonymous limb waved a cooking pot, not with any great vigour, for fear of upsetting the precarious balance of life under the foliage. But it was enough to catch the South African pilot's eye.

After a week of plucking Mozambicans from the worst floods in living memory, the helicopter edged in for another rescue. The gale pumped out by its rotors opened the tree like a flower, pushing the leaves and branches aside to reveal eight people perched high above the water.

It is a precarious business for everyone involved. The exhausted, often ailing, Mozambicans must hang on harder than ever to prevent the helicopter's winds tossing them into the water.

The pilot has to get close enough to winch down one of the crew, without letting the tail collide with the tree. It is a particularly difficult task when there are so few reference points for him to maintain his position.

Sometimes all that is visible above the waterline is the tree over his shoulder, so he must keeping glancing back to ensure that the helicopter is not drifting too close.

The fear of the moment was written over Celeste Libombo's face. She had little choice but to put her faith in the man lowered to grab her, but the elderly woman was still reluctant to let go of the tree. Eventually she was torn from the vegetation that had been her home for five days and hauled aboard the helicopter.

She sat stunned on the floor. Perhaps it was out of amazement at having finally been plucked to safety, or perhaps out of uncertainty at the deafening noise in a strange, lurching contraption.

In the upside down world that is now Mozambique, people are not the only ones living in trees. Millions of insects seek refuge in the foliage. Ms Libombo, whose apparent frailty belied the strength she mustered to survive in a tree, said her clothes and head were covered in bugs for days.

"Sometimes I couldn't open my eyes because the insects crawled into them. We poured water over ourselves to get them off but they always came back," she said. "There was no food, and drinking the water made me sick. If you are in a tree you have to do all your private things in front of everybody. If you are young it is easy; you can climb down to the water. If you are old it is very hard to move."

Then there are the snakes. Green mambas are particularly feared as they wriggle through the water in search of safety among the trees or slivers of high ground packed with people. A good aim with a sling shot can stun a snake long enough for other hands to beat it to death. Everyone knows that a single bite, with no means of treating it, is a death sentence.

As the survivors from the trees are dropped on the road, and the helicopters sweep back to repeat the exercise, another struggle begins. The lucky ones are merely exhausted, dehydrated and hungry. But many have malaria, or have been laid low by consuming nothing but leaves and the water below their feet. The water does not look too bad; just a little muddy. But hidden in it are rotting corpses, animal carcasses and sewage washed from the village pit toilets.

Some of the rescued are wounded or have hands torn to pieces by clinging to bark. The pilots picked up one women who had lost her nails trying to maintain her grip.

There were too few helicopters to pluck all the survivors from the flood. There were even fewer - just a lone aircraft at one stage - to deliver food to the growing in formal camps on high ground.

People are not starving yet, but food is becoming as much a matter of urgency as rescue. It is not just a case of preventing malnutrition. Bodies weakened by hunger and lack of clean water are good refuges for disease, particularly in overcrowded camps. Aid workers live in fear of the first cases of cholera.

Not all the tree dwellers are grateful to see the helicopters. Some people furiously wave them away. Perhaps they fear to be tossed from the tree. It is more likely that they do not want to abandon what little they have left.

From the branches, many people can see their homes. They are waiting for the waters to subside. Better to go home, rescue what you can and start replanting crops, than to end up in a camp.

But they will not have heard that a fresh torrent of water is on its way down the Limpopo and Save rivers, and that Cyclone Gloria is hovering menacingly around the Mozambique channel. The worst may be yet to come.

webTitle: Helpers torn between rescue and relief effort

fields.headline: Helpers torn between rescue and relief effort
fields.standfirst:
Mozambique floods: special report
Disaster Relief - MOD site
Disasters Emergency Committee - Moazambique Floods Appeal
Department for International Development
fields.trailText: With tonnes of aid finally arriving in Mozambique, emergency workers are torn between competing demands for helicopters to continue rescuing tens of thousands of people trapped by the floods, and the need to deliver supplies to those already rescued.
fields.body:
With tonnes of aid finally arriving in Mozambique, emergency workers are torn between competing demands for helicopters to continue rescuing tens of thousands of people trapped by the floods, and the need to deliver supplies to those already rescued.

Stocks of food, tents and other supplies are building up in the capital, Maputo. But the problem remains how to get the aid to the flooded regions when most of the air transport is dedicated to plucking people from danger, particularly as more rains and overflowing rivers are predicted.

More than 12,000 people have been airlifted to safety by South African air force helicopters, but tens of thousands are still stranded.

There was relief in some areas yesterday as the waters fell, permitting many people to wade to safety. But Roy Trivedy, of Save the Children, said that with more floods predicted, the rescue would remain the priority.

"The government has taken a decision that they need to move these people if the rivers are rising again. Once these people are out we'll begin the second stage of this operation, to look after people until they go back to their homes."

But every person saved adds to the pressure on the refugee camps packed with hungry and sick survivors. The population of Chaquelan camp has risen from almost nothing to 30,000 in four days.

It is luckier than most. Oxfam has been able to fly in water purification equipment and plastic sheeting, but at other sites aid workers fear people could die in substantial numbers if they do not receive food and clean water soon.

The problem will be eased by the arrival of additional equipment, but it could take days to arrive. The US is sending helicopters and transport planes. Britain has sent a warship with five helicopters; France is sending one with two helicopters.

webTitle: UK aid shambles prompts treasury pledge

fields.headline: UK aid shambles prompts treasury pledge
fields.standfirst:
Mozambique floods: special report
Disaster Relief - MOD site
Disasters Emergency Committee - Moazambique Floods Appeal
Department for International Development
fields.trailText: A government review is to be carried out into its shambolic handling of the Mozambique flood crisis that resulted in a crucial two-day delay in sending out rescue helicopters.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Lucy Ward and Owen Bowcott
fields.body:
A government review is to be carried out into its shambolic handling of the Mozambique flood crisis that resulted in a crucial two-day delay in sending out rescue helicopters.

With Downing Street desperate to end the debilitating internal arguments of the last week over Britain's response to the floods, the Treasury also announced last night that it will fund any extra spending due to the crisis from its reserves.

A Whitehall source disclosed that the government is to look at the breakdown of spending to try to prevent a re-run of the row between the ministry of defence and the international development secretary, Clare Short, over who should foot the bill for the operation.

The two departments have been at loggerheads over the cost of sending four British Puma helicopters. The issue was discussed between the two departments on Tuesday but the helicopters did not leave until Thursday, and are not due to be operational until today at the earliest.

A British navy auxiliary vessel, the Fort George, which has five more helicopters, has also been ordered to the area.

The full extent of the row was exposed yesterday when an exasperated Ms Short disclosed on BBC radio that the MoD had demanded £2.2m from her department to provide the helicopters. Staggered by the sum, she initially turned the offer down as too expensive, believing it would be cheaper to hire helicopters closer to the region.

She said: "If the MoD is charging very high prices and coming in very slow, then we don't buy that, we buy something else.

"This is the old issue between departments. Often - usually - the MoD asks for the full cost of the operation, and that comes in very expensive."

The MoD initially argued that the high cost was partly a result of having to hire an Antonov plane to transport the helicopters from Britain, though it was learned yesterday that this only amounted to £270,000.

The MoD dug in, even though the Treasury told the department on Tuesday that it was prepared to be flexible given the special circumstances. A decision to fly out the helicopters was finally taken late on Wednesday.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, was forced to intervene on Thursday to try to bring the simmering row to an end. He asked both Ms Short and the defence secretary, Geoffrey Hoon, to remain behind for a chat after Cabinet.

The MoD, caught on the hop yesterday, changed its position. Mr Hoon has now offered to meet £615,000 of the cost of the operation from his budget, with Ms Short's department paying £1.5m.

Both the MoD and Ms Short united with Downing Street yesterday to try to play down the row. Ms Short, whose behaviour in going public incensed some of her ministerial colleagues, said the whole thing was "out of proportion" compared with what was happening in Mozambique. She denied there had been any delay.

But the issue of the government's handling of the crisis will not go away. Bowen Wells, the chairman of the Commons international development committee, said last night his committee is to investigate how the MoD arrived at the £2.2m figure, which he called "extravagant".

Mr Wells said: "When we were dealing with the famine in Ethiopia, the ministry of defence wanted to charge huge sums for transporting food and other equipment out to Ethiopia."

Aid agencies were also critical. Oxfam put in a submission to the last defence strategic review, urging that the International Development department should not have to shoulder the entire bill for emergency military aid .

"DfID should not have to pay the full cost, they should only be paying the marginal cost. If these helicopters didn't go to Mozambique, they would be hovering over Salisbury Plain," said Ian Bray of Oxfam.

webTitle: How can they be so petty?

fields.headline: How can they be so petty?
fields.standfirst: Fiddling while the floodwaters riseMozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: All week the public's frustration has been mounting at the flat-footed humanitarian response to the catastrophe in Mozambique. Technology could bring us agonising pictures of the drowning of a nation, but we were asked to believe it was too difficult to get more helicopters into the country.
fields.body:
All week the public's frustration has been mounting at the flat-footed humanitarian response to the catastrophe in Mozambique. Technology could bring us agonising pictures of the drowning of a nation, but we were asked to believe it was too difficult to get more helicopters into the country. At the start of the week, the world had left it to a pitifully inadequate five South African helicopter crews to attempt the herculean task of saving thousands of people.

Divisions between the ministry of defence (MoD) and the department for international development (DfID) have been simmering throughout. On Thursday, Number 10 waded in (a sure sign that they saw a public relations disaster in the making) to announce that a vessel had set off for Mozambique with the much needed helicopters; the problem was that it would take them a week to get there. Then yesterday morning, the Whitehall row erupted into the public domain. Clare Short, appearing on early morning radio, could not contain her resentment at her MoD colleagues, accusing them of offering helicopters at too high a price and too slow a delivery. She had shopped elsewhere, she said, and chartered helicopters in South Africa. Those who have watched the scenes on television this week with a gathering anger will know how she feels, and sympathise. The government's response has looked chaotic, weak and divided. The public has responded to the emergency appeal by raising £4m in 24 hours, Yet here were cabinet ministers fighting over a mere £2m.

No one in government comes well out of this episode; and that, it has to be said, goes for Clare Short too. The MoD and its secretary of state, Geoffrey Hoon, are cast as the obvious villains of the piece: their crime - and it is one - was to propose charging DfID the full cost of the helicopters (which included fixed prices such as pilots' salaries) rather than the marginal cost incurred in Mozambique. That offence looked even worse after it emerged that the treasury had expressly reassured them that normal charging could be waived given the scale of the crisis. Defence forces in other countries (for example, Belgium) do not charge full costs in humanitarian operations; nor did the MoD do so for their assistance in either Kosovo or the Turkish earthquake. Rightly, the government and the Commons' international development committee announced yesterday that they will investigate this long-running grievance between the two departments.

But Ms Short may come to regret her outburst. Her negotiations with Mr Hoon exposed her inadequate political skills. She will not have helped her chance of support in cabinet by breaking the principle of collective government in showing disloyalty to a colleague. Worst of all, she has undermined the credibility of the government's relief operation. Instead of getting kudos for having spent over £6m (more than many other countries) and for having finally organised the helicopters (though arguably they will be too late to be useful), the government was being lambasted yesterday. The running story all day was of a government row. The Tories pitched in with claims that political infighting had cost lives.

The crucial issue here is the speed and effectiveness with which the international community responds to catastrophes. This is not a matter of logistics but of political will and this week has given a depressing glimpse into the petty penny-pinching rivalries and public relations preoccupations of the politicians, and how the generosity of their electorate put them to shame.

fields.headline: BAE seeks a hi-tech gloss
fields.standfirst:
Focus to remain on aircraft and defence systems
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: BAE Systems yesterday sought to give its shares a hi-tech gloss when it posted its first results since the merger of British Aerospace and the Marconi defence business.
fields.body:
BAE Systems yesterday sought to give its shares a hi-tech gloss when it posted its first results since the merger of British Aerospace and the Marconi defence business.

Among the plethora of financial figures, BAE also broke out the number of software and systems engineers that it employs, a special section on internet related savings and a list of inventions -including a 30p silicon gyro which replaces a £500,000 box of electronic tricks - which it headed "technology for the 21st century".

BAE is not looking to turn itself into a dot.com; executives insist the company will remain focused on its defence and civil aircraft systems. But with profits before tax of £790m (including one month's contribution from Marconi), higher than expected post-merger savings, a £36bn order book and a balance sheet that will be "net ungeared" this year, BAE is clearly feeling frustrated with a share price which has fallen 16% over the past year.

"No company in our sector is in a stronger position; on a global basis we have opportunities and options that no one else has got," according to chairman Sir Richard Evans.

Chief executive John Weston noted that the company had been seen as a UK manufacturer of aircraft, rather than a global business with a strong systems engineering and software presence.

The next few months will see a series of crucial decisions which will have a crucial bear ing on BAE's development. The Italian government will decide between BAE Systems and the Franco-German-Spanish combine, European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company (Eads), as to which will be the best partner for its aerospace company, Alenia.

At the same time BAE and Eads are working on the proposals to turn civil aircraft maker Airbus Industrie from a partnership into an integrated company.

BAE believes the pressure is on Eads to reach a solution within the next few months - ahead of the European grouping's plans for a stock market flotation. And it may only be a matter of weeks before the British government decides on launch aid for the A3XX - the super jumbo that Airbus would like to build.

In the meantime BAE remains on the look out for acquisitions, with the United States a likely target area.

Though the figures were better than the City had been expecting - Commerzbank global equities raised its recommendation to buy - the shares still fell 2% to 316p.

Among the plethora of financial figures, BAE also broke out the number of software and systems engineers that it employs, a special section on internet related savings and a list of inventions -including a 30p silicon gyro which replaces a £500,000 box of electronic tricks - which it headed "technology for the 21st century". BAE is not looking to turn itself into a dot.com; executives insist the company will remain focused on its defence and civil aircraft systems. But with profits before tax of £790m (including one month's contribution from Marconi), higher than expected post-merger savings, a £36bn order book and a balance sheet that will be "net ungeared" this year, BAE is clearly feeling frustrated with a share price which has fallen 16% over the past year. "No company in our sector is in a stronger position; on a global basis we have opportunities and options that no one else has got," according to chairman Sir Richard Evans. Chief executive John Weston noted that the company had been seen as a UK manufacturer of aircraft, rather than a global business with a strong systems engineering and software presence. The next few months will see a series of crucial decisions which will have a crucial bear ing on BAE's development. The Italian government will decide between BAE Systems and the Franco-German-Spanish combine, European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company (Eads), as to which will be the best partner for its aerospace company, Alenia. At the same time BAE and Eads are working on the proposals to turn civil aircraft maker Airbus Industrie from a partnership into an integrated company. BAE believes the pressure is on Eads to reach a solution within the next few months - ahead of the European grouping's plans for a stock market flotation. And it may only be a matter of weeks before the British government decides on launch aid for the A3XX - the super jumbo that Airbus would like to build. In the meantime BAE remains on the look out for acquisitions, with the United States a likely target area. Though the figures were better than the City had been expecting - Commerzbank global equities raised its recommendation to buy - the shares still fell 2% to 316p.

fields.headline: Triumph of the young pretenders
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: What price inexperience? This was a week for youthful credulity, crowned by the formal launch of the Lastminute.com flotation. It was also the week that saw the departure of the London investment community's most unreconstructed bear, his performance destroyed by a surfeit of sagacity.
fields.body:
What price inexperience? This was a week for youthful credulity, crowned by the formal launch of the Lastminute.com flotation. It was also the week that saw the departure of the London investment community's most unreconstructed bear, his performance destroyed by a surfeit of sagacity.

The chutzpah inherent in the Lastminute offer defies description. Not a great product. Not a great deal of revenue. But a phenomenal name-awareness campaign involving blanket coverage of London's bus shelters and tube stations. Its name should at least have reached 100% of the capital's homeless population. How many number among Lastminute's claimed 1m subscribers.

Asked at this week's press conference why she was fronting the company's launch, Martha Lane Fox said she guessed it was because she is young, blonde and female.

Lastminute's founders - subject to any global market quake - will emerge from this flotation as paper millionaires many times over. The trick, if my pessimism about their business model is well founded, will be for them to execute an elegant exit from a meaningful slug of their paper and into cash.

They need look no further than the board of Psion for guidance. On the day that 3Com greased the palms of US investors with the partial spin-off of its Palm subsidiary, Psion rode the attendant wave of publicity to issue £100m of new shares and for directors to sell £100m of their own stock.

I was taught to scrutinise directors' share dealings very carefully as a lead indicator of future share price performance. I can also say with some experience that £100m of directors' share sales is way outside normal acceptable boundaries. Psion shares? Well, they leapt 12% on the news. Hmmm.

The technology mania is having a debilitating effect on the investment managers of the City. One this week professed exhaustion having assessed 20 proposed flotations - some straight to bin, others full analysis with company meetings attached. It is hardly surprising that so many share prices are sagging as funds raise cash to plough into new issues.

The performance disparity between "new" and "old economy" investments has been cited as the straw that finally broke the hold of Tony Dye on his position at the top of UBS's investment subsidiary, PDFM. Mr Dye has been famous as a harbinger of doom in recent years, his funds focused defensively in anticipation of a crack in prices and a downward readjustment of valuations.

Year after year the crack failed to appear. In the final months of 1999 the surge in technology stocks put even greater water between PDFM's fund performance and that of the competition. A victory for credulity, momentum investing and the herd instinct.

PDFM's performance woes, and Mr Dye's stance against the herd, have rarely attracted the scorn of the investment community. Rather the group has earned admiration for its resilient de fence of an intelligent investment stance and its unwillingness to take the "easy" option and capitulate in the face of relentlessly rising world equity markets.

However, there is no right or wrong in investment analysis, merely the discipline of rising and falling asset prices. A case of rather be lucky than good.

Market discipline has proved very painful for many seasoned investors, not just the departed Mr Dye. One fortysomething fund manager this week confessed to me that the final months of last year had proved particularly gruelling - not least watch ing young pretenders to his star status surfing the technology bubble with success.

The cult of youth is far-reaching. The UK's monetary policy committee is on a charm offensive intended to talk down expectations of further interest rate rises. At the forefront is the MPC's newest and youngest member, Sushil Wadhwani, who suggests the technology revolution is raising the potential of the economy to generate low inflation growth.

No one could accuse Mr Wadhwani of youthful naivety. Perhaps, however, he is more ready to challenge the "wisdom" of old economics than his older colleagues on the committee - particularly the career lifers of the Bank of England.

Age need be no barrier, however. The ultimate economic "new ager" must be Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan. This septuagenarian has run the financial world on a long leash in recent years because of his belief in the miraculous impact of technology on productivity. Does he need a last minute holiday this weekend?

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities

fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which backed the losing bidder in the battle for C&W HKT , is now cosying up to victor Pacific Century CyberWorks by stating both are "very committed" to pursuing an internet and pay television joint venture.

Mr Murdoch's youngest son, James, said News Corp wanted to work with Richard Li, who controls PCCW, the 10-month old internet start-up.

News Corp earlier this week announced it had withdrawn a $1bn investment in Singapore Tele communications, the losing bidder in the £24bn takeover of C&W HKT.

fields.headline: DoubleClick backs down
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: DoubleClick, the online advertising company, has backed down over its plans to build personal profiles of people who surf the Web saying that a net "standard" has to be agreed.
fields.body:
DoubleClick, the online advertising company, has backed down over its plans to build personal profiles of people who surf the Web saying that a net "standard" has to be agreed.

The company's proposals sparked federal and state investigations, uproar among privacy advocates, and more than 100,000 consumer complaints because of its plans to merge personal information with previously anonymous internet habits.

Kevin O'Connor, the company's chief executive, admit ted that he had made a mistake in pushing ahead with the plans before any industry guidelines had been agreed. "We are stopping" he said. "We are putting everything involved with that on hold until some kinds of standards are established by the government and industry."

Investors in DoubleClick, which reaches about half of all internet users through advertising agreements with more than 1,300 websites around the world, welcomed the change in stance. Shares in the group, which have fallen sharply since the first lawsuit was filed at the end of January, were up $6 to almost $90 at midday yesterday.

In spite of the consumer furore, Mr O'Connor still believes the company was doing the right thing and simply "got ahead of the market".

DoubleClick sparked the complaints with its plans for Abacus, a direct offline marketing operation for which it paid $1bn last year. Yesterday Mr O'Connor sought to downplay investor fears that the cost now appeared too high, given the moratorium. "This issue affects just a couple of future products," he said.
