fields.headline: Hamilton's payment is stayed
fields.standfirst: Hamilton, Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton yesterday won a stay on paying £500,000 towards the £2m bill for his failed libel action against Mohamed Al Fayed as it emerged that police are investigating an allegation that the Harrods owner bought documents stolen from the disgraced ex minister's solicitors.
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton yesterday won a stay on paying £500,000 towards the £2m bill for his failed libel action against Mohamed Al Fayed as it emerged that police are investigating an allegation that the Harrods owner bought documents stolen from the disgraced ex minister's solicitors.

Mr Hamilton and his wife, Christine, were at the high court in London for a private hearing before Mr Justice Morland, who presided over the libel trial in December.

Reading a statement, the judge said: "Police investigations are being carried out into the circumstances in which certain confidential papers which had been in the possession of Mr Hamilton's lawyers came into the possession of unauthorised persons.

"Against that background, enforcement of the order for costs made against Mr Hamilton at the end of the trial has been stayed pending the outcome of the investigation."

When the deadline of the order expired a week ago, the former MP for Tatton confirmed that he was not able to pay, leaving Mr Fayed free to enforce the debt if he chose to.

City of London police have confirmed that they are investigating allegations by Mr Hamilton in the media that Mr Fayed had paid £10,000 for documents stolen from rubbish bags outside his lawyers' offices. Mr Fayed denies the claim.

The judge also stayed the order against Lord Harris of High Cross, who co-ordinated Mr Hamilton's £400,000 fighting fund, directing him to disclose the names of backers who had donated more than £5,000. That order, which expired a week ago, also hangs on the outcome of the investigation.

Associated Newspapers was ordered to disclose a list of confidential material in its possession.

webTitle: Surgeon heading kidney inquiry faces action himself

fields.headline: Surgeon heading kidney inquiry faces action himself
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The Royal College of Surgeons is standing by an inquiry into the removal of a man's healthy kidney, even though it was conducted by a surgeon facing legal action over a similar allegedly botched operation.
fields.body:
The Royal College of Surgeons is standing by an inquiry into the removal of a man's healthy kidney, even though it was conducted by a surgeon facing legal action over a similar allegedly botched operation.

It emerged yesterday that Robert Fletcher Deane, one of two experts asked to investigate why a 70-year-old man's healthy kidney was removed at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli five weeks ago, is facing a lawsuit after a healthy kidney was allegedly removed from a 42-year-old woman during an operation in Glasgow three years ago.

Graham Reeves died on Wednesday and the findings of the inquiry, which had been due to be published on Thursday, have been handed to the coroner. John Roberts, a consultant, and two other surgeons have been suspended over the operation on Mr Reeves.

The Royal College of Surgeons, which chose Mr Deane and another senior urologist to take charge of the inquiry into the operation on Mr Reeves, said it would not have appointed him had it been aware of the legal action.

"The college deeply regrets that it was unaware of this legal action regarding Mr Deane," a spokesman said yesterday. "Had it been aware of this at the outset, it would immediately have sought another consultant to conduct the inquiry.

"Nevertheless, the college believes that the inquiry was conducted thoroughly and that its findings and recommendations are valid and will help to ensure that such a tragic incident does not occur again."

It has been alleged that Mr Deane removed a healthy kidney from Mary McComish, of Easterhouse in Glasgow, when he operated on her at Gartnavel hospital in 1997.

Mrs McComish's lawyer, Ian Watson, said his client had undergone a kidney transplant in 1994. Three years later she became ill and went into hospital to have a non-functioning kidney removed but the transplanted one was removed instead.

Mr Watson said he raised an action for compensation on the basis of alleged negligence and the hospital trust had accepted liability for the mistake.

He said that Mrs McComish's family felt very aggrieved about what had happened and felt Mr Deane's involvement in the Welsh inquiry was inappropriate.

Mrs McComish, who underwent a further transplant in January, was still, he said, "very poorly".

A statement issued by the North Glasgow university hospitals trust said the operation on Mrs McComish "did not go to plan".

A spokeswoman for the trust said it had acknowledged liability for the incident and a settlement on the damages claim still had to be agreed.

But the statement said: "The trust's management team was clear and in agreement that there was no requirement to take disciplinary action against Mr Fletcher Deane."

It concluded: "The trust is committed to reaching a settlement of the claim as soon as possible. It would also like to stress that Mr Fletcher Deane is a highly respected, extremely experienced surgeon. He has a renowned reputation and is currently president of the British Association of Urological Surgeons."

Mr Deane has declined to comment on the details of the law suit. He said on Thursday night: "It is public knowledge that I was appointed on to the Graham Reeves inquiry. I cannot talk about the legal case that you are referring to as it is sub judice."

A spokeswoman for the Carmarthenshire NHS trust, which runs Prince Philip hospital, said: "The trust commissioned the Royal College of Surgeons to carry out an independent investigation into the tragic incident at Prince Philip hospital. Yesterday the board considered the findings of the independent report alongside their own findings from an internal investigation.

"We are not able to comment further."

fields.headline: Dazed & confused
fields.standfirst: In Benetton's billboards we see the true, glorious folly of fashion attempting to think about anything bigger than the size of its butt
fields.trailText: My petty-minded yet enjoyable campaign to prove that everyone connected with the world of fashion is, in fact, literally a cretin and should have their voting rights promptly removed, received a wonderful boost this week when I was sent the March issue of Dazed & Confused magazine. For a start, what proof of their stupidity it was to send a copy to me, who hates fashion as much as any half-articulate person does. Because, of course, only those who haven't got the wit to speak for themselves would ever want their clothes to do it for them.
fields.body:
My petty-minded yet enjoyable campaign to prove that everyone connected with the world of fashion is, in fact, literally a cretin and should have their voting rights promptly removed, received a wonderful boost this week when I was sent the March issue of Dazed & Confused magazine. For a start, what proof of their stupidity it was to send a copy to me, who hates fashion as much as any half-articulate person does. Because, of course, only those who haven't got the wit to speak for themselves would ever want their clothes to do it for them.

Inside, there was more fun when a conversation with Tommy Lee about his ornamental fish spells "koi" as "coy" throughout. Mr Lee, apparently, has "a coy tattoo" and asks "Have you ever fed a coy?" Doh! No!

But there are even bigger laffs in the Amendments and Apologies section, when one of the Amendments (not, interestingly, an Apology, which might have been a mite more sensitive) goes: "Issue 59 featured clothes by Sonia Rykiel with additional badges sewn on. Dazed & Confused were not aware that the badge in question was WWII insignia relating to a German Nazi Panzer Division. We would like to make it clear that we in no way intended to cause offence and had we been aware of the symbolism of it would not have been [sic] used as a styling accessory to the clothing. We are issuing this statement so that anyone who my [another sic!] have misinterpreted this shoot will now know that this was an innocent and naive error."

Bless! Of course it was. Because, as I said a couple of weeks back with reference to the rag trade's about-face when it comes to fur, in fashion there is only one rule: Does it look good? If it does, be it the pelt of a tortured animal or Nazi insignia, it must be "good". If not, though ever so virtuous, it's simply a waste of space. This is the impeccable pretzel logic of fashionistas that brings us back to them time and time again when searching for a suitable recipient for the Cretin of the Century commemorative fruit-bowl.

I was still gurgling with delight over Dazed & Confused's dazed confusion when I saw one of those new Benetton billboards, the ones featuring the faces of the poor oofums currently cooling their heels on America's Death Row, which have been erected in the hope of selling yet a few more stripy jumpers to a few more Swiss students. In Benetton's attempt to boost sales of their supernaturally banal woollies by linking them with matters of life and death ("I've got a new blue jumper! Therefore, I'm helping cure Aids/stop racism/abolish the death penalty!"), we see the true, glorious folly of fashion trying to think about anything bigger than the size of its butt or further away than the end of its bobbed nose.

Yet even here it is as woolly as its own jumpers, and operating to the same old liberal consensus splashed with a bit of Kensington Gore. Fashion is notoriously prone to protecting its own, and though I have no way of proving it, I'd bet that if the killer of Gianni Versace - Andrew Cunanan - had not turned his gun upon himself, no way would Benetton ever dream of putting his mug up there for all to sympathise with. Gianni, you see, was an artist; the poor gimps these handsome guys killed were just civilians , who probably didn't even know the difference between taupe and greige!

I have no problem with people protesting against the use of the death penalty in the US, but I do think that they are, for the most part, incredibly dishonest. In all pictorial pleas against it, we only ever see the face of the poor Joe waiting to be fried; in all his isolated and imperfect humanity, shorn of all worldly goods, he can't help but seem a little Christlike. What we never see is any reference to the events that got him on to Death Row in the first place. How much more shocking and truthful it would be if, instead of just the face of the killer, we saw the following: X [picture of killer] is due to die for doing this [photograph of the victim's body at the scene of the crime] and this [press photograph of victim's immediate family and friends at funeral, their agony clearly visible on their faces] to Y [picture of victim, preferably happy and smiling, ideally blowing out candles at most recent birthday party].

See? It's so much more upsetting, and so much more honest. But you won't ever see it, because there has always been a tendency among abolitionists to play down the humanity of the victims of convicted killers ("Oh well, they're dead! Nothing more can hurt them!" - ignoring, of course, the constant pain and grief of their loved ones living on) in order to boost the humanity quotient of the killer. ("There, but for fortune, go you or I!") But what you get from this is an extremely skewed set of values that actively champion the rights of the strong over the weak.

In the new Tom Hanks film, The Green Mile, not one of the crimes of the gentle-giant killers on Death Row is thought suitable for our delicate ears - not one! This was a mistake, and only had the effect of making one try to work out which one was the child-rapist and which one the serial killer of old ladies. In other words, by attempting to draw a veil over the crimes of the "heroes", they actually made it worse.

No group has a greater built-in bullshit detector than the young, which is why less than 48 per cent of under 25s in this country are registered to vote in the next election. And I notice that support for capital punishment is now highest among the young on both sides of the Atlantic, who are invariably the most liberal on other issues. I cannot help but feel that the mistakes of the abolition lobby have contributed greatly to this. It is a simplistic notion, yet one increasingly accepted, that the most recent victim of violence in any situation is the real victim; thus the killer on Death Row is more important than his innocent victim, or the destruction of Dresden far wickeder than the Luftwaffe's earlier destruction of Coventry.

But killers do not simply wake up one morning, like Josef K, innocent dupes of an evil system, and Dresden didn't happen because Churchill woke up one morning in a lousy mood. When they choose evil, people choose their paths, whether they end up on Death Row or in the Luftwaffe. To deny this is not just to commit terrible disrespect towards all the poor, wretched and backward Americans who do not commit any violence whatsoever, and to all the Germans who did not follow Hitler. And for us to stand in the shoes of the violent criminal, in uniform or in prison drab, and attempt to portray them as innocent victims of Fortuna is, I feel, to rob even wrong-doers of the little dignity they possess. But then, what would fashion types know about dignity?

Because, of course, only those who haven't got the wit to speak for themselves would ever want their clothes to do it for them. Inside, there was more fun when a conversation with Tommy Lee about his ornamental fish spells "koi" as "coy" throughout. Mr Lee, apparently, has "a coy tattoo" and asks "Have you ever fed a coy?" Doh! No! But there are even bigger laffs in the Amendments and Apologies section, when one of the Amendments (not, interestingly, an Apology, which might have been a mite more sensitive) goes: "Issue 59 featured clothes by Sonia Rykiel with additional badges sewn on. Dazed & Confused were not aware that the badge in question was WWII insignia relating to a German Nazi Panzer Division. We would like to make it clear that we in no way intended to cause offence and had we been aware of the symbolism of it would not have been [sic] used as a styling accessory to the clothing. We are issuing this statement so that anyone who my [another sic!] have misinterpreted this shoot will now know that this was an innocent and naive error." Bless! Of course it was. Because, as I said a couple of weeks back with reference to the rag trade's about-face when it comes to fur, in fashion there is only one rule: Does it look good? If it does, be it the pelt of a tortured animal or Nazi insignia, it must be "good". If not, though ever so virtuous, it's simply a waste of space. This is the impeccable pretzel logic of fashionistas that brings us back to them time and time again when searching for a suitable recipient for the Cretin of the Century commemorative fruit-bowl. I was still gurgling with delight over Dazed & Confused's dazed confusion when I saw one of those new Benetton billboards, the ones featuring the faces of the poor oofums currently cooling their heels on America's Death Row, which have been erected in the hope of selling yet a few more stripy jumpers to a few more Swiss students. In Benetton's attempt to boost sales of their supernaturally banal woollies by linking them with matters of life and death ("I've got a new blue jumper! Therefore, I'm helping cure Aids/stop racism/abolish the death penalty!"), we see the true, glorious folly of fashion trying to think about anything bigger than the size of its butt or further away than the end of its bobbed nose. Yet even here it is as woolly as its own jumpers, and operating to the same old liberal consensus splashed with a bit of Kensington Gore. Fashion is notoriously prone to protecting its own, and though I have no way of proving it, I'd bet that if the killer of Gianni Versace - Andrew Cunanan - had not turned his gun upon himself, no way would Benetton ever dream of putting his mug up there for all to sympathise with. Gianni, you see, was an artist; the poor gimps these handsome guys killed were just civilians , who probably didn't even know the difference between taupe and greige! I have no problem with people protesting against the use of the death penalty in the US, but I do think that they are, for the most part, incredibly dishonest. In all pictorial pleas against it, we only ever see the face of the poor Joe waiting to be fried; in all his isolated and imperfect humanity, shorn of all worldly goods, he can't help but seem a little Christlike. What we never see is any reference to the events that got him on to Death Row in the first place. How much more shocking and truthful it would be if, instead of just the face of the killer, we saw the following: X [picture of killer] is due to die for doing this [photograph of the victim's body at the scene of the crime] and this [press photograph of victim's immediate family and friends at funeral, their agony clearly visible on their faces] to Y [picture of victim, preferably happy and smiling, ideally blowing out candles at most recent birthday party]. See? It's so much more upsetting, and so much more honest. But you won't ever see it, because there has always been a tendency among abolitionists to play down the humanity of the victims of convicted killers ("Oh well, they're dead! Nothing more can hurt them!" - ignoring, of course, the constant pain and grief of their loved ones living on) in order to boost the humanity quotient of the killer. ("There, but for fortune, go you or I!") But what you get from this is an extremely skewed set of values that actively champion the rights of the strong over the weak. In the new Tom Hanks film, The Green Mile, not one of the crimes of the gentle-giant killers on Death Row is thought suitable for our delicate ears - not one! This was a mistake, and only had the effect of making one try to work out which one was the child-rapist and which one the serial killer of old ladies. In other words, by attempting to draw a veil over the crimes of the "heroes", they actually made it worse. No group has a greater built-in bullshit detector than the young, which is why less than 48 per cent of under 25s in this country are registered to vote in the next election. And I notice that support for capital punishment is now highest among the young on both sides of the Atlantic, who are invariably the most liberal on other issues. I cannot help but feel that the mistakes of the abolition lobby have contributed greatly to this. It is a simplistic notion, yet one increasingly accepted, that the most recent victim of violence in any situation is the real victim; thus the killer on Death Row is more important than his innocent victim, or the destruction of Dresden far wickeder than the Luftwaffe's earlier destruction of Coventry. But killers do not simply wake up one morning, like Josef K, innocent dupes of an evil system, and Dresden didn't happen because Churchill woke up one morning in a lousy mood. When they choose evil, people choose their paths, whether they end up on Death Row or in the Luftwaffe. To deny this is not just to commit terrible disrespect towards all the poor, wretched and backward Americans who do not commit any violence whatsoever, and to all the Germans who did not follow Hitler. And for us to stand in the shoes of the violent criminal, in uniform or in prison drab, and attempt to portray them as innocent victims of Fortuna is, I feel, to rob even wrong-doers of the little dignity they possess. But then, what would fashion types know about dignity?

fields.headline: In country
fields.standfirst: The local farmer says that my objections to the clay-pigeon shoot show that I am not a true country man, a charge I am happy to accept
fields.trailText: The local farmer says that my objections to the clay-pigeon shoot show that I am not a true country man, a charge I am happy to accept
fields.body:
I have always thought that one of the main reasons for the popularity of blood sports in the country is the pointlessness of going outdoors with no purpose or destination in mind. Even if it is a warm and sunny day, even if the landscape is beautiful, a country walk can often feel futile and self-indulgent. You walk about a bit and then walk home, which is fine if you have a particular interest in birds or trees or wild flowers, but not so fine if you don't. I feel much the same about jogging, though I have never done it. There is something vaguely shameful, or at least embarrassing, about engaging in outdoor exercise for its own sake. That's why millions of birds have to be slaughtered each year, and millions of fish caught - to bestow a purpose on the urge to take the air. They do not know it, but they die in a noble cause.

Country walks are one of things that have put me off staying with people in the country at weekends. "Shall we go for a little walk before lunch?" they say, and off you traipse dolefully. Another depressing thing about country weekends is the Sunday papers. They cast a pall of gloom over Sunday mornings, spread out over the kitchen table or piled up on a coffee table in the sitting room. Hosts generously think that they should buy a lot of Sunday papers so that there is something for everyone to read, but it would be kinder of them to buy none. I do like Sunday lunch, however. It is a meal better consumed in the country than in town.

For many years, I have seldom gone to the country for weekends, partly for the above-mentioned reasons, partly because it's so dreadf ul getting there, and partly, I have to confess, for lack of being invited. But things have changed now. Since the beginning of the year, I have been going practically every weekend to Northamptonshire, where a small late-Victorian house has suddenly fallen into my hands.

There will be purists who say that it is not in proper country, lying as it does between Northampton and Milton Keynes. But it has an enormous garden and an almost unspoilt view, marred only at night by the orange glow of road lights on the horizon. And it looks immediately on to two of the earliest Palladian buildings in England, little 17th century pavilions that were once linked to a country house burnt down more than 100 years ago. So there is quite a lot to feast the eye on.

Getting there by car from London on the M1 takes about 75 minutes if the going is good; but often it is not, either because of accidents or because of something known on the radio as "sheer weight of traffic". Even that, as I found last weekend, can have its benefits. I was forced off the motorway at Hemel Hempstead and drove northwards towards Leighton Buzzard along a pretty valley road which showed that, even in the south of England, the destruction of the countryside is far from complete.

My house itself has some disadvantages, the main one being the Sunday-morning clay-pigeon shoot, which takes place less than 100 yards away. For a couple of hours, it is like living next to the Battle of the Somme. (The farmer, who makes a bit of money out of it, says that my objections show I am not a true country man, a charge I am happy to accept.) And when there is motor-racing at Silverstone a few miles away, the sky fills with helicopters carrying fat cats such as Bernie Ecclestone to and from the circuit and sounding like the soundtrack of Apocalypse Now.

But in general, I find I am very happy during my country weekends, especially as I seldom walk further than the herb garden to pick some sprigs of rosemary for the Sunday roast lamb. When I am not lounging about, I cook (which is far more enjoyable in the country than in town), spend time at my computer, and entertain family and friends. On the basis of very limited experience, I already feel able to pass on some useful tips about how to enjoy weekends in the country.

These are expensive, but important. First, take no luggage with you from the town (have everything you really need, such as a toothbrush and a razor, in both places). Second, have a well-stocked freezer. Third, have plenty of wine and all the ingredients for making a Bloody Mary. Fourth, have plentiful supplies of coal and firewood. And finally, have a machine called a Grenadier Firelighter. It looks like a large electric hair-dryer, and it blows out immensely hot air. Just pour some coal into the grate without paper or kindling wood, point the Grenadier at it, and within two minutes you have a roaring fire. It is frightening, but wonderful.

webTitle: Strident sound of upwardly mobile chat show

fields.headline: Strident sound of upwardly mobile chat show
fields.trailText: Queen Mum's funeral arrangements | More bonkers mission statements
fields.body:
Last year I was on a Eurostar train from Paris, returning after a day's work. I wanted a beer, a sandwich and a snooze, but I couldn't sleep because the chap across the aisle was permanently on his mobile phone, banging on to a secretary called Samantha. He talked from half an hour south of Lille all the way to London, interrupted only by the 20 minutes we were in the tunnel. Evidently the topic was very urgent: "I need those contracts on my desk tomorrow, Sam," and "you get on the line to Hardwicks first thing and tell them that those specs won't do". And so forth.

What was amazing was that in almost two hours of talk - how his battery lasted I do not know - I was completely unable to work out what his business did, whether it manufactured things, offered a service, or just generated faxes, emails and phone calls to no apparent purpose.

Then this week, I saw a giant poster above Waterloo's Eurostar terminal. "It takes powerful software to do business with New York en route from Paris to London. That's the software IBM makes," and I realised there were people cutting deals in America while they were on the train. No naps, no lager. That's the trouble with this country; nobody has any repose. We're all frantically busy, inventing activities we think we have to do but which produce nothing at all, least of all increased happiness for us and our families. We urgently need time to stare into space, or pick our toenails while watching daytime TV. A new report from Hull University says that people who hang around doing what they enjoy are happier than people who spend their lives being unnecessarily active. My point, I think, is proved.

The other day I spoke to a group of students in Oxford. We couldn't get into the room because the chap who had to sign for the key hadn't turned up. He was finally tracked down to his bedroom, where he had "overslept". It was 1.15 pm. At first I thought this was silly, then I reflected that it was actually rather a good idea. We all ought to lie in bed until the afternoon, at least once a week. We ought to switch off our mobile phones, only pick up our emails once a week, and slob out for as long as possible. On a train, we should sleep, or read a book unrelated to work. Only then will we recover our senses.

 Thanks for your letters about Wigan folk and their love for pies. Mrs M Robinson of Winstanley, Wigan, writes with a week-old clipping from the admirable Wigan Reporter, which always has the hottest pie scoops: "It could only happen in Wigan - a chip pie! Edwards Bakers in Platt Bridge have bowed to demand and combined the two things Wiganers enjoy best to launch their latest culinary invention." The baker, Duncan Edwards, describes the delicacy with as much enthusiasm as Marco-Pierre White could ever muster: "Basically, it's a pastry case filled with chips and served with gravy... it's not that fattening, honest." Mmmm. Next, the pie pie, rich flaky pastry served in a crisp pastry crust.

 And thanks too for letters and emails about the Queen Mum, and my view that the Labour party - even today's party - has done far more for Britain over the past 100 years. Most, though not all, agree with me, and that includes Martin Bell, MP. "You may like to know that the BBC started rehearsals for its Queen Mother funeral broadcast in 1983. I was at the time reporting from a grief-stricken Canada. Many of those participating are now dead."

I gather the Beeb has since scaled down its plans, which will now be somewhere between a brief mention on the news and six months of national mourning, culminating with Jennie Bond committing ceremonial suttee on the pyre. Incidentally, Martin is having, he says, the best time of his life as an MP. He feels he cannot break his promise to stand only once in Tatton, so is looking round for a seat with similarly unusual circumstances. After this week's events, I wonder if Teresa Gorman's Billericay might be a possibility.

 I see that the Northern Ireland tourist board is making yet another attempt to get the punters over there. It's a good idea. One of the great joys of working there was the fabulous scenery, which you didn't have to share with anyone except, curiously, a few Swiss people who presumably didn't read the papers.

I recall climbing and horse-riding in the mountains of Mourne, clambering over the Giant's Causeway, and one of the most idyllic days I have ever spent, with friends in a boat on Lough Erne. The lake is full of islands and we hopped from one to the other in the blazing sunshine, bottles of cold wine in the bilges. We picnicked on one island in the shade of a ruined church. Another had, in a slightly sinister way, been taken over by bluebells, which carpeted every square inch. It was glorious.

Apart from the Swiss, the only person we saw was William Craig, a former home secretary who then ran a sort of paramilitary movement, the Ulster Vanguard. Bill always preferred a drink to a march, so we didn't really mind.

 More bonkers mission statements next week. In the meantime, I like Bradford University's "Making Knowledge Work" (Alan Cornell of Plymouth likes the mill-owner ring: "we'll make tha' work, knowledge!") A colleague on the FT sends me the mission statement of an internal magazine, QWKLink: "the Communications Team is the voice of global process improvement procedures, and QWKLink is the communication vehicle which focuses on bringing these procedural enhancements to you."

fields.headline: Brooding on chasubles
fields.standfirst: Oh brave new world, that has such vestments in it.
fields.trailText: Oh brave new world, that has such vestments in it.
fields.body:
 Soon after the second world war, two majors in the British army, on their way home for demobilisation, met in a bar in Tournai. They had known each other at Oxford and began to discuss what they might do when the war was over. One, who was Labour, said he meant to become a politician. The other, a Tory, was unsure. He thought he might become an orchestral conductor. Four years later, they met again on the hustings in the 1950 election. The Labour man was conceding defeat to the Tory. The seat was Bexley; the Labour man, Ashley Bramall; the Tory, Edward Heath, who this week completed a 50-year stint in the Commons. What a frightful place the Commons is sometimes, though. I heard the exchanges when Teresa Gorman was being debated: the Tory bigwig Sir Peter Tapsell braying away about her being a combative and zany lady and then adding that he'd known quite a lot of combative and zany ladies in his long life. And immediately all that dreadful clubland chortling, no doubt on the calculation that s-e-x was raising its head.

 There are divisions in the Church of England, I see, over dress. Traditionalists, the Times reported this week, remain wedded to ornate chasubles, copes and stoles, but radicals wear just about anything: one Mancunian officiates in a combat jacket, leather trousers and boots. As a church official commented: "Vestments are part of the layers of mystery." Since reading all this, I have caught myself brooding on chasubles. What, apart from a canon in Oscar Wilde, is a chasuble? A conical cape, the authorities say, with a hole to put your head through, and seams reinforced by decorated strips of material called orphreys. Orphrey would make a splendid name for a canon, too. A merchant of ecclesiastical vestments advertises albs, chasubles and stoles. An alb, it's explained, is a long white tunic down to the ankles, while a stole, as in lay couture, is a stole. An amice is a simple scarf of white linen or wool worn under the alb (though radicals no doubt wear it over the alb, to show they are radicals). There used to be something called a dalmatic - a garment of wool or linen reaching the knee with baggy elbow-length sleeves. What a rich world this is, and so unexplored.

 But costume is not the only mystery now dividing the church. The word "ek" is another. Apparently they've been debating the meaning of that for two years. The blame for this lies less with the synod than with the Greeks, who devised a word which equally means "by", "of" or "from". I shall look with new respect from now on at the north country exclamation "by ek", which always seemed plain before, but which I now have to add to my list of ecclesiastical mysteries. The same report on the synod's debate on the Nicene Creed, in which "ek" is embedded, quotes someone called Bruinvel as saying:"We should keep the creed as it is. It has lasted years and years. Why change it now?" Here is another mystery. What is a Bruinvel? Could it be the singular form of the former Tory MP Peter Bruinvels who, before he succumbed to the rise of Labour, declared himself, in his zeal for capital punishment, ready to carry out the work of the hangman if no other volunteer could be found?

Curious (Cricklewood) writes : What is a thurifer?

Smallweed knowledgeably responds: It's an acolyte who carries a thurible.

Curious (Cricklewood) counters: What, in that case, is a thurible?

Smallweed impatiently snaps: It is something a thurifer carries.

 Enough of ecclesiastical matters. I deeply deplore the behaviour of banks in trying to exploit the need of the public to draw money from holes in the wall owned by other people's providers. This has led to an undesirable torrent of references on the BBC to something they call "withdrawral". Even the delightful Winifred Robinson, who gratifyingly has appeared several mornings this week on the Today programme, appeared to insert a phantom "r" in this word, thus reducing the mountain of her merits by a molehill. Most of these people, if asked to do so, could pronounced the word "drawl"; so why not "withdrawal"? This is one mystery we could well do without.

 I am glad to see the Dome is doing better, not because I think it especially wonderful, but because its success would represent a victory for word-of-mouth over the lying right-wing press. These newspapers have persistently said not just that the enterprise is full of vacuity and cost far more money than it is worth, which is true; but also that customers have been coming away feeling cheated, which, as all the polls have shown, is not. (There was a pseudo-poll on the internet which declared it not worth the entrance fee, but most of those who responded would never have been there.) Smallweed has been monitoring the performance of the anti-Dome papers in order to name the fattest lie of the lot. The winner, as you'd expect, is that monument to human mendacity, the Daily Mail, one of whose columnists, Ephraim Hardcastle (not his real name, I suspect!) alleged that polls which said the public was happy were bogus. They got the results they did, he blustered, because people who had wasted their money did not wish to admit as much to strangers with clipboards. The idea that the British public is afraid to admit it has wasted its money is one that only the desperate could ever advance. I had planned to award an alb to the champion liar, but albs would be wasted on Ephraim.

 The aftertaste of a world which has gone for ever, no 238 in an occasional Smallweed series: "My late father-in-law, AM Thompson, was co-founder of the Clarion and contributed to its pages under the pseudonym Dangle" - letter to the Daily Telegraph.

Traditionalists, the Times reported this week, remain wedded to ornate chasubles, copes and stoles, but radicals wear just about anything: one Mancunian officiates in a combat jacket, leather trousers and boots. As a church official commented: "Vestments are part of the layers of mystery." Since reading all this, I have caught myself brooding on chasubles. What, apart from a canon in Oscar Wilde, is a chasuble? A conical cape, the authorities say, with a hole to put your head through, and seams reinforced by decorated strips of material called orphreys. Orphrey would make a splendid name for a canon, too. A merchant of ecclesiastical vestments advertises albs, chasubles and stoles. An alb, it's explained, is a long white tunic down to the ankles, while a stole, as in lay couture, is a stole. An amice is a simple scarf of white linen or wool worn under the alb (though radicals no doubt wear it over the alb, to show they are radicals). There used to be something called a dalmatic - a garment of wool or linen reaching the knee with baggy elbow-length sleeves. What a rich world this is, and so unexplored.  But costume is not the only mystery now dividing the church. The word "ek" is another. Apparently they've been debating the meaning of that for two years. The blame for this lies less with the synod than with the Greeks, who devised a word which equally means "by", "of" or "from". I shall look with new respect from now on at the north country exclamation "by ek", which always seemed plain before, but which I now have to add to my list of ecclesiastical mysteries. The same report on the synod's debate on the Nicene Creed, in which "ek" is embedded, quotes someone called Bruinvel as saying:"We should keep the creed as it is. It has lasted years and years. Why change it now?" Here is another mystery. What is a Bruinvel? Could it be the singular form of the former Tory MP Peter Bruinvels who, before he succumbed to the rise of Labour, declared himself, in his zeal for capital punishment, ready to carry out the work of the hangman if no other volunteer could be found? Curious (Cricklewood) writes : What is a thurifer? Smallweed knowledgeably responds: It's an acolyte who carries a thurible. Curious (Cricklewood) counters: What, in that case, is a thurible? Smallweed impatiently snaps: It is something a thurifer carries.  Enough of ecclesiastical matters. I deeply deplore the behaviour of banks in trying to exploit the need of the public to draw money from holes in the wall owned by other people's providers. This has led to an undesirable torrent of references on the BBC to something they call "withdrawral". Even the delightful Winifred Robinson, who gratifyingly has appeared several mornings this week on the Today programme, appeared to insert a phantom "r" in this word, thus reducing the mountain of her merits by a molehill. Most of these people, if asked to do so, could pronounced the word "drawl"; so why not "withdrawal"? This is one mystery we could well do without.  I am glad to see the Dome is doing better, not because I think it especially wonderful, but because its success would represent a victory for word-of-mouth over the lying right-wing press. These newspapers have persistently said not just that the enterprise is full of vacuity and cost far more money than it is worth, which is true; but also that customers have been coming away feeling cheated, which, as all the polls have shown, is not. (There was a pseudo-poll on the internet which declared it not worth the entrance fee, but most of those who responded would never have been there.) Smallweed has been monitoring the performance of the anti-Dome papers in order to name the fattest lie of the lot. The winner, as you'd expect, is that monument to human mendacity, the Daily Mail, one of whose columnists, Ephraim Hardcastle (not his real name, I suspect!) alleged that polls which said the public was happy were bogus. They got the results they did, he blustered, because people who had wasted their money did not wish to admit as much to strangers with clipboards. The idea that the British public is afraid to admit it has wasted its money is one that only the desperate could ever advance. I had planned to award an alb to the champion liar, but albs would be wasted on Ephraim.  The aftertaste of a world which has gone for ever, no 238 in an occasional Smallweed series: "My late father-in-law, AM Thompson, was co-founder of the Clarion and contributed to its pages under the pseudonym Dangle" - letter to the Daily Telegraph.

webTitle: A quiet night in with the birds

fields.headline: A quiet night in with the birds
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
'Hear that?" said Bill Oddie with a quick sidelong glance at the camera. "Kirsch-chucka-whascha? That's a corncrake." And that other sound? The thrush nightingale: like the song nightingale, it repeats little phrases in its song. And that? The golden oriel. And that? The scarlet rosefinch. And that? My washing machine going through its spin cycle. And if you listen really carefully I think you can hear - yes! - that's a black T-shirt mixed in with the whites. Damn!

It was May in Poland, and Oddie was wandering through its abundant wetlands. He used to be a corncrake in the 70s, an awkward-looking bird who made odd rasping sounds. His natural habitat was in a field with Tim Brooke-Taylor and Graeme Garden. He then affected, paradoxically, the odd strutting walk of a rooster in platforms. Next he was like a smaller, more flighty Harry Secombe, though less devoted to the raspberry (parp!) in his characteristic song. Thirty years later in Birding with Bill Oddie (BBC2), he has mellowed into a thrush nightingale - pleasingly repetitive and easy on the ear.

Oddie and Polish bird expert Marek Borkowski stood on their jeep looking across the marshes. They adjusted their lenses and hoped to see aquatic warblers holding secret philosophy discussion groups in the long grass. "Run dum dip id ip," said Marek, though whether he was imitating the song of the aquatic warbler or inventing a new dialect wasn't clear. "Oh flip," said Bill excitedly as he pulled the focus on his camera.

It's nice to hear people say "flip", that old word from the lexicon of sanitised TV, resuscitated for a gaudier age in which swearing is commonplace and games shows such as Prickly Heat (Sky 1) consist of show-offs running across beaches with ice cubes crammed into their bikini bottoms. Isn't it? Too flipping right it is.

But Bill and Marek were looking in the wrong direction. The aquatic warblers? They were in Marek's luxuriant beard, that soft matted number containing all the warmth and nesting materials the birds needed to get them through the cool spring evening.

This was a lovely half hour, one of those mildly educative programmes broadcast on Friday evenings that are muted and beautifully photographed. I was lulled into a cat nap by the sound of the middle-spotted woodpecker, only to be rudely awakened by the corncrake's distinctive "Kirsch-chucka-whascha". That's why corncrakes disappeared from Britain: it was nothing to do with farming methods; they were strangled by dozy lumps like me.

I could hear the Bialowieza forest growing and rotting in the spectral calm of this programme. I could hear insects being born in their millions and being eaten by a variety of birdlife much richer than that of Britain, that home of industrialised agriculture and decimated woodlands. The appeal of Poland for Oddie was that one could see there the birds of Victorian England - among them the yellowhammer, the red-banded shrike, and, my favourite, the big-bearded tough. In this rural Poland there were a pair of horses pulling a plough guided by the farmer on foot. Not the sort of thing you see as you speed up the M1.

This was a fanciful Poland, but more pleasant to look at for that. "It's not so much the sights as the sounds of Poland I'll remember. There wasn't a moment in which I couldn't hear birdsong," said Oddie, and he spoke for me too. Now, for instance, if you listen carefully, you can hear the great reed warbler chuntering and the river warbler like a busy sewing machine as the sun sets behind the closing credits.

On Sky Sports Interactive they have birdwatching, too. It's called the PlayerCam and what it involves is quite interesting. During a football match you push a few buttons on your digital handset and, instead of watching the game from the touchline, you can follow a single player as he tries to hide himself like a shy corncrake near the centre circle. To my mind, this new facility involves too many close-ups of Alan Shearer hawking into the turf and nameless midfielders picking their noses when they think - crazy fools! - that they are not being watched. Have these vulgarians never heard of hankies? Isn't it amazing that our footballers don't use their massively inflated salaries to buy a few Ultra-Balm tissues and ask their shirt designers to tailor sleeves in which to tuck the used ones discreetly?

fields.headline: Amazing future of the wireless
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
There's something curiously satisfying about wireless becoming a current word again. Only a few months ago it was still an arch way of referring to radio. Suddenly it's cutting-edge mobile phone-speak. Of course, when people talk of Wireless Application Protocol, they are talking about mobile telecommunications. But might not Wap also have a radio dimension ?

The Wap-enabled phone, after all, can access the internet, and the internet is where increasing quantities of radio will be sited. Better, surely, to hear it on a machine already geared up for listening, and which is mobile, than from an immobile PC. In a few years' time (especially if calls are cheaper or free), instead of people on the tube with an earpiece ignoring Tony Blair while listening to their Walkman, we may have people on the bus with an earpiece ignoring Tony Blair while listening to their net radio station.

If the mobile phone ever does double up as a trannie (it would save shlepping around two pieces of equipment), it will probably be used for listening to stations - such as American ones - not available here. We may yet be shocked by American jocks.

In Radio 4's new series The Ageing Game, presenter Barbara Myers typed her personal details into www.livingto100.com and was delighted to be told that she'd live until 98 and a half. Perhaps they should rename it wishfulthinking.com. One pretends to listen to this kind of programme for the science, but really one just wants to calculate one's own odds. Having a baby in your 40s apparently promises long life. Being neurotic doesn't.

This was a far less gimmicky programme than such a synopsis suggests. It included some astringent comments on the stereotyping of old people, as well as predictably upbeat, energetic examples of the "superyoung". One 53-year-old so hymned her own powers of positive thinking and stamina that her life may well be at risk from more healthily misanthropic types. Could we have acceptance of ageing as a theme one week?

The most powerful programme of the week was Taking Note (Radio 4), a series of personal diaries by black and Asian police officers in the year following the Macpherson report. Detective Inspector David Michael, returning to the Met after four years fighting a racial discrimination case, has continued to suffer abuse, hate mail, and passive aggression from his colleagues. But according to one white colleague, it's all just matey banter.

To recruit more ethnic minority police the Met commissioned a rap song which they thought would give them cachet in the streets, only to incur derision and accusations of stereotyping. If the Met can get it so wrong on their own patch, what chance of them getting it right with the public?

On her new late-night programme Access All Areas (Classic FM), Natalie Wheen interviews major musicians and offers a notice-board of music events around the country - the kind of thing Henry Kelly does between the racing tips.

One could debate whether listeners really need to know what the Southampton Youth Band are getting up to. But what the show usefully does is reveal the extent of music-making around the country, and integrate amateur and local events with glitzy national ones. Classic FM has been resolutely a station for the don't-know-much-about-music listener. Here's a glimpse of its potential as a station for those who make music too.

Finally, BBC1 is currently running an amusing ad for Radio 5 Live in which a footie fan astounds his family and friends with his copious knowledge of politics. Of course the joke only works if you accept the stereotype that, sans 5 Live, all footie fans would be thick.

fields.headline: The cure
fields.trailText: Just how would Jeremy Marks set about curing me (Sex and salvation, March 2)? Would he begin by making blunt my razor sharp wit, or dumbing down my stylish dress sense? Would he take my lively fun-loving life and turn it into dull domesticity?
fields.body:
Just how would Jeremy Marks set about curing me (Sex and salvation, March 2)? Would he begin by making blunt my razor sharp wit, or dumbing down my stylish dress sense? Would he take my lively fun-loving life and turn it into dull domesticity? No, I know. It would have to be my dignity and self-respect - they would have to be the first to go. Nice jumper though, Jeremy, such a brave choice!
Paul Patrick
Burnley, Lancashire

 Fortunately, a lot more people are cured of Christianity and "become" gay than vice versa.
Dr Robert Johnston
Northampton
robj@writeright.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Ethics and aesthetics
fields.trailText: You published a photo of the Eric Morecambe statue by Ian Walters (Double act, March 1) but with no indication of the fact that he had created it. Figurative sculptors get a thin enough time of it as it is without having their work consigned to anonymity by the newspapers.
fields.body:
You published a photo of the Eric Morecambe statue by Ian Walters (Double act, March 1) but with no indication of the fact that he had created it. Figurative sculptors get a thin enough time of it as it is without having their work consigned to anonymity by the newspapers.

We know Alan Shearer kicks the goals, you tell us. We know Elton John sings the songs, you tell us. But when a sculptor makes a statue of a personality like Eric Morecambe or, reaching back into last week's news, Stanley Matthews, the public is left in ignorance of their creators. Fair dos for portrait sculptors, please.
Anthony Stones
Society of Portrait Sculptors

 It is honest and courageous of the Tate and National Gallery to list and publish their paintings of doubtful origin (Shadow cast over great masters, March 1). Yet, this airing of scruples is a recent phenomenon. Looting and rape used to be the legitimate perk of military life. I remember seeing the dinner service of Caroline Bonaparte proudly displayed in an English stately home.

To whom do works of art really belong? An artist does not create his talent. It is a gift from above, to relieve his frustrations and give pleasure to the onlookers. Ideally, like the natural world, they belong to mankind, not to an individual. A public gallery is the right place for them. Were the source of wealth of those who can afford old masters to be scrutinised as closely as the origin of their purchases, few would pass the ethical test.
Simone Crawley
Stockport

fields.headline: Do your bit
fields.trailText: Obviously Tony Blair doesn't realise the full meaning of the words "voluntary work" (Blair volunteers to give up a day, March 2). One does the job of one's own volition, but also without payment.
fields.body:
Obviously Tony Blair doesn't realise the full meaning of the words "voluntary work" (Blair volunteers to give up a day, March 2). One does the job of one's own volition, but also without payment. How much poorer the world would be if it were not for the millions of us who do regular voluntary work. Great it would be if Tony and his employees were to donate their excessive pay earned through their pleasant days of truancy to the homeless and to the disaster-stricken areas of the world.
Christine Lemon
Brentwood, Essex

 Voluntary work should be unpaid. Come on, Mr Blair and colleagues, volunteer but also donate your day's salary to fund full-time helpers to work with you.
Iris Nutting
London

fields.headline: Benz effect
fields.trailText: Steve Ridgeway (Letters, March 3) must have been too liberal with the libations (from that libran Liberian librarian). Benz had nothing to do with it. Daimler called its cars after Mercedes Jellinek, daughter of their major distributor, in 1900 when Mercedes was about 10.
fields.body:

Daimler called its cars after Mercedes Jellinek, daughter of their major distributor, in 1900 when Mercedes was about 10. Benz and Daimler didn't merge until 1924 when the Mercedes name was so established that the cars became Mercedes-Benz. So no Brooklyn effect. Mind you, BMW don't seem to like the name Rover much ...

Milford, Surrey

fields.headline: Diagnosis on Pinochet
fields.trailText: It may salve liberal consciences to repeat that dictators have been given notice there is no hiding place (Not waving, but a warning, March 3). To seriously believe that is self-delusion.
fields.body:
It may salve liberal consciences to repeat that dictators have been given notice there is no hiding place (Not waving, but a warning, March 3). To seriously believe that is self-delusion. The only possible conclusion to draw from the whole grubby farce is that if you are a Muslim dictator or one that the Americans don't like, you may have a problem. If you are the ex-dictator of a country with significant trading relations with the west, no international treaty is worth the paper it is written on, as a suitable technicality will be found to avoid the theoretical danger of prosecution.

As under the Conservatives, so under New Labour: business profits are more important than any number of tortured, maimed and murdered trade unionists. Geoffrey Robertson cites the prosecution of the ex-president of Chad as proof that the international community is now prepared to take action against dictators accused of torture and genocide. Does he truly believe this admirable prosecution would be taking place if western profits were significantly boosted by exports to Chad and if a large faction of Chad's ruling class still supported their ex-president?
Dave Hunt
London
d.hunt@radleyyeldar.com

 Geoffrey Robertson says that "at least a British government was prepared to let the law take what turned out to be a momentous course". Unlike other European governments whose subjects were tortured or murdered in Pinochet's jails, no British government ever took any legal step anywhere to bring to justice the man who had violated the rights of British citizens in Chile. Other countries started the process to bring Pinochet to justice, and the home secretary was bound to pay lip service; the one and only decision Mr Straw took of his own free will was to send Pinochet home.
William Gill
London

 If people want to know why the Pinochet case finished, then almost certainly the answer lies in the meeting between Robin Cook and his opposite numbers in Chile and Spain last autumn. They engineered this way out of a situation none of these governments wanted. After this meeting Pinochet was reportedly too ill to face trial and Jack Straw ordered medical tests. Britain only had to judge whether his crimes were extraditable, and Jack Straw up until January of this year had stuck to his word that he would follow the decisions of the courts.

This has been a successful piece of political planning and not the just end to a historic process. This case will change international human rights. Sadly, though, none of this can be accredited to the government. When Pinochet walked to his plane, he was the beneficiary, once again, of political plotting.
Chris Welch
Sheffield
C.Welch@shu.ac.uk

 Given the enormity of the crimes involved, the other countries should at least have been given the opportunity to carry out their own medical examinations. If somebody is well enough to entertain Baroness Thatcher, it is reasonable to suppose they are well enough to stand trial.
Joe Charnock
Boston, Mass

 So, according to Norman Lamont, there is no evidence against Pinochet except that of his victims. Well, that's OK then.
Dr Sam Langridge
Buxted, Sussex
samlang444@aol.com

 Jack Straw has tortured our feelings, killed our hope.
Sergio Leon
Bristol

 There is no justice in this world.
Clea Cook
Taunton, Somerset
cook@linndhu.freeserve.co.uk

Does he truly believe this admirable prosecution would be taking place if western profits were significantly boosted by exports to Chad and if a large faction of Chad's ruling class still supported their ex-president? Dave Hunt London d.hunt@radleyyeldar.com  Geoffrey Robertson says that "at least a British government was prepared to let the law take what turned out to be a momentous course". Unlike other European governments whose subjects were tortured or murdered in Pinochet's jails, no British government ever took any legal step anywhere to bring to justice the man who had violated the rights of British citizens in Chile. Other countries started the process to bring Pinochet to justice, and the home secretary was bound to pay lip service; the one and only decision Mr Straw took of his own free will was to send Pinochet home. William Gill London  If people want to know why the Pinochet case finished, then almost certainly the answer lies in the meeting between Robin Cook and his opposite numbers in Chile and Spain last autumn. They engineered this way out of a situation none of these governments wanted. After this meeting Pinochet was reportedly too ill to face trial and Jack Straw ordered medical tests. Britain only had to judge whether his crimes were extraditable, and Jack Straw up until January of this year had stuck to his word that he would follow the decisions of the courts. This has been a successful piece of political planning and not the just end to a historic process. This case will change international human rights. Sadly, though, none of this can be accredited to the government. When Pinochet walked to his plane, he was the beneficiary, once again, of political plotting. Chris Welch Sheffield C.Welch@shu.ac.uk  Given the enormity of the crimes involved, the other countries should at least have been given the opportunity to carry out their own medical examinations. If somebody is well enough to entertain Baroness Thatcher, it is reasonable to suppose they are well enough to stand trial. Joe Charnock Boston, Mass  So, according to Norman Lamont, there is no evidence against Pinochet except that of his victims. Well, that's OK then. Dr Sam Langridge Buxted, Sussex samlang444@aol.com  Jack Straw has tortured our feelings, killed our hope. Sergio Leon Bristol  There is no justice in this world. Clea Cook Taunton, Somerset cook@linndhu.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Trade-off over aid
fields.trailText: Contrary to Martin Woollacott's passing reference, in his otherwise excellent article on the belated aid to Mozambique (Comment, March 3), Portugal was the first country to send a donation of £2m to Mozambique.
fields.body:
Contrary to Martin Woollacott's passing reference, in his otherwise excellent article on the belated aid to Mozambique (Comment, March 3), Portugal was the first country to send a donation of £2m to Mozambique, a member of the Community of Portuguese Language Countries as well as the Commonwealth. This was remarkable given the fact that Portugal has been spending tens of millions of pounds in assisting East Timor to recover from the massive devastation caused by Indonesia in the wake of the referendum for independence.

In Mozambique, Portugal was soon overtaken by Britain and others, a fact that is appreciated in Portugal. But it has given rise to a national controversy over whether Portugal, instead of using its modest resources in East Timor, should try and rally international support to press Indonesia to pay adequate reparations to the Timorese for the devastation. The proceeds would release funds for more aid to Mozambique and it would be in keeping with the policy of reconciliation started by the new Indonesian government. The transfer would make an important moral distinction between the man-made tragedy in East Timor and the ecological disaster Mozambicans are suffering.
Antonio de Figueiredo
London

 The US has a massive naval base in nearby Diego Garcia. To my knowledge they have not sent even a single helicopter.
Jenny Rathbone
London
Jenny.Rathbone@islington. gov.uk

 Perhaps we need to ask when nearby rich countries, for example Saudi Arabia, are going to shoulder some of the responsibility in helping those who are unable to help themselves.
Chris Meadows
Bedford
cmeadows@globalnet.co.uk

webTitle: Not just the job for many

fields.headline: Not just the job for many
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's contention that there are enough vacancies for most of the claimant unemployed (Brown attacked for using 'fiddled' figures on jobless, March 1) begs the question "what kind of vacancies"? Unemployed people often remain so because they cannot find vacancies at a sufficient wage.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's contention that there are enough vacancies for most of the claimant unemployed (Brown attacked for using 'fiddled' figures on jobless, March 1) begs the question "what kind of vacancies"? Unemployed people often remain so because they cannot find vacancies at a sufficient wage.

In my own research with jobseekers last summer in six different areas, only nine out of 79 people on benefits said they were willing to work for the national minimum wage of £3.60 per hour, and of these six were 25 or younger. They were hardly demanding a fortune. An hourly wage of merely £4.50, or less, would be acceptable to 34, although in London nobody said they would work for less than £5. Almost one in five in the sample had mortgages and were clear that low pay would mean losing their homes. The working families' tax credit is of no help to the childless - over two-thirds of this sample.

Many of the vacancies on offer are part-time or temporary. It is unhelpful and unfair that someone who moves from benefits to a temporary or part-time job, and then tries to keep off the dole by getting a better job before the first one ends, risks being denied benefit if they lose the second job. This occurs because jobseeker rules can penalise them for having left the first job voluntarily.
Anne Gray
South Bank University
anne.gray@geo2.poptel.org.uk

fields.headline: Put up or shut up
fields.standfirst:
It's time to bite the bullet, Ken

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Now it's getting ugly - and confusing. The battle of Frank Dobson vs Ken Livingstone has got down and dirty, with the two old bruisers now wrestling in a mudbath of their own making. Fresh from their Thursday night clash on Question Time - as gripping a moment of television as you could wish for - the two rivals got stuck in again yesterday.
fields.body:
Now it's getting ugly - and confusing. The battle of Frank Dobson vs Ken Livingstone has got down and dirty, with the two old bruisers now wrestling in a mudbath of their own making. Fresh from their Thursday night clash on Question Time - as gripping a moment of television as you could wish for - the two rivals got stuck in again yesterday. On TV Dobbo had swivelled round, like Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry, daring Ken to "make my day". As if that was not quite macho enough, he yesterday urged Mr Livingstone to stop "peddling lies" to his friends in the Tory party and (worse) the media. Red Ken dished it back, expressing the hope that Frank will feel "better soon" - a not-very-coded reference to the rumours, which emanated from the Livingstone camp earlier in the campaign, that Mr Dobson was "clinically depressed." To Chris Evans he promised that if Frank stands down, he would "pay his barber's bill for the next 10 years". Edifying it is not.

Who wins and who loses from this bear-pit approach to politics? The Labour party must surely suffer. Having spent more than a decade presenting itself as an organisation of almost military discipline, Labour now has to watch as two party members whack each other. Mr Dobson says Mr Livingstone's plans for London would be "ruinous"; Ken says than "in any normal country" Frank would have left the stage by now - as a loser.

But the less obvious casualty of this internal warfare could be Ken Livingstone himself. For one thing, his supporters are growing confused. What exactly did happen in his Monday night meeting with John Prescott? Was he presented with some nuclear item of scandal that Millbank would leak if he dares run as an independent? Or, conversely, was he beginning to negotiate a deal, which could lead to Mr Dobson standing down and Mr Livingstone inheriting the nomination? That may seem appealing to Ken, but it would be less so to the Londoners who like the former GLC leader precisely because he is the man against the machine - not the beneficiary of backroom dealmaking. All this delay is clearly taking its toll on Mr Livingstone - he looked uncharacteristically tense on Thursday - but it will also sap the goodwill of his potential voters. They like his stance against politics-as-usual. All this delay makes him look too much like a calculating politician. If he is going to run alone, he should say so very soon.

webTitle: Serb crowd fails to halt return home

fields.headline: Serb crowd fails to halt return home
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: French peacekeeping troops in Kosovo achieved a minor victory yesterday when they returned 38 ethnic Albanians to their flats on the Serb-dominated north side of Mitrovice.
fields.body:
French peacekeeping troops in Kosovo achieved a minor victory yesterday when they returned 38 ethnic Albanians to their flats on the Serb-dominated north side of Mitrovice.

The operation followed a standoff of several hours between Serb protesters and the K-For troops, which culminated in the use of teargas against the angry, stone-throwing crowd.

The returnees were the first group to be escorted home out of some 1,500 Albanians who fled after a gun and grenade attack last month by Serb gangs, which claimed the lives of at least 10 Albanians.

Yesterday's success was achieved only when the Albanians were driven in armoured cars along a back route across the river Ibar, rather than over the two bridges which connect the two sides of the city. An earlier effort to escort them over a temporary footbridge on Thursday was abandoned when Serbs threw stones at two Albanians who tried to cross.

Yesterday's effort looked doomed when scores of middle-aged Serb women gathered close to the Albanians' flats long before their expected return, and threw stones at reporters. Meanwhile, around 50 men kept a lookout on the river bank for the Albanians.

The French troops resorted to teargas to try to disperse the Serbs - who included men with walkie-talkies - when they re-grouped near the main bridge, believing it would be used to take the Albanians home. A UN police car had its windows smashed and three French soldiers were slightly injured by stones.

The 38 returnees all lived in three tower blocks along the river. But about two-thirds of the Albanians forced to flee last month live in even more dangerous parts of the city.

Several foreign police officers stationed in Mitrovice, as well as officials from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, have called the returns to the three tower blocks a symbolic diversion from the main issue - the target of re-unifying the whole of Mitrovice.

UN officials screened all Albanian applicants to be sure they were going home voluntarily but the UNHCR, which has the primary responsibility for returns, is concerned that they are being put under pressure to go home despite security concerns. French and Danish troops will guard the entrances to the flats.

In the last nine months, tens of thousands of Serbs and Roma - including some from southern Mitrovice - have been displaced from their homes throughout Kosovo. UN officials fear that concentrating on what is the first case of Albanians being forced to flee their homes since K-For's arrival in June sends out the wrong signal.

"We're very much in favour of people going back but we want it to be more than symbolic. It's important that returns are comprehensive and to all areas where people want to go, both in the north and south. Returns must be lasting, meaningful, and as widespread as possible," said Dennis McNamara, the UNHCR special envoy.

Yesterday's incident has highlighted major differences between the approach of the French troops and the UN po lice, whose numbers have more than doubled since the killings last month.

In an attempt to change tactics, the UN has put a Dane in charge of police in northern Mitrovice, in place of a French officer.

Bernard Kouchner, the French former minister who heads the UN mission in Kosovo, has drawn up an ambitious plan to unify Mitrovice by using strict identity checks to control access to the city, and by arresting troublemakers . But the plan cannot get off the ground until security improves.

There are also plans for more foot patrols instead of the armoured vehicle patrols which are favoured by the French. "We're trying to impress on the French K-For commander that we do the police thing," said a senior UN officer yesterday.

"Up to now there has been a very weak will to deal with harassment. Local police on foot would identify the troublemakers as they come out of the bars. It's a question of familiarity and experience."

fields.headline: Z is for zonked
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report A Guardian guide to the US elections
fields.trailText: A Guardian guide to the US elections
fields.body:
For those who feel that the US electoral system makes the rules of cricket look simple, we offer this handy alphabetical guide to next week's climactic Super Tuesday primaries.

A: Al, as in Gore. Vice-president, Democratic frontrunner, woodentop.

B: Beauty contest. A popular vote not involving delegates or swimsuits.

C: Christian right. Scary stuff.

D: Delegates. People in funny hats who wave flags at party conventions.

E: Exit, as in polls. Treat with care.

F: Founding Fathers. Traitors to the British Crown. It's all their fault.

G: George, as in W Bush. Republican money-bags, fake Texan, Mommy's boy.

H: House, as in White. DC rent-free pad, 42 previous occupiers, vacant soon.

I: Independent, as in voter. Swingers, Vietnam vets, John McCain supporters.

J: Jewish vote. Absolutely crucial in New York, less so in Idaho.

K: Knicks. Bill Bradley's basketball team which proved white men can jump.

L: Lewinsky, as in Monica. Also known as Clinton fatigue. 'Nuff said.

M: Monica, as in Lewinsky. Stop it!

N: Negative advertising. Telling lies in the privacy of other people's homes.

O: As in "Oh gee! Mom! I won the primary!" (Calm down, George).

P: Political action committee. Lobbyists who buy the candidates and the elections on behalf of corporate America.

Q: Quayle, as in ex-Veep Dan. Sadly, he dropped out early on. Spell potatoe, Dan.

R: Registered voters, or (loosely) party members. Bush and Gore's core support.

S: Stump. Remains of a tree (see "A").

T: TV debates. In which candidates spontaneously exchange hurtful barbs from carefully rehearsed scripts.

U: Unimpressed. Condition of most voters, who will abstain next week.

V-W: Vote-winner. A policy everybody can agree with (like bombing Saddam).

X: As in kissing babies.

Y: Yuk!

Z: Zoo. It sure is.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Jerome Burne misses a fundamental point when commenting on the apparent third name-change in as many decades: from 'alternative' to 'complementary' to 'integrative' medicine (Healing In Harmony, February 26). The alternative medicine world itself pushed for the name-change to 'complementary medicine', but both here and in the US, the term 'integrated medicine' comes from the orthodox camp, from those who wish to integrate complementary medicine within a health-care team led by orthodox doctors. This medical dominance is causing some wariness and scepticism among complementary therapists; many see it simply as a form of creeping medical imperialism.
Dr David St George
Senior Lecturer in Clinical Epidemiology
fields.body:
Jerome Burne misses a fundamental point when commenting on the apparent third name-change in as many decades: from 'alternative' to 'complementary' to 'integrative' medicine (Healing In Harmony, February 26). The alternative medicine world itself pushed for the name-change to 'complementary medicine', but both here and in the US, the term 'integrated medicine' comes from the orthodox camp, from those who wish to integrate complementary medicine within a health-care team led by orthodox doctors. This medical dominance is causing some wariness and scepticism among complementary therapists; many see it simply as a form of creeping medical imperialism.
Dr David St George
Senior Lecturer in Clinical Epidemiology

Integration is a seductive theme. However, in the push to produce evidence to underpin complementary medicine (CM), we risk reducing it to the level of a treatment like any other. 'Lavender oil three times a day' on a patient's prescription will not be a sign of successful integration, but of failure.

There is a growing body of evidence to suggest that successful treatment is determined not just by what the practitioner does but by who they are, and the quality of the relationship they have with the patient. Time, patience, trust, understanding, the capacity to listen and, dare I say it, love, appear to be key features in determining the outcome of any treatment. OM or CM? It probably doesn't matter.
Professor Stephen G Wright
St Martin's College, Lancaster

If complementary methods do no harm, let those who have failed to get any help from orthodox methods try them. Arguments are pointless: try it.
Anne Wilks
Whitstable, Kent

People must understand that to compare OM with CM is like comparing astronomy with astrology. What matters is not just whether something appears to work but also the logical and philosophical assumptions that underpin it.
Roger A Fisken
Bedale, North Yorkshire

So, constipated mathematicians nowadays 'work it out with a pencil'. (Tell us a joke, February 26) I seem to remember having to use logs. Maybe we had harder problems.
Dr Quentin L Burrell
Ballabeg, Isle of Man

As a former chair of planning in Barnsley, I would wish for more listing of buildings, not less (The Hold Of The Old, February 19). The criticisms I have relate to the English Heritage contracts. For instance, a row of four John Carr miners' cottages, his first model housing for Earl Fitzwilliam in 1797, are not listed, the reason given that they have two inserted windows. Could it just be that all this is seen as 'regional', 'the lndustrial North'?
W R Norbury
Barnsley

Matthew Fort drove to Blackeath, via Elephant & Castle (Eating Out, February 26). Once there, he and a colleague drank two glasses of champagne, a bottle of a pinot grigio and half a bottle of claret, before driving back. Mmm. All the roads between the Elephant & Castle and Blackheath would be less clogged up and a lot safer if there were not so many over-fed drunks driving around on them.
Martin Guha

fields.bodyText: Jerome Burne misses a fundamental point when commenting on the apparent third name-change in as many decades: from 'alternative' to 'complementary' to 'integrative' medicine (Healing In Harmony, February 26). The alternative medicine world itself pushed for the name-change to 'complementary medicine', but both here and in the US, the term 'integrated medicine' comes from the orthodox camp, from those who wish to integrate complementary medicine within a health-care team led by orthodox doctors. This medical dominance is causing some wariness and scepticism among complementary therapists; many see it simply as a form of creeping medical imperialism. Dr David St George Senior Lecturer in Clinical Epidemiology Integration is a seductive theme. However, in the push to produce evidence to underpin complementary medicine (CM), we risk reducing it to the level of a treatment like any other. 'Lavender oil three times a day' on a patient's prescription will not be a sign of successful integration, but of failure. There is a growing body of evidence to suggest that successful treatment is determined not just by what the practitioner does but by who they are, and the quality of the relationship they have with the patient. Time, patience, trust, understanding, the capacity to listen and, dare I say it, love, appear to be key features in determining the outcome of any treatment. OM or CM? It probably doesn't matter. Professor Stephen G Wright St Martin's College, Lancaster If complementary methods do no harm, let those who have failed to get any help from orthodox methods try them. Arguments are pointless: try it. Anne Wilks Whitstable, Kent People must understand that to compare OM with CM is like comparing astronomy with astrology. What matters is not just whether something appears to work but also the logical and philosophical assumptions that underpin it. Roger A Fisken Bedale, North Yorkshire So, constipated mathematicians nowadays 'work it out with a pencil'. (Tell us a joke, February 26) I seem to remember having to use logs. Maybe we had harder problems. Dr Quentin L Burrell Ballabeg, Isle of Man As a former chair of planning in Barnsley, I would wish for more listing of buildings, not less (The Hold Of The Old, February 19). The criticisms I have relate to the English Heritage contracts. For instance, a row of four John Carr miners' cottages, his first model housing for Earl Fitzwilliam in 1797, are not listed, the reason given that they have two inserted windows. Could it just be that all this is seen as 'regional', 'the lndustrial North'? W R Norbury Barnsley Matthew Fort drove to Blackeath, via Elephant & Castle (Eating Out, February 26). Once there, he and a colleague drank two glasses of champagne, a bottle of a pinot grigio and half a bottle of claret, before driving back. Mmm. All the roads between the Elephant & Castle and Blackheath would be less clogged up and a lot safer if there were not so many over-fed drunks driving around on them.
