fields.headline: Devon sent
fields.standfirst: Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes rescues a vegetarian family stuck in a rut of pasta and jacket spuds. Robin Stummer looks on in awe.
fields.trailText: The challenge
fields.body:
The challenge

A young vegetarian family is too busy to rustle up anything other than quick, uninspired weekday meals. The youngest daughter has leukaemia, so needs an immune system-boosting diet to help stave off bugs. They begged the kitchen doctor to teach them some tasty alternatives to their routine fare . . .

Axminster: 5,600 souls, market on Thursday, voluminous quantities of prime British carpet and, one day last month, a distinguished visitor of the culino-medical variety. As the sun rose on that day, Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, was speeding west from London on another foodie mercy dash. Destination was the home of the Austin family - Julie, Bill and daughters Kez, 11, and Mattie, just two-and-a-bit - in a hamlet a mile out of town.

The Austin household is special in several respects, but most relevant for KD purposes is that Mattie has leukaemia, they don't eat meat or fish, and their lives have become extremely hurried. Steering a course around the food foibles of two kids is a thankless task at the best of times, but add the disciplines imposed by serious illness while keeping to a strictly vegetarian diet, and creative cooking, day in, day out, becomes almost impossible. Or, as Julie phrased it, "Please help. We need fast food for vegetarians. The most common phrase in our house is, 'Oh no, not pasta again!' And jacket potatoes are considered a treat!"

It's 11.30am. Outside Austin Towers, the thrum of a hot engine is followed by the plod of KD feet. Salvation in time for lunch? Maybe. Rosie, ever the expert, offers her professional opinion as to the likelihood of the Austin's experiencing an eating-something-pretty-damned-quick scenario: "Um, we have to do some shopping for food." Ah, yes, food: so often the overlooked element in any meal. KD piles back into the car and, five minutes later, is prodding produce at Millers farm shop.

Soon, she has secured 90% of her requirements: two boxes of the freshest veg, and all at a snip. But the polenta was hiding. Axminster town beckoned. Sadly, the words "shopping" and "Axminster" are coming to mean just one thing: Tesco. New Britain's favourite supermarket recently opened a branch here, one that has been separating the people of Axminster from their pennies with the usual efficiency. It's not exactly Thomas Hardy, and you can't help but wonder what the prospects are for the region's independent traders. Still, at least we found some polenta.

Back at Austin Towers, things begin to happen. Kez sets about chopping four onions and, despite a torrent of tears, presses on, knowing that through her discomfort would come happiness for all. Or something like that. Mattie, wisely, is treating the whole circus with caution, and retires for crisis talks with Postman Pat. "I cook pasta all the time," confesses Julie once more as the cheese pancakes take shape, "but everyone complains."

"You cook it too much!" interjects Kez earnestly, making sure the point is not lost. It isn't. With unashamed glee, the KD, now finding her pace and possessed of a devilish grin, produces her collection of big, sharp knives. It's time to get serious.

An hour later, there's a rich mix of smells wafting around the house: a hint of coriander, a touch of honey and sesame seed. On the table, a tray of polenta lies prone; in the oven, foil parcels of veg hiss gently to themselves, and a nut bake bakes. The febrile goings-on lure Mattie back for a look, just in time for the highlight of the day. From somewhere, a pastry cutter in the form of Po Teletubby is produced; two or three times it is pressed into the polenta, each time with a primitive murmur of approval from the slavering onlookers. Finally, the small Po figures are placed in a frying pan and left to their fate, monitored by Mattie with such nonchalance that you wonder if ritualistic Po-frying is a regular feature of life in this part of Devon. And that, more or less, was where KD called it a day. But how did it taste? Smiles all round is how it tasted.

All recipes serve four.

Recipes consist of five basics (polenta; couscous; cottage-cheese pancakes; nut bake) and various complementary dishes. Mix and match, depending on what you feel like on the day.

Polenta

Buy quick-cook polenta and follow the instructions: it's usually about 500g polenta to 1.5l salted water (the salt is important, otherwise it is very bland). Bring the water to the boil, add a large knob of butter or good glug of olive oil, then pour in the polenta steadily, stirring all the while. Now add some cheese: either Parmesan or, for a punchier flavour, blue cheese or soft goat's cheese. Stir until the polenta is stiff and starts to leave the sides of the pan; usually four to five minutes. Pour on to a lined baking sheet and leave to cool for 30 minutes. To finish, cut the cold polenta into circles or triangles, place in a hot, oiled frying pan or under the grill, and cook until golden on both sides.

Couscous

Bring 250ml stock or water to the boil, pour into a bowl containing 250ml by volume couscous, stir, cover and leave for 10 minutes, so the grain can absorb the liquid. Flavour the stock with chillies, herbs or spices; alternatively, when the couscous has puffed up a bit, dress with olive oil, lemon juice and herbs. Serve warm or cold (you can make it in advance, and reheat gently). Stir in some nuts or olives as well, if you fancy.

Cottage cheese pancakes

55g self-raising flour

Salt and black pepper

25g softened butter

110g cottage cheese

2 large eggs, lightly beaten

2-3 tbsp milk

Season the flour, tip it into a blender and add the butter and cheese. Whizz for a couple of minutes, then pour in the eggs and milk, to slacken the batter. Leave to rest for 10 minutes, then cook in a hot, lightly oiled frying pan just as you would normal pancakes.

Nut bake

The dull name belies a very tasty dish - a far cry from bland nut roast of yore.

25g butter (or 2 tbsp olive oil)

1 onion, chopped

225g mixed nuts, chopped (I use mostly pinenuts, and a mixture of cashews and ground hazelnuts)

100g white breadcrumbs

2 large eggs

4 tbsp milk

For the stuffing

175g soft brown breadcrumbs

6 tbsp olive oil (or 75g butter)

lemon, juiced and zested

4 tbsp chopped mixed fresh herbs (sage, parsley, thyme, rosemary, perhaps even a little watercress)

To finish

50g butter

25g finely ground mixed nuts

25g soft brown breadcrumbs

Preheat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. In a frying pan, sweat the onion in butter until soft. Tip into a bowl, leave to cool for a minute or two, then add the nuts, breadcrumbs, eggs and milk.

In a separate bowl, mix together the stuffing ingredients. Butter a baking tin, and dust with the ground nuts and breadcrumbs. Spread half the nut mix in the base of the tin, spread with stuffing, then cover with the remaining nut mixture. Cover with foil and bake for 30 minutes. Serve hot or warm.

Cannellini beans with leek, celeriac and mustard

2 tbsp olive oil or 25g butter

3 leeks, washed and cut into rings

1 celeriac, peeled and cut in chunks

Vegetable stock (or water)

1 tin cannellini beans, drained

3 tbsp grain mustard

2 tbsp crème frache (optional)

2 tbsp chives, chopped fine

Heat the butter or oil in a frying pan, add the leeks and celeriac, and sauté gently for a couple of minutes. Pour in enough stock or water to cover, season and simmer until the vegetables are almost tender. Add the beans and mustard, and continue simmering for five minutes longer (add more stock if necessary).

Remove a quarter of the mixture and whizz it up in a blender until smooth. Add the crème frache to the purée, then stir back into the pan. Add the chives, and serve with any of the basics - it goes especially well with the nut bake and pancakes.

Spanish-style chickpea and pumpkin casserole

150g pumpkin, peeled and diced

3 pears, peeled, cored and diced

400g tinned chickpeas, drained

250g green beans, topped and tailed

100ml olive oil

1 white onion, peeled and chopped

1 tsp paprika

150ml chopped tinned tomato

1 small slice white bread, diced

2 clove garlic, peeled and crushed

10 almonds toasted

2 tbsp hot vegetable stock

2 tbsp sherry vinegar

Fill a pan with water to cover the first four ingredients, bring to the boil and drop in the pumpkin. Bring back to the boil, simmer for five minutes, add the pears, return to the boil again, then add the chickpeas. Simmer for 25 minutes. Add the beans and simmer until tender.

Meanwhile, heat 50ml olive oil in a pan and fry the onion until golden. Add the paprika and tomato, and cook until the liquid is reduced by half. Heat the rest of the oil in another pan, fry the bread and garlic until golden, then tip into a blender, add the almonds and whizz to a paste. Slowly add the stock and vinegar to the paste. Tip the tomato mix into the vegetable pot, then stir in the garlic-and-nut paste to thicken the sauce.

Vegetable bourride

Only buy asparagus and Jerusalem artichoke when in season - what's on offer at other times is very second-rate.

750ml vegetable stock

1 cauliflower, broken into florets

1 head broccoli, broken into spears

250g new potatoes, scrubbed and cut into quarters

4 Jerusalem artichokes, peeled and sliced

2 courgettes, cut in half and sliced

1 bunch of asparagus, peeled

2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed

100g mayonnaise

Chives and parsley, chopped fine

In a big pot, bring the stock to the boil, season, then blanch the vegetables one by one until cooked. Remove with a slotted spoon, drain, and keep warm in a low oven. Whizz the garlic and mayonnaise in a blender, then, once all the vegetables are cooked, add 300ml of the stock and blend again. Place the veg on a platter, pour over the garlicky sauce and sprinkle with the herbs.

Mushroom, spinach and pinenuts

2 cloves garlic, peeled and grated

3 shallots, peeled and chopped fine

225g mixed mushrooms, cleaned and chopped into good-sized pieces

500g baby spinach (or frozen)

85g pinenuts, gently toasted

2 tbsp olive oil

Heat half the oil in a pan, and gently sauté the garlic, shallots and mushrooms. When they are soft, add the spinach and let it wilt. Season, then add the nuts and the remaining olive oil. Serve with any of the basics.

Root vegetables en papillote

50g butter

12 cloves garlic, still in their skins

A selection of: shallots, peeled but kept whole; carrots, parsnips, new potatoes, turnips, swede, sweet potato, peeled and chopped into even-sized pieces

Zest and juice of 1 lemon

2 tbsp brandy (optional)

125ml vegetable stock (water)

1 tbsp honey

100-150g cooked chestnuts, chopped (optional)

Fresh rosemary or thyme

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/ gas mark 6. Cut four squares of tinfoil, and lift each one in the corners to form a sort of container. Sauté the garlic, shallots and carrots in half the butter until lightly browned. Add the remaining vegetables, season and sauté for a few minutes longer. Divide the fried vegetables between the tinfoil parcels.

Put the rest of the butter in the pan, add the lemon juice and zest, brandy, stock and honey, bring to the boil, and simmer until reduced. Spoon a little into each package, add the chestnuts and a sprig or two of rosemary or thyme.

Pull the edges of the foil together and fold over to seal. Place on a baking tray, and bake for 20 minutes, until the vegetables are tender. Serve straight from the packages, or turn out on to plates.

Simple tomato sauce

3 cloves garlic

3 sticks celery

3 carrots

2 onions

2 tbsp olive oil

14oz chopped tin tomatoes

1 bouquet garni

Crush the garlic, chop the vegetables quite fine and sauté in the oil. Sweat until soft, add the tomatoes and the bouquet garni, bring to a boil, season and simmer for 30 minutes. Serve with the polenta, nut bake or pancakes.

Variations

Provençal vegetable sauce

Cook as above, except sweat some chopped courgette, aubergine and red pepper with the other vegetables, and deglaze the pan with a little wine vinegar before adding the tomatoes. Before serving, add basil and black olives.

Spicy tomato sauce

Cook as above, except add some fresh, finely chopped chilli and ginger to the vegetables, and deglaze the pan with wine vinegar before continuing

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Time was when The Red House was a no-go area for Matthew Fort. Not any more
fields.trailText: Time was when The Red House was a no-go area for Matthew Fort. Not any more
fields.body:
It used to be a bit of a place of pilgrimage, did The Red House. You'll find it at Marsh Benham, just beyond Newbury, tucked away on a lane that leads down to an eloquent and sylvan stretch of the River Kennet, where I used to try to catch trout. It was a place of many spectacular humi-liations, not the least of which happened when I went fishing there with Raymond Blanc.

The idea was that my brother, the Heron and I would provide the suave charmer of the restaurant range with a bit of bank space in return for a spot of lunch. We were to be joined by another friend, who would be bringing with him a Very Important Person Indeed, which is where the lines of communication got really rather confused and led to tears.

Our friend (not RB or the VIPI, but the other fellow - I'll call him Carstairs) was under the impression that RB would also provide lunch for him and the VIPI. The only trouble was that, by the time they got to the riverbank, we had eaten all the lunch. I forget now whether this was because it was so delicious or because RB's sense of riverbank portion control verged on the monastic. The memory of Carstairs' look of uncomprehending disbelief slowly giving way to incoherent rage makes me laugh out loud even now. To this day, he speaks of the episode with undiminished bitterness.

That is all water through the sluice gate, and you may well ask why we didn't all just pop along to The Red House for a pint and something wholesome. Well, the truth of it is that at the time, you would have preferred on the whole to go hungry than eat there. The fact that Carstairs and the VIPI did indeed go hungry rather proves my point. However, word came down river from Marjoribanks that The Red House had changed, been bought, done up, built a proper kitchen, hired a decent chef and generally got its act together. Come on down, he said, and see f or yourself. So I did.

Money has indeed been spent on The Red House. In reality, it is no longer really a pub at all. Oh, it serves beer - and cares for it properly, too - and there's a bar and everything, but you can tell from the pale, polished floor, the upmarket chairs and tables, the French accents of some of the waiting staff, the pricing and the brand spanking new light'n'airy dining room lined with books at the back that, in its heart of hearts, The Red House now believes that it is a restaurant. There's nothing wrong with that, so long as the food justifies the ambition.

The chef in charge of the kitchen is Rupert Rowley, a graduate of L'Ortolan and the John Burton-Race school of culinary excellence, and his menu is an interesting compilation. There's a bit of Italy, with a risotto of wild mushrooms and a tomato-and-mozzarella tart with balsamic vinegar dressing, and even a bit of Asia, what with a selection of fresh fish and mussels simmered in a Thai-style broth, but for the most part the dishes are irredeemably French, which, after a couple of weeks of Eurofusion food is a bit of a relief.

So it was a saucisse de morteau with warm new potato and parsley salad, followed by grilled wood pigeon breast on a fondant potato with chive sauce for me; and, for Marjoribanks, ham and foie gras terrine with piccalilli and toast, followed by oxtail braised in red wine and stuffed with mushroom mousse, with mash and roast root veg. It was something of a masculine affair, I'll grant you, but Rowley has his lighter side, too. We just chose to ignore it. Anyway, on paper, this looked like a pretty decent line of hale and hearty cuisine bourgeoise.

So it was, in a way. The food - all of it - was exceptionally well-cooked. The potato salad resisted gently to the tooth, and the sausage was a delicate, high-born thing. The dressing had been lightened with chicken stock to make it well-rounded and mild-mannered. The pigeon had body and texture, without being tough and indigestible. There were lots of unadvertised carrot slices, sweet and glistening with butter, and the chive sauce was emulsified to a refreshing lightness.

Marjoribanks complained that his terrine didn't have enough foie gras in it (at £7 for a healthy slab, what did he expect?), but he had nothing but praise for the succulence of the ham or the sharpness of the piccalilli. And his oxtail very nearly brought him to a complete standstill. It was a thing like Ayers Rock, the oxtail circling a fine mousse, with loads of wine-dark gravy and cup-winning mash.

Only in the oxtail were form and function united in a mighty whole.

Nor would it make the bill of £71.55 any less acceptable. If only I could have slipped away afterwards for an hour or two on the riverbank.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Salt of the earth
fields.trailText: Salt of the earth
fields.body:
The subject

NaCl, mostly. One of the four basic tastes. Formerly, it was a luxury ('salary' = money to buy salt); now, it's dirt-cheap, unless self-consciously expensive. Essential ingredient in food. Essential ingredient in food snobbery.

The basics

Rock salt comes from underground mineral deposits left by prehistoric seas. Just add water, extract, evaporate, purify. Sea salt is - duh! - sea water pumped into shallow pans and evaporated. On the whole, sea salt is less refined than rock. But both varieties may be mixed with an anti-caking agent (for better pouring) and iodine (for nutritional gains).

The details

Or should I say, 'the debates'. Many people of good judgment believe that sea salt is the only salt that's worth its salt. Their argument: trace elements from the briny deep confer flavour and health benefits that refined rock salt lacks. Their internal debates: is salt from Guérande better than that from Noirmoutier, and is Sicily or Portugal the salt world's next star? Is fleur de sel - the pearly-white stuff from the top of the evaporation pan - better than damp, grey sel gris , which contains more trace elements? Meanwhile, on the other side of the debate, consider this: in every blind tasting I've heard of, expert panels preferred food that was seasoned with plain table salt (the same goes for those that I have conducted personally). Tasted on its own, sure, the fancy, high-priced versions (especially Ravidà, 020-8740 1335) win out, but ask yourself one question: do I eat salt neat? NB Low-sodium salt substitutes are revolting. NB again The one must- have salt - in addition to industrial table salt, of course - is Maldon Sea Salt. Lovely, pyramidal crystals (a result of evaporation by simmering), and crunch as well as taste.

Where to buy

Most supermarkets sell sea salt and the marvellous Maldon. For exclusive brands with impeccable eco-credentials, try health-food shops and fancy grocers.

The easy way out

Huh?

fields.headline: Garden
fields.standfirst: Your buttercups may be running over but, for Christopher Lloyd, that's one of spring's delights
fields.trailText: Your buttercups may be running over but, for Christopher Lloyd, that's one of spring's delights
fields.body:
Everybody loves buttercups - except farmers. Forget about them for the moment. Buttercups come in a great surge of the most brilliant yellow, from late March on. Where drainage is poor and the ground heavy, there'll seem to be nothing but buttercups on poor farmland. As a child, I loved to walk - better still, to shuffle -through them, getting my shoes covered with their pollen, which is as bright as the flower, though the flower itself is beautifully lacquered with a high-polish, light-reflecting gloss. So, if you hold a buttercup to your skin, the light it sheds will make your skin a glorious shade of yellow.

Buttercups, like the whole ranunculus family to which they belong, are poisonous. Cattle and sheep avoid them, but they form an unwelcome component of hay. You are supposed to be a bad farmer if you own fields of buttercups, but these become increasingly rare where the plough is repeatedly making its rounds and disturbing the ground.

There are four principal species in my garden, and I didn't have to invite them. First on the scene is goldilocks, Ranunculus auricomus , which I shall expect to see any moment now. It has markedly cupped, quite small but richly-coloured flowers and makes colonies, mixing happily with mauve lady's smock, Cardamine pratensis and wood anemones, Anemone nemorosa .

Next, mid-April, R. bulbosus , which you can easily recognise because its green sepals, instead of lying in the same plane as the petals, are turned back and clasp the stem. It will be out with the first carmine flower heads of red clover, and they make an exciting contrast in a setting of young spring grass.

Then, R. acris , which is probably the most versatile of the buttercups. Fairly tall, at 0.6m, it has a widely branching habit, flowering May-June. This has a neat, double-flowered form, 'Flore Pleno'. The pale citrinus makes a change from the usual, somewhat penetrating buttercup yellow. 'Stevenii' (1.5m) is quite a giant, semi-double and showy. It is not hard to control as a border perennial, and in its season can be effectively contrasted with a blood-red oriental poppy such as Papaver orientale 'Goliath', (which is not the same as 'Beauty Of Livermere').

Last, a tiresome weed, the creeping buttercup, R. repens , which runs like blazes through your lawns and borders and is especially at home in wet soil. But that has a charming double-flowered variety, pleniflorus , which will make a low ground-covering carpet. If you like "weeds" in your lawn and don't mow every week, you could establish it there, first making sure it wouldn't be competing with the single-flowered type-plant.

There are other good, hardy buttercups. R. constantinopolitanus 'Plenus' flowers in April and makes large, very double rosettes, yellow shading to green at the centre. It needs well-fed border fare and is rather subject to the attentions of vine weevil, but otherwise easy. This is a striking plant. R. gramineus takes us into the lance-leaved kinds of buttercup, glaucous in this case and a good background to 0.3m-high flowers. The roots are tuberous and can be divided. This is spring-flowering and nice with anything blue, such as Omphalodes cappado cica 'Cherry Ingram'. The lesser spearwort, R. flammula , grows in shallow water or close by, and makes a cloud of quite small buttercup flowers that you should try to get near to the water forget-me-not, Myosotis scorpioides , which is early summer flowering, blue with a yellow eye. The great spearwort, R. lingua , usually grown in its largest, showiest form 'Grandiflorus' (1.2m), makes a big splash in fairly shallow water for a long summer season, but its colonial activities will need curtailing fairly frequently if it has a free root run.

Quite different, though an out-and-out aquatic, is the water crowfoot, R. aquatilis , which is an underwater oxygenator, with thread-fine foliage, but rises to the surface with floating, rounded leaves, there making, if you have a good strain, a delightful display of white flowers.

The popular celandines are all derivatives of R. ficaria , which has the same sort of lacquered yellow flowers as buttercups, but shiny, shovel-shaped leaves. All their flowers arise unbranched from ground level on a lowish plant. It mutates readily and there are ever so many named varieties. The roots are clustered little tubers, easily breaking off, so this species can be a difficult weed to manage under mixed border conditions. Spot treatment with Roundup may be the answer.

The flowers open only in sunshine and warmth, though the double kinds are always expanded. R. ficaria flore-pleno has tight, green-centred rosettes, and is a charmer in lawn turf, if you will allow that. One saving grace (if you look at it that way) in celandines is that they disappear completely from sight at the end of spring.

I must fit in R. aconitifolius in its neatly double-flowered form, 'Flore Pleno' (0.35m). In spring, its dark, jagged leaves are a background for a branching inflorescence of pure white, neatly doubled little rosettes. Give it moisture and it will be no trouble, but the further north you go, the happier it is

 Christopher Lloyd's Gardening Year is published by Frances Lincoln, priced £25. To order a copy at the special price of £22, plus 99p UK p&p, freephone CultureShop on 0800 3166102.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: If only I'd invested £1,000 in deadcool.com, I'd now be a multi-millionaire
fields.trailText: If only I'd invested £1,000 in deadcool.com, I'd now be a multi-millionaire
fields.body:
Great-Aunt Elspeth has a date. She is going to Slimbridge Wildfowl Trust with her beau, Alec. He is a small and whiskery widower. He looks a bit like Bill Oddie with a puncture. "He's got a wonderrrful pairrr of binocularrrs, dearrr! " confides the aunt in excitement.

The rest of us are celibate and broke. Henry has been dumped by Holly. I never liked her. Too prickly. She three-timed him with his mates Chazza and Jezza. Now his heart is broken and also his spine. He lies in bed all day at weekends and shows no sign of A-level hysteria. All over the country young people are hitting the books. Henry is hitting the sack.

"Say something to him!" I hiss to ex-Spouse. "Give him some help and encouragement!" Ex-Spouse looks up languidly from his newspaper and frowns as if I have uttered an obscenity.

"We are emotionally dysfunctional males," he reminds me. "For me to offer help or encouragement would be the greatest cruelty."

"Well take him to a football match or something!"

Ex-Spouse sighs at this apparent faux pas. "We are beyond football," he informs me wearily.

Harriet appears, clutching a book. "I'm reading Persuasion!" she cries. "It's wonderful! I want to go to Lyme Regis!" It seems the males of the family are set in emotional concrete, whilst the females are springing gracefully from delight to delight. Except me, of course. Because at the back of my mind is the corrosive knowledge of financial ruin, fast approaching like a train. An Italian or French train, obviously. Unless one of us finds gainful employment something embarrassing and public is going to happen. If only I had invested £1,000 in deadcool.com eight months ago, I would now be a multi-millionaire. If only I'd selected six right numbers in the Lottery last week instead of five wrong ones! What was I thinking of? The moment the numbers were announced it was obvious they were the ones it was going to be. But away with these dreams of instant riches! I am educated, am I not? I am not yet of pensionable age. My children no longer need constant care, being at the age of Persuasion and Prostration. What I need is a job. Seize and peruse local paper.

"Have you a kind and caring nature?" Sod that! That's what got me into this mess in the first place. "Join our small team of airbrush painters producing high-quality ornamental animals." Have already produced an ornamental animal - ie, Henry - and consider one is enough. "Assembly Engineer to build, install and service CMMs." Reading job ads always leaves me with a melancholy conviction that I understand absolutely nothing of the modern world. CMMs, for instance. What happened to words for God's sake? "Funeral Director Requires Book-Keeper." Ah! Tempted.

Though I think I could mess up even that. There I'd be, installed at my gleaming workstation at the pearly gates, and there's St Peter getting his beard in a twist, "Where's the book? Where's the blinking book? You stupid woman!" I'm getting one of my hot flushes, ransacking the drawers. "I've seen it somewhere, sorry, give me a minute, have a cup of tea or something." I would try the patience of a saint.

"Mum? I've finished Persuasion and I'm reading Emma now! What's a valetudinarian?"

"Someone who's always miserable and anxious and imagining that they're ill."

"Oh, what, you mean like Daddy?" Harriet encouraged by the news that there is somebody in the book called Harriet, even though she is a little bit thick.

Great-Aunt Elspeth returns, not quite as radiant as I anticipated. "Alec insisted on telling me all about his wife's operrrations by the flamingoes," she complains. "It was quite trrrraumatic , dearr ." Offer tea and sympathy.

The best moment today was talking to Harriet about Jane Austen. Yes! That's it! I shall turn the house into a Coaching Inn! Draft advert to put in local paper. There must be lots of anxious parents hereabouts whose offspring are approaching exams. I just hope Joseph Conrad's not on the syllabus. Not enough bitchy tea-parties.

fields.standfirst: Peter Brammer used to work as a welder in a steelworks. Now, he has turned his blowtorch to more domestic matters. By Chris Arnot

fields.body:
Peter Brammer pulls up just inside the gateway of his favourite Sheffield scrapyard and reaches for the cigarettes on the dashboard of his Land-Rover Discovery. "That's it," he says, gazing through the windscreen. Not a pretty sight, as you might imagine. Even in a city whose steely traditions have ensured that scrapyards are plentiful, this one is bigger and uglier than most.

The predominant colours are brown. Brown mud. Brown rust. Mountains of rusting metal are occasionally swooped over by pecking cranes. Brammer can sometimes be found browsing around the lower slopes, seeking out the unlikely raw materials of his trade. He has the vision and the know-how to transform something ugly and no longer functional into stylish, sometimes stunning, pieces of furniture that find their way into smart galleries and the homes of people whose experience of scrapyards is even more limited than mine.

His home is a mile or so across town, at the end of a terrace near Sheffield Wednesday's ground. The house was in a sorry state when he bought it with his partner, Tammy Whitaker, but they liked the irregular shape of the rooms and the potential of the loft space. After much back-breaking work, he now has a room at the top where he can relax with his guitar or his computer, develop new ideas and show off his work. "It's the kind of stuff you either love or hate," he says. "There's no in-between." Black and white, then, like the impression given by this attic. The first thing you notice are the black banisters: not straight, but curved, as if sagging in the middle because the spidery web of steel beneath is too delicate to support them. This is an illusion, of course. Like his free-standing furniture, the rails are industrial strength, expertly welded and, as their creator puts it, "likely to last until the next millennium".

The next thing that strikes you is a swing chair in elegantly curved black steel, dangling from a black hook screwed into an exposed beam on a sloping, white ceiling. It looks excruciatingly uncomfortable, but turns out to be quite bearable when you're tucked up inside, knees curled under your chin, feeling like a giant bird in an open cage. "My chairs are not designed to sleep in," Brammer concedes. "If you want comfort, buy a Shackleton's high-backed armchair." This swing chair was made during "dinner breaks" while he was still working as a welder in a steelworks. "I nearly got the sack for it, although I was only using scrap metal from the skip. They don't like you doing your own thing. I should have been in the 'snap cabin' listening to the lads going on about football and how many women they had last night."

And what did the lads think of his efforts? "Individually, they were quite interested, but collectively they'd take the piss. Somebody asked me what I was going to do with this chair. When I told them I was going to hang it off a beam at home, they thought I was mad."

Just over a year ago, he took voluntary redundancy and invested the £2,500, plus a grant from the Prince's Trust, in his own company, Aesthenia. At the age of 30, his destiny is now in his own hands, metaphorically and literally.

Being good with his hands was always going to be useful for someone who left school at 16 with a City & Guilds certificate in maths. Nothing else. Not even an O-level in metalwork. "I didn't like the place, and I couldn't wait to get out."

Less predictable was the gradual emergence of a creative side to his character. Two factors brought it out. The first was when, at 18, he was badly injured in a car accident and spent three years in hospital. "I was bored senseless, so I started drawing," he recalls, gesturing at some of the mesmerising, geometric shapes on the walls of his attic.

"I also started to question what I was doing with my life." Which meant that he was open to the possibility of change when he finally emerged into the real world again and met Tammy at a nightclub. She helped open his eyes to a world he had never even dreamed of. They went to galleries together. They went travelling together.

"Last year, there were five of us in an Escort 1300 and we did nine countries in three weeks," he recalls, happily. This summer, they're off to Barcelona, where he intends to feast his eyes on Antonio Gaudí's stunning cathedral, Sagrada Familia. "Some people reckoned they saw Gaudí's influences in my work," he says. "Charles Rennie Mackintosh as well. But at the time I'd never heard of either of them. I have now."

Certainly, there's something Mackintosh about the elegant, slim, tall chair that graces a corner of the attic, next to the steely tendrils of an even taller candelabra. But it seems unlikely that the great exponent of Art Nouveau would have designed a chair cut from a grid of machine-tool parts. The rusting remains of the grid languish on what Brammer calls his "mini-scrapheap", behind his workshop in Rotherham. There with it are other unlikely raw materials, including radiators, exhausts, metal fuseboxes and the sort of gate used to stop toddlers plunging down stairs.

This is the second workshop to come his way via the local authority's enterprise scheme. The first burnt down within a week of him moving in, the result of an accident involving a blowtorch and contractors working on the roof. Never one to waste an opportunity, he recycled the molten steel floor and transformed it into a 15-stone dragon's head, which attracted some much-needed publicity on regional television when it was shown at an exhibition in Leeds.

An artist, then, as well as a designer? Brammer is not entirely happy with either tag. He's acutely conscious of his lack of a fine-art background and has a fear of sounding pretentious. "Some people in the art world seem more interested in talking about it than doing it," he mutters. "And some galleries seem more interested in what your name is and where you come from than what you have to offer. Somebody asked me if one of my pieces had a name. I said, 'Yes, it's a chair.' 'Anything else to say about it?' 'No.'"

Lizzie Roberts, of the Atelier 18 Gallery in Nottingham, has long since given up trying to coax an artist's statement out of Brammer. "But if I put one of his pieces in the window, I know it will attract passers-by," she says. "We're as far from the sea as it's possible to be in this country, but I've just sold one of his chairs for £400 to a prosperous-looking chap who wanted to put it next to the wheel on his boat."

An unlikely spot to find a piece of steel with style that might easily have been condemned to a last rusting place in a Sheffield scrapyard

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck makes everything all-white
fields.body:
Having indulged in an orgy of red wines lately, not only on the grounds of the increasing popularity of the colour but also because reds rate higher than white overall, I thought it was high time I put together a purely all-white column. Several difficulties lay in my way when this mildly unfashionable notion first occurred: first, a good white wine always costs a deal more than a good red (because, old rieslings and certain chardonnays apart, complexity is easier to achieve in red grapes, as the skins play a greater part in their manufacture); second, outstanding whites don't come cheap; third, certain of these wines can hardly be characterised as superplonks.

An example of this last is Wine Rack's and Bottom's Up's Zind-Humbrecht Riesling Wintzenheim 1997, an Alsatian of consummate finesse and subtlety, yet one that costs, not unreasonably, £9.99. It is a beautiful construct from nose to throat: refined, elegant, gracious. A class, 17-point act, it's a superlative bargain. So, maybe it is a superplonk, after all.

In somewhat wider distribution by Thresher, which runs the two above chains (under the umbrella of 1st Quench, which includes Victoria Wine), are Pewsey Vale Riesling 1997 (16 points, £5.99) and Thomas Mitchell Marsanne 1996 (16 points, £5.99), from Australia. With the riesling, the satin texture is one thing, the nigh-classic mineralised aroma another (something no European riesling acquires so young), and the finish yet another. That is a significant part of what complexity in a wine means. If you were to cellar it for five years, who knows if 19 points, or even perfection, won't emerge? The marsanne, a grape of hearty disposition and southern French provenance, in Aussie hands results in coagulated fruit of substance, depth and staying power that is ideal with Thai fishcakes, scallops, squid etc.

Altogether spicier, and perhaps more exotic, is a Cape wine at superstore branches of the CWS: Fairview Chardonnay 1998 (16.5 points, £5.99) carries hints of wood-smoke, oak, yoghurt and fresh, under-ripe melon. It is a modern classic; a chardonnay that wears a rich, beautifully textured coat of substantial yet not indelicate fruit. Rieslings apart (the Zind-Humbrecht is one such), it is rare for this columnist to consider a bottle of white wine capable of being a thrilling companion for the whole duration of a book-read, but this is one.

Marks & Spencer's Sierra Los Andes Gewürztraminer 1999 (16 points, £5.50), from Chile, is not something I could imagine performing a similar feat because it is more suited to food than mood. With its rich, rose-petal perfume, well- controlled, rosy/melon/raspberry fruit, and an excellent finish of style and weight, this is something of a worry for Alsace. At the price, which is the same as a co-operative-made, own-label supermarket Gewürztraminer, it is a more daring wine, and more able to age and develop surprising sides to its nature.

Majestic has one of the most delicious pinot grigio's I've tasted: Pinot Grigio Alois Lageder 1998 (16 points, £8.49). Takes some thinking about that price, but then so does the wine, since it offers an astonishing level of nutty, peachy, thought-provoking fruit. Beautifully supple and textured, it suits a wide variety of fish dishes, but is also an interesting, different aperitif. It is made by a craftsman, and it performs like something finely crafted. Majestic's Capel Vale Riesling 1998 (16 points, £7.49), from Australia, is wilder, offering as it does a busy style of riesling that has lingering echoes of spicy gooseberries and pears.

Two excellent Somerfield whites are Domaine du Bois Viognier Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (16 points, £4.99) and Domaine d' Arain Muscat de Frontignan (16 points, £3.99 in a 50cl bottle). The viognier, a modish grape nowadays, has simply terrific apricot fruit, which is dry and elegant. The muscat offers wonderful, honeyed, strawberry-and-peach-edged sweetness, making it perfect with pastries and even ice creams. Or pour it over a friendly naked sybarite and lick it off.

 Superplonk 2000 and Streetplonk 2000 are both published by Hodder at £5.99 each. To order copies at the special price of £4.99 per book, plus 99p UK p&p, freephone CultureShop on 0800 3166102.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: My mother called. 'I'll be in London with the girls. I need a break before the Big Day.' She wanted me to organise her hen night - again. I found www.partyexpress.co.uk: 'heart of London's West End', 'three-course meal served by muscle-bound waiters', 'a cocktail of non-stop comedy, dancing and, last but not least, a male erotic dancer for your finale!' Sounded right. I also explored www.superactive.co.uk, among others.
fields.body:
My mother called. 'I'll be in London with the girls. I need a break before the Big Day.' She wanted me to organise her hen night - again. I found www.partyexpress.co.uk: 'heart of London's West End', 'three-course meal served by muscle-bound waiters', 'a cocktail of non-stop comedy, dancing and, last but not least, a male erotic dancer for your finale!' Sounded right. I also explored www.superactive.co.uk, among others.

I went home after the office, followed the Mayo Clinic stretching routine (www.mayohealth.org) and then worked my thighs really hard (my personal trainer is away with his lover). I arrived at the restaurant just after 11pm; the worst should be over by now, I thought. How wrong can you be? As soon as I walked in, I bumped into Sir Kevin, one of the non-execs, who was with Meg from human resources. You can't jump to conclusions but, if dinner was above board and on expenses, they wouldn't have been in a restaurant with Escalope Valdostana on the menu. It had to be illicit - and he pretended not to see me.

Just as well: Mum and her friends were being watched by everyone else, and the erotic dancer was thrusting his leather-packaged goodies to the tune of La Vida Loca. Pouting as if she were Joan Collins, Mum slipped an amaretto in her mouth - and then she went purple. She was doing a Gemma Bovary on me!

Pandemonium followed. Someone shouted for a doctor. Sir K and Meg ran away. Quick as a flash, I pulled out my laptop and my mobile, and connected to www.paramedicine.com, which explains the Heimlich Manoeuvre. Fists, hard pressure, hey presto: Mum spat out the amaretto. It was all over as quickly as it had began. She and her friends were gone, but the erotic dancer was still there. I asked him if he wanted a lift.

fields.headline: Squeezed to death
fields.standfirst: Half a million children have died in Iraq since UN sanctions were imposed - most enthusiastically by Britain and the US. Three UN officials have resigned in despair. Meanwhile, bombing of Iraq continues almost daily. John Pilger investigates
fields.trailText: Half a million children have died in Iraq since UN sanctions were imposed - most enthusiastically by Britain and the US. Three UN officials have resigned in despair. Meanwhile, bombing of Iraq continues almost daily. John Pilger investigates
fields.body:
Wherever you go in Iraq's southern city of Basra, there is dust. It gets in your eyes and nose and throat. It swirls in school playgrounds and consumes children kicking a plastic ball. "It carries death," said Dr Jawad Al-Ali, a cancer specialist and member of Britain's Royal College of Physicians. "Our own studies indicate that more than 40 per cent of the population in this area will get cancer: in five years' time to begin with, then long afterwards. Most of my own family now have cancer, and we have no history of the disease. It has spread to the medical staff of this hospital. We don't know the precise source of the contamination, because we are not allowed to get the equipment to conduct a proper scientific survey, or even to test the excess level of radiation in our bodies. We suspect depleted uranium, which was used by the Americans and British in the Gulf War right across the southern battlefields."

Under economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations Security Council almost 10 years ago, Iraq is denied equipment and expertise to clean up its contaminated battle-fields, as Kuwait was cleaned up. At the same time, the Sanctions Committee in New York, dominated by the Americans and British, has blocked or delayed a range of vital equipment, chemotherapy drugs and even pain-killers. "For us doctors," said Dr Al-Ali, "it is like torture. We see children die from the kind of cancers from which, given the right treatment, there is a good recovery rate." Three children died while I was there.

Six other children died not far away on January 25, last year. An American missile hit Al Jumohria, a street in a poor residential area. Sixty-three people were injured, a number of them badly burned. "Collateral damage," said the Department of Defence in Washington. Britain and the United States are still bombing Iraq almost every day: it is the longest Anglo-American bombing campaign since the second world war, yet, with honourable exceptions, very little appears about it in the British media. Conducted under the cover of "no fly zones", which have no basis in international law, the aircraft, according to Tony Blair, are "performing vital humanitarian tasks". The ministry of defence in London has a line about "taking robust action to protect pilots" from Iraqi attacks - yet an internal UN Security Sector report says that, in one five-month period, 41 per cent of the victims were civilians in civilian targets: villages, fishing jetties, farmland and vast, treeless valleys where sheep graze. A shepherd, his father, his four children and his sheep were killed by a British or American aircraft, which made two passes at them. I stood in the cemetery where the children are buried and their mother shouted, "I want to speak to the pilot who did this."

This is a war against the children of Iraq on two fronts: bombing, which in the last year cost the British taxpayer £60 million. And the most ruthless embargo in modern history. According to Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, the death rate of children under five is more than 4,000 a month - that is 4,000 more than would have died before sanctions. That is half a million children dead in eight years. If this statistic is difficult to grasp, consider, on the day you read this, up to 200 Iraqi children may die needlessly. "Even if not all the suffering in Iraq can be imputed to external factors," says Unicef, "the Iraqi people would not be undergoing such deprivation in the absence of the prolonged measures imposed by the Security Council and the effects of war."

Through the glass doors of the Unicef offices in Baghdad, you can read the following mission statement: "Above all, survival, hope, development, respect, dignity, equality and justice for women and children." A black sense of irony will be useful if you are a young Iraqi. As it is, the children hawking in the street outside, with their pencil limbs and eyes too big for their long thin faces, cannot read English, and perhaps cannot read at all.

"The change in 10 years is unparalleled, in my experience," Anupama Rao Singh, Unicef's senior representative in Iraq, told me. "In 1989, the literacy rate was 95%; and 93% of the population had free access to modern health facilities. Parents were fined for failing to send their children to school. The phenomenon of street children or children begging was unheard of. Iraq had reached a stage where the basic indicators we use to measure the overall well-being of human beings, including children, were some of the best in the world. Now it is among the bottom 20%. In 10 years, child mortality has gone from one of the lowest in the world, to the highest."

Anupama Rao Singh, originally a teacher in India, has spent most of her working life with Unicef. Helping children is her vocation, but now, in charge of a humanitarian programme that can never succeed, she says, "I am grieving." She took me to a typical primary school in Saddam City, where Baghdad's poorest live. We approached along a flooded street: the city's drainage and water distribution system have collapsed. The head, Ali Hassoon, wore the melancholia that marks Iraqi teachers and doctors and other carers: those who know they can do little "until you, in the outside world, decide". Guiding us around the puddles of raw sewage in the playground, he pointed to the high water mark on a wall. "In the winter it comes up to here. That's when we evacuate. We stay as long as possible, but without desks, the children have to sit on bricks. I am worried about the buildings coming down."

The school is on the edge of a vast industrial cemetery. The pumps in the sewage treatment plants and the reservoirs of water are silent, save for a few wheezing at a fraction of their capacity. Many were targets in the American-led blitz in January 1991; most have since disintegrated without spare parts from their British, French and German builders. These are mostly delayed by the Security Council's Sanctions Committee; the term used is "placed on hold". Ten years ago, 92% of the population had safe water, according to Unicef. Just before Christmas, the department of trade and industry in London blocked a shipment of vaccines meant to protect Iraqi children against diphtheria and yellow fever. Dr Kim Howells told parliament why. His title of under secretary of state for competition and consumer affairs, eminently suited his Orwellian reply. The children's vaccines were banned, he said, "because they are capable of being used in weapons of mass destruction". That his finger was on the trigger of a proven weapon of mass destruction - sanctions - seemed not to occur to him. A courtly, eloquent Irishman, Denis Halliday resigned as co-ordinator of humanitarian relief to Iraq in 1998, after 34 years with the UN; he was then Assistant Secretary-General of the United Nations, one of the elite of senior officials. He had made his career in development, "attempting to help people, not harm them". His was the first public expression of an unprecedented rebellion within the UN bureaucracy. "I am resigning," he wrote, "because the policy of economic sanctions is totally bankrupt. We are in the process of destroying an entire society. It is as simple and terrifying as that . . . Five thousand children are dying every month . . . I don't want to administer a programme that results in figures like these."

When I first met Halliday, I was struck by the care with which he chose uncompromising words. "I had been instructed," he said, "to implement a policy that satisfies the definition of genocide: a deliberate policy that has effectively killed well over a million individuals, children and adults. We all know that the regime, Saddam Hussein, is not paying the price for economic sanctions; on the contrary, he has been strengthened by them. It is the little people who are losing their children or their parents for lack of untreated water. What is clear is that the Security Council is now out of control, for its actions here undermine its own Charter, and the Declaration of Human Rights and the Geneva Convention. History will slaughter those responsible."

Inside the UN, Halliday broke a long collective silence. Then on February 13 this year, Hans von Sponeck, who had succeeded him as humanitarian co-ordinator in Iraq, resigned. "How long," he asked, "should the civilian population of Iraq be exposed to such punishment for something they have never done?" Two days later, Jutta Burghardt, head of the World Food Programme in Iraq, resigned, saying privately she, too, could not tolerate what was being done to the Iraqi people. Another resignation is expected.

When I met von Sponeck in Baghdad last October, the anger building behind his measured, self-effacing exterior was evident. Like Halliday before him, his job was to administer the Oil for Food Programme, which since 1996 has allowed Iraq to sell a fraction of its oil for money that goes straight to the Security Council. Almost a third pays the UN's "expenses", reparations to Kuwait and compensation claims. Iraq then tenders on the international market for food and medical supplies and other humanitarian supplies. Every contract must be approved by the Sanctions Committee in New York. "What it comes down to," he said, "is that we can spend only $180 per person over six months. It is a pitiful picture. Whatever the arguments about Iraq, they should not be conducted on the backs of the civilian population."

Denis Halliday and I travelled to Iraq together. It was his first trip back. Washington and London make much of the influence of Iraqi propaganda when their own, unchallenged, is by far the most potent. With this in mind, I wanted an independent assessment from some of the 550 UN people, who are Iraq's lifeline. Among them, Halliday and von Sponeck are heroes. I have reported the UN at work in many countries; I have never known such dissent and anger, directed at the manipulation of the Security Council, and the corruption of what some of them still refer to as the UN "ideal".

Our journey from Amman in Jordan took 16 anxious hours on the road. This is the only authorised way in and out of Iraq: a ribbon of wrecked cars and burnt-out oil tankers. Baghdad was just visible beneath a white pall of pollution, largely the consequence of the US Air Force strategy of targeting the industrial infrastructure in January 1991. Young arms reached up to the window of our van: a boy offering an over-ripe banana, a girl a single stem flower. Before 1990, such a scene was rare and frowned upon.

Baghdad is an urban version of Rachel Carson's Silent Spring. The birds have gone as avenues of palms have died, and this was the land of dates. The splashes of colour, on fruit stalls, are surreal. A bunch of Dole bananas and a bag of apples from Beirut cost a teacher's salary for a month; only foreigners and the rich eat fruit. A currency that once was worth two dollars to the dinar is now worthless. The rich, the black marketeers, the regime's cronies and favourites, are not visible, except for an occasional tinted-glass late-model Mercedes navigating its way through the rustbuckets. Having been ordered to keep their heads down, they keep to their network of clubs and restaurants and well-stocked clinics, which make nonsense of the propaganda that the sanctions are hurting them, not ordinary Iraqis.

In the centre of Baghdad is a monument to the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, which Saddam Hussein started, with encouragement from the Americans, who wanted him to destroy their great foe, the Ayatollah Khomeini. When it was over, at least a million lives had been lost in the cause of nothing, fuelled by the arms industries of Britain and the rest of Europe, the Soviet Union and the United States: the principal members of the Security Council. The monument's two huge forearms, modelled on Saddam's arms (and cast in Basingstoke), hold triumphant crossed sabres. Cars are allowed to drive over the helmets of dead Iranian soldiers embedded in the concourse. I cannot think of a sight anywhere in the world that better expresses the crime of sacrificial war.

We stayed at the Hotel Palestine, once claiming five stars. The smell of petrol was constant. As disinfectant is often "on hold", petrol, more plentiful than water, has replaced it. There is an Iraqi Airways office, which is open every day, with an employee sitting behind a desk, smiling and saying good morning to passing guests. She has no clients, because there is no Iraqi Airways - it died with sanctions. The pilots drive taxis and sweep the forecourt and sell used clothes. In my room, the water ran gravy brown. The one frayed towel was borne by the maid like an heirloom. When I asked for coffee to be brought up, the waiter hovered outside until I was finished; cups are at a premium. His young face was streaked with sadness. "I am always sad," he agreed matter-of-factly. In a month, he will have earned enough to buy tablets for his brother's epilepsy.

The same sadness is on the faces of people in the evening auctions, where intimate possessions are sold for food and medicines. Television sets are the most common items; a woman with two toddlers watched their pushchairs go for pennies. A man who had collected doves since he was 15 came with his last bird; the cage would go next. Although we had come to pry, my film crew and I were made welcome. Only once, was I the brunt of the hurt that is almost tangible in a society more westernised than any other Arab country. "Why are you killing the children?" shouted a man from behind his bookstall. "Why are you bombing us? What have we done to you?" Passers-by moved quickly to calm him; one man placed an affectionate arm on his shoulder, another, a teacher, materialised at my side. "We do not connect the people of Britain with the actions of the government," he said. Laith Kubba, a leading member of the exiled Iraqi opposition, later told me in Washington, "The Iraqi people and Saddam Hussein are not the same, which is why those of us who have dedicated our lives to fighting him, regard the sanctions as immoral."

In an Edwardian colonnade of Doric and Corinthian columns, people come to sell their books, not as in a flea market, but out of desperate need. Art books, leather bound in Baghdad in the 30s, obstetrics and radiology texts, copies of British Medical Journals, first and second editions of Waiting For Godot, The Sun Also Rises and, no less, British Housing Policy 1958 were on sale for the price of a few cigarettes. A man in a clipped grey moustache, an Iraqi Bertie Wooster, said, "I need to go south to see my sister, who is ill. Please be kind and give me 25 dinars." (About a penny). He took it, nodded and walked smartly away.

Mohamed Ghani's studio is dominated by a huge crucifix he is sculpting for the Church of Assumption in Baghdad. As Iraq's most famous sculptor, he is proud that the Vatican has commissioned him, a Muslim, to sculpt the Stations of the Cross in Rome - a romantic metaphor of his country as Mesopotamia, the "cradle of Western civilisation". His latest work is a 20-foot figure of a woman, her child gripping her legs, pleading for food. "Every morning, I see her," he said, "waiting, with others just like her, in a long line at the hospital at the end of my road. They are what we have been forced to become." He has produced a line of figurines that depict their waiting; all the heads are bowed before a door that is permanently closed. "The door is the dispensary," he said, "but it is also the world, kept shut by those who run the world." The next day, I saw a similar line of women and children, and fathers and children, in the cancer ward at the Al Mansour children's hospital. It is not unlike St Thomas's in London. Drugs arrived, they said, but intermittently, so that children with leukaemia, who can be saved with a full course of three anti-biotics, pass a point beyond which they cannot be saved, because one is missing. Children with meningitis can also survive with the precise dosage of antibiotics; here they die. "Four milligrams save a life," said Dr Mohamed Mahmud, "but so often we are allowed no more than one milligram." This is a teaching hospital, yet children die because there are no blood-collecting bags and no machines that separate blood platelets: basic equipment in any British hospital. Replacements and spare parts have been "on hold" in New York, together with incubators, X-ray machines, and heart and lung machines.

I sat in a clinic as doctors received parents and their children, some of them dying. After every other examination, Dr Lekaa Fasseh Ozeer, the oncologist, wrote in English: "No drugs available." I asked her to jot down in my notebook a list of the drugs the hospital had ordered, but rarely saw. In London, I showed this to Professor Karol Sikora who, as chief of the cancer programme of the World Health Organisation (WHO), wrote in the British Medical Journal last year: "Requested radiotherapy equipment, chemotherapy drugs and analgesics are consistently blocked by United States and British advisers [to the Sanctions Committee in New York]. There seems to be a rather ludicrous notion that such agents could be converted into chemical or other weapons."

He told me, "Nearly all these drugs are available in every British hospital. They're very standard. When I came back from Iraq last year, with a group of experts I drew up a list of 17 drugs that are deemed essential for cancer treatment. We informed the UN that there was no possibility of converting these drugs into chemical warfare agents. We heard nothing more. The saddest thing I saw in Iraq was children dying because there was no chemotherapy and no pain control. It seemed crazy they couldn't have morphine, because for everybody with cancer pain, it is the best drug. When I was there, they had a little bottle of aspirin pills to go round 200 patients in pain. They would receive a particular anti-cancer drug, but then get only little bits of drugs here and there, and so you can't have any planning. It is bizarre."

In January, last year, George Robertson, then defence secretary, said, "Saddam Hussein has in warehouses $275 million worth of medicines and medical supplies which he refuses to distribute." The British government knew this was false, because UN humanitarian officials had made clear the problem of drugs and equipment coming sporadically into Iraq - such as machines without a crucial part, IV fluids and syringes arriving separately - as well as the difficulties of transport and the need for a substantial buffer stock. "The goods that come into this country are distributed to where they belong," said Hans von Sponeck. "Our most recent stock analysis shows that 88.8% of all humanitarian supplies have been distributed." The representatives of Unicef, the World Food Programme and the Food and Agricultural Organisation confirmed this. If Saddam Hussein believed he could draw an advantage from obstructing humanitarian aid, he would no doubt do so. However, according to a FAO study: "The government of Iraq introduced a public food rationing system with effect from within a month of the imposition of the embargo. It provides basic foods at 1990 prices, which means they are now virtually free. This has a life-saving nutritional benefit . . . and has prevented catastrophe for the Iraqi people."

The rebellion in the UN reaches up to Kofi Annan, once thought to be the most compliant of secretary-generals. Appointed after Madeleine Albright, then the US representative at the UN, had waged a campaign to get rid of his predecessor, Boutros-Boutros Ghali, he pointedly renewed Hans von Sponeck's contract in the face of a similar campaign by the Americans. He shocked them last October when he accused the US of "using its muscle on the Sanctions Committee to put indefinite 'holds' on more than $700 million worth of humanitarian goods that Iraq would like to buy." When I met Kofi Annan, I asked if sanctions had all but destroyed the credibility of the UN as a benign body. "Please don't judge us by Iraq," he said.

On January 7, the UN's Office of Iraq Programme reported that shipments valued at almost a billion and a half dollars were "on hold". They covered food, health, water and sanitation, agriculture, education. On February 7, its executive director attacked the Security Council for holding up spares for Iraq's crumbling oil industry. "We would appeal to all members of the Security Council," he wrote, "to reflect on the argument that unless key items of oil industry are made available within a short time, the production of oil will drop . . . This is a clear warning." In other words, the less oil Iraq is allowed to pump, the less money will be available to buy food and medicine. According to the Iraqis at the UN, it was US representative on the Sanctions Committee who vetoed shipments the Security Council had authorised. Last year, a senior US official told the Washington Post, "The longer we can fool around in the [Security] Council and keep things static, the better." There is a pettiness in sanctions that borders on vindictiveness. In Britain, Customs and Excise stops parcels going to relatives, containing children's clothes and toys. Last year, the chairman of the British Library, John Ashworth, wrote to Harry Cohen MP that, "after consultation with the foreign office", it was decided that books could no longer be sent to Iraqi students.

In Washington, I interviewed James Rubin, an under secretary of state who speaks for Madeleine Albright. When asked on US television if she thought that the death of half a million Iraqi children was a price worth paying, Albright replied: "This is a very hard choice, but we think the price is worth it." When I questioned Rubin about this, he claimed Albright's words were taken out of context. He then questioned the "methodology" of a report by the UN's World Health Organisation, which had estimated half a million deaths. Advising me against being "too idealistic", he said: "In making policy, one has to choose between two bad choices . . . and unfortunately the effect of sanctions has been more than we would have hoped." He referred me to the "real world" where "real choices have to be made". In mitigation, he said, "Our sense is that prior to sanctions, there was serious poverty and health problems in Iraq." The opposite was true, as Unicef's data on Iraq before 1990, makes clear.

The irony is that the US helped bring Saddam Hussein's Ba'ath Party to power in Iraq, and that the US (and Britain) in the 1980s conspired to break their own laws in order, in the words of a Congressional inquiry, to "secretly court Saddam Hussein with reckless abandon", giving him almost everything he wanted, including the means of making biological weapons. Rubin failed to see the irony in the US supplying Saddam with seed stock for anthrax and botulism, that he could use in weapons, and claimed that the Maryland company responsible was prosecuted. It was not: the company was given Commerce Department approval.

Denial is easy, for Iraqis are a nation of unpeople in the West, their panoramic suffering of minimal media interest; and when they are news, care is always taken to minimise Western culpability. I can think of no other human rights issue about which the governments have been allowed to sustain such deception and tell so many bare-faced lies. Western governments have had a gift in the "butcher of Baghdad", who can be safely blamed for everything. Unlike the be-headers of Saudi Arabia, the torturers of Turkey and the prince of mass murderers, Suharto, only Saddam Hussein is so loathsome that his captive population can be punished for his crimes. British obsequiousness to Washington's designs over Iraq has a certain craven quality, as the Blair government pursues what Simon Jenkins calls a "low-cost, low-risk machismo, doing something relatively easy, but obscenely cruel". The statements of Tony Blair and Robin Cook and assorted sidekick ministers would, in other circumstances, be laughable. Cook: "We must nail the absurd claim that sanctions are responsible for the suffering of the Iraqi people", Cook: "We must uphold the sanctity of international law and the United Nations . . ." ad nauseam. The British boast about their "initiative" in promoting the latest Security Council resolution, which merely offers the prospect of more Kafkaesque semantics and prevarication in the guise of a "solution" and changes nothing.

What are sanctions for? Eradicating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, says the Security Council resolution. Scott Ritter, a chief UN weapons inspector in Iraq for five years, told me: "By 1998, the chemical weapons infrastructure had been completely dismantled or destroyed by UNSCOM (the UN inspections body) or by Iraq in compliance with our mandate. The biological weapons programme was gone, all the major facilities eliminated. The nuclear weapons programme was completely eliminated. The long range ballistic missile programme was completely eliminated. If I had to quantify Iraq's threat, I would say [it is] zero." Ritter resigned in protest at US interference; he and his American colleagues were expelled when American spy equipment was found by the Iraqis. To counter the risk of Iraq reconstituting its arsenal, he says the weapons inspectors should go back to Iraq after the immediate lifting of all non-military sanctions; the inspectors of the international Atomic Energy Agency are already back. At the very least, the two issues of sanctions and weapons inspection should be entirely separate. Madeleine Albright has said: "We do not agree that if Iraq complies with its obligations concerning weapons of mass destruction, sanctions should be lifted." If this means that Saddam Hussein is the target, then the embargo will go on indefinitely, holding Iraqis hostage to their tyrant's compliance with his own demise. Or is there another agenda? In January 1991, the Americans had an opportunity to press on to Baghdad and remove Saddam, but pointedly stopped short. A few weeks later, they not only failed to support the Kurdish and Shi'a uprising, which President Bush had called for, but even prevented the rebelling troops in the south from reaching captured arms depots and allowed Saddam Hussein's helicopters to slaughter them while US aircraft circled overhead. At they same time, Washington refused to support Iraqi opposition groups and Kurdish claims for independence.

"Containing" Iraq with sanctions destroys Iraq's capacity to threaten US control of the Middle East's oil while allowing Saddam to maintain internal order. As long as he stays within present limits, he is allowed to rule over a crippled nation. "What the West would ideally like," says Said Aburish, the author, "is another Saddam Hussein." Sanctions also justify the huge US military presence in the Gulf, as Nato expands east, viewing a vast new oil protectorate stretching from Turkey to the Caucasus. Bombing and sanctions are ideal for policing this new order: a strategy the president of the American Physicians for Human Rights calls "Bomb Now, Die Later". The perpetrators ought not be allowed to get away with this in our name: for the sake of the children of Iraq, and all the Iraqs to come

Paying the Price: Killing The Children Of Iraq, a documentary by John Pilger and Alan Lowery, will be on ITV this Monday at 9.30pm.
