There is an Iraqi Airways office, which is open every day, with an employee sitting behind a desk, smiling and saying good morning to passing guests. She has no clients, because there is no Iraqi Airways - it died with sanctions. The pilots drive taxis and sweep the forecourt and sell used clothes. In my room, the water ran gravy brown. The one frayed towel was borne by the maid like an heirloom. When I asked for coffee to be brought up, the waiter hovered outside until I was finished; cups are at a premium. His young face was streaked with sadness. "I am always sad," he agreed matter-of-factly. In a month, he will have earned enough to buy tablets for his brother's epilepsy. The same sadness is on the faces of people in the evening auctions, where intimate possessions are sold for food and medicines. Television sets are the most common items; a woman with two toddlers watched their pushchairs go for pennies. A man who had collected doves since he was 15 came with his last bird; the cage would go next. Although we had come to pry, my film crew and I were made welcome. Only once, was I the brunt of the hurt that is almost tangible in a society more westernised than any other Arab country. "Why are you killing the children?" shouted a man from behind his bookstall. "Why are you bombing us? What have we done to you?" Passers-by moved quickly to calm him; one man placed an affectionate arm on his shoulder, another, a teacher, materialised at my side. "We do not connect the people of Britain with the actions of the government," he said. Laith Kubba, a leading member of the exiled Iraqi opposition, later told me in Washington, "The Iraqi people and Saddam Hussein are not the same, which is why those of us who have dedicated our lives to fighting him, regard the sanctions as immoral." In an Edwardian colonnade of Doric and Corinthian columns, people come to sell their books, not as in a flea market, but out of desperate need. Art books, leather bound in Baghdad in the 30s, obstetrics and radiology texts, copies of British Medical Journals, first and second editions of Waiting For Godot, The Sun Also Rises and, no less, British Housing Policy 1958 were on sale for the price of a few cigarettes. A man in a clipped grey moustache, an Iraqi Bertie Wooster, said, "I need to go south to see my sister, who is ill. Please be kind and give me 25 dinars." (About a penny). He took it, nodded and walked smartly away. Mohamed Ghani's studio is dominated by a huge crucifix he is sculpting for the Church of Assumption in Baghdad. As Iraq's most famous sculptor, he is proud that the Vatican has commissioned him, a Muslim, to sculpt the Stations of the Cross in Rome - a romantic metaphor of his country as Mesopotamia, the "cradle of Western civilisation". His latest work is a 20-foot figure of a woman, her child gripping her legs, pleading for food. "Every morning, I see her," he said, "waiting, with others just like her, in a long line at the hospital at the end of my road. They are what we have been forced to become." He has produced a line of figurines that depict their waiting; all the heads are bowed before a door that is permanently closed. "The door is the dispensary," he said, "but it is also the world, kept shut by those who run the world." The next day, I saw a similar line of women and children, and fathers and children, in the cancer ward at the Al Mansour children's hospital. It is not unlike St Thomas's in London. Drugs arrived, they said, but intermittently, so that children with leukaemia, who can be saved with a full course of three anti-biotics, pass a point beyond which they cannot be saved, because one is missing. Children with meningitis can also survive with the precise dosage of antibiotics; here they die. "Four milligrams save a life," said Dr Mohamed Mahmud, "but so often we are allowed no more than one milligram." This is a teaching hospital, yet children die because there are no blood-collecting bags and no machines that separate blood platelets: basic equipment in any British hospital. Replacements and spare parts have been "on hold" in New York, together with incubators, X-ray machines, and heart and lung machines. I sat in a clinic as doctors received parents and their children, some of them dying. After every other examination, Dr Lekaa Fasseh Ozeer, the oncologist, wrote in English: "No drugs available." I asked her to jot down in my notebook a list of the drugs the hospital had ordered, but rarely saw. In London, I showed this to Professor Karol Sikora who, as chief of the cancer programme of the World Health Organisation (WHO), wrote in the British Medical Journal last year: "Requested radiotherapy equipment, chemotherapy drugs and analgesics are consistently blocked by United States and British advisers [to the Sanctions Committee in New York]. There seems to be a rather ludicrous notion that such agents could be converted into chemical or other weapons." He told me, "Nearly all these drugs are available in every British hospital. They're very standard. When I came back from Iraq last year, with a group of experts I drew up a list of 17 drugs that are deemed essential for cancer treatment. We informed the UN that there was no possibility of converting these drugs into chemical warfare agents. We heard nothing more. The saddest thing I saw in Iraq was children dying because there was no chemotherapy and no pain control. It seemed crazy they couldn't have morphine, because for everybody with cancer pain, it is the best drug. When I was there, they had a little bottle of aspirin pills to go round 200 patients in pain. They would receive a particular anti-cancer drug, but then get only little bits of drugs here and there, and so you can't have any planning. It is bizarre." In January, last year, George Robertson, then defence secretary, said, "Saddam Hussein has in warehouses $275 million worth of medicines and medical supplies which he refuses to distribute." The British government knew this was false, because UN humanitarian officials had made clear the problem of drugs and equipment coming sporadically into Iraq - such as machines without a crucial part, IV fluids and syringes arriving separately - as well as the difficulties of transport and the need for a substantial buffer stock. "The goods that come into this country are distributed to where they belong," said Hans von Sponeck. "Our most recent stock analysis shows that 88.8% of all humanitarian supplies have been distributed." The representatives of Unicef, the World Food Programme and the Food and Agricultural Organisation confirmed this. If Saddam Hussein believed he could draw an advantage from obstructing humanitarian aid, he would no doubt do so. However, according to a FAO study: "The government of Iraq introduced a public food rationing system with effect from within a month of the imposition of the embargo. It provides basic foods at 1990 prices, which means they are now virtually free. This has a life-saving nutritional benefit . . . and has prevented catastrophe for the Iraqi people." The rebellion in the UN reaches up to Kofi Annan, once thought to be the most compliant of secretary-generals. Appointed after Madeleine Albright, then the US representative at the UN, had waged a campaign to get rid of his predecessor, Boutros-Boutros Ghali, he pointedly renewed Hans von Sponeck's contract in the face of a similar campaign by the Americans. He shocked them last October when he accused the US of "using its muscle on the Sanctions Committee to put indefinite 'holds' on more than $700 million worth of humanitarian goods that Iraq would like to buy." When I met Kofi Annan, I asked if sanctions had all but destroyed the credibility of the UN as a benign body. "Please don't judge us by Iraq," he said. On January 7, the UN's Office of Iraq Programme reported that shipments valued at almost a billion and a half dollars were "on hold". They covered food, health, water and sanitation, agriculture, education. On February 7, its executive director attacked the Security Council for holding up spares for Iraq's crumbling oil industry. "We would appeal to all members of the Security Council," he wrote, "to reflect on the argument that unless key items of oil industry are made available within a short time, the production of oil will drop . . . This is a clear warning." In other words, the less oil Iraq is allowed to pump, the less money will be available to buy food and medicine. According to the Iraqis at the UN, it was US representative on the Sanctions Committee who vetoed shipments the Security Council had authorised. Last year, a senior US official told the Washington Post, "The longer we can fool around in the [Security] Council and keep things static, the better." There is a pettiness in sanctions that borders on vindictiveness. In Britain, Customs and Excise stops parcels going to relatives, containing children's clothes and toys. Last year, the chairman of the British Library, John Ashworth, wrote to Harry Cohen MP that, "after consultation with the foreign office", it was decided that books could no longer be sent to Iraqi students. In Washington, I interviewed James Rubin, an under secretary of state who speaks for Madeleine Albright. When asked on US television if she thought that the death of half a million Iraqi children was a price worth paying, Albright replied: "This is a very hard choice, but we think the price is worth it." When I questioned Rubin about this, he claimed Albright's words were taken out of context. He then questioned the "methodology" of a report by the UN's World Health Organisation, which had estimated half a million deaths. Advising me against being "too idealistic", he said: "In making policy, one has to choose between two bad choices . . . and unfortunately the effect of sanctions has been more than we would have hoped." He referred me to the "real world" where "real choices have to be made". In mitigation, he said, "Our sense is that prior to sanctions, there was serious poverty and health problems in Iraq." The opposite was true, as Unicef's data on Iraq before 1990, makes clear. The irony is that the US helped bring Saddam Hussein's Ba'ath Party to power in Iraq, and that the US (and Britain) in the 1980s conspired to break their own laws in order, in the words of a Congressional inquiry, to "secretly court Saddam Hussein with reckless abandon", giving him almost everything he wanted, including the means of making biological weapons. Rubin failed to see the irony in the US supplying Saddam with seed stock for anthrax and botulism, that he could use in weapons, and claimed that the Maryland company responsible was prosecuted. It was not: the company was given Commerce Department approval. Denial is easy, for Iraqis are a nation of unpeople in the West, their panoramic suffering of minimal media interest; and when they are news, care is always taken to minimise Western culpability. I can think of no other human rights issue about which the governments have been allowed to sustain such deception and tell so many bare-faced lies. Western governments have had a gift in the "butcher of Baghdad", who can be safely blamed for everything. Unlike the be-headers of Saudi Arabia, the torturers of Turkey and the prince of mass murderers, Suharto, only Saddam Hussein is so loathsome that his captive population can be punished for his crimes. British obsequiousness to Washington's designs over Iraq has a certain craven quality, as the Blair government pursues what Simon Jenkins calls a "low-cost, low-risk machismo, doing something relatively easy, but obscenely cruel". The statements of Tony Blair and Robin Cook and assorted sidekick ministers would, in other circumstances, be laughable. Cook: "We must nail the absurd claim that sanctions are responsible for the suffering of the Iraqi people", Cook: "We must uphold the sanctity of international law and the United Nations . . ." ad nauseam. The British boast about their "initiative" in promoting the latest Security Council resolution, which merely offers the prospect of more Kafkaesque semantics and prevarication in the guise of a "solution" and changes nothing. What are sanctions for? Eradicating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, says the Security Council resolution. Scott Ritter, a chief UN weapons inspector in Iraq for five years, told me: "By 1998, the chemical weapons infrastructure had been completely dismantled or destroyed by UNSCOM (the UN inspections body) or by Iraq in compliance with our mandate. The biological weapons programme was gone, all the major facilities eliminated. The nuclear weapons programme was completely eliminated. The long range ballistic missile programme was completely eliminated. If I had to quantify Iraq's threat, I would say [it is] zero." Ritter resigned in protest at US interference; he and his American colleagues were expelled when American spy equipment was found by the Iraqis. To counter the risk of Iraq reconstituting its arsenal, he says the weapons inspectors should go back to Iraq after the immediate lifting of all non-military sanctions; the inspectors of the international Atomic Energy Agency are already back. At the very least, the two issues of sanctions and weapons inspection should be entirely separate. Madeleine Albright has said: "We do not agree that if Iraq complies with its obligations concerning weapons of mass destruction, sanctions should be lifted." If this means that Saddam Hussein is the target, then the embargo will go on indefinitely, holding Iraqis hostage to their tyrant's compliance with his own demise. Or is there another agenda? In January 1991, the Americans had an opportunity to press on to Baghdad and remove Saddam, but pointedly stopped short. A few weeks later, they not only failed to support the Kurdish and Shi'a uprising, which President Bush had called for, but even prevented the rebelling troops in the south from reaching captured arms depots and allowed Saddam Hussein's helicopters to slaughter them while US aircraft circled overhead. At they same time, Washington refused to support Iraqi opposition groups and Kurdish claims for independence. "Containing" Iraq with sanctions destroys Iraq's capacity to threaten US control of the Middle East's oil while allowing Saddam to maintain internal order. As long as he stays within present limits, he is allowed to rule over a crippled nation. "What the West would ideally like," says Said Aburish, the author, "is another Saddam Hussein." Sanctions also justify the huge US military presence in the Gulf, as Nato expands east, viewing a vast new oil protectorate stretching from Turkey to the Caucasus. Bombing and sanctions are ideal for policing this new order: a strategy the president of the American Physicians for Human Rights calls "Bomb Now, Die Later". The perpetrators ought not be allowed to get away with this in our name: for the sake of the children of Iraq, and all the Iraqs to come © John Pilger Paying the Price: Killing The Children Of Iraq, a documentary by John Pilger and Alan Lowery, will be on ITV this Monday at 9.30pm.

webTitle: McCain puts his faith in Murphy's law

fields.headline: McCain puts his faith in Murphy's law
fields.standfirst:
Super Tuesday is nearly here, and the chaos theory of the Republican outsider's aide is his best hope
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: If John McCain defies the odds again to score a series of wins in next week's "Super Tuesday" Republican primaries, then put his success down to Murphy's law. Mike Murphy's law.
fields.body:
If John McCain defies the odds again to score a series of wins in next week's "Super Tuesday" Republican primaries, then put his success down to Murphy's law. Mike Murphy's law.

On this final weekend before 16 states hold primaries and caucuses on March 7, the Arizona senator faces an uphill struggle in his battle to decisively defeat George W Bush. Mr McCain is the frontrunner in New England and is just about ahead in New York, but he trails in the crucial state of California, and everywhere else. It looks bad - unless you apply Murphy's law.

The unwritten rules of modern politics say that a political campaign must be controlled, crafted, cautious and centrist. But Mr Murphy, 37, who is the senator's chief strategist, is rewriting the campaign rulebook in ways which have brought Mr McCain far closer to the Republican nomination than seemed possible at the start of the year.

Mr Murphy's law says that chaos is good. It relies on the unexpected. It says that the balance of power in modern elections can be upset by the candidate who uses audacity - and jokes - to tap into new groups of voters and to put together fresh coalitions.

If you start from behind like Mr McCain, then playing it safe and staying on message is simply a one-way ticket to defeat at the hands of an opponent with greater resources.

Mr McCain is the larger-than-life centrepiece of his own campaign. Of the four main challengers in the 2000 race to the White House, he is the one with easily the most interesting life story to tell. That story - with five and a half years in a Vietnamese jail at its heart - provides the Kryptonite which gives Mr McCain's campaign its energy and renewal.

The Arizona senator is comfortable because he is "running in his own skin", as Mr Murphy likes to put it. Mr McCain says what he thinks, most of the time within earshot of the media, who have unprecedented access to him, and he does not take polls before deciding his views. Among Mr Murphy and other top aides, the key phrase in strategy discussions is always the same: "Let McCain be McCain."

Yet the casualness of the McCain campaign has been both genuine and deceptive. Behind the improvisation and informality, and the impression that the team is made up of people who are just having what the senator frequently calls "a great ride", there is a trio of highly experienced, consummately professional campaign chiefs who planned the McCain insurgency long ago, in surprising detail and with great ruthlessness.

In addition to Mr McCain and his wife Cindy, the three key people in the senator's inner circle are campaign director Rick Davis, political director John Weaver, and the engagingly zany, wise-cracking Mr Murphy. "He's smart. He's a great tactician and strategist," Mr McCain says.

Mr Murphy was the last of the three to board Mr McCain's campaign bus, the Straight Talk Express. Until August 1999, he had remained loyal to the former Tennessee governor Lamar Alexander, for whom he had run a spirited campaign in 1996. But since Mr Murphy joined Mr McCain, there has been little doubt that he has given the bid most of its flair, encouraging Mr McCain to play to his strengths.

The Alexander campaign provided Mr Murphy with priceless experience on running an "insurgency" campaign for the Republican nomination against an establishment favourite. Mr Murphy is also a well-read strategist and has run Republican election battles for party liberals such as Christie Whitman, conservatives such as Oliver North, and even, though he keeps quiet about it these days, George W Bush's brother Jeb.

Nevertheless, the McCain campaign has been his pièce de résistance . It has been a campaign full of breathtaking risks, the latest of which was Mr McCain's extraordinary onslaught on Monday against his party's religious right.

Mr McCain lambasted rightwing conservatives such as Pat Robertson and Jerry Falwell as "agents of intolerance" - later he called them an "evil influence" - before calling Mr Bush "a Pat Robertson Republican who will lose to Al Gore".

For a candidate who needs the votes of core Republican supporters to win Tuesday's primaries, this is audacity of a high order. Many pundits dismiss it as suicidal. But Murphy's law is about mixing it up and creating confusion. His objective is to draw Mr Bush into reckless confrontations which enable Mr McCain to label the Texas governor as the campaign bully who is in hock to the extreme right and to large corporate interests.

On his campaign bus this week, Mr McCain put it like this: "There's a famous Murphy saying, which he stole from somebody: 'When you wrestle with a pig, you both get dirty and the pig likes it'."

This week's Bush wins in Virginia, North Dakota and Washington state have been widely seen as the writing on the wall for Mr McCain. But when Mr Murphy assessed the results for the inner circle, he was as upbeat as ever.

"If we buy the thesis that Washington and Virginia are devastating, then it's Armageddon and we might as well start having orgies and that stuff, because it's all over," he said. "We have to ignore these results because we don't have any choice. We have to focus on the 7th."

Mr Murphy has said there are three categories of states at stake on Tuesday. Category number one, the states where Mr McCain is probably going to win, consists of Massachusetts, Connecticut, Maine, Rhode Island and Vermont.

Category two comprises the states which Mr Bush will probably win, and in which the McCain campaign has effectively conceded defeat. The most important of these is Georgia, the only Southern state at stake on March 7.

The third category consists of the battleground states where the contest will be won or lost. Mr McCain's best chance here is in New York, where 101 delegates are at stake and where a poll this week among Republicans put him six points ahead of Mr Bush. Next best is Ohio, with 69 delegates, where McCain heads tomorrow, but where Mr Bush still leads in the polls.

Most critical of all is California, with 162 delegates at stake in a winner-takes-all "closed" contest. Only Republican votes count, but voters of all parties can participate.

California looks bad for Mr McCain. He trailed by 47% to 26% there among Republicans in a poll on Wednesday. If Mr McCain loses among Republicans but wins among voters as a whole, Mr Murphy wants him to challenge the "winner-takes-all" rule inside the California Republican party.

"We'd win a fair fight," Mr Murphy is fond of saying.

Yet even if the senator is defeated on Tuesday, Mr Murphy will have left his mark on the history of American election campaigning. And if Mr McCain enjoys a comeback victory on March 7, Mr Murphy will be hailed as one of the political geniuses of the age.

fields.headline: How to... fold things
fields.trailText: As the world becomes ever more crowded, so folding will become ever more important. Folding things helps you fit them in spaces; research has shown that 90% of women who complain about lack of storage space for their clothing are strangers to folding.
fields.body:
As the world becomes ever more crowded, so folding will become ever more important. Folding things helps you fit them in spaces; research has shown that 90% of women who complain about lack of storage space for their clothing are strangers to folding.

Most of us are already pretty familiar with folding, thanks to the folding stuff. Only rich men in big coats and with wallets like wine menus don't fold their cash.

Folding sheets used to be a big thing. One person stood at each end of the sheet and both folded several times in completely different directions until one of them got fed up and left. Then the other person had to finish folding it by standing on top of the wardrobe to get enough height to let the sheet hang straight, before flicking it up and attempting to catch it halfway in a little fold. This performance explains why most people now use a duvet.

Things that fold out are fun, because they suddenly go from two dimensions to three. For example, fold-out chairs make you more aware of the joy of sitting, and a fold-away bed helps you sleep better, because you know that the alternative would be sleeping standing up. Fold-up furniture also has a built-in slapstick factor, in that it's likely to fold up with you still in it. This slapstick factor is not always a good thing - you would, for example, hesitate before doing serious business with somebody who uses a folding bicycle.

Folding things does three things: it makes things smaller, it makes them squarer and it gives you nice edges. That's why you can't get a folding blancmange. Folding is about control and order and discipline. It can also be an incredibly frustrating and boring thing to do: too much of it, and you end up wanting to cause havoc and destruction. That's why basic army training consists of folding things followed by bayonet practice.

Folding is an art, and if you've ever seen someone try to fold a large newspaper in a crowded train you'll know that few have the required artistry.

If you think you can fold things, try opening out an Ordnance Survey map and then folding it back so that all the creases go the same way. Research has shown that the likelihood of folding a map so that it goes back the same way it was before you unfolded it is less than being hit by a block of frozen urine jettisoned from a passing airliner.

webTitle: Trial verdict puts Gore fundraising in spotlight

fields.headline: Trial verdict puts Gore fundraising in spotlight
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Vice-president Al Gore's political fundraising is set to become a major campaign issue again, after an associate was convicted of channelling more than $100,000 in illegal contributions to Democratic party candidates during the 1996 election campaign.
fields.body:
Vice-president Al Gore's political fundraising is set to become a major campaign issue again, after an associate was convicted of channelling more than $100,000 in illegal contributions to Democratic party candidates during the 1996 election campaign.

Maria Hsia, 48, an immigration adviser in Los Angeles, faces a possible maximum 25-year prison sentence after being convicted by a federal court in Washington.

The case against her puts the spotlight back on one of the most embarrassing episodes in Mr Gore's career, his 1996 visit to a Los Angeles Buddhist temple at which dozens of monks and nuns were asked to sign cheques to the Democratic national committee - for which they were later reimbursed - to disguise the fact that the donations came from the Hsi Lai temple itself, whose charitable status precluded it from making political payments.

Ms Hsia was found guilty of channelling $65,000 to the DNC in this way on the day after Mr Gore's visit in April 1996. She was also responsible for arranging donations from other illegal donors, including the temple, to the Clinton-Gore 1996 re-election campaign, and to congressman Patrick Kennedy, son of the Massachusetts Democratic senator Edward Kennedy.

Prosecution lawyers said Mr Gore, Mr Kennedy and the DNC were unwitting beneficiaries of dishonesty.

fields.headline: Alexei Sayle
fields.standfirst: Alexei Sayle, 52, was born in Liverpool. His father was a railway guard, his mother worked for Littlewoods Pools. Having studied at art school, he made his name in the 80s writing and performing in the TV series The Young Ones. He has just published his first collection of stories, Barcelona Plates.
fields.trailText: The questionnaire
fields.body:
With which historical figure do you most identify?
When you're brought up in a Communist home, and you're told that a little Georgian genocidist with a moustache is the greatest figure of the 20th century, you get put off historical figures.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Saying nasty things to people for a cheap laugh, then feeling really guilty.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Not being able to take a joke.

What vehicles do you own?
Alfa Romeo 166 3-litre V6 and nine bicycles.

Where would you like to live?
Anywhere as long as it's for ever. I don't want to die.

What do you most dislike about your appearance ?
I suppose I could be fatter.

What is your favourite smell?
Polish. The language, not the furniture cleaning substance.

What is your favourite word?
Tracheotomy.

What is your favourite book?
Guns Of The Elite: Special Forces Firearms from 1940 to the Present Day, by George Markham, published by Arms & Armour.

For what cause would you die?
The cause I am most likely to die for is the re-unification of Ireland, since there are still factions within the republican movement who think it's a good thing if innocent Indian newsagents, children and comedians living in the cities of the UK are macerated for something they feel it would be nice for them to have.

How often do you have sex?
Depends what you define as sex.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
A Browning 9mm Hi Power semi automatic pistol with customised grip and front sight, and a Ruger Mini Light 14 5.56mm automatic assault rifle with folding stock for the weekends.

What would you motto be?
'Mustn't Grumble', but in Latin.

How would you like to die?
In a shoot-out with reactionary government forces in the hills of El Salvador along with my all-ballerina squad of left-wing rebels.

Do you believe in life after death?
Not if I have to share it with Jim Davidson.

How would you like to be remembered?
As the director of The African Queen because that would mean I was John Huston.

webTitle: Naked body in chains case puzzles police

fields.headline: Naked body in chains case puzzles police
fields.trailText: Police are baffled as to whether a woman's naked body weighted with chains found on a Suffolk beach is a case of murder or suicide.
fields.body:
Police are baffled as to whether a woman's naked body weighted with chains found on a Suffolk beach is a case of murder or suicide.

Detective Superintendent Adrian Braddy said yesterday that the woman had entered the water alive, and could have been killed by someone who believed that, by padlocking her with 24lbs of chains and body-builder's weights, they could drown her and make the body sink without trace. But strong currents meant the weight was insufficient to sink the body in one place for any length of time.

However, there was a possibility the woman had walked into the sea after fixing the weights to herself. "All we can say for sure is she was alive when she entered the water, and her death appears suspicious," said Mr Braddy, who is leading the investigation.

Identifying the woman, aged between 20 and 40, was the key, he added. She was discovered at high tide by a woman walking her dog at Kessingland, near Lowestoft, on Thursday morning. Bizarrely, the case echoes the plot of PD James's novel, Devices and Desires, where the detective, Commander Adam Dalgliesh, discovers the body of a naked young woman as he walks the same coast. Baroness James has a holiday home eight miles south, at Southwold.

In the real case, the woman had drowned and was in the water days rather than weeks. If it was less than 48 hours, she must have gone in close to Kessingland. Detectives were investigating reports of suspicious activity involving a woman on the coast nearby.

However, there remained a possibility she was dropped overboard some way off the coast.

Detectives have asked forces around Britain to try for a match with recent missing persons files; there was none in Suffolk and neighbouring Norfolk. The woman was 5ft 9in, slim, nine stone, with brown collar-length hair, and a pierced left ear - although no jewellery was found. She had an appendix scar, but no other distinguishing features.

The body was weighed with 3kg of chain, with links of 1xin, threaded through three 2.5kg weights, and attached with two padlocks.

A post mortem found some bruises on her head and the side of her face from before death. Tests were being done to see if she had been drugged.

"However, at this time we are unable to say if she was assaulted," said Mr Braddy.

"The bruises could have been the weights banging against her in the water. There is no evidence of a significant attack. And it would have been possible for her to padlock herself - but I have never come across a suicide like this."

webTitle: Right to roam bill will also protect wildlife

fields.headline: Right to roam bill will also protect wildlife
fields.standfirst: The Countryside and Rights of Way Bill http://www.ramblers.org.uk/ The Ramblers' Association http://www.countryside-alliance.org/ Countryside Alliance http://www.foe.co.uk/pubsinfo/infoteam/pressrel/2000/20000303124335.html Friends of the Earth's reaction
fields.trailText: The government yesterday fulfilled its manifesto pledge to introduce a right to roam over 4m acres of England and Wales and at the same time brought in new powers to protect wildlife.
fields.body:
The government yesterday fulfilled its manifesto pledge to introduce a right to roam over 4m acres of England and Wales and at the same time brought in new powers to protect wildlife.

The countryside and rights of way bill delighted the green lobby and the ramblers. The only dissent came from the Country Landowners Association which fears members' property and livestock will be interfered with.

The bill gives magistrates new powers to force landowners to unblock paths.

It is the culmination of many years campaigning, and of the hard work by Michael Meacher, the environment minister, to convince Downing Street that legislation is a vote winner.

The right to roam does not extend to cycling, horse riding or driving a vehicle. Dogs must be kept on leads during the spring and where stock is present. Landowners will be able to close areas for 28 days a year for shooting or other reasons, and longer if they can con vince committees of local interest groups they have good reasons.

Landowners who put up bogus notices claiming land is closed when it is not can be fined £200. There will not be access to gardens, parks or cultivated land, and the exact wording of what constitutes rough grazing will be fought over in parliament.

On rights of way Mr Meacher said the bill was the most radical improvement for many years. It will require local authorities to draw up plans to improve their rights of way network, including producing recreational circular walks. The bill will redesignate 4,000 miles of rights of way as a new category of public highway. This will be for all traffic, except motorised vehicles - horse riders, cyclists and drivers of horse drawn vehicles.

The new powers for magistrates will provide a means to clean up to an estimated 10,000 miles of blocked footpaths. Most are blocked through neglect, but some are deliberately barred by landlords willing to flout the existing weak laws.

English Nature, the government's watchdog which is charged with protecting sites of special scientific interest, is given sweeping new powers which will at last enable it to do so. These include intervening to prevent neglect and force landlords to restore damaged sites. In the event of complete breakdown of relations the courts can order the restoration of sites at the owner's expense and ulti mately the compulsory purchase of them.

The right to roam does not include coasts and woodlands, which some campaigners wanted, but Mr Meacher said this may happen in the future. There is provision in the bill for landowners to voluntarily bestow a right to roam on property currently outside the bill - which would remain in perpetuity.

It will take about two to three years before the bill allows the right to roam. Once legislation is passed the land involved has to be mapped and local committees set up with the landlords and interest groups to get agreement on such things as boundary markers, car parks, gates and local rules on dogs and closures of areas for rare plants or birds.

The bill absolves landlords from claims for walkers breaking legs or other injuries caused by "natural accidents" but they will still be liable if walkers trip over old farm machinery or down a mineshaft that should be capped.

Kate Ashbrook, chairman of the access committee of the 128,000-strong Ramblers Association, said: "This is an historic day, very good news at long last."

Tony Juniper, of Friends of the Earth, said: "This is long overdue legislation but the government deserves a pat on the back."

Main Points

 Right to roam over 4m acres of open land - mountain moor, heath, down and registered common land

 New powers for magistrates to remove obstructions to public paths

 Extra protection for sites of special scientific interest. Landowners can be ordered to look after them and restore them if damaged

 New offence of reckless disturbance of wildlife - aimed at motor bike scramblers and four-wheel drivers

 Prison sentences and increased fines for wildlife offences such as egg stealing

fields.headline: MP awarded £60,000 for wife-beating libel
fields.trailText: The Labour MP Jimmy Wray is known in the Commons as a fighter and yesterday he won his toughest battle yet when a judge awarded him £60,000 in damages for newspaper claims that he had beaten his former wife.
fields.body:
The Labour MP Jimmy Wray is known in the Commons as a fighter and yesterday he won his toughest battle yet when a judge awarded him £60,000 in damages for newspaper claims that he had beaten his former wife.

Mr Wray, 64, the MP for Glasgow Baillieston, had sued Associated Newspapers for defamation over a front page story in the Mail on Sunday in 1998 in which his ex-wife, Catherine, claimed he had punched her, grabbed her throat and held a knife to her neck during their troubled 12-year marriage.

The case was heard at the court of session in Edinburgh last month, and in his judgment yesterday Lord Johnston said he considered Mr Wray an honest man who felt deeply wronged.

Lord Johnston said there was insufficient evidence to support the Mail on Sunday article.

The newspaper had claimed its story was true.

"In this day and age when not every member of the Westminster parliament had been shown to have clean hands with regard to his public life and private life, the type of allegation in this article must reflect very seriously on the political position of an MP," Lord Johnston wrote.

"Privately, the impact of this article must have been devastating in the short term, and very stressful in the long term, even if the effects are now diminishing," he added.

Mr Wray, speaking at his Glasgow home with his new wife, Laura, and their young son, Frankie, said he had suffered personally and professionally from the allegations. He had originally sought £1.5m, a figure which had changed to £140,000 during his action.

"My reputation was on the line. You have to go where angels fear to tread and I have been a fighter all my life," he said.

"I would never have backed down. These allegations were false, they were fabricated and there was no evidence to back them up whatsoever. I got the right result and deserved to get the right result," Mr Wray added.

He declined to comment further on the claims by his ex-wife, whom he had portrayed in court as an insecure drunk who was obsessed with his money and came at him with knives "countless times".

"It was a rotten thing to do. It was evil," he said. "Let her get on with her life and let me get on with mine."

Catherine Wray told the court she had been paid £25,500 for the story at a time when she was struggling to survive financially.

She claimed she had received medical treatment for abuse she frequently suffered at his hands during their marriage.

Lord Johnston said the manner in which the story had been sold during divorce proceedings "must at least raise a question mark over the motive behind the whole exercise".

A spokesman for Associated Newspapers said: "We are very disappointed with the verdict and are actively considering an appeal."

Mr Wray is renowned in parliamentary circles as a die-hard socialist, cut from the cloth of old Labour and shaped by a life in Glasgow politics.

He became an MP more than 30 years ago after a string of make-do jobs as a chimney sweep, a rag and bone man, a coal man and a lorry driver.

Mr Wray's deprived childhood is legendary in the Commons.

He grew up in a family of 10 in a room and kitchen in the tough Gorbals area of Glasgow, and all his clothes were bought at army surplus stores.

He became fed up, he famously joked to the house during one debate, of always going to school dressed as a Japanese general.

He was a fighter, too, brawling in the street as a youth.

"You just learnt to defend yourself," he told the Guardian in 1998. "That was the Gorbals way."

fields.headline: Lagerfeld does right by Coco
fields.trailText: Coco Chanel would have approved. The spirit of Chanel autumn/winter 2000 is thoroughly modern but full of historical references that pay tribute to Coco's greatest innovations. In Karl Lagerfeld's hands, the 90-year-old label storms into the 21st century with a clever mix of traditional suiting and street-influenced chic that should keep every customer happy.
fields.body:
Coco Chanel would have approved. The spirit of Chanel autumn/winter 2000 is thoroughly modern but full of historical references that pay tribute to Coco's greatest innovations. In Karl Lagerfeld's hands, the 90-year-old label storms into the 21st century with a clever mix of traditional suiting and street-influenced chic that should keep every customer happy.

Karl Lagerfeld is one of the most experienced designers in Paris. As well as having worked for design houses as diverse as Balmain, Chloe and Valentino, he is responsible for the hugely successful turnaround in Fendi's fortunes. It was his monogrammed fur Fendi coats and bags that first caught the imagination of the fashion pack.

For Chanel this season the interlocked C monogram appeared as a pattern on tights, earrings and diamante neck chains. Like so many designers in Paris and Milan, Lagerfeld drew on the eighties for inspiration, with patent ankle boots, mohair legwarmers and high hair making an appearance on the catwalk, to the strains of Madonna's Material Girl.

There was enough classic Chanel suiting to add gravitas, however, in black and white dogtooth check or in raspberry pink boucle trimmed with sequins.

Pearls also made a comeback, although in a far more modern incarnation than the simple string Coco liked to wear. Lagerfeld called them "ping pong pearls". There was something space-age about the way they hung, threaded on silver wire, like models of molecules in a lab.

Denim also made a comeback: quilted skirts and matching throws were worn with baggy cowl-neck sweaters, while jeans were tight and subtly monogrammed. So what if the denim had a similar wash to that seen at Helmut Lang last season: a magpie such as Lagerfeld is clever enough to stamp everything with his own identity. For in the great retro frenzy that was the autumn/winter collections, didn't everyone borrow from everyone?

Paris fashion week ends today.

webTitle: Green group urges cash for drivers 'dirty' cars

fields.headline: Green group urges cash for drivers 'dirty' cars
fields.trailText: A "cash for cars" scheme to clear the roads of old vehicles that emit too much pollution was welcomed by environmental groups yesterday.
fields.body:
A "cash for cars" scheme to clear the roads of old vehicles that emit too much pollution was welcomed by environmental groups yesterday.

But the department of the environment, transport and the regions said the report, from the commission for integrated transport, did not represent government policy.

The report suggested motorists should be offered up to £750 to get rid of old cars which emit high levels of pollution.

An incentive would be to give the owners of older cars up to three years' worth of public transport vouchers if they scrapped their heavily-polluting vehicles.

Drivers of less-clean cars should also be given an incentive to fit catalytic converters to the vehicles, the commission's pollution working group said in a report to the government.

Also, local authorities could declare "low-emission zones" from which vehicles without catalytic converters would be excluded, the commission proposed.

Friends of the Earth said the report was "full of practical ideas for cutting pollution in towns".

FoE transport campaigner Roger Higman added: "Tougher measures, including cuts in traffic levels, will be needed to stop smogs in the worst polluted cities and in country areas."

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said: "There are some sound ideas in the report. Our own Stop Fuming campaign has shown that it's the older cars that are the biggest polluters."

A ministry spokesman said: "It's a useful contribution to the pollution debate. We'll consider it carefully."

fields.headline: Newspaper must reveal its source
fields.trailText: Lawyers for Elton John yesterday won a court order forcing the Daily Express to reveal the source of a confidential legal document containing advice on the singer's financial affairs.
fields.body:
Lawyers for Elton John yesterday won a court order forcing the Daily Express to reveal the source of a confidential legal document containing advice on the singer's financial affairs.

Mr Justice Morland ruled at the high court in London that the newspaper should disclose its source by noon on Wednesday.

The defendants - Express Newspapers, Express editor Rosie Boycott and journalist Rachel Baird - were granted leave to appeal.

The judge heard last week that the original draft of a barrister's written opinion, which had been "binned" at his chambers in Middle Temple, found its way into the hands of Miss Baird.

Anthony Scrivener QC, for Mr John, said that after making notes of the document, Miss Baird tore it into pieces and asked a colleague to dispose of it. It ended up in a dustbin in Soho.

When Miss Baird telephoned Sir Elton's lawyers for a comment, they immediately obtained an injunction banning publication.

The newspaper argued that it had a "public interest" defence under section 10 of the contempt of court act which recognised journalists' duty to protect their sources.

Mr Scrivener had told the judge that lawyer-client confidentiality could not be over ridden by any argument that journalists were duty-bound to protect someone who had disclosed an individual's private affairs when disclosure was not genuinely "in the public interest".

Michael Beloff QC, for the newspaper, argued that in this case lawyer-client confidentiality was not entitled to any special protection.

webTitle: Farmer cleared of harrow murder of wife

fields.headline: Farmer cleared of harrow murder of wife
fields.trailText: A farmer is considering taking civil action against the police after a jury yesterday cleared him of murdering his wife by crushing her to death with a heavy piece of farm machinery.
fields.body:
A farmer is considering taking civil action against the police after a jury yesterday cleared him of murdering his wife by crushing her to death with a heavy piece of farm machinery.

Rosie White, 42, died beneath the metal teeth of a power harrow on the couple's farm near Roche, Cornwall, in July, 1998.

The prosecution had alleged that John White lured her under the machine to help with repairs before deliberately dropping the harrow on her by flicking a switch in the cab of his tractor.

But the jury at Truro crown court accepted that Mrs White's death had been a tragic accident, taking just 75 minutes to deliver a unanimous not guilty verdict at the end of a nine day trial.

Mr White, 49, who told the court his wife must have darted underneath the harrow to rescue her pet puppy, said he had been through "18 months of sheer hell" and now wanted to return to running the farm and bringing up the couple's three sons.

"I'm glad that it's all over. I just hope we can get on with our lives now."

As Mr White expressed the hope of being able to get back to "some sort of normality", his solicitor, John Evans, launched a fierce attack on the way police allegedly handled the case.

"I personally have been ap palled at the number of witnesses I have spoken to in the course of this trial who have been browbeaten by the police over a period of many hours.

"I don't think that is acceptable. We will be contemplating further proceedings but I am not prepared to say any more at this stage."

During his eight hours in the witness box, Mr White had sobbed as he told the jury how he found his wife's body, a discovery that still haunted him.

He not seen his wife when he got out of the cab of the tractor and thought she must have wandered off.

It was not until four hours later that he started to worry. He came back to the tractor and found her legs sticking out from under the harrow.

After finding the body shortly after 6pm on July 24, 1998, he called 999 and begged paramedics not to use lights and sirens so as not to alarm the couple's three boys who were playing nearby.

He said he had no real explanation for the accident, but there was "no reason in this world" why he would ever have wanted to harm his wife to whom he had been married for 18 years.

He denied rumours that he had been having an affair with his wife's best friend and neighbour, Jackie Warne, or that he was in financial difficulties.

The court heard that White stood to gain £80,000 in insurance following his wife's death and that the accounts of Higher Brynn Farm were £56,000 overdrawn at the time she died.

But Mr White told the jury the farm had always made a profit and was now in credit. His bank manager was totally happy with the way he ran the farm.

Devon and Cornwall police yesterday defended the decision to bring the prosecution, claiming the circumstances of Mrs White's death were at variance with the accounts given by her husband.

"It was felt there were a number of questions that needed to be answered," Detective Superintendent Chris Borland said after the verdict.

Mrs White's mother, Madeline Vian, said her family was satisfied with the verdict.

"We feel that some of the unanswered questions have been answered about what happened on that dreadful day."

webTitle: Ex-Bay City Roller admits having child pornography

fields.headline: Ex-Bay City Roller admits having child pornography
fields.standfirst: Bay City Rollers site
fields.trailText: A former Bay City Roller has admitted having child pornography at his home in Edinburgh.
fields.body:
A former Bay City Roller has admitted having child pornography at his home in Edinburgh.

Derek Longmuir, 48, who was the drummer of the 1970s tartan rock band, pleaded guilty at Edinburgh sheriff court yesterday to two charges of possessing indecent films, photos, videos and computer images of children.

Longmuir, a nurse at Edinburgh royal infirmary, claimed the material belonged to a friend. He also admitted downloading four indecent pictures from the internet on his computer, but said it was only curiosity while taking a break from studying for a nursing degree.

Sentence was deferred until March 24 for a psychiatric and other reports, and Longmuir was released on bail.

Longmuir was found with dozens of videos and films and more than 100 computer images of child porn when police, acting on a tipoff, raided his home in September 1998.

Officers who interviewed him said he had been in a state of shock.

Robbie Burnett, defending, said his client was not a paedophile and had been storing the pornography for a friend who had bought it in Portugal and left it with Longmuir when he returned to the United States.

However, because Longmuir had been aware of the indecent content of the material he had pleaded guilty to the charges, Mr Burnett said.

The Bay City Roller was unrecognisable from his days in tartan bell bottoms and platforms. Dressed in a navy blue suit, he sat nervously in the dock as his offences were read to the court.

Asking the sheriff not to consider a jail sentence, Mr Burnett said Longmuir was a respected nurse and offered the court references from hospital colleagues.

Longmuir had lost the bulk of the vast amounts of money he should have earned as a Bay City Roller to agents, managers, record companies and legal representatives, and had now to work hard for a living, said Mr Burnett.

After a short-lived career as a property developer during the 1980s, Longmuir had qualified as a nurse five years ago.

He and his brother, Alan, who played bass guitar, founded the group with singer Les McKeown and guitarists Stuart Wood and Eric Faulkner; between 1975 and 1978 their singles outsold even the Beatles. The first hit, Shang-a-Lang in 1974, was followed by Bye Bye Baby and Give a Little Love.

In 1978 the group disbanded after arguments. Much of their royalties slipped through their fingers.

Their former manager, Tom Paton, was jailed for three years in 1982 after admitting sexually abusing teenage boys at his home outside Edinburgh.

fields.headline: Child, 3, left locked in nursery
fields.trailText: An inquiry was under way yesterday after a child aged three was left unsupervised in a nursery while the rest of his group of 30 children were taken on a day trip.
fields.body:
An inquiry was under way yesterday after a child aged three was left unsupervised in a nursery while the rest of his group of 30 children were taken on a day trip.

Bryce Hall was accidentally left behind at Deneside infants school in Seaham, Co Durham. When teachers realised he was missing as they arrived at a museum in Middlesbrough over an hour later, they phoned colleagues at the school, who let him out of the locked nursery.

The headteacher of the council-run school, Julia Phipps, yesterday promised his parents a full inquiry into the incident on Wednesday. "This incident is unacceptable. I want to discover how it came to happen and to ensure it never occurs again."

The parents, who both work for the county council, said they were furious that their son was left alone. His mother, Lisa Hall, 25, said: "He could have swallowed something, something could have fallen on top of him, or even worse he could have slipped out of the door and into the street.

"Why didn't [the teachers] count the number of children on the bus?"

Mrs Hall believes Bryce was locked in the nursery by a member of staff who did not spot him.

webTitle: Keeping the British aid effort ship shape

fields.headline: Keeping the British aid effort ship shape
fields.standfirst: Rob Holden: Sailor turned civil servant runs disaster response team
fields.trailText: Rob Holden still has a stonemason's handshake from the apprenticeship he served as a teenager. It feels as if he were trying to squeeze chips of granite off the unwary hand that's placed in his.
fields.body:
Rob Holden still has a stonemason's handshake from the apprenticeship he served as a teenager. It feels as if he were trying to squeeze chips of granite off the unwary hand that's placed in his.

But now he is the man who decides what aid Britain should send when disasters strike, as head of the crisis response team at the international development department's conflict and humanitarian aid department, known by the confusing acronym of Chad. You turn up at the Victoria Street headquarters to be told "He's in Chad", and then learn that this means the building behind.

There are only four people in the office that takes the decision to act in a crisis, but there is an unending flow of crises and they seem to be getting worse. In the last four months the office has dealt with mudslides and floods in Venezuela, typhoons in Orissa, a major earthquake in Turkey, the storms in France, and an influx of Angolan refugees into Zambia. "Nine major natural disasters last year not including Kosovo, and we do a heck of a lot of work in Kosovo."

But the decision to act, he says, is normally quite an easy one. "You can decide off one piece of paper. The first thing you've got to look at is what is causing the problem. What's the scale? The impact? The severity?"

He talks with bullet point compression, fast and emphatically. "Is there a government? Is the government able to deal with it?"

Seeing that something must be done, then, is quick. Deciding how to do it takes a little longer.

"The problem with Mozambique is that we have no hard information. When a major disaster hits we put our own technical staff into the field to get good credible information back to us very quickly."

So far the department has put money into Mozambique through Unicef, the International Red Cross, the World Food Programme, and Oxfam, as well as its own emergency response team, which has sent inflatable boats, life rafts, and even two helicopters chartered form the Ukraine.

In all this there is a rather military style. He talks for most of the time like a man who values effectiveness over efficiency, though he can drop into management speak where necessary. This is not surprising, since, after his time as a stonemason, he spent seven years in the Royal Navy as a marine engineer. This varied background has helped him a great deal, he says, in dealing with the world outside the civil service.

Armies are involved one way or another with almost every disaster. It is a great advantage to know how they think, and what their aims and values are.

What is astonishing is what he did after leaving the navy: he retrained as a nurse, at the same time taking a degree in planning for humanitarian operations. He says there was nothing he had seen in particular which determined him on this course, no moment when he realised that the world was full of suffering he might relieve. Indeed, he sounds like any businessman selling himself when he discusses the change.

"I came out of the Navy in 1989 not really knowing what I wanted to do. I was questioning what value did I bring to society: what difference did I want to make?

"To give up a house, to give up a living, and to go back to university at age of 26 took a lot of soul-searching. About a year, in fact: but after a long time, with no bolts of lightning, I decided on the health care field and the humanitarian field. I felt it was somewhere that I could make a difference."

It doesn't sound like being a civil servant, but he loves it. "I came into the department as a health expert, but I branched out very quickly into the general humanitarian field. I like the view here."

He still rushes round the world: two trips already this year, and nine last year. the head of the whole department, Makesh Kapila, is in East Timor at the moment. The workload, he thinks, can only get steadily worse as the world gets more crowded.

"All the projections show that the numbers continue to grow," he says. Though earthquakes and typhoons are no more common than they used to be, they are far more destructive, he adds, as a result of mass urbanisation, and the exploitation of more and more marginal habitats.

I leave him hunched over a phone, trying to find some helicopters to hire.

webTitle: Priest and mother of seven set up home

fields.headline: Priest and mother of seven set up home
fields.standfirst: Catholic church in Ireland beset by another celibacy scandal
fields.trailText: In the porch of St Anne's Church in Sligo, Co Mayo, there are a myriad of notices - for Alcoholics Anonymous, Alzheimer's help groups and organisations helping those with family members in jail. One, though, immediately catches the eye, advertising Accorn, the Catholic marriage guidance agency.
fields.body:
In the porch of St Anne's Church in Sligo, Co Mayo, there are a myriad of notices - for Alcoholics Anonymous, Alzheimer's help groups and organisations helping those with family members in jail. One, though, immediately catches the eye, advertising Accorn, the Catholic marriage guidance agency.

Another reveals the church's latest accounts. It shows wages for three priests and other staff came to Ir£47,406.28 last year, approximately £39,500. It is now saving on one of those salaries.

Father Sean Page, 41, walked out just over a month ago. He has now set up home with Marie Leydon, a married mother of seven, setting tongues wagging in the west of Ireland town and alarm bells ringing at Catholic church headquarters in Dublin.

They are no Richard Chamberlain or Rachel Ward, handsome stars of the television adaption of Colleen McCullough's ecclesiastical love story, The Thorn Birds.

They now live in a grim council estate rather than on the wide expanses of the fictional Drogheda, Australia-style. Their tale, though, is true.

It is the biggest such controversy to hit the Catholic hierarchy in Ireland since Bishop Eamonn Casey fled to south America after it was revealed he had fathered a child in 1973 to an American divorcee, Annie Murphy.

He is now believed to be living in England.

Father Page will say mass for the first time in six weeks at a special service at the Southern Hotel in Sligo tomorrow. With him will be renegade Bishop Pat Buckley, whose liberal views have put him on collision course with his former paymasters.

Father Page says: "This is no crusade against the Catholic church. But I spent 10 years in training and 10 more at St Anne's. It would be wrong to walk away from all of that."

Sligo is bitterly divided. Some people come up to Father Page, shake his hand, and wish him well.

One man calls at the door to ask some pastoral advice, prefering that to going to St Anne's.

Many disapprove of the relationship. But others are instead angry about the way he quit the church, outlining his case in interviews with the Irish media rather than explaining from the pulpit.

The Catholic church rejects suggestions that the episode cuts to the core of the celibacy debate, now seen as the biggest single barrier to attracting new recruits. It said yesterday: "It is his decision. There is nothing that can be done now about it."

Bishop Buckley believes there are scores of priests engaged in clandestine sexual relationships and more still who quit, unable to obey their celibacy vows. The difference is they depart quietly.

But Father Page is happy to receive visitors at the three-bedroom home he now shares with Ms Leydon, 40, and her children, David, 13, Michelle 12, Niall, 11, Colm, nine, Brian, eight, Kenneth, six, and Diarmuid Sean, two. His calm life in the parochial house is gone forever, swapped for nappy changing, mass breakfast-making and struggling for the first time with laundry.

The children's father had split from Ms Leydon, now using her maiden name, when she was four weeks pregnant with her last child. She had known Father Page for nine years through St Anne's youth club, but the pair began to become close from June 1998 when he was counselling her over her marriage break-up.

He says: "I began coming round here more often than would be normal. It started off once a day, twice, and then three times. Everyone in the town got to know about it, but, although our feelings were developing, it was a platonic relationship back then.

"I came here for Christmas dinner rather than go to the bishop's. It was then we decided to make a go of it together."

His bishop, Christopher Jones, in late January issued Father Page with an ultimatum to choose. The couple immediately fled with the children to Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh, at the end of January. They say it was only then their relationship became physical.

They are now back in Sligo, waiting for the first dole cheque. The couple think they will receive about Ir£200 a week, and Father Page is learning the value of money for the first time.

"I used to get Ir£610 in my pocket each month, though my lodgings and food was all paid for. £30 would do me all week. Now it is all gone after buying three bags of shopping."

Father Page, who peppers his speech with language more typically associated with blue collar workers, says his feelings changed when the youngest son started to call him daddy. He says: "You don't want to feck about with a young boy's feelings."

His relationship, he admits, is in part about conquering the loneliness, which he used to suppress through heavy drinking. He came off the booze two years ago, and sees his relationship with his new partner and the children as a package.

He believes celibacy places a terrible burden on priests. He thinks it makes it impossible for them properly to advise on many issues.

The couple plan to marry in a civil ceremony when Ms Leydon's divorce comes through this year. She said: "We should have met 20 years ago. He is an amazing man, and we are both truly happy for the first time. I doubt if anyone will give two hoots about this in a few months' time."

The children's father had split from Ms Leydon, now using her maiden name, when she was four weeks pregnant with her last child. She had known Father Page for nine years through St Anne's youth club, but the pair began to become close from June 1998 when he was counselling her over her marriage break-up. He says: "I began coming round here more often than would be normal. It started off once a day, twice, and then three times. Everyone in the town got to know about it, but, although our feelings were developing, it was a platonic relationship back then. "I came here for Christmas dinner rather than go to the bishop's. The couple immediately fled with the children to Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh, at the end of January. They say it was only then their relationship became physical. They are now back in Sligo, waiting for the first dole cheque. The couple think they will receive about Ir£200 a week, and Father Page is learning the value of money for the first time. He thinks it makes it impossible for them properly to advise on many issues. The couple plan to marry in a civil ceremony when Ms Leydon's divorce comes through this year. She said: "We should have met 20 years ago. He is an amazing man, and we are both truly happy for the first time. I doubt if anyone will give two hoots about this in a few months' time."

webTitle: Council tests postal voting to lift turnout

fields.headline: Council tests postal voting to lift turnout
fields.trailText: Britain's first entirely postal election will be held in a local government experiment in May designed to raise abysmal levels of voting in a council denounced as a Labour "rotten borough".
fields.body:
Britain's first entirely postal election will be held in a local government experiment in May designed to raise abysmal levels of voting in a council denounced as a Labour "rotten borough".

In the Conisbrough ward of Doncaster, South Yorkshire, 10,900 households will be asked to update the electoral register this month and then vote exclusively by post.

Voters will be sent ballot papers at least 10 days before the election, with a letter requiring signatures from themselves and a witness to deter fraud. The ballot will come with two pre-paid envelopes to ensure that the vote itself remains secret.

The experiment has been approved by the home office and all main political parties as one of a number of pilot schemes sanctioned by the representation of the people bill, which is due to get final parliamentary approval before May. It follows an initiative to change voting at a Conisbrough byelection in November from the customary Thursday to a weekend, which fell foul of previous legislation.

In spite of a barrister's opinion that the law banning weekend voting was worth testing, Doncaster altered the vote to a Friday - and turnout dropped from the low twenties to 16%.

The seat was held by Labour, whose previous councillor triggered the byelection when he was one of the Doncaster members jailed for expenses fraud.

Reformers in Doncaster have qualms about the postal pilot because of security concerns and the problems of monitoring thousands of voters' and witnesses' signatures.

Former Labour councillor Ron Rose, chief whistleblower over the "Donnygate" scandal which led to the expenses charges and a continuing inquiry into other alleged corruption, said yesterday: "Organising mass witness statements would be very easy to do and regrettably is in the tradition of groups in Doncaster in the past which effectively decided local council policy."

Mr Rose, a playwright working on a TV series based on the Donnygate scandal, said all-postal voting was easier to manipulate than the polling station system. "I can well imagine the sort of vote organising which could go on round here if, for instance, a candidate became known for having pro-abortion views."

Councillor Bev Marshall, chairman of Doncaster's corporate services panel, said: "I hope the people of Conisbrough will take up the challenge and prove to the rest of the country that an all-postal ballot will be a success."

fields.headline: Supergrasses
fields.standfirst: Failed cases put question mark over worth of their evidence
fields.trailText: McGuinness and Garner
fields.body:
McGuinness and Garner

Detective constables Terry McGuinness, 41, and Kevin Garner, 39, were partners in corruption throughout their posting to the flying squad at Rigg Approach, east London, from 1990 to 1998.

When caught in a CIB sting operation called Brunei in December 1997 both men decided to "roll over". They alleged widespread corruption among officers at Rigg, leading to Operation Ethiopia.

Almost a year after his arrest McGuinness pleaded guilty to 14 offences including conspiracy to steal and perverting the course of justice. He has not been sentenced.

The two detectives implicated themselves and others in the theft of £300,000 which the Flying Squad had recovered from armed robbers. The pair were in a good position to benefit corruptly. Garner was the court liaison officer responsible for putting prosecution papers together while McGuinness was responsible for keeping the money secure.

However, the officers implicated by the two supergrasses were cleared last December after a long CIB investigation. This and the crime prosecution service's decision not to proceed against 80 Flying Squad officers named by the men has put a big question mark over their value as witnesses.

Garner will be sentenced after giving evidence against several colleagues in a forthcoming trial. He pleaded guilty to 12 counts of corruption in September 1998.

The CPS has set up a team to re-examine cases handled by convicted corrupt officers. Abraham Shakes, in whose case Garner was the principal prosecution witness, had his conviction for conspiracy to commit armed robbery quashed last April.

Neil Putnam

Putnam, a detective constable on the south-east London regional crime squad, was arrested in July 1998. He came under surveillance when a drug trafficker, criminally and sexually involved with a colleague, blew the whistle in the hope of reducing a 15-year sentence.

Putnam, 42, decided to "roll over" and was debriefed by CIB over four months. He admitted 16 offences including conspiracy to supply cannabis and opium and perverting the course of justice.

Putnam's prison diarylaims CIB officers took him out for hill walks, shopping trips to Tesco and even allowed him to test drive an Alpha Romeo.

CIB told the Guardian Putnam received no financial inducements except what he was entitled to. He was sentenced last month to just under four years after pleading guilty and giving evidence against two colleagues. The court was told that Putnam was a supergrass "worth his weight in gold" because he had given information voluntarily - otherwise he would not have been caught. The judge said witnesses would have led CIB to Putnam anyway.

webTitle: Sir Stan - a hero passes into folklore

fields.headline: Sir Stan - a hero passes into folklore
fields.standfirst: Fans pack Stoke to mourn the passing of Stanley Matthews and his era of sporting purity
fields.trailText: Sir Stanley Matthews, the Pied Piper of English football, worked his magic one last time yesterday when his light, deft winger's body returned in state to his beloved and adoring cluster of towns in the Potteries. One hundred thousand people sent off England's best ambassador.
fields.body:
Sir Stanley Matthews, the Pied Piper of English football, worked his magic one last time yesterday when his light, deft winger's body returned in state to his beloved and adoring cluster of towns in the Potteries. His memory conjured 100,000 people - last night's official Staffordshire police count - of all ages onto the streets despite a wet, cramping wind for a funeral parade fit for a Victorian monarch. And all this for a prodigy whose prime 50 years ago, as his soccer colleague Jimmy Hill said in wonder, is known to young people only from scratchy old newsreels.

An estimated 10,000 were at Stoke City's Britannia stadium, another 20,000 in or outside St Peter's church, where his quick spirit was laid to rest, with his great fellow players Nat Lofthouse, Sir Tom Finney, Sir Bobby Charlton and Gordon Banks among his pallbearers.

Others lined pavements often 10ft to 12ft deep and mounted the roofs of department stores along the 14-mile route as the cortege passed places dear to him in the six Potteries towns: Longton, Fenton, Hanley, Burslem, Tunstall and Stoke itself.

In one of the drabber parts of Stoke, miles from the official route, someone had tied a bouquet to a wire fence with a card saying "Stan the Man, Rest in Peace - from an Evertonian".

Hundreds more bouquets were more conspicuously left outside the front door of Britannia stadium, although his family had asked for no flowers. Along the two-mile road to the ground, Sir Stanley Matthews Way, red and white shirts and scarves in the Stoke colours were wrapped round lamp posts and pavement bollards like heraldic banners in a mediaeval court.

The note of wonder and informality continued in church, where the first hymn listed was And Did Those Feet?, usually called Blake's Jerusalem, and the second, chosen by Matthews' family, was Lord of the Dance. Many of the 300 fans who were given a third of the church seats draped Stoke City scarves over their gallery balcony.

But the watchword of the day was respect. Cheers began in a few throats and a few fists punched the air. But these gestures were choked off by the collective mood of the crowds.

Instead, there was applause. It started in the cortege's journey of honour through the three-year-old, £14.7m stadium, on an exposed hill above the towns. Hands were at first too cold to clap loudly or without pain.

But they persisted and warmed into the first of a series of great, solemn, minutes-long ovations of respect which were repeated wherever the motorcade travelled on its 75-minute tour.

Accessible magic

Noticeably, they were as warm for the cars carrying members of Matthews' family as for the leading hearse, decked with red roses and white carnations in the shape of a football jumper carrying the number seven, his playing position.

As the rector of Stoke, Canon Edgar Ruddock, said in St Peter's, the day marked "the passing of a hero into the folklore and mythology of Stoke City, Port Vale, Blackpool - and through them into the worldwide community of sport".

It also marked the passing of a different kind of England, one which was thought to have been almost forgotten long before he died, a country in which modesty was respected or worshipped almost as much as popular virtuosity.

Matthews was a hero of 1940s and 1950s children's cigarette cards and comic books as well as newsreels. He was the real-life counterpart of Wilson the Wonder Man who - long before Roger Bannister - once ran a mile in a still unbeaten 3min 43sec, wearing a black, long-sleeved Victorian bathing costume. Matthews' wizard dribbles were viewed as almost as remarkable.

But his was a more accessible magic. Anyone could grow up to be like him if they trained very hard, went to bed at 9pm and never got big-headed. His fitness was again drummed in by yesterday's speeches.

"I never once saw him out of breath in the football field", said the former England player Jimmy Armfield. Peter Coates, ex-Stoke City chairman, said: "He never criticised the modern game. He never said players weren't as good as in his day."

His world has been dismissed to the remote past. But yesterday among the street crowds and at Britannia stadium there was a sense even among younger fans that its virtues ought to be brought back.

Duncan Bagnall, a 35-year-old local government worker, said: "It seems like something's gone now. He embodied something that was perfect. Later people like Gary Linker have tried to do it but never quite managed it".

Yesterday's turnout was not only for the wizard of dribble, or Der Zauberer (the sorcerer) as German players called him, but for a local hero who was given his nickname by Keele students in a song they wrote after his 1965 knighthood: "You've heard of Greaves and Puskas and Pele from Brazil/But Stanley Matthews of the Potts is the greatest of them all."

And so his funeral procession, looping and dog-legging through the small brick streets and ring roads of the modern Pot teries, took in not only his statue, where spectators stood with bowed heads as the hearse passed, but his primary school and his birthplace in Seymour Street, Hanley.

The house stands only just over half a mile from the birthplace of Arnold Bennett, novelist of five of the towns. Bennett, influenced by sombre French realists, said: "Pessimism -when you get used to it - is just as agreeable as optimism."

Matthews' feet spoke for the more gladsome side of Stoke, which gave him back full-hearted gratitude at his funeral. "The ball ran for me," he used to say after a good match. As it did, for him and for his kind, on one final farewell day yesterday.
