webTitle: Internal inquiries that would haunt police

fields.headline: Internal inquiries that would haunt police
fields.standfirst: Ghost Squad:  Findings may have led Condon to overestimate criminality
fields.trailText: The Ghost Squad began in early 1994 as an intelligence cell set up in strange circumstances. Inspector Dave Woods told his colleagues he had cancer of the throat and would be retiring from the CID, the Met's 3,000-strong pool of specialist detectives.
fields.body:
The Ghost Squad began in early 1994 as an intelligence cell set up in strange circumstances. Inspector Dave Woods told his colleagues he had cancer of the throat and would be retiring from the CID, the Met's 3,000-strong pool of specialist detectives.

In a small world fuelled by rumour and rivalry, word soon spread that "Woods was going to die". His unwitting colleagues had a whip round for him unaware that this was a cover story developed by the Yard's intelligence chiefs.

Since 1992 Inspector Woods had been working on a covert operation called Fantasy, targeting organised criminals in London's East End. Insp Woods ran the cell which gathered and processed intelligence from two other secret operations, code-named Fairway and Frantic.

SO10, the Met's undercover unit, had helped to set up a covert pub venture in Canning Town, the Durham Arms, as part of Operation Frantic. The Durham Arms was a notorious villains' pub where guns were marketed and international drugs deal worked out, and the Met jumped at the chance to take it over when a brewery put the pub on the market.

The pub was staffed with two undercover officers and, according to one police officer who worked there, hidden microphones were placed on the tables and bar and a camera fitted in the dart board. But when the juke box was playing it rendered the microphones inaudible, the source said.

The Met's bugging unit, TSU, had also inserted probes into the business premises of a local crime family, the Sabinis, and set up listening posts in a council estate opposite. This was Operation Fairway.

The three operation were said to have cost over £3m but achieved few far reaching results - except one. Bugging devices had picked up gangsters talking about police officers they claimed to control, a senior retired police source said.

According to this officer, the names of these policemen were kept in a top secret file marked "police corruption", accessible only by Inspector Woods and his superior, Chief Superintendent Tom Williamson.

They took the file to John Grieve, then director of intelligence at Scotland Yard, and his deputy, Roy Clark. The intelligence chiefs helped to develop the cover story that Inspector Woods had retired with cancer. In reality he was promoted to chief inspector within CIB, the Met's anti-corruption branch, and given another even more secret mission.

Inspector Woods was to take a small team of officers to the old cadet centre at Wanstead, north-east London, and set up an intelligence cell, or Ghost Squad, dedicated to spying on officers named in the secret file.

Police corruption was already a hot political issue for the Met by the time the secret dossier landed on John Grieve's desk in early 1994. First there was an on-going drug corruption inquiry into officers at Stoke Newington police station in north London. The Yard was also struggling to deal with the growing campaign against police racism and allegations of a cover-up led by the parents of Stephen Lawrence, who had been murdered in April 1993. Suggestions had also surfaced of a corrupt link between the police and south-east London drug traffickers.

The Ghost squad was authorised by the Met commissioner, Sir Paul Condon, on the basis of a "strictly confidential" strategy document which the Yard will not release.

Sir Paul's anti-corruption campaign, with the Lawrence inquiry, would haunt his office for the next six years. But he stressed the need to "wear the short term damage" rather than turn a blind eye while the problem got worse.

The Ghost Squad targeted the entire Surbiton regional crime squad, where the corrupt officer John Donald was based. It is also believed that intelligence picked up during Operation Fairway led to the targeting of Flying Squad officers covering east London.

From 1994 to 1996 the Ghost Squad used covert techniques to spy on suspected CID officers in the front line against organised crime - those considered most vulnerable to crossing the line. "Woods worked on the principle that knowledge is power" and built a secretive empire using civilians and ex-military personnel, a former member of CIB told the Guardian. However, when he handed over control of the intelligence cell to Supt David Bailey in 1996 it was in chaos because of excessive secretiveness and poor communications, the source said.

The same source said another elite covert unit was set up as the operational arm of the intelligence cell. This unit acted as a surveillance team, developed sting operations and also tried to infiltrate undercover officers into specialist squads where detectives came into contact with large amounts of drugs and cash.

These undercover officers do not appear to have succeeded in gathering admissible evidence leading to successful prosecutions. So far none has been called as witnesses in police corruption trials.

As the Ghost squad developed it compiled a secret list of suspected officers, a former CIB officer said. The commissioner had asked his intelligence chiefs to "scope" the extent of corruption back in 1993. So when Sir Paul Condon told the home affairs select committee in December 1997 that there were up to 250 corrupt officers in the Met it is believed he was referring to this uncorroborated intelligence list.

The Met says its anti-corruption drive was "intelligence driven". But senior serving and retired officers interviewed by the Guardian point out that "intelligence is not evidence" and therefore should be critically evaluated by people who know the difference, and properly corroborated before irrevocable actions are taken.

The commissioner's estimate has since become a "stick to beat him with", say CIB chiefs, who quickly moved to play down the numbers.

CIB deny there was ever a "score sheet", or that arrests were made to justify the commissioner's "speculation" in the Commons. But senior officers have told the Guardian of a secret blacklist of about 200 "untrustworthy officers". Developed out of the Ghost Squad's intelligence work, the list has been in operation for several years, they say.

CIB denied there was such a list but told the Guardian it is developing a policy to inform officers applying for sensitive postings of "doubts about their integrity".

This unit acted as a surveillance team, developed sting operations and also tried to infiltrate undercover officers into specialist squads where detectives came into contact with large amounts of drugs and cash. These undercover officers do not appear to have succeeded in gathering admissible evidence leading to successful prosecutions. So far none has been called as witnesses in police corruption trials. As the Ghost squad developed it compiled a secret list of suspected officers, a former CIB officer said. The commissioner had asked his intelligence chiefs to "scope" the extent of corruption back in 1993. So when Sir Paul Condon told the home affairs select committee in December 1997 that there were up to 250 corrupt officers in the Met it is believed he was referring to this uncorroborated intelligence list. But senior serving and retired officers interviewed by the Guardian point out that "intelligence is not evidence" and therefore should be critically evaluated by people who know the difference, and properly corroborated before irrevocable actions are taken. But senior officers have told the Guardian of a secret blacklist of about 200 "untrustworthy officers". webTitle: Murdoch's £40m stake in Chelsea takes football club collection to five

fields.headline: Murdoch's £40m stake in Chelsea takes football club collection to five
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch's influence over English football grew further yesterday when British Sky Broadcasting spent £40m on a 9.9% stake in the parent company of Chelsea FC.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's influence over English football grew further yesterday when British Sky Broadcasting spent £40m on a 9.9% stake in the parent company of Chelsea FC.

The acquisition gives BSkyB the right to act as exclusive media agent to the London club for the next five years and adds to a trophy cabinet that already includes shares in Leeds United, Sunderland, Manchester United and Manchester City.

Importantly the deal comes just weeks ahead of the auction for the broadcast rights of the Premier League which is expected to result in a £1bn haul for football's top flight. Rights to Premiership games will be negotiated centrally but the acquisition of another stake is bound to raise questions over what say BSkyB will have behind the scenes.

The media landscape has altered significantly since 1996 when BSkyB paid £670m to screen live Premiership games and the company now faces much fiercer competition. Mr Murdoch, who owns a controlling 40% of BSkyB, once de scribed sport as the "battering ram" for broadcasters to break into new markets and recent arrivals such as ONdigital and cable companies.

Rivals have also been buying up stakes in football clubs. Granada owns a 9.9% stake in Liverpool and NTL, a New York-based business which is now the biggest cable company, owns 9.9% in Aston Villa and Newcastle.

BSkyB's deal with Chelsea includes the formation of a joint venture to develop a Chelsea interactive television channel likely to offer lucrative pay-per-view games and internet business with 70% of revenues going back to the club and the rest to the media group.

A spokesman for BSkyB said the club was attractive because of its strong fan base and added that no other deals with football clubs were in the pipeline.

Chelsea chairman Ken Bates said the club had been approached by a number of potential media investors in the past two years but viewed BSkyB's as the best offer. "This represents another milestone along the road to Chelsea becoming an enduring force in European football," he said.

The deal values Chelsea at around £400m, making it the second most valuable club in Britain behind Manchester United.

It is unclear how much of the cash will end up on the field. The finance director, Michael Russell, said much of the cash injection would be used to improve the club's Stamford Bridge stadium. "I would imagine that quite a lot of the money will be spent on completing the west stand development. I would think it will need in the region of £20m to £25m for the west stand and north-east corner infills which would raise the capacity to around 42,000."

BSkyB last year saw its at tempt to buy Manchester United for £623m blocked by the monopolies and mergers commission, causing a shift in strategy to snapping up smaller stakes in other clubs.

Under current Premier League rules, no single investor can hold more than 10% in more than one club and a spokesman said concerns would be raised if any individual investor took stakes in more than six clubs. Collective decisions in the Premier League need a two-thirds majority - which means that seven clubs would be needed to block any vote.

"We do monitor these sorts of developments. The Premier League rulebook is very robust on this. It isn't just about limiting multiple stakes to below 10%. In the rule book there is provision for the Premier League to intervene if it believes there are any signs of undue influence between clubs. Our view is that there is no need for any direct intervention at this stage."

BSkyB has been careful to dampen controversy by not seeking representation on the Chelsea board.

Manchester City

Sunderland

Chelsea

fields.headline: Officers tell of lives destroyed
fields.standfirst: The targets: Detectives investigated for six years
fields.trailText: Detective Inspector John Redgrave and Detective Constable Michael Charman, two experienced Met detectives, never thought their involvement in Operation Nightshade would destroy their careers.
fields.byline: Michael Sean Gillard and Laurie Flynn. Additional research by Laura Milne
fields.body:
Detective Inspector John Redgrave and Detective Constable Michael Charman, two experienced Met detectives, never thought their involvement in Operation Nightshade would destroy their careers.

They have been under investigation for six years, three of them secretly, and suspended for three. This is despite the original allegations against them being withdrawn in January 1997, before their houses were raided and they were suspended. Last December they were cleared of all criminal proceedings, but they remain suspended.

"I have been suspended in relation to a complaint that is six years old.This has caused the complete destruction of every aspect of my personal and professional life, friends, finanacial security, family, marriage, career and reputation," Redgrave said. "The building blocks of life have all gone with no hope of recovery."

Nightshade was an Anglo-American police sting across three continents. It had three lines of inquiry - a cocaine shipment from Venezuela to the UK, a money laundering scam and an illegal arms deal.

Nightshade started in June 1993 from information provided by a Kent businessman Geoffrey Brennan, who had unusual contacts with some notorious south-east London gangsters. Brennan became an informant for the Met and was handled by Charman.

Brennan was then contacted by a group of Texas-based criminals who boasted of high political connections. They involved him in the money laundering scam and asked if he could find a buyer for arms worth millions of dollars.

Brennan was authorised to introduce two British undercover officers posing as representatives of Protestant terrorists from Northern Ireland. After bugging meetings in London and Houston, Red grave's team had strong evidence against the gang. They were taped saying the weapons would be stolen from an army base in the US and shipped to Ireland via Sierra Leone.

But at a delicate point in the arms negotiations Nightshade began to fall apart. In August 1993, two months into the sting, Brennan was charged with the theft of £400,000. This money had been deposited in his business account by the Texan gang as part of their money laundering scam.

Police documents seen by the Guardian show the arms dealers continued to do business with the undercover officers, faxing them price lists and equipment details. The documents also show that Redgrave and his American counterparts were close to arresting the Texan gang.

But in late 1994, with negotiations almost finalised, the gang suddenly backed off and Nightshade, which had cost millions of pounds, collapsed with no arrests.

Redgrave and Charman went on to other Met operations against organised crime. They believed that Brennan, the informant, was still under investigation for the theft. In fact it was the two detectives who were under investigation.

In June 1994, while Redgrave was still trying to arrest the arms dealers, Brennan began a series of secret meetings with Superintendent Roger Gaspar, head of the Met's complaints investigation branch (CIB), the anti-corruption squad.

Gaspar was also in charge of a highly secret intelligence cell - dubbed the Ghost Squad - which had begun looking at police officers suspected of major corruption. He taped an interview with Brennan over two days while CIB kept him in hiding. In the transcripts seen by the Guardian Brennan admits stealing £400,000 during Nightshade and claims he also bunged Redgrave and Charman £50,000 to turn a blind eye.

Brennan was introduced to CIB by Detective Sergeant Chris Smith of the Flying Squad. Brennan had been an informant registered to him for 20 years before Operation Nightshade began.

As a result of Brennan's allegations, the Ghost Squad targeted Redgrave and Charman using covert surveillance and bugging. This CIB operation was called Cornwall.

CIB had plans to turn Brennan into its first supergrass in the anti-corruption crusade. Brennan and his family were put into a witness protection programme with new identities. The theft charges were quietly dropped.

For two-and-a-half years from June 1994 to early 1997 the Ghost Squad secretly monitored every move and financial transaction by Redgrave and Charman.

Redgrave, 46, had joined the Met in 1970. One commanding officer remarked in an early appraisal: "When [Redgrave] leaves the division many an east end criminal will breathe a sigh of relief." Charman, 47 had joined when he was 19. One of his senior commanders who spoke to the Guardian considers him to be an honest cop who was "always first through the door".

The Ghost Squad allowed Redgrave and Charman to carry out difficult operations with access to very sensitive material and large sums of money, hoping to catch them in the act.

Both detectives received outstanding reports from their line managers. One on Redgrave noted that "his one desire in life was to arrest and convict major criminals within the law and by ethical means". There were also commendations from senior Scotland Yard commanders.

One of the most bemusing aspects of the affair came in 1996 when the Ghost Squad watched John Redgrave receive a long service and good conduct medal from the then Met Commissioner, Sir Paul Condon, the man who had set up its secret operation.

Meanwhile, by August that year, Brennan was completing his second year in CIB's witness protection programme. In September 1996 he was passed to a new CIB controller, Superintendent Dave Bailey, recently appointed head of the Ghost Squad.

The Guardian has spoken extensively to Brennan about what happened after this changeover. He was re-arrested for the original theft allegations.

Soon after this, Brennan tried to extricate himself by contacting Charman for the first time in over two years. Brennan told Charman that he and his partner had been the targets of a CIB corruption investigation since June 1994. He also gave Charman an extract of a secret tape recording he had made of his conversation with Bailey.

Brennan's visit set off a chain of events that was to rock CIB to its core. Shocked at what they had heard, Charman and Redgrave informed their superiors who advised them to write a report to the overall head of CIB, Deputy Assistant Commissioner Roy Clark, and Met commanders. Between November 1996 and January 1997 they wrote six reports. The reports, seen by the Guardian, summarised Brennan's explosive claims about the Bailey tape and included a partial transcript.

According to the detectives, Clark did not respond to any of their reports. But undoubtedly CIB now knew that the existence of the Ghost Squad and its methods had been exposed to two of its principal targets.

Then on January 29 1997, the deputy chairman of the police complaints authority, John Cartwright, received a letter from Brennan. In the letter, obtained by the Guardian, Brennan withdrew the allegations against Redgrave and Charman which he had made almost 28 months earlier.

Brennan told the PCA his interview with CIB in June 1994 was "evidentially worthless" and contained "false allegations" against the detectives.

He said Smith, his handler for 20 years, "moonlighted" with Brennan doing private security work and enlisted three other named, serving, officers to work with him for money.

Brennan reaffirmed his statements in the withdrawal letter when interviewed this week by the Guardian. He alleges that Smith "rehearsed" him for the taped interview with CIB.

Smith later told a court that Brennan was motivated by malice and was hostile towards him after he was rearrested for the theft in late 1996.

Brennan's letter to the PCA was received on the same day by CIB. But seven days later, on February 4 1997, CIB still arrested and suspended Redgrave and Charman on the basis of allegations it knew had been withdrawn. Correspondence in the Guardian's possession shows that for almost two years CIB and the PCA insisted to lawyers representing the detectives that there had been no withdrawal of the complaint by Brennan.

CIB admitted to the Guardian that it received the withdrawal letter from Brennan seven days before it raided the detectives' homes.

CIB investigated Smith after he was exposed in the trial of an armed robber at the Old Bailey in February 1998 for lying on oath about his relationship with Brennan. CIB officers escorted Smith to court during the five day cross-examination and witnessed his evidence at first hand. Smith told the judge his relationship with Brennan was part of a "very secret inquiry" and he had acted with the knowledge of the former head of the Ghost Squad, Gaspar, now the director of the national criminal intelligence service.

Fifteen months after Brennan made his allegations against Smith, CIB interviewed the officer under caution. The transcript, seen by the Guardian, shows he admitted receiving money for moonlighting through Brennan and by implication confessed to misleading the court.

The Guardian has learned that in September 1996, when Smith officially "retired" from the Met, a rumour was already doing the rounds of the private security business. Three company directors, all former policemen, told the Guardian they were warned not to do business with a company Smith had set up called Esher Investigations. They were told it was an undercover CIB operation designed to catch ex-policemen paying for illegal police computer checks.

CIB would not comment on whether Smith was one of its covert officers. In a statement it said Smith was told in July 1999 there was "insufficient evidence to provide a realistic prospect of conviction for any criminal offences".

In 1985 Charman and his inspector at the time formally reported Smith over his allegedly "corrupt relationship" with Brennan. Smith denied that his relationship with Brennan was corrupt.

Approached at home, Smith refused to discuss this, Brennan or Nightshade but he did deny working for CIB.

CIB told the Guardian that Bailey was under investigation in relation to allegations by Brennan. But the Guardian has learned from a former CIB source that Bailey was not suspended or investigated when the allegations were made against him.

According to the source, Bailey left the Ghost Squad and went to work for the security service MI5, where he still is. CIB itself is the subject of an internal investigation over allegations from Redgrave and Charman that it tried to "entrap" them in an unsuccessful operation mounted after the collapse of Operation Cornwall.

The case was thrown out last May by a magistrate after a brief committal hearing. A judge threw out CIB's attempt to overturn this decision.

Finally, last December, after almost six years of investigation, CIB told Redgrave and Charman they would not face criminal charges over the original corruption allegations. They are still suspended and face one disciplinary charge which they say has no foundation.

Redgrave's MP, Andrew Mackinlay, has written to the PCA and Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens, describing the affair as "a very unsavoury can of worms". CIB refuses to disclose how many millions of pounds Operation Cornwall cost the public but claims its investigation was "even handed".

fields.headline: Stings
fields.standfirst: Flaws undermine CIB's covert operations against officers
fields.trailText: Keith Pedder
fields.body:
Keith Pedder

Former detective Keith Pedder was acquitted last September of conspiring to corrupt a police officer. The evidence had been obtained by entrapment.

In his complaint to the Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens, Pedder said he was set up by CIB to prevent publication of his book critical of senior officers' conduct.

CIB denies there was a hidden agenda but CIB commander Andy Hayman agreed the judge was "justified in his criticism". Last November Sir John gave the investigation to an outside force.

Pedder has named officers, some inside CIB, who are the subject of official complaints but have not been investigated.

Redgrave and Charman

In May 1999 suspended detectives John Redgrave and Michael Charman complained about the Met and CIB after a failed "entrapment" operation which a stipendiary magistrate later refused to commit to trial.

CIB gave Charman's girlfriend an unsolicited police document in a sealed envelope which she took home. CIB had bugged her work and home telephones. They raided the house when the suspended officers were shown the document in passing. All three were charged for conspiracy to pervert the course of justice and breaches of the official secrets act.

Deputy assistant commissioner Andrew Trotter is investigating whether the operation was "unlawful and malicious" and if CIB conspired to pervert the course of justice by withholding evidence during the committal.

The officers were cleared of wider corruption allegations last December.

Keith Green

Former detective Keith Green was acquitted in December 1998 after Operation Brunei. The CIB drugs sting did net two corrupt Flying Squad detectives turned supergrasses, Terry McGuinness and Kevin Garner.

The jury believed Green, 42, was doing a former colleague a favour and was unaware there were drugs in parcels he had been asked to collect.

Green's solicitors alleged "intimidatory behaviour" was used to press Green to become a supergrass.

John Bull

Operation Nectarine, a joint CIB and Kent police case against Detective Superintendent John Bull and seven others for conspiracy to supply £12m of cannabis, was thrown out by Judge Harvey Crush at Maidstone crown court last month.

A drug trafficker had turned supergrass and implicated Mr Bull. But Judge Crush identified six flaws in Operation Nectarine:

A "strong suggestion of financial inducements".

"Wholesale breaches" of laws governing trial conduct and evidence preparation.

Failure to record and retain crucial material was "symptomatic of the culture of non-disclosure and non-compliance".

1,700 pages of "highly significant" police and CIB documents were not at first disclosed despite judges' orders.

Failure to tape record all meetings with the supergrass.

"Oppressive behaviour" and "pressure" when debriefing the supergrass.

fields.headline: Corruption squad under fire
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police's much vaunted anti-corruption drive, which has been under way for six years, is now itself the subject of three inquiries because of allegations over the way it operates, an investigation by the Guardian has revealed.
fields.byline: Michael Sean Gillard and  Laurie Flynn
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police's much vaunted anti-corruption drive, which has been under way for six years, is now itself the subject of three inquiries because of allegations over the way it operates, an investigation by the Guardian has revealed.

The inquiries into the complaints investigation branch (CIB), two of them internal and one by an outside force, have been prompted by complaints that the anti-corruption squad, dubbed the Untouchables, used discredited methods to pursue serving and former officers.

They include entrapment operations; inducements to supergrasses; non-disclosure to the defence of vital documents in court cases; widespread breaches of laws regulating police evidence-gathering procedures; and double standards in the handling of complaints.

One solicitor involved in a recently collapsed trial said aspects of the CIB strategy reflected a return to discredited policing methods prevalent in the 1960s and 1970s.

Commander Andy Hayman, director of the CIB, said it was not able to sustain the current effort and was reassessing its methods.

In a briefing earlier this week, Scotland Yard said 75 people had been charged with corruption offences, including 26 serving police officers and 11 former officers. Of the 26 serving officers, there have been five convictions and one acquittal, and one is awaiting sentence.

The Yard said 70 serving officers had been suspended. What they did not reveal was that the CIB has secured only seven convictions for major corruption in six years. And of those seven, four are of supergrasses - three of them serving police officers who have turned on their former colleagues, and the other a retired detective.

Four high-profile court cases have collapsed, and the crown prosecution service has decided not to proceed against more than 80 serving officers - the majority of them named by the supergrasses.

Of the 70 officers still suspended, more than two-thirds have not been charged and a significant number, which the Yard will not disclose, have already been cleared internally of any criminal activity.

The results are very different to those envisaged in 1994, when the anti-corruption drive was launched amid great secrecy by the then Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir Paul Condon.

In a dramatic flourish, he pledged there would be "no hiding place" for corrupt, dishonest or unethical police officers. In 1997 he told a Commons select committee his intelligence chiefs had identified up to 250 "bent coppers", mainly in specialist squads.

But the Guardian has learned that as well as an apparent failure to catch and convict corrupt officers on the scale promised, the CIB is being undermined from within - most obviously by its reliance on supergrasses.

Serving officers in the Met's organised crime group - the squads that target drug traffickers and armed robbers - said it was ironic that the CIB was relying so heavily on the old supergrass system which the rest of the Met had long since replaced with less problematic methods of evidence gathering, such as infiltration by undercover officers.

The CIB has always had a reputation for unconventional methods. Much of its operational strategy is driven by a secret intelligence unit, dubbed the "ghost squad".

Cmdr Hayman said: "We are operating within the criminal justice system but that is difficult because we are right at the cutting edge of policing."

He was keen to "push the parameters" of the system to be ahead of the officers being targeted. Cutting-edge methods used in the past include covert surveillance and bugging - inside homes, offices, squad cars and police stations.

In one case £500,000 of cannabis was planted in an east London flat, and word passed to two flying squad officers, who were then caught on video trying to steal the drugs. The pair were convicted and turned supergrass.

But even this case went partly wrong when a third officer, who was acquitted, then alleged he had been offered inducements, including a reduced sentence, a safe house, a new identity and financial help on release.

Sir John Stevens, who took over as the Met's commissioner last month, was made aware of the problems surrounding CIB tactics after a discreet lunch last November with Lady Emily Blatch, a conservative peer.

She told the Guardian she was concerned that the CIB was acting on the basis of "preordained guilt" to "meet targets". She told Sir John it was important "to root out corruption without bringing disrepute on the Met".

The CIB denies arrests were made to justify Sir Paul's "speculation" that there were up to 250 corrupt officers in the Met. But police sources said there is a secret blacklist of 200 officers, whom the CIB regards as "untrustworthy", compiled from intelligence gathered by the ghost squad.

fields.headline: Livingstone peddling lies says Dobson
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's war over its London mayoral nomination got personal yesterday as Frank Dobson accused Ken Livingstone of peddling lies and playing games.
fields.body:
Labour's war over its London mayoral nomination got personal yesterday as Frank Dobson accused Ken Livingstone of peddling lies and playing games.

He sought to capitalise on his BBC Question Time confrontation with an open letter ridiculing the Brent East MP as unable to decide whether to stand as an independent. Mr Livingstone responded by hoping "Frank will be feeling better soon" and declaring he would not descend to his "personal abuse".

Mr Dobson's assault followed Thursday night's television challenge to Mr Livingstone to "make my day" and announce he would stand, or withdraw. Yesterday Mr Dobson accused the former GLC leader of being "unable to make the simplest of decisions without weeks of game playing". Mr Livingstone's policies would "undermine the police, drive jobs out of London and saddle London with billions of debt", adding: "To listen to you and your friends, the police, rather than criminals, are the problem".

Mr Livingstone replied by insisting Mr Dobson debate whether Londoners should choose their own transport system, and whether they should only be allowed candidates "imposed on them by the centre". He would try "to persuade Labour in the time that remains to respect the clearly expressed wishes of Londoners".

Millbank is convinced it has the opinion poll favourite on the defensive and has high hopes of the Dobson launch on Monday, when Mr Livingstone will rally his campaign to force Mr Dobson to stand down.

webTitle: Rivals squabble as housing survey shows fall in prices

fields.headline: Rivals squabble as housing survey shows fall in prices
fields.trailText: House prices fell by the largest amount in a single month for almost six years in February, the Halifax said yesterday.
fields.body:
House prices fell by the largest amount in a single month for almost six years in February, the Halifax said yesterday.

The figures provide the first evidence that the property market may be beginning to slow down, with the Halifax saying that the price of the average UK property fell 0.9%, wiping £795 off its value. The findings surprised City analysts and provoked a row with the Nationwide building society, which earlier this week said house prices rose by a record amount last month.

Nationwide, which reported a 2.2% increase in February, said the Halifax's figures were "all over the place". But the Yorkshire-based lender fired back, saying Nationwide's figures had a "southern bias".

Both lenders use highly complex methodologies for calculating house price changes based on mortgages taken out with them, involving tracking the values of a typical "basket" of houses. They take a range of factors into account, from the purchase price and location to the number of toilets.

The squabbling will confuse many homeowners and buyers. According to the Halifax, the average house price is £84,449 compared with £85,244 a month ago. Group economist Martin Ellis said the fall, which followed two very strong rises in December and January, "may be an indication that the pace of house price growth is beginning to ease".

But he added it was highly unlikely to mark the beginning of a slide in prices and the end of the strongest surge since the property boom of the late 80s. The Halifax said its figures fitted in with Bank of England data this week, but they contradict a spate of other surveys that indicate the housing boom is accelerating, not slowing.

Nationwide said on Wednesday that the average home jumped in value by more than £2,000 last month to £77,072 - the biggest increase since it started compiling monthly data in 1991.

Asked to explain the fall, the biggest since May 1994, Mr Ellis said that possibly the market was not quite as strong as it was two or three months ago, adding: "We didn't think those rapid rates would be sustained."

While there was no regional breakdown, Mr Ellis said the north-south divide still remained. He said that both the Halifax and Nationwide estimated house prices were up 15% over the year, but added that his Swindon-based rival had "a southern bias".

webTitle: How to succeed in the guru business

fields.headline: How to succeed in the guru business
fields.standfirst: John Birt - the BBC's former 'Dalek in an Armani suit' - is to write a management manual. What does he know about it, asks  Stephen Overell
fields.trailText: John Birt - the BBC's former 'Dalek in an Armani suit' - is to write a management manual. What does he know about it, asks Stephen Overell
fields.body:
If it were not for the rumoured £250,000 advance, John Birt's announcement that he is to write a management book would be seen as last-gasp chest-puffing from a man who is unsure about his retirement. As it is, public amusement has turned to anger. How can he get away with it? Is this the Birt whose Armani "wardrobe expenses" provoked uproar, who turned the BBC into a nomenklatura of contract-enforcers?

"He could not be less well-qualified to be a management guru," one BBC staffer lamented. Such a view is based on a misunderstanding. A man's past has no bearing upon future success as a business guru. The two leading management gurus, Tom Peters and Michael Porter, started as a consultant and an academic; they have scarcely managed a soul in their lives, yet command £35,000 an hour lecture fees.

If the lucrative career of Tom Peters is anything to go by, John Birt's hunger to reinvent himself augurs well. Five years after Peters wrote In Search Of Excellence, the 1982 book that sold 5.5m copies, two thirds of the excellent companies in his case studies were facing ruin. But he bounced back with Thriving On Chaos, which said there were no excellent companies. He is still dominant today.

Chaos is what gurus are about. The expansion in the management theory industry since 1980 relies on uncertainty in work and business. Only a third of the 500 top companies of 1970 still exist today; some 44% of the male British workforce has been unemployed at some time since 1990.

Managers hope to find solutions in books like The Age Of Unreason (Charles Handy), The Change Masters (Rosabeth Moss Kanter) and Managing In A Time Of Great Change (Peter Drucker). US companies spent $21bn on external advice in 1999. McKinsey & Co, the best-known management consultancy in the world, published just two books between 1960 and 1980. Since 1980, it has turned out over 60. The average British company binges on 13.7 new management techniques in a year.

To be a guru is to enjoy a speed of influence on the real world that would be envied by scientists and sociologists. The biggest management technique of the 90s, business process re-engineering, was set off by a 1993 book, Re-engineering The Corporation, by James Champy and Michael Hammer, consultants at CSC Index. It sold 250,000 copies in its first three months.

The re-engineers advocated tearing up all the old rules about how work was organised - "reversing the industrial revolution" as enthusiasts proselytised. By 1994, Price Waterhouse said that 68% of all British companies were engaged in re-engineering. Workers justly feared it. At Lloyds Bank, re-engineering meant the numbers of branches were cut from 2,100 to 1,800.

Does John Birt have what it takes to join the gurus? Being a guru requires far more than writing a management book. Ken Blanchard wrote the very well-known book, The One Minute Manager, rarely out of the New York Times bestsellers list during the 80s. But within the genre, he is still not regarded as a guru. This may be because he lacks razzmatazz.

Peter Drucker, the guru's guru, set the standards with his eerie foresight. Back in the 50s, when state ownership was the dominant ideology and the west was enjoying a post-war manufacturing boom, he predicted that governments would privatise their assets, manual labour would decline and the knowledge-based economy would emerge.

Judging from the careers of the most successful practitioners, management guru status requires big new ideas; a measure of original thinking; an ability to bring context to chaos; to confect concepts that illuminate inarticulate feelings about work or business. Sometimes, gurus become living exemplars of their ideas. Peters famously posed in pink boxer shorts on the cover of his book, Crazy Times Call For Crazy Organisations.

His presentations are a performance of raving, sweat-drenched demotic. Charles Handy, progenitor of "portfolio working" (workers accumulating tasks to earn an income rather than having one job) and advocate of downshifting, rarely gives lectures, preferring a quiet life at his homes in Norfolk, London and in Tuscany.

Gurus need to become their own brand: the ideas they propound in subsidiary activities - speech-giving and private consulting work - all have to work together, building on and extending what has gone before. Kanter preaches the message that big companies stifle the creativity of their staff; the companies invite her to advise on where they are going wrong; the prestige of her clients helps reinforce her brand; and she can then use her experiences of working with them as material for the next book.

Gurus need charisma. They share slots on the business lecture circuit with Margaret Thatcher and Henry Kissinger. Bill Clinton was so impressed by the work of Stephen Covey, a strict Mormon and author of The Seven Habits Of Highly Effective People, that he persuaded him to travel to Camp David from his Covey leadership centre, a remote ranch outside Salt Lake City where executives can get away from it all, weep, read "wisdom literature", watch footage of the Berlin Wall collapsing and rescue each other from expensively faked calamities in the mountains.

In Britain we have been sniffy about gurus. The Japanese managed a creditable economic miracle without their assistance, after all. The two gurus we have produced pursued singular paths and owe their success to satisfying different needs. John Adair helped the army define what it means by leadership. His book, Action-Centred Leadership (1973), broke down the functions of leaders into planning, informing, supporting, controlling, evaluating etc, and these still hold good for officers learning their trade at Sandhurst.

Charles Handy has achieved great popularity as a sage by preaching a kinder capitalism, which marries traditional capitalist motivation with a morality of self-denial - of saying "enough is enough". His ideas of "citizen companies" peopled by individuals with notions of "proper selfishness" have struck a chord now that the big ideological battles of left versus right are no longer seen as relevant. His "portfolio career" idea comforts those who have been re-engineered out of a salaried job.

The term guru does have pejorative associations: Peter Drucker used to say that people use the word because charlatan is too long. John Birt won't be able to change that, no matter how often, and how lucratively, his management advice might be called upon.

fields.headline: Something nasty in the woods
fields.standfirst: With his twee arrangements of twigs and stones, Andy Goldsworthy dominates land art. But his time may be up, as Grizedale forest replaces his sculptures with work that better reflects our relationship with nature.  Jonathan Jones reports
fields.trailText: With his twee arrangements of twigs and stones, Andy Goldsworthy dominates land art. But his time may be up, as Grizedale forest replaces his sculptures with work that better reflects our relationship with nature. Jonathan Jones reports
fields.body:
Take a trip to the Lake District, to Grizedale forest, and you will discover a graveyard of our attempts to represent nature. Here among the trees, where each artwork on the trail is marked by twee little carved animals, is Britain's most famous collection of land art.

It's got everything, from a painted rock to a statue of a fox, but the supreme mausoleum in the cemetery is Andy Goldsworthy's Wall That Went for a Walk. Goldsworthy's dry stone wall emerges from the pine forest, squiggles in a gentle S shape in and out of the trees, and is a trivial bore. The wall launched one of the most successful careers in contemporary art and today Goldsworthy travels the world arranging leaves and photographing them. He's just taken another wall for a walk in the US and later this year has an exhibition at the Barbican. Who cares? Goldsworthy's art says nothing about the violence, hypocrisy and waste of our relationship to nature and is about as radical as the Body Shop.

Even the Grizedale Society, which runs the sculpture park, is getting sick of Goldsworthy. It recently appointed a new director who promised at his interview that he would ban wood and stone artworks from the forest. Adam Sutherland has already concealed one Goldsworthy sculpture of a pine cone with a wooden box and is trying to persuade the artist to let him sell it.

When I meet him he reluctantly leads me to see Wall That Went for a Walk. He's a lot more interested in the logging going on nearby, telling me how the machine can cut each tree trunk to lengths determined by the tree's thickness. Then we're off, churning up the mud, to see the digital art, video art, and performance art that he has commissioned for the forest.

Above Coniston Water, the firs are a whispy veil through which you look down on one of the most mused-over landscapes in the world. Down there, somewhere in the trees, is Ruskin's house, and across the lake is the view he revelled in, of the Old Man of Coniston. Golden, sublime, perfect, it feels like a landscape deliberately created to give visual pleasure. Which is what Ruskin thought it was. Except what are these glassy blobs dripping down the trunks of the trees in the foreground? They don't fit in at all. Get closer to the trees, and you can see that inside the transparent beads are faded pictures of blue water, green trees, mountains placed here by artist Samantha Clark.

Sutherland shows me signposts in the forest that say "Great view", a big metal billboard in a woodland clearing where he plans to screen horror films, and a video in which artist Marcus Coates tries to walk like a stoat on specially made "stoat stilts". What distinguishes these wacky new approaches to forest art from the pastoral fictions of Goldsworthy and co is that they deal with what landscape is in Britain today: a tourist vista layered over a real rural working environment. Sutherland used to run a gallery in the Scottish Highlands and he knows, and cares, about country ways. Grizedale attracts all sorts of people, he says, "from people who hug to people who hunt".

The new art projects at Grizedale examine both the construction of landscape as a tourist fiction and what really goes on here. There is a team of professional deer stalkers who each shoot about 120 animals a year, and one of them has a collection of deformed deer skulls which Sutherland wants to exhibit as an artwork. But the idea that art might be about losing yourself, destroying reason, is something the British shy away from. That is what Romantic art was about and it's what you can still see in a figure like Robert Smithson, who was killed in a helicopter crash in 1973 while photographing one of his remote earthworks from the air.

Instead of Smithson we get Goldsworthy. This has to do with a deep change that took place in the British sense of landscape and it can be traced here, in the Lake District, at Wordsworth's Dove Cottage. The discovery of the Lake District, Britain's first and still hugely popular nature resort, by poets and painters brought visitors flocking here from the 1760s onwards.

The cult of wild, overpowering landscape in the 18th century was shot through with social radicalism. It was the dream of a place beyond the confines of existing society, and it appealed to revolutionaries and outsiders. It was a way for women to imagine the world differently, like the heroine of Ann Radcliffe's 1794 novel The Mysteries of Udolpho whose ability to appreciate and draw the picturesque Italian landscape keeps her sane when she's imprisoned by a sadistic Bluebeard. It was a way for William Wordsworth memorabilia to express the huge longings that made him sympathise with the French revolution.

But when you visit Dove Cottage and see Wordsworth memorabilia you can see how the wars with France after the revolution changed everything. Wordsworth had a lover and a child in France but he ended up here, in the Lake District, and mountains ceased to be symbols of subversion. They became images of quietude and tranquility. From writing a poem to the slave liberator Toussaint L'Ouverture in which he exults that nature itself is freedom and that "Thou hast left behind Powers that will work for thee; air, earth and skies", he ended up complaining that working class tourists were spoiling it all. When Wordsworth celebrated the "solitude" of the Lakes he was himself contributing to the end of that solitude. Today, the national park around Ambleside has a permanent population of 40,000 and attracts 14 million visitors a year.

Britain fell in love with wild places just as the countryside was enclosed and domesticated by large-scale farmers, when remote places were taken over by tourism and their ruggedness prettified by teashops. It has left us with a feeble, muted relationship to our own landscape. We don't seem to be able to talk about the British countryside at all except in terms of banning fox-hunting and furthering ramblers' access. Perhaps it would be less easy for vested interests to present themselves as defenders of the country against ignorant townies if we could represent our landscape in a grander, more imaginative way than a stone fox and a tasteful wall.

fields.headline: Return of the exiles
fields.standfirst: A new wave of Iranian film-makers is winning official support, writes  Sheila Whitaker
fields.trailText: A new wave of Iranian film-makers is winning official support, writes Sheila Whitaker
fields.body:
Whether in obvious or less discernable ways, cinema is often a nation's barometer. In Iran, where the national desire for reform and liberalisation made itself resoundingly felt in the recent elections, last month's Fajr film festival in Tehran opened its doors wide to outside influences, most obviously in the retrospectives of two highly political filmmakers, Constantin Costa-Gavras and Francesco Rosi, both of whom attended.

The home crop was led by Smell of Camphor, Fragrance of Jasmine, written and directed by Bahman Farmanara. His first film in 20 years, Farmanara has spent the intervening period in exile in Canada. Smell of Camphor centres on the philosophical reflections of a film director who, similarly, hasn't made a film in two decades, whose wife and three Iranian director friends have died, and who himself now feels death approaching. It is an elegiac, often ironic and amusing meditation that won best screenplay in the international section and best film in the Iranian section.

In line with the national mood, the theme of exile may well overtake that of the Iran-Iraq war, which seems to have been largely exorcised. Strangers, a road movie clearly influenced by his own experiences, is a first feature by a 25-year-old US-born Iranian, Ramin Bahrani. Kaveh (played by Bahrani), a young Iranian visiting Iran for the first time to seek out his father's childhood home, meets a truck driver, Abdul, deep in the southern Iranian countryside. He gives him a lift and, albeit unwillingly, deviates from his delivery schedule to help Kaveh find the village and the graveyard of his murdered grandfather. The film has many strengths - not least in highlighting the misplaced notion that the dollar can buy anything.

That the most interesting films came from exile directors was further confirmed by One More Day, an impressive first feature by Babak Payami, who was born in Tehran but now lives in Canada. It deals with a chance meeting between a man and a woman at a bus stop; an event which becomes an unspoken daily ritual in which they try to break the isolation and loneliness of their lives.

The film follows the man in his wanderings around Tehran dealing in medications as, gradually, we discover that he is a widower and she lives with her brother. The camera moves hardly at all, there is little narrative, and Payami refuses to let anything be hurried: we watch two lives, empty of purpose and joy, become attached by the slenderest of threads which, inevitably, cannot hold them together.

The audience award was shared by Bride of Fire and Born in September. The former confronts a tribal tradition in southern Iran that forces young women to marry their first cousin, if he so desires. The heroine, a medical student in Tehran, returns home to ask that her cousin, an illiterate fisherman and cigarette smuggler, waive his rights. He refuses and she finally marries him only to burn herself alive by the marriage bed.

Born in September is the story of a young man (played by Iranian screen idol Mohammad Reza Foroutan) and a woman, both Tehran university students involved in political protests which eventually force him to leave the city. She follows, but ultimately he forces her to return to carry on the struggle. While neither of these are particularly impressive movies, it is intriguing that their romantic love stories confront the issues of women's rights and political freedom: to that extent, perhaps, the award reflects the contemporary climate.

Iranian cinema guru Abbas Kiarostami continues to write scripts for others, and his influence has produced a new genre of films - represented this year by The Whisper, written and directed by Parviz Chahbazi, and The Willow and the Wind, written by Kiarostami but directed by Mohammad Ali Talebi. Both are disappointing.

In The Whisper, three orphan street sellers endlessly seek an adult to accompany them to a clinic so that the youngest boy can be circumcised. In The Willow and the Wind a young boy, breaking a schoolroom window, is told that he cannot attend school until he replaces it. First he has to find the money, then walk miles across country to the glazier and return in appalling weather carrying the pane of glass - only to break it in the classroom.

Dariush Mehrjui, whose pre-revolutionary films (The Cow, The Postman and The Cycle) were little short of masterpieces, has been in decline since and Mix, his latest, is a silly, unrevealing comedy about the post-production of a movie in time for a festival screening.

Of more interest was Her Eyes, directed and acted by Faramarz Qaribian. Released from jail after 15 years, Mansour (Qaribian) falls in love with the 20-year-old daughter of his former cellmate only to find that the local mobster is also lusting after her. It's beautifully shot, with a commendable sense of film noir and good playing from all the leads.

The significance of Farmanara's return to Iran became even more apparent when the minister of culture and Islamic guidance, Ata'ollah Mohajerani, in his closing speech, welcomed him back to Iran and called for others to return. This is surely remarkable (although exiles have been able to visit) but, other imperatives aside, it may be that Mohajerani understands the positive impact that returning directors can have on Iranian cinema when he asked them to reflect on artistic as well as social issues.

He also referred to the need to build more cinemas (nearly 200 were burned down during the revolution) and improve the existing ones - apologising to the audience, many of whom had to stand.

But, perhaps most importantly, he insisted that Iranian cinema's international success must be maintained: while this year's crop may not have been everything he would have wished, there are exciting signs of a new, more open era dawning. And with Samira Makhmalbaf - director of The Apple - and Abolfazl Jalili in post-production, and Mohsen Makhmalbaf beginning a new film this month, the immediate future looks healthy.

webTitle: It was only rock'n'roll reporting but I liked it

fields.headline: It was only rock'n'roll reporting but I liked it
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
As anyone who reads this column regularly might have deduced by now, I don't spend all my time living in the noughties; I check in on Saturdays, berate the dumbing down of pop culture, then nip back to my base in 60s San Francisco. Things are cooler there, in my communal villa on Haight St: clothes, music, people, drugs, journalism. I've got an assignment for Rolling Stone, the underground magazine founded above a Frisco printer's shop in the Summer of Love: it's a piece on the kidnapping of an heiress by a notorious acid-rock band, which my editor said I could file "whenever the vibe feels right".

My perception of Rolling Stone's editorial policy in the late 60s might be a shade naive. But only a shade. The impression, flicking through back issues, is of a magazine at leisure yet on the cusp of the inside story, blessed with preternaturally talented writers thriving on elastic deadlines and unlimited interview access. If you wanted to hear why Evil Knievel was a violent megalomaniac, watch a kidnapping case unfold or get John Lennon's exclusive post-McCartney wrath, you read Rolling Stone.

Audacious reporters who interviewed in disguise, heroic gonzos who got so far inside the story they became a crucial part of it, florid prose bashed out at three o'clock in the morning_ It's not surprising Rolling Stone's superscoop ranks kept multiplying: RS promised that being a journalist would be as electrifying as being a rock star.

"All the News that Fits," was Rolling Stone's original slogan. "It's meant to suggest that Rolling Stone's mission is defined on its own terms_ not shrinking from saying what we think and telling it like it is," explained founder Jann Wenner in 1987. I don't buy that but I still buy Rolling Stone, with the sad knowledge that reading it is a search for a veracious nugget in the wreckage of its reputation.

"Telling it like it is" means reflecting what's going on in American pop culture at the time. So now we get an infinite parade of movie starlets, models and corporate pop bands on the cover, the execrable Random Notes section at the front (the deepest subtext of which being: "Look! Celebrities speak!), the readable but distanced and passionless review section, and the odd bit of investigative reportage, usually by a veteran "name" writer from the halcyon days. This is Y2K, according to Rolling Stone.

Which would be fine, if the truth peeked through more often: if putting Kid Rock on the cover was a ploy to show the kids that they were frauds and get them to buy the Wondermints album instead; if reflecting the times could be combined with setting a new agenda for them. But no. Meticulous as it might be, the writing now feels like one authoritative but acquiescent voice providing surface detail without question marks or spirit. Weirdly, for a publication that endorsed New Journalism, no one seems to write in the first person any more.

Rolling Stone is now the ultimate metaphor for the hippie traitor, swallowed by all the things it originally rejected. In this fortnight's issue, I learned that Liz Hurley's cleavage is more succulent than Courtney Love's, that Leonardo DiCaprio's beard is still at the GCSE stage, that anti-establishment punks advertise Calvin Klein jeans, and that Mexicans have no word for teenager and hence couldn't cope with the antics of disgraced Latin Madonna Gloria Trevi.

This last story is fascinating and seriously researched, but you feel that if it had been written in 1969 it would have been shaken inside out; that Dan Baum, the writer, would have been a character in the story - camping outside Trevi's prison cell, harassing the Mexican authorities - not just a name you notice as an afterthought. That's the difference, you see: I might be biding my time on the heiress-acid rock debacle, but, once I get inside it, I intend to have me some fun.

fields.headline: The last word on...   Racism
fields.standfirst: Racism is on its deathbed - the question is, how costly will racists make the funeral? -  Martin Luther King
fields.trailText: Racism is on its deathbed - the question is, how costly will racists make the funeral? - Martin Luther King
fields.body:
Just as a jury in upstate New York acquits four police officers of wrongdoing in the Harlem shooting of Amadou Diallo - they said they thought his wallet was a gun, and fired 41 bullets at him - so a human rights commission in South Africa begins to investigate systematic racism in the country's media.

Here, meanwhile, the fall-out from the Lawrence tragedy continues, and tensions simmer between British Muslim youth and the surrounding majority society. Everywhere one looks, race and racism make angry welts on the body politic, and deep wounds.

It is an irony that although racism is a reality, and a harsh one, race itself is a complete fiction. It has no genetic or biological basis. All human beings are closely related to one another, and at the same time each human being is unique. Not only is the concept of race entirely artificial, it is new; yet in its short existence it has, like most lies and absurdities current among us, done a mountain of harm.

The first classification of humans into races was mooted by Linnaeus, who recognised it as a mere convenience with no basis in nature. He employed the same criteria as in his botanical classifications, namely, outward appearance, giving rise later to the simplistic typing of all humans into "Caucasoid", "Negroid" and "Mongoloid". But advances in genetics have demolished such taxonomies, by taking DNA as the criterion of classification. Linnaeus's system says that one of Buddhism's holy plants, the lotus, is related to the water lily; DNA comparison says it is related to London's familiar and beloved plane tree.

In human terms, DNA analysis dismantles the idea of race completely. "Race has no basic biological reality," says Professor Jonathan Marks of Yale University, "the human species simply doesn't come packaged that way." Rather, race is a social, cultural and political concept based on superficial appearances and historical conditions, largely those arising from encounters with other peoples as Europe developed a global reach, with the slavery and colonialism that followed.

It was not only Linnaeus who knew that "race" is a fiction. The physical diversity of human populations today is purely a function of geographical accidents of climate and the isolation of wandering bands.

webTitle: Pinochet receives a hero's welcome on his return

fields.headline: Pinochet receives a hero's welcome on his return
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet returns home to hero's welcome
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: As the helicopter carrying Augusto Pinochet landed on the roof of Santiago's military hospital yesterday morning, swirling gusts of wind thrust into the air thousands of pink leaflets saying "Welcome back, Chile's liberator".
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  and  Jonathan Franklin  in Santiago
fields.body:
As the helicopter carrying Augusto Pinochet landed on the roof of Santiago's military hospital yesterday morning, swirling gusts of wind thrust into the air thousands of pink leaflets saying "Welcome back, Chile's liberator".

Rising high above a chanting crowd waving Chilean flags and posters of the former dictator, the floating pamphlets gave the appearance of a presidential tickertape parade.

Yesterday was the day General Pinochet lived again. Almost 24 hours after his Chilean airforce plane left RAF Waddington in Lincolnshire, marking an end to 503 days of international humiliation under house arrest in a Surrey mansion, the general, 84, returned to a hero's welcome.

At 10.39am local time, the man judged too unfit by doctors to undergo extradition procedings to Spain on torture charges was wheeled backwards out of the plane and lowered on to the tarmac of Santiago's international airport. He was helped to his feet, clasping a white stick for support.

He hugged the army chief, General Ricardo Izurieta, followed by his own daughter, Lucia. He then walked on his own, slowly but steadily, waving with a big grin to the crowd of military dignitaries, family and friends. A brass band played his favourite military marches. It was as if he had never stood down.

In central Santiago up to 5,000 supporters had gathered around the military hospital. The atmosphere was like a national jubilee. People - overwhelmingly women - wore Pinochet T-shirts and badges, and were draped in the blue, red and white of Chile's flag.

A sound system in a derelict building opposite played Chilean folk music as couples danced on the pavement. A school bus dropped off 200 pupils in uniform, who sang: "Chi-chi-chi. Le-le-le. Viva Chile Pinochet."

Many had driven hours to be there. Omar Silva, 34, a farmworker, had come 200 miles. "Pinochet is like a father to me. He made the country great. I am here to pay my respects. It is a very happy day for Chile," he said.

Fernanda Ortega, 17, had played truant from school with four other friends. "I am here so that he knows that we still love him," she said.

Minutes after landing at the military hospital, a beaming Gen Pinochet appeared at the top-floor window and waved to the crowds with both hands. He had changed out of his blue suit and purple tie and was wearing a white hospital top.

According to Raul Troncoso, the interior minister, the hospital will conduct "a thorough exam to see if Pinochet is fit to stand trial. The Chilean justice system will make its own decisions following the democratic laws of Chile."

The general is expected to stay there for three or four days before moving to one of his residences.

While he is obviously weak, the ease with which Gen Pinochet walked on the tarmac put the government on the defensive. "The fact that a person gets off a plane walking doesn't mean he is well enough to go on trial," Mr Troncoso said.

In the only violent flashpoint of the day, a group of 50 anti-Pinochet protesters near the hospital were quickly surrounded by military police with dogs, water cannon, guns and batons and forcibly escorted down a sidestreet. Pinochet supporters tried to charge them, throwing stones and plastic bottles.

The main anti-Pinochet demonstrations were around the presidential palace. A few hundred protesters - mostly relatives of those killed under the general's regime - had stayed up all night in the Plaza de la Constitucion. They waved black flags and posters of relatives who disappeared.

Gen Pinochet faces 60 civil lawsuits in Chile alleging human rights abuses, and these could lead to criminal proceedings if courts strip him of his immunity from prosecution as a life senator. But legal experts say that, despite recent human rights trials, successful court action will be difficult because of the armed forces' continuing influence.

In a national broadcast, President Eduardo Frei - who hands over to Ricardo Lagos on March 11 - said: "No Chilean citizen is above the law. The Chilean courts must say their word now. That is what a large majority of Chileans want."

But the grandiose welcome ceremony, which included the top military brass, exposed the tense relationship between the army and the government. Neither President Frei nor any of his officials were on hand; Mr Frei had left to inaugurate a dam in northern Chile.

Stark social divisions were evident. Many houses in the capital's richer neighbourhoods hoisted Chilean flags to celebrate. The wounds of his rule have not healed.

"We don't believe this story about Pinochet's illnesses. He's not just laughing at his victims - he's made fools of the whole world," said Patricia Silva, head of the group of relatives of executed political prisoners.

Carlos Reyes of the London exile group Chile Democratico said: "He was given a hero's welcome and red carpet treatment. He's fooled the doctors and fooled the British authorities... It's what we said would happen all along."

Gen Pinochet had been expected to land in the early hours at the northern desert port of Iquique. But the Boeing refuelled on the British-held island of Ascension and flew straight to Santiago.

webTitle: Business as usual for pursuer of Pinochet

fields.headline: Business as usual for pursuer of Pinochet
fields.standfirst:
Claudio Cordone Amnesty man led fight to try Chile dictator
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Claudio Cordone is the man who has for the last 14 months been co-ordinating Amnesty International's pursuit of Augusto Pinochet. He has worked for Amnesty since 1985, first as a researcher for nine years, and then at the next level up as a manager, with a year off working for the UN in Bosnia, where he helped to set up the office of human rights investigations. He has never wanted any other career. Human rights seems to him to contain all sorts of fascinating puzzles as well as work that must be done.
fields.body:
Claudio Cordone is the man who has for the last 14 months been co-ordinating Amnesty International's pursuit of Augusto Pinochet. He has worked for Amnesty since 1985, first as a researcher for nine years, and then at the next level up as a manager, with a year off working for the UN in Bosnia, where he helped to set up the office of human rights investigations. He has never wanted any other career. Human rights seems to him to contain all sorts of fascinating puzzles as well as work that must be done.

He was the child of Italian diplomats, brought up in the Middle East, who after taking a law degree in Italy did a further two years of middle eastern studies in the United States, with the aim of working for human rights in the region. The rule at Amnesty is that people cannot work on their own countries, but they must know the countries they work on: something of their culture and enough of their language to read the paper. "You don't need a legal background" he says. "You pick that up as you do the job. Almost everything we do involves the law."

For the Pinochet campaign, he was trying to co-ordinate the efforts of a dozen people and half a dozen country sections. "We would discuss 'why isn't the level of involvement of the Spanish government right?'; and 'what needs to be done in Spain or elsewhere to get the government moving'; or what the best strategy is to deal with public opinion in Chile.

"We had to bear in mind all that and try to keep focused the main objectives of our involvement, which was to make sure that some key precedents were set and not be drawn to too much into other points. The key thing for us was to make sure that the discretion of the home secretary be narrowed down. The fitness to stand trial should not be a decision for the home secretary but should be a decision for the court."

But this kind of international lobbying, aimed at changing particular laws, is not really what made Amnesty famous. The emotional appeal of the organisation is not that it upholds laws, but that it upholds standards.

He talks as if the emotional appeal of the organisation is at least as much trouble as it is worth. "What's most difficult to deal with are the expectations arising from Amnesty being well-known and people expecting more than it can actually deliver.

"We're still very small compared to what people expect from us: they expect us to take every individual case into consideration, which it's very difficult to do.

"We are unique in that we have members and we have groups that can work on individual cases," But, he says, the number of cases that could legitimately be taken up by far exceeds the resources available. It's also obvious that the horrors of the world could overwhelm the full-time researchers if they did not have distancing mechanisms.

"There is less burnout than one might expect: we have fairly good systems. People here focus on what is needed to change things. If you are interviewing a torture victim you are focused on how this is going to look and what you need to get out of it to have a good powerful document and that is a factor in getting the emotional business under control. The fact that we take all key decisions in London has the advantage of giving you that minimum of distance from the immediate event which is necessary for judgment."

So what will he do now that Pinochet has gone home? "I shall continue to work on the things that allow people to get away with murder."

fields.headline: Work and women
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: This weekend, the churches of the United Kingdom are thinking and praying about the needs of women across the world.
fields.body:
This weekend, the churches of the United Kingdom are thinking and praying about the needs of women across the world.

Although I have enjoyed all the benefits of education, technology, transport, fast communications and satisfying professional work, and - for a large part of my life - been able to exercise choice, not all women in our culture have that luxury. Women make up 44% of the UK labour force, but some have their options closed very early. Lone parenthood, for example, does not confer wide career opportunities, nor do the demands of being carers. Some women are trapped in low-paid jobs or the spiral of poverty and abuse.

In third-world countries, the limitations are multiplied. Women's lives there are as demanding as anywhere in Europe or North America, yet their choices are often minimal. Sharp inequalities exist in healthcare and nutrition, education and training, and in earnings. Where men endure hardship and deprivation, women endure them more; where men struggle for access to education and training, women struggle more.

This is not because women in these countries have no access to paid work. The figures compare with those in the west; women make up 42% of the workforce in sub-saharan Africa, yet experience fewer benefits from work. A large part of women's work is in low-paid occupations - usually agriculture. In such subsistence economies, they do not have the choice between stay-at-home motherhood or paid employment. They have both.

Here, work does not open up choices and lifestyle improvements - indeed, it may close them down. This is partly because the employment of women is not the result of education, but often instead of it. Among Ethiopian women over 25, for example, illiteracy rates are as high as 89%. Their labour is simply needed for survival. They often have little job security and minimal access to further training. They have also little opportunity to accumulate savings, or receive credit.

Many of the funding programmes designed to help developing countries have not worked in women's interests. Men have tended to be the beneficiaries of structural adjustment programmes because they spend more time - double that of women - producing marketable goods for export. Yet, the reality of external debt impacts as much on women as on men. So does the experience of being on the wrong end of global trade networks, where what they produce is at the mercy of a first-world pricing system. When we get our goods cheap, it is often third-world women who are picking up the tab.

With its global network, the Christian church is in a position to effect real change here. Working in partnership with third-world women, Christian organisations like Tear Fund have been developing educational projects, setting up clinics, extending literacy for girls, installing boreholes for fresh water and initiating new small businesses. Because money from the UK becomes vastly inflated in poor economies, whatever the churches raise can produce extraordinary results. Fair-trading programmes also restructure the trading relationship, paying coffee-bean pickers more, and accepting profits that are less.

When women work two-thirds of the world's hours, receive one-tenth of the world's income and own one-hundredth of the world's property, we need the moral will to begin a structural change. In affluent Britain, this involves re-examining the ethics of choice - for freedom of choice brings moral obligations. If our freedom to spend and consume is enjoyed at the expense of women in the third world, it must be too costly.

 Elaine Storkey is president of Tear Fund
