fields.headline: Alan Woods
fields.trailText: Alan Woods, who has died aged 43 of cancer, was an art historian for more than 10 years at the school of fine art in the Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art, Dundee. He will, however, be best remembered for Being Naked Playing Dead (1996), regarded by its subject, Peter Greenaway, as the best critical writing on his films, and as founder editor (and driving force) of the fine art journal, Transcript.
fields.body:
Alan Woods, who has died aged 43 of cancer, was an art historian for more than 10 years at the school of fine art in the Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art, Dundee.

He will, however, be best remembered for Being Naked Playing Dead (1996), regarded by its subject, Peter Greenaway, as the best critical writing on his films, and as founder editor (and driving force) of the fine art journal, Transcript. Based around interviews, the journal gave Woods special pleasure, bringing him into contact with artists who interested him in Britain, the US and elsewhere. It is a sad irony that shortly before his death Manchester University Press agreed to become its publishers.

Rooted in the visual arts - and, above all, in film - he also exhibited his own collages, loved music, poetry (which he wrote), literature and was knowledgable about popular culture. And, of course, he loved football.

The son of a Methodist minister, Alan graduated from Cambridge University and moved to Dundee in the late 1980s to take up his first teaching post. As a teacher, he was in his element one-to-one, offering ideas, connections and directions to open up to students the widest possible horizons. He published in the Cambridge Quarterly and wrote many exhibition catalogues (the artists were almost always his friends). His recent publications included essays on David Hockney, RB Kitaj and Howard Hodgkin.

His book on Ralph Rumney, a founding member of the Situationist International and a close friend, will be published next year, but he died with many other projects in mind: a book on Howard Hodgkin and another on Bob Dylan among them.

Alan will be missed not only as a scholar cut off before his time, but as a man: generous, warm, irrepressibly witty and with a great gift for friendship.

Jonathan Romney writes: Alan Woods was a walker; in all his time as a student at Cambridge, one of the dissident, non-bike-riding minority. For some time, this rather isolated him; he would make long, occasional treks into college from the various flats where he kept his ever-expanding collections of books, records and art.

In some ways, he was isolated by his work too. Switching as a graduate from history to art history, he embarked on a thesis that had as its starting points vorticism and time. Over several years, the work spread its scope in a way that might not have fitted the traditional template of a PhD thesis, but that allowed Alan to pursue his omnivorous cultural and intellectual appetites.

He rather cultivated the role of the lugubrious hermit but, when he moved to Scotland, he really blossomed. His natural gregariousness came to the fore in his career as a critic, curator and generous encourager in the art world. He loved working on the past, but got a special kick from the present, from his dialogue with contemporary artists. His interests weren't indiscriminate; he simply refused to censor anything interesting just because it wasn't strictly "useful" or "relevant".

He was one of those natural critics who manage to make an idiosyncratic canon out of their own tastes. Everything he enthused about - video installations, Edinburgh fringe stand-ups, the gloomier Richard Thompson albums, the detritus and ephemera he used in his collages - became part of an overall self-portrait.

The proof of his serious approach to life and art was his readiness to be facetious. I'll miss sharing the 20-minute volleys of puns. I just wish we'd had time to compare notes on the new Steely Dan CD.

fields.bodyText: Alan Woods, who has died aged 43 of cancer, was an art historian for more than 10 years at the school of fine art in the Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art, Dundee. He will, however, be best remembered for Being Naked Playing Dead (1996), regarded by its subject, Peter Greenaway, as the best critical writing on his films, and as founder editor (and driving force) of the fine art journal, Transcript. Based around interviews, the journal gave Woods special pleasure, bringing him into contact with artists who interested him in Britain, the US and elsewhere. It is a sad irony that shortly before his death Manchester University Press agreed to become its publishers. Rooted in the visual arts - and, above all, in film - he also exhibited his own collages, loved music, poetry (which he wrote), literature and was knowledgable about popular culture. And, of course, he loved football. The son of a Methodist minister, Alan graduated from Cambridge University and moved to Dundee in the late 1980s to take up his first teaching post. As a teacher, he was in his element one-to-one, offering ideas, connections and directions to open up to students the widest possible horizons. He published in the Cambridge Quarterly and wrote many exhibition catalogues (the artists were almost always his friends). His recent publications included essays on David Hockney, RB Kitaj and Howard Hodgkin. His book on Ralph Rumney, a founding member of the Situationist International and a close friend, will be published next year, but he died with many other projects in mind: a book on Howard Hodgkin and another on Bob Dylan among them. Alan will be missed not only as a scholar cut off before his time, but as a man: generous, warm, irrepressibly witty and with a great gift for friendship. fields.headline: James MacGibbon
fields.standfirst: Energetic and creative publisher behind generations of fine writers
fields.trailText: Among the cautious organisation men and women of today's publishing world, globalised and accountant-driven, it is not easy to imagine anyone quite like James MacGibbon, who has died aged 88. Not that there was ever anyone quite like James: romantic communist and first publisher of Solzhenitsyn; dandy, ardent sailor, a terrific charmer with a serious interest in labour history, and until almost the end still fairly bouncing into the room, full of grins and all his latest enthusiasms.
fields.body:
Among the cautious organisation men and women of today's publishing world, globalised and accountant-driven, it is not easy to imagine anyone quite like James MacGibbon, who has died aged 88. Not that there was ever anyone quite like James: romantic communist and first publisher of Solzhenitsyn; dandy, ardent sailor, a terrific charmer with a serious interest in labour history, and until almost the end still fairly bouncing into the room, full of grins and all his latest enthusiasms.

He was born into a wealthy Scottish commercial family, though his father, who died when James, his youngest son, was 10, had become the minister of Glasgow Cathedral, the Church of Scotland equivalent of an Anglican dean. After schooling at Fettes, then a fairly fierce beating establishment which may have stirred early rebelliousness, he went not to university, but into publishing at 17, after impressing the British head of Putnam & Co, met by chance at a funeral. Arriving in the week that Putnam brought out Erich Remarque's All Quiet On The Western Front (with spectacular success), he quickly decided that publishing was the life for him.

For the next few years he shared his mother's Park Lane flat, becoming something of a debs' delight, until another chance encounter, with the head of a big German printing firm, offered a life-changing opportunity - both to escape from his formidable mother and to discover a very different world. He went to Berlin in 1932 as a publishing apprentice, working in Ullstein Verlag and various other firms, encountering the work of the Bauhaus and Expressionist painting, and watching the gathering clouds which were to bring the Nazis to power.

It was not until 1936, not long after his marriage to the writer Jean Howard, that a new way of looking at his life - and the way the world was going in that "low, dishonest decade" - led him to join the Communist party. Appalled at the way the Spanish republican government was being left to the mercies of Franco and his fascist allies, James and Jean canvassed the British political parties as to what they were going to do about Spain. Only the CP seemed to provide an effective answer, and he campaigned hard in an out of the party, helping also to run a home for Basque orphans. In 1938, he was arrested for writing "Save the Czechs" on a Whitehall pavement when Chamberlain returned from Munich.

James was, however, never a masochistic prisoner of the party. Essentially, what he had enlisted in was the "fine old conflict", and the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact didn't prevent him from knowing where the front lay; the day after war was declared, he volunteered for the marines. His good German and knowledge of Berlin quickly got him drafted into military intelligence, eventually serving as GSO2 (Ops) to the British director of planning for the combined chiefs in Washington in 1944. Certainly, he had left the communists by the time of the Hungarian uprising in 1956, and it is unlikely that he had been an active member for many years before that.

Back in civilian life, James rejoined Putnam and became managing director before deciding in 1948 to start up his own firm, with his wife, his friend Robert Kee and start-up capital of £6,000. MacGibbon and Kee, until it was taken over and broken up by Granada, was one of the liveliest literary publishing houses of the 50s and early 60s.

It may have been at its best in the relatively short period after financial difficulties obliged James to sell to the leftwing property millionaire Howard Samuel - in those years when Doris Lessing joined the list and Tim O'Keeffe was nursing Flann O'Brien back to writing life (as well as introducing to English readers the remarkable Polish expressionist novelist Witold Gombrowicz).

But the firm's begetters had laid a fine foundation, launching, among others, the novelist Colin MacInnes, and producing among many diversely good things, novels by Thomas Hinde, Noel Annan's biography of Leslie Stephen, Humphrey Lyttelton's autobiography, some good late essays of Desmond MacCarthy, and a famous children's book which James got Cecil Day Lewis and Edward Ardizzone to make out of the story of the film, Nous, les Gosses.

Among his later coups, when he was second-in-command to Victor Gollancz in the early 60s (not his happiest berth), was getting the rights to Solzhenitsyn's One Day In The Life Of Ivan Denisovich. As a literary agent at Curtis Brown, his personal stable of writers included John Le Carré and Rumer Godden. From his later time as managing director at Macdonald's, where he made Catherine Cookson a world bestseller, and developed a line of good books on naturalism and his great love, sailing, he is remembered as a skilful and encouraging trainer of some of the better publishers of the next two generations. His last job in publishing - more sailing and country books - was with David & Charles, in Newton Abbott, Devon.

In retirement, James remained variously active as, for example, publishing adviser to the Melanie Klein Trust (Jean's interest in her work once took the whole family through Kleinian analysis) and as Stevie Smith's literary executor. Late, and lively still, he retreated to Manningtree, North Sea sailing and his last substantial piece of work, the translation of the great Breton bible of sailing lore and practice, The New Glenan's Sailing Manual.

James had discovered a passion for sailing during his wartime visit to America, and had subsequently cruised in the Baltic, and off the Dutch, Breton and Irish coasts, but had to give up in his late 70s after being winched on a rough day off the Goodwins with his crew Richard Holmes, biographer of Shelley and Coleridge.

Thereafter, he kept an eye on things marine through a telescope mounted in the window of his litle house overlooking the Crouch, and often enough from the window of the Butt and Oyster at Pin Mill, where his Cheverton Crusader was moored. By now his political moorings had long been in CND and the Labour party, serving as an alderman in Camden in the 1960s, and later taking turn about as chairman and treasurer at Manningtree with the Guardian's quondam education correspondent.

I think Robert Kee is right when he says that the clue to James MacGibbon - his practically engaged political idealism, his energy and curiosity - was his innocence, in the most active sense of the word. I couldn't imagine anyone calling James "an old boy", but that eager, amiable, rebelly boy was alive in him to the end.

He is survived by his wife, two sons and a daughter.

James MacGibbon, publisher, born February 18 1912; died February 29 2000

fields.headline: Mae Faggs Starr
fields.standfirst: Woman athlete running into US history
fields.trailText: Aeriwentha "Mae" Faggs Starr, who has died aged 67, was the first American national star to emerge from Tennessee State University, which was to produce so many great female athletes of the 1950s and 60s. She competed in three Olympic Games, the first in London in 1948 when she was 16. She returned in 1952 to help the United States win the gold medal in the 4x100 metres relay in Helsinki, and a bronze medal four years later in Melbourne.
fields.body:
Aeriwentha "Mae" Faggs Starr, who has died aged 67, was the first American national star to emerge from Tennessee State University, which was to produce so many great female athletes of the 1950s and 60s.

She competed in three Olympic Games, the first in London in 1948 when she was 16. She returned in 1952 to help the United States win the gold medal in the 4x100 metres relay in Helsinki, and a bronze medal four years later in Melbourne.

On the 1956 squad, Faggs passed the baton for the third leg to a 16-year-old who would soon reach her own great fame, Wilma Rudolph, winner of three Olympic gold medals in Rome in 1960. Faggs had met and trained with the young Rudolph at Tennessee State.

Faggs, who was born in Bayside, New York, was offered a scholarship to Tennessee at a time when they were extremely rare for female athletes in the male-dominated world of American sport. "She was an early pioneer," her husband, Eddie, said. "Mae had been to the Olympics when she got a scholarship to Tennessee State. They had a one-woman track team there for a while."

It was Faggs's success which first drew national attention to Tennessee and helped persuade other talented young athletes - like Rudolph - to enrol in the programme, organised by the respected coach Ed Temple. He once recalled that Faggs, who at 5ft 2in tall was small for a world-class sprinter, became a real leader of the team at Tennessee. "She was always urging on the younger team members, by turns encouraging, cajoling and chal lenging," he said. "She was always a team leader."

Faggs was the US 100m champion in 1955 and 1956, and won the 200m title in 1954, 1955 and 1956. She also won a silver medal in the 100m at the 1955 Pan American Games in Mexico City. She was elected to the US Track & Field Hall of Fame in 1976.

Following her retirement Faggs moved to Cincinnati to start a teaching career at Lockland Wayne High School. She became administrator in the Princeton City Schools and led the Princeton High School girls' track and field team to the Ohio championship in 1989.

She is survived by her husband, a son and daughter and two grandchildren.

webTitle: Spurned men dream of Rimini in the city of the chaste

fields.headline: Spurned men dream of Rimini in the city of the chaste
fields.trailText: I asked for silk. He thought I said "sex". The conversation turned strange.
fields.body:
I asked for silk. He thought I said "sex". The conversation turned strange.

"Not in Rome," he smiled. "Not here you won't."

I was in a department store surrounded by ties he was supposed to sell, but he persisted. "Roman girls," he explained, "are special. It doesn't matter what you say, where you take them, they will not sleep with you." He saw my bewilderment and thought I looked hurt. "Any man - not just you."

A silk tie, I wanted to interject, but a favourite topic had been uncorked. He was unstoppable. A flood of lamentation and advice lasted several minutes before a sly tap of his nose and one word: "Rimini." An oasis of requited lust, apparently.

Stay long enough in a huddle of males aged under 60 and a resigned consensus tends to emerge that young Roman women are chaste.

Yet the city reeks of sex. Newsagents stuff porn magazines into the same racks as newspapers. Business weeklies put female bottoms and breasts on their covers. Mainstream celebrities strip off for hugely popular calendars. Local television channels turn blue after midnight.

Female police have new uniforms of hip-skimming holsters, very tight shirts and 5cm heels. Like female street-sweepers and bus drivers, many are draped in jewels and wear heavy make-up.

This is the city where Sophia Loren and Gina Lollobrigida blazed a trail for a femininity that was instinctive, strong, sensual and sexual.

Today contraception is freely available, abortion is legal, unmarried mothers are not shunned and the males are not shy. So when did Roman womanhood become chaste? No McKinsey-style sex survey has been done here, but there is no mistaking the perception.

One explanation is that Romans tend to live with their parents until they marry. It is too expensive to move out and Mama rarely objects. The result can be seen outside nightclubs and bars in the early weekend hours: couples entwined around scooters for marathon snogs.

Couples with cars head for the Gianicolo, a park south of the Vatican, but the tie-seller described it as the graveyard of many false hopes.

Other theories bounced between male huddles is that Rome heightens the timeless duality of the Madonna-whore; or that the Pope's sermons are more influential than they appear.

But cross the gender line and a different answer awaits. "Guys here are always talking like that, dreaming of Rimini," said Monique, a teacher. "But they are the old-fashioned ones. They want to sleep around but marry a virgin."

A new law allows men to take paternity leave. Monique snorted. Getting men to take responsibility for the consequences of sex was beyond legislation, she said.

webTitle: Mexico and Mitsubishi forced to leave whales in peace

fields.headline: Mexico and Mitsubishi forced to leave whales in peace
fields.trailText: Environmentalists are celebrating a decision by the Mitsubishi corporation and the Mexican government to abandon plans for a salt factory in a Pacific coast lagoon that lies in an area almost untouched by human intervention.
fields.body:
Environmentalists are celebrating a decision by the Mitsubishi corporation and the Mexican government to abandon plans for a salt factory in a Pacific coast lagoon that lies in an area almost untouched by human intervention.

The decision followed a big environmental campaign in the US and Mexico. More than 700,000 letters of objection poured in to the salt company jointly owned by the government and the Japanese corporate giant, and there were calls for an international boycott of Mitsubishi goods.

A coalition of environmental groups and scientists argued that the California grey whales that winter and breed in the area and other endangered species could have been at risk if the plant had gone ahead in Baja California, in north-western Mexico.

The Mexican president, Ernesto Zedillo, and the vice-president of Mitsubishi's operations in North America, James Brumm, announced on Thursday that plans to build the plant at Laguna San Ignacio had been abandoned.

Mr Zedillo said that a $1m (£600,000) study commissioned by his government and Mitsubishi had concluded that the whales would not be at risk, but it was accepted that the 116-square-mile salt works might "alter the landscape" irreparably in and around the Vizcaino Biosphere Reserve. "This is a place that has had minimum interference by humans, one of the few places like that left on the planet," he said.

Mr Brumm of Mitsubishi said that although more than 200 permanent jobs would have been provided by the $120m development, "it is better to leave this as an untouched area for ecotourism."

The decision follows what is almost certainly the most intensive joint campaign ever organised between US and Mexican environmentalists. A coalition of more than 50 groups, most of them US-based, collaborated to swamp the Mexican government and the salt company, Essa, which was 51% owned by Mexico and 49% by Mitsubishi. The plant at issue would have been Essa's second in the area.

A "Mitsubishi: Don't Buy It" boycott campaign was launched and than 40 Californian cities passed resolutions condemning the plan.

Protest groups welcomed the surprise decision to shelve the project. Homero Aridjis, the poet and writer who is president of the Group of 100 - the Mexican organisation that led the campaign - was reported as saying: "It has been a tough fight for five years with one of the richest corporations in the world and the Mexican government." Jared Blumenfeld of the International Fund for Animal Welfare said: "We applaud Mitsubishi's transition from environmental outlaw to environmental champion."

The plant, due to be completed by 2003, would have extracted industrial salt from the sea water in evaporating ponds.

Mr Brumm of Mitsubishi said a turning point came in November when the UN scientific and cultural body Unesco put out a report on the potential impact of the works.

"The Unesco report... said the whale wasn't in danger, but it said if you go ahead you should take into account the integrity of the landscape," he said.

"The Unesco report... said the whale wasn't in danger, but it said if you go ahead you should take into account the integrity of the landscape," he said.

webTitle: A century of eating has left Michelin overstuffed

fields.headline: A century of eating has left Michelin overstuffed
fields.standfirst: Chefs complain that famed guide now rates decor as much as food
fields.trailText: Back in 1900, petrol cost 50 centimes a litre, a Georges Richard two-seater Poney automobile cost 3,500 francs, a night in a two-star hostelry including three-course meal with wine cost 10-13 francs, and the Michelin tyre company published its first Red Guide to the hotels and restaurants of France.
fields.body:
Back in 1900, petrol cost 50 centimes a litre, a Georges Richard two-seater Poney automobile cost 3,500 francs, a night in a two-star hostelry including three-course meal with wine cost 10-13 francs, and the Michelin tyre company published its first Red Guide to the hotels and restaurants of France.

"This present work," that first booklet declared, "aims to provide information useful to the motorist travelling in France... We promise to be pitiless in striking from our lists any establishment whose cuisine, accommodation, water closets or service are notified to us as being defective."

Pitiless they may have been, but there is one restaurant in France which Michelin's feared inspectors, despite a century of trying, have been unable to fault. This week, le Grand Monarque in Chartres celebrated the unique achievement of appearing in all 100 annual Red Guides.

"We only realised when all the papers started calling," said Bertrand Jallerat, 29, who with his wife Nathalie took over the running of the 19th-century coaching inn two years ago from his father Georges. "I'm grateful for the accolades, but really it's a tribute to the two families who've run the place for the past 10 decades."

Much may have changed in the world since the dawn of the last century; the Michelin guide itself, for example, has grown from a give-away pocketbook about how to repair your punctures into an awesome 1,800-page foodie's bible whose coveted stars are so sought after that chefs have been known to commit suicide on losing one.

But the recently refurbished dining room of le Grand Monarque remains a modest monument to the only three things that have ever really mattered in this realm: good food and fine wine served in pleasant surroundings. Most of its customers - local businessmen, elderly ladies, even tourists in town for the famous cathedral - have been before.

"The menu's a bit more adventurous than it was in 1900," said the chef, Michel Menier. "Then, of necessity, it was strictly regional; now with modern-day transport we can get fresh ingredients every day from anywhere in France. But we still serve a few of the same dishes."

Today's £23 three-course menu features paté de Chartres - a long standing speciality - and the pièce de résistance, côte de veau Curnonsky. This was the pseudonym of one Maurice Edouard Saillard, an all-time star in the galaxy of French foodies who was known as the Prince of Gastronomes. His early 20th-century recipe for veal cutlet? Simply, "In the manner of le Grand Monarque at Chartres".

Nor have the three cellars, containing 35,000 bottles, changed very much.

The Jallerats and the Drouets before them have always bought selected Loire valley and Bordeaux wines the year they come on to the market, allowing the restaurant today to offer 20-year-old vintages of Chateau Petrus and Chateau Haut-Brion at £200-£300 a bottle - a lot of money, but maybe half what a Paris wine merchant would demand'.

There is just one small fly in le Grand Monarque's soup (as it happens, a lobster consommé served with wild mushrooms): although it has been listed in all the Michelin guides it did, some 15 years ago, lose the single Michelin star it had held for many years. No one knows quite why; perhaps the chef had an off-day.

Whatever the reason, Mr Jallerat is not so sure he wants it back - and sadly for Michelin these days, he is not alone in feeling that a star can be more trouble than it is worth. Critics, even in France, are increasingly arguing that the centenarian guide has failed to move with the times and rewards tradition rather than innovation.

More important, several top chefs have recently broken rank and complained vociferously that the guide's practice of rating comfort as highly as cuisine means they are bankrupting themselves on fripperies rather than food. Mr Jallerat shares their view.

"This isn't a chi-chi restaurant that charges the earth, it's a hotel restaurant that fills its dining room by providing decent eats in a nice atmosphere seven days a week," he said.

"A mention in the guide is very, very important - but if I get a star, I'll have to buy crystal glasses for 10 times the price and the customers will start expecting three different kinds of appetiser. It's not my priority."

webTitle: Roberts and Lucas top fame and fortune lists

fields.headline: Roberts and Lucas top fame and fortune lists
fields.trailText: Money is not everything, as the film-maker George Lucas could tell you. Earnings last year of $400m (£250m) on the back of the latest Star Wars movie might have seemed more than satisfactory.
fields.body:
Money is not everything, as the film-maker George Lucas could tell you. Earnings last year of $400m (£250m) on the back of the latest Star Wars movie might have seemed more than satisfactory.

But the cash cut very little ice when it came to Oscar-nomination time - and it could not even buy him the ranking of the world's number one celebrity, according to Forbes magazine, which chronicles the fortunes of the world's rich and famous.

Even though Lucas made more than twice as much money as his nearest competitor, he came second to the phantom menace of Julia Roberts, who accumulated a mere $50m, according to the annual table of celebrity power.

Power is calculated by balancing money against appearances in the press, website hits and - significantly when considering the claims of the bearded creator of a popular culture franchise against a noted beauty - appearances on magazine covers.

Whatever the rankings of Lucas and Roberts prove, they represent the volatile nature of fame. Neither appeared on last year's list, a period unmarked by a Star Wars outing and before Roberts's box-office hit Notting Hill.

The award for celebrity consistency, if there were one, would go to Oprah Winfrey, the daytime talkshow queen whose $150m earnings put her second on the cash list, two places better than in the previous 12 months.

Conversely, that for inconsistency would go to Jerry Seinfeld. Then, as the biggest name in comedy, he earned $267m, making him the world's highest-paid celebrity. Now, following his decision to end his long-running TV sitcom, he is nowhere on the chart.

The ephemera game put paid to the Spice Girls. Twelve months ago they took the number 21 spot for earnings with $49m. This year they do not even register in the top 100. On the other hand, the performance of the Rolling Stones indicates that rock and roll truly will never die - at least, not at the cash register - as long as it is well enough established. They raked in $50m, down by $7m; but even that cost them only one place in the money rankings.

Impressive though these figures may be, Forbes suggests that they would be barely acceptable for the celebrity of the future. "Hollywood pays Jim Carrey [number 20 in the earnings list] $20m a pop to mug in movies," it says. "Baseball pitching ace Kevin Brown, 59, gets $15m a year for his split-fingered fastball. Colin Powell, 81, pulls in $80,000 for a one-hour speech. Those are the going rates for today's top celebrities. Tomorrow's stars will make even more.

"All of 18 years old, teen pop star Britney Spears earned some $15m last year. Not bad, but wait till next year: Britney dolls are moving off the shelves."

But in this particularly uncertain world it is impossible to say where JK Rowling will figure by then. This year her accumulation of $40m makes the Harry Potter author the world's 24th highest-paid celeb, a position that puts her in an unlikely sandwich between Michael Jordan and Cher and makes her second only to the Rolling Stones among the British.

Britain's Lennox Lewis ($29m) finally overcame Evander Holyfield ($35.5m) to become the world heavyweight boxing champion but made it only to 36th place, seven behind the American.

Bringing up the rear for Britons is Elizabeth Hurley (number 71, $7m), better known for her dresses and her self-effacing boyfriend, Hugh Grant, than she is for her work in the fields of cosmetics and film production.

Grant may have much to be self-effacing about. While Notting Hill helped to propel Roberts up the rankings, the modern-day David Niven does not make the cut.

webTitle: German MP exposed as happy camper

fields.headline: German MP exposed as happy camper
fields.standfirst: A small caravan is home to the unconventional Konrad Kunik
fields.trailText: Konrad Kunick chooses his words carefully when asked what his fellow MPs think of him. "I don't know what they  think," he says with a sly smile. "But what they  say  is that I am rare bird".
fields.body:
Konrad Kunick chooses his words carefully when asked what his fellow MPs think of him. "I don't know what they think," he says with a sly smile. "But what they say is that I am rare bird".

This he undeniably is. Since the German parliament moved to Berlin last autumn, while colleagues have been sheltering from the harsh Prussian winter in plush, centrally-heated hotels, Mr Kunick, 59, has been living on a camp site.

By choice.

"We get an allowance for our expenses which we can spend as we like," he said. "I decided to spend mine on a new caravan. I am paying it off in instalments at DM750 [£235] a month".

The caravan came with an awning attached and when the weather was milder, Mr Kunick, a Social Democratic MP from Bremen, used that for shelter instead.

"I'd had an accident with the caravan on the autobahn. I could have gone to a hotel, but the weather was beautiful and there was no reason to move", he said.

Mr Kunick who - it may be noted - turned up late for his interview with the Guardian because of a raging cold, developed a taste for the outdoor life as a boy.

"I was a scout. We used to camp out in Wehrmacht tents left over from the war".

He reached parliament after a varied life that included work as a merchant seaman, rail manager and auditor. Though his unconventional accommodation preference only recently became public knowledge, he said he had taken to living in a caravan shortly after being elected to parliament in 1994 when the capital was still in Bonn.

One of the advantages of his lifestyle was that it allowed him spend the least possible time wearing a suit. Mr Kunick said he usually travelled up from the camp site on the outskirts of Berlin dressed casually and with a knapsack on his back, changing into more formal gear at his office on the Unter den Linden.

His ascetic way of life has recently come under threat. A previously unknown ultra-rightwing group calling itself the Werewolves named him on a website as one of several politicians who "needed to be watched". Mr Kunick said he was concerned that the federal security authorities might order him into more easily protected lodgings.

"I feel my freedom is being cramped," he said.

It is perhaps an odd take on events, coming from someone who lives in a space measuring 4m by 2m.

But Mr Kunick disagrees.

"It's a lot bigger than Job's barrel," he said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Chechnya visit by Red Cross
fields.body:
Chechnya visit by Red Cross

Russia last night agreed to allow the head of the International Committee of the Red Cross, Jakob Kellenberger, to visit Chechnya next week.

The pledge was made at a meeting between the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, his counterparts from the European Union, and the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright.

Russia has been under pressure from the west to allow greater access to the north Caucasus region after recent allegations of serious human rights abuses. Ian Black, Brussels

Mother killed by swarm of bees

A swarm of bees killed a 38-year-old woman and stung her toddler more than 50 times, police in Sydney said yesterday.

Maryanne Savor was playing with her one-year-old daughter, Natalie, outside their home in Sydney when they were attacked by thousands of bees which they kept in hives in the garage.

Savor tried to run into the house, but collapsed and died, probably from a toxic reaction. Her child was last night in a serious but stable condition in hospital. Reuters, Sydney

Boy jumps to death at school

A Japanese schoolboy jumped to his death out of a second-floor classroom window in front of stunned classmates yesterday.

Yohei Ajimi, a 13-year-old pupil in Kyoto, said: "I am going to die." He then ran towards the window and threw himself out, falling 8.5m (28ft) to the ground.

The school's headmaster said he was unaware of any bullying involving the boy. No suicide note was found, but he had mentioned killing himself, classmates said. A record 33,000 Japanese killed themselves in 1998. Reuters, Tokyo

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our report of the appointment of Helen Boaden as controller of Radio 4, page 2, yesterday, we mistakenly said that Rod Liddle, the editor of the Today programme, was among those who applied for the job. He was not. Sorry for any embarrassment.
fields.body:
In our report of the appointment of Helen Boaden as controller of Radio 4, page 2, yesterday, we mistakenly said that Rod Liddle, the editor of the Today programme, was among those who applied for the job. He was not. Sorry for any embarrassment.

Paul Routledge of the Mirror has asked us to say that, contrary to a statement in our Diary, page 22, yesterday, he is not "landlord of six properties in Yorkshire". He owns one property in Yorkshire which he lives in himself.

In our report of the opera ball in Vienna, page 15, yesterday, we said Jacqueline Bisset accepted an invitation to attend but then decided not to go at the last minute. In fact, Ms Bisset did go, as readers who saw her interviewed on television called to point out.

Derek Turner, the editor of the right-wing magazine Right Now!, says that contrary to what we stated in a report headed Leeds don to attack Lawrence findings, page 6, March 2, he is not and never has been a member of the National Front.

Our piece, Tantrums and tiaras, about Elton John's Broadway music, page 13, G2, March 2, ended abruptly. Here is how it should have ended, with the missing bit in square brackets, "It's a lit[tle bit funny this feeling inside."]

The operatic bass Robert Lloyd has pointed out that he is a little older than we suggested in our Birthdays column, page 24, March 2. He was 60, not 59. Apologies.

fields.headline: An ordinary genius
fields.standfirst: At the age of 11 months, he hummed a Bach fugue and was recognised as an exceptional talent. Now, at 28 still living with his mother and teacher, he has a worldwide reputation as a remarkable pianist. But, Nicholas Wroe reports, stories of the socially inept prodigy don't hold up

fields.body:
Just over a year ago, Evgeny Kissin was asked to name his closest friends. The 28-year-old Russian pianist paused for an agonising 15 seconds before mentioning two Russian conductors, both over twice his age and one of whom he hadn't seen for five years. The message was clear: "Kissin inhabits a social incubator," the questioner confidently declared, "untouched by human hand, immersed in his playing, unaware of his powers."

The notion of the mature artistic genius but socially infantile human being is a seductive one, and looking at the bare facts of Kissin's life it is easy to see why it should so persistently attach itself to him. He was a remarkable child prodigy and has become one of the great musical talents of our age, yet he still lives and travels everywhere with his mother and teacher. His manner is, at least initially, extremely disconcerting, with the long pauses before answering questions and luxuriant Eraserhead hair-style only adding to the air of ethereal strangeness. "He is partly on earth and partly somewhere else", said Mark Zilberquit, the music critic and author of Russia's Great Modern Pianists. "He was never a child prodigy, but a small genius. Now he is just a genius."

Record companies and concert promoters have to an extent colluded in this supposed otherworldliness. "His image wasn't the sort of thing that promoters would latch onto, like they would sex appeal or something like that," says Charles Hamlen, his former manager. "But there is a kind of mystique to him and seeing that dissolve when he is at the piano is fascinating. Partly it is his total mastery of the instrument. Technically, he can do anything. But that is connected to something more spiritual. You have a sense that when he is making music, he produces on the piano exactly what he hears in his head."

But while this portrait of the artist makes perfect sense in terms of pop psychology, the actual story is not quite so neat. Kissin had misunderstood the question about his friends, and was trying to name people the interviewer might have heard of. In fact, he has a loyal circle of what anyone would acknowledge as real friends. And they don't recognise the well-rehearsed caricature of him as a man-child savant.

On meeting him, the preliminary sense of strangeness can soon wash away. He is surprisingly solidly built, tall, and has a deep voice at odds with his wan image. Toby Hoffman is a viola player who has known Kissin since he was 21. "When we first met he was a bit shy and insulated by his family," says Hoffman. "But that's not unusual for people who have a musical upbringing. People say it's not healthy that he lives with his family and his teacher, but in reality there is nothing unhealthy about the way he lives.

"When he needs to be on his own he is. It would have been more dangerous if he'd been thrown out to make a career on his own. When the time comes to leave his family, I'm sure he'll do it. He's very intelligent and he knows what he wants to do, and the way he has managed his life has meant his extraordinary talent has not been burned out."

Kissin's virtuosity and musicality are the stuff of legend. In a world where child prodigies are nothing new, he was always something special. Aged two, he picked out his first tunes on a piano, at 10 made his performing debut with a professional orchestra, and at 11 gave his first recital. In 1984, when he was 12, in the great hall of the Moscow Conservatory he played both Chopin piano concertos, something not attempted since the turn of the century. And while the history of child prodigies is littered with the human wreckage of hopes unfulfilled and talent squandered, his career has been one of uninterrupted progression. At 17, he was asked by Herbert von Karajan to play Tchaikovsky's B flat minor concerto. The great conductor was so entranced by Kissin's performance that, it is said, at one point he forgot to cue in a flute.

At the end of Kissin's 1990 Carnegie Hall debut, the conductor Zubin Mehta was so overwhelmed that, when Kissin leaned forward to shake his hand, Mehta grabbed his head and kissed it before virtually flinging the young pianist back at the near-hysterical audience. In 1997, he was the first pianist to give a solo recital at the Proms. He played to the biggest Proms audience ever (over 6,000), and rewarded them with the most-ever encores (seven).

"There are only a few individuals in an incredibly crowded marketplace at the moment who are both superb artists and have broken through to a wider public," says Nicholas Kenyon, the Proms director. "Kissin is one of them. It's something to do with the fantastic concentration he puts into every note and the way he manages to sustain the arch of a piece from beginning to end. These people have to be cherished and we must hope that they are not led astray by that wider success. So far there is no sign whatsoever that Kissin has or will be."

Amongst his peers he commands an awed respect. "You see pianists all the time at his concerts," says Hamlen, who has now left the industry but remains in close contact with Kissin. "There's no jealousy, they are just astonished by him. At the end of the Carnegie Hall debut his last encore was a Prokofiev toccata, which is an absolute finger buster. He played it like I'd play Chopsticks. The pianist Andr Watts, who was next to me, said the only appropriate reaction was to laugh. 'Otherwise I'd just have to go and jump off the George Washington Bridge.' It was astonishing." When the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet, also a precocious young performer, first heard a tape of Kissin he was out driving. He recalls having to pull over, so moved was he by the performance.

Kissin displays a mixture of embarrassment and critical prudence when discussing such matters as genius. "It is a very powerful word. I take it to mean the highest degree of talent and it is often used to describe various other, very high, degrees of talent." When pushed to name musicians who qualify, he lists the pianists Carlos Kleiber and Sviatoslav Richter, the singer Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, and conductors Leonard Bernstein and von Karajan.

"Needless to say I would never ascribe it to myself and I am cautious about applying it to others," he adds. Very few people are cautious about applying it to him. From almost the very beginning he was identified as a remarkable child. He was born in 1971 in a Moscow hospital specialising in the care of mothers-to-be with heart problems. But the birth was straightforward And his mother, Emilia, has suffered no further heart trouble since. He has one sister, Alla, 10 years older than him, also a talented pianist.

His father was an engineer. "He had a secret job", says Kissin, "in a rocket factory." Igor Kissin was a Communist party member, but it seems to have been more a requirement of his job than out of overwhelming conviction, although he had the semi-official role of "agitator" at work - the person in each group who kept performance up to the mark. "He used to receive a magazine called The Agitator to advise him how to do it", says Kissin. "We had piles of them in the toilet of our country house." The family dacha was more of a holiday chalet than a stately pile, with its outside toilet and cold water supply. It had been built by Kissin's grandparents in the 50s when Nikita Khrushchev, former premier of the Soviet Union, allowed small plots of land to be used to grow vegetables. Kissin spent whole summers there as a child.

Although Emilia Kissin was a piano teacher, there was little other musical tradition in the family. Kissin has heard that one ancestor played the cello, and his maternal grandfather could also apparently play the mandolin, but there were never any professional musicians. So when the 11-month-old boy, who had been an abnormally quiet baby, suddenly sang the theme of the Bach A major fugue his sister had just been playing on the piano, "my parents were astonished," he says.

"And from that moment on I stared singing everything. Classical, pop songs, anything I heard from the radio or was being played at home. When my parents would take me out I would sing in the street and passers-by would listen and give lots of advice. It is common in Russia to give advice," he adds with a smile, "even to people you don't know and on subjects you know nothing about."

When young Evgeny, known as Genya to family and friends, was two years and two months old - he is scrupulously accurate about this sort of thing - he was tall enough to reach the piano keyboard, and started to pick out tunes, first with one finger and then with all the rest. At six he was taken to Anna Pavlovna Kantor, a teacher at the Moscow Gnessin school of music for gifted children. Kissin recalls her listening to him playing and "then she called a couple of other teachers over and I was accepted".

He didn't study in the same way as other pupils. He suffered from bouts of pneumonia in his first three years and the school established a "free attendance" regime for him which continued when he was well. Kantor, with no family of her own, has now essentially joined the Kissin family, travelling everywhere with Genya to provide him with "consultations", his preferred word to describe their work together.

He remembers composing music in bed while he was ill, and that at seven he gave a concert of his own compositions. "I began improvising as early as I began playing," he says. "So as soon as I learned the notes I began to put music down on paper and whenever I learned something new I would use it for my own compositions." He continued composing until his mid teens, by which time he had tried all the different styles from classical through to modern and concluded that, "I had nothing else to say". His celebrity was travelling fast and he was a prize exhibit of the Soviet state music system. Kissin was featured on an English language radio programme and recalls his reaction to the huge post-bag it precipitated.

One Swedish listener asked for information on his home. "She asked about my nursery, the living rooms, my office and bedroom," he says. "Everybody who read that letter and knew how I lived laughed. At that time me and my parents and my sister were living in a three room flat of 38 square metres. The living room was a bedroom for my parents and every night and every morning I had to move the furniture. We had a grand piano in my room but to avoid sleeping right next to the radiator I had to move my bed so that my head was under the piano. Then, when I got up, I had to move the furniture again in order to practise."

The family moved soon after, to a larger home, but only after the head of the composers' union pulled some strings. While Genya's talent made his family eligible for such special treatment, they were still subject to persecution in other ways. As Jews, albeit non-practising, Kissin says they were subject both to systematic anti-Semitism as well as day-to-day indignities. "My mother didn't get very far in her job," he says, "although she was not very ambitious anyway. And my father, while he had a rather prestigious job, also encountered anti-Semitism. I have never encountered it at an official level but of course I have in daily life, since I was a small child. And it is especially frightening because it comes from other children of the same age."

The family didn't observe any aspects of Jewish life, partly because they didn't know anything about it, he explains. Kissin says he is now interested in this heritage, but as much in terms of its cultural as religious aspects. He made his performing debut at 10 with Mozart's piano concerto K466, and gave his first solo recital at 11. Marina Bower first saw him play when he was 12. Some years later she became his agent in France and recalls that even then she instantly knew, "I was in the presence of a phenomenon. It wasn't just a young boy, it was a unique personality."

But it was when, aged 12, he performed the two Chopin concertos in the Moscow Conservatory with the Moscow State Philharmonic, that news of him spread outside Russia. Dan Gorgolione was working for CBS records in New York. "Danny Barenboim had brought in this tape and a colleague played it to me. As I listened, tears were literally rolling down my cheeks, so I asked who was playing. I just couldn't believe when I was told it was some 12-year-old Russian boy." Similar scenes were being enacted in record company offices throughout the west, but access to Kissin was reserved for a very different set of cultural sponsors.

Following the recital he was invited - "it was not the sort of invitation one declines" - to perform at the Kremlin to commemorate Lenin's birthday, a bizarre story. The piece he was instructed to play was repeatedly changed, once because it would be one minute too long. He had to play in front of a jury headed by the minister of culture, a chemist by profession, "who approved of my playing but criticised the orchestra".

On the day of the performance, he was initially denied entrance to the Kremlin because he didn't have an internal passport (children were not issued with them) and then his mother and teacher - who had been placed in a side room with closed-circuit broadcast of the concert - couldn't hear the performance because a song and dance troupe played dominoes so loudly. When his teacher moved her chair closer to the television she was told that moving chairs was forbidden. At the end of the saga Kissin received a letter from an official expressing the hope that he would become a good citizen of the motherland. Last year, he received another special "invitation" and played at Prince Charles's 50th birthday party.

Kissin says he has no recollection of things getting any more serious as he began to undertake more major engagements. "Things were serious from the beginning, I was in a school that trained professional musicians." But he was increasingly aware of expectations. "My teacher was always making me conscious of that to motivate me to work harder," he says. "She kept telling me that the higher I was getting the more was being expected from me, and I had to fulfil those expectations."

While this sounds like one of those horror stories in which gifted children are worked to the bone, in this case his mother and teacher were already beginning effectively to manage the pressures put on him. He only recently found out that the reason the family went to a small town outside Moscow for a few weeks following the Chopin recital was to protect him from "all the fuss that would follow such a major debut".

His first appearances outside the Soviet Union were in 1985 when he performed in East Berlin and Budapest. He toured Japan in October 1986 and in 1987 made his debut in western Europe at the Berlin Festival. But the race to record him in the west was by now seriously underway.

In December 1987 Dan Gorgolione heard that he would be playing in London the following May with the London Symphony Orchestra. "So I booked the orchestra for the following day. I asked who the conductor of the concert was and I was told, 'some nobody'. It was Valery Gergiev."

Because Kissin was under 18, his affairs were handled by the ministry of education in Moscow. Gorgolione sent telexes enquiring about recording him but received no reply. "So there I was with an orchestra booked and no confirmation," he recalls. "Then I saw he was playing in Madrid so I got on the plane and went. After the concert, which he played like God himself, I was taken backstage and introduced by a mutual friend. Genya pointed his finger right at my face and said, 'I make record for you'. Apparently the telexes had got through but they just hadn't bothered to reply."

The recording, in Walthamstow, was of Rachmaninoff's second concerto. Kissin was nervous, it was his first studio recording, and they only had six hours studio time. It is usual to have twice that. "But, to his enormous credit, Gergiev got him through", says Gorgolione. "He talked to him like he would to a baby brother and he nurtured him along."

As Kissin's career increasingly spread westward he came under the wing of Charles Hamlen at the International Management Group agency. "I first heard him play live in this empty, dilapidated ballroom in a hotel in Germany on a dilapidated baby grand piano. He completely brought to life the Liszt Spanish Rhapsody. It was one the most transfixing moments of my entire musical life. Then he did this incredible pastiche of everything from Bach to Mozart to ragtime, all running into each other. It was hilarious."

By the time of his American debut in 1990 there was already a huge buzz about him in New York. He first played four concerts with the New York Philharmonic and then 10 days later sold out Carnegie Hall on the opening night of its centenary season. "I remember people waving $100 bills begging for tickets," remembers Hamlen. "You just knew from the first note that this was something you would talk about 50 years later."

His triumph whipped up a New York media storm. Every television talk show wanted the young Russian genius but, as Dan Gorgolione recalls, Kissin had little idea what a talk show was and certainly no idea of how to play the game. "He didn't know how to schmooze, and thought an interview was like an exam where he had to give correct answers. He went on Good Morning America and was charming but we turned down the Johnny Carson show; we didn't want to push our luck."

Kissin left Russia in 1991, which meant he avoided conscription, and didn't return until 1997, when he was awarded the Triumph Prize, the highest cultural honour in the Russian republic. He shows little sentiment about the place but expresses some disappointment at political developments. "I left at the time of the collapse of the Soviet Union, just after the failure of the communist coup. I was optimistic then and I couldn't imagine at that time that things would develop the way they have."

He is equally clear-eyed about his place in the much vaunted Russian music tradition ("loud and fast", Gergiev has joked). "I never thought much about it when I was living and studying in Russia, because it was an integral part of my personality. It was the press who made me think about it. I wouldn't say I'm much interested in it. I think music is above that."

Since he emigrated he has enjoyed remarkable success. He played at the 1992 Grammy award ceremony to a television audience of 1.5 billion, and has issued a steady stream of highly acclaimed recordings. When Nicholas Kenyon was looking for someone for a special Prom concert Kissin was an obvious choice. The piano was placed in the middle of the vast arena in the Albert Hall. "I really wanted someone who could sustain a whole solo recital and the thing about Kissin is he just has this unmistakable star quality the moment you hear him play. There was a sense of risk that one instrument in the vast space wouldn't communicate. But from the very beginning people were held by it. The impact was partly due to people standing just a few feet from the piano. There was an extraordinary feeling of intimacy despite having 6,000 people in the hall. He has been back every year since, and will be back again this year."

This month sees his seventh Chopin recording and the start of a British tour. He complains that the lead times for such events are increasingly restrictive. "I would prefer not to have to decide upon programmes so early. In the first half of the last century concerts were planned no longer than a few months in advance. Now concerts are planned two or three years ahead and all the managers and promoters demand programmes at least a year in advance. Maybe if I become more famous I will be able to tell the promoters to just say 'programme to be announced'."

He plays about 60 concerts a year and makes the point that while he learns a new piece in rehearsal, there is no substitute for playing it in front of an audience. "Rostropovich told me to always start performing a piece before it is completely ready. I find that it can't be completely ready anyway until you have played it several times in public. Rostropovich added that it improves the nervous system as well," he smiles.

But having now performed professionally for almost two decades, does he ever feel the need to have a break? "I once took a four-month break," he says, "and I'd like to take a longer break at some stage - not from music but from performing music. It would give me more time to learn new repertoire, read books, perhaps to visit places I didn't have the opportunity to explore when touring. And to make new friends."

He is godfather to Olivia Flatto's six year old daughter Julia. "It's the best thing we did," says Flatto, who met him on a cultural cruise. "He's a wonderful godfather. Both our children love him. He even sits at the piano with them and they play Twinkle Twinkle, Little Star. But their enthusiasm can sometimes be a little embarrassing. We have other friends who are musicians and Julia says things like 'you are a pianist, but you are not as good as my godfather'."

"I've been out with him until two and three in the morning in New York," reports Toby Hoffman. "Not doing anything wild or crazy but just having dinner or visiting friends. He's not kept in a cage. We've been out with women and he's been involved with a number of women. They are often a bit older than him because I think women of his age are not usually so developed and mature."

Kissin now has homes in London (a flat in Victoria), and New York (an apartment on the Upper West Side within walking distance of the Lincoln Centre and Carnegie hall; former residents of the block have included Stravinsky, Mahler and Yehudi Menuhin).

Kissin says he wouldn't get married for the sake of getting married but doesn't want to remain single all his life. It sounds as if the career comes first, but Marina Bower doesn't see it in quite those terms. "First of all he is truthful to himself, and music is the major part of his life. He didn't choose it as a career. He does it because it is an urge and that's why at each concert he gives the utmost of himself without thinking of what effect it will have on his career."

Gorgolione is genuinely proud about the way he has matured. personally and professionally. "His only intention is to make the best music. The hype, the career, the adulation don't mean much. He is out there to face the bull, but the bull isn't the public, it's the music itself and he is there to serve the composer. He's probably the highest-paid pianist in the world, but the money and celebrity don't mean anything to him."

Just before Christmas he played a benefit concert for a charity run by Charles Hamlen that raises funds for Aids research through classical concerts. "He raised nearly $90,000," says Hamlen. "It was a private house, albeit a glorious house, and he was playing to just 100 people, but he took it every bit as seriously as he would playing Carnegie Hall."

It is this attitude that will see him through to the long term, contends Toby Hoffman. "You occasionally hear people say that his music has never been as beautiful as when he was a child. I just don't think that's true. I hear a lot of development. A life in music is just that, a life. The great masters of the piano earn their reputations over 50 or 60 years. It's a continual exploration. There's no question that he's a genius. But he's a 28-year-old genius. As he matures as a person so will his understanding of the music. He understands what he wants to do and I can't see it getting anything but better."

Some critics have noted a lack of emotionalism and occasional over-reliance of his phenomenal technique. His recording of Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata didn't receive universal acclaim and Kissin has acknowledged that he was not happy with that recording. "There is more to Beethoven's music than I managed to bring out," he said. "I thought I'd brought it to a higher level in some of my recitals."

He is duly respectful about the roll call of 20th-century greats with whom he has played. "But while it is always a thrill to meet these great people, it is also a thrill to work on and perform great music. When that ceases the musician is finished. In our profession the feeling of awe is vital. It is something that cannot be faked."

Life at a glance: Evgeny Kissin

Born: Moscow, October 10 1971. Education: Moscow Gnessin school of music for gifted children. Ongoing work with Anna Pavlovna Kantor.

Key concerts: 1982 debut playing Mozart's piano concerto K466 with the Orchestra of Ulyanovska; 1984 two Chopin concertos with the Moscow State Philharmonic; 1988 Tchaikovsky's first concerto with Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan; 1990 North American debut with New York Philharmonic and Zubin Mehta; Opened Carnegie Hall's centennial season; 1997 first piano recital in the BBC Proms.

Key recordings: Rachmaninov piano concerto no. 2, London Symphony Orchestra, Gergiev; The Legendary 1984 Moscow Concert; Chopin Live at Carnegie Hall; Rachmaninov piano concerto no. 3, Boston Symphony, Ozawa; Beethoven concertos nos 2 and 5, Philharmonia Orchestra, Levine.

 Chopin Recital by Evgeny Kissin is on RCA Red Seal records. Tour dates: March 15, Glasgow, Royal Concert Hall; 19, Manchester, Bridgewater Hall; 26, Dublin, National Concert Hall ; 28, Birmingham, Symphony Hall; April 14, Birmingham; 15, London, Festival Hall.
