When young Evgeny, known as Genya to family and friends, was two years and two months old - he is scrupulously accurate about this sort of thing - he was tall enough to reach the piano keyboard, and started to pick out tunes, first with one finger and then with all the rest. At six he was taken to Anna Pavlovna Kantor, a teacher at the Moscow Gnessin school of music for gifted children. Kissin recalls her listening to him playing and "then she called a couple of other teachers over and I was accepted". He didn't study in the same way as other pupils. He suffered from bouts of pneumonia in his first three years and the school established a "free attendance" regime for him which continued when he was well. Kantor, with no family of her own, has now essentially joined the Kissin family, travelling everywhere with Genya to provide him with "consultations", his preferred word to describe their work together. He remembers composing music in bed while he was ill, and that at seven he gave a concert of his own compositions. "I began improvising as early as I began playing," he says. "So as soon as I learned the notes I began to put music down on paper and whenever I learned something new I would use it for my own compositions." He continued composing until his mid teens, by which time he had tried all the different styles from classical through to modern and concluded that, "I had nothing else to say". His celebrity was travelling fast and he was a prize exhibit of the Soviet state music system. Kissin was featured on an English language radio programme and recalls his reaction to the huge post-bag it precipitated. One Swedish listener asked for information on his home. "She asked about my nursery, the living rooms, my office and bedroom," he says. "Everybody who read that letter and knew how I lived laughed. At that time me and my parents and my sister were living in a three room flat of 38 square metres. The living room was a bedroom for my parents and every night and every morning I had to move the furniture. We had a grand piano in my room but to avoid sleeping right next to the radiator I had to move my bed so that my head was under the piano. Then, when I got up, I had to move the furniture again in order to practise." The family moved soon after, to a larger home, but only after the head of the composers' union pulled some strings. While Genya's talent made his family eligible for such special treatment, they were still subject to persecution in other ways. As Jews, albeit non-practising, Kissin says they were subject both to systematic anti-Semitism as well as day-to-day indignities. "My mother didn't get very far in her job," he says, "although she was not very ambitious anyway. And my father, while he had a rather prestigious job, also encountered anti-Semitism. I have never encountered it at an official level but of course I have in daily life, since I was a small child. And it is especially frightening because it comes from other children of the same age." The family didn't observe any aspects of Jewish life, partly because they didn't know anything about it, he explains. Kissin says he is now interested in this heritage, but as much in terms of its cultural as religious aspects. He made his performing debut at 10 with Mozart's piano concerto K466, and gave his first solo recital at 11. Marina Bower first saw him play when he was 12. Some years later she became his agent in France and recalls that even then she instantly knew, "I was in the presence of a phenomenon. It wasn't just a young boy, it was a unique personality." But it was when, aged 12, he performed the two Chopin concertos in the Moscow Conservatory with the Moscow State Philharmonic, that news of him spread outside Russia. Dan Gorgolione was working for CBS records in New York. "Danny Barenboim had brought in this tape and a colleague played it to me. As I listened, tears were literally rolling down my cheeks, so I asked who was playing. I just couldn't believe when I was told it was some 12-year-old Russian boy." Similar scenes were being enacted in record company offices throughout the west, but access to Kissin was reserved for a very different set of cultural sponsors. Following the recital he was invited - "it was not the sort of invitation one declines" - to perform at the Kremlin to commemorate Lenin's birthday, a bizarre story. The piece he was instructed to play was repeatedly changed, once because it would be one minute too long. He had to play in front of a jury headed by the minister of culture, a chemist by profession, "who approved of my playing but criticised the orchestra". On the day of the performance, he was initially denied entrance to the Kremlin because he didn't have an internal passport (children were not issued with them) and then his mother and teacher - who had been placed in a side room with closed-circuit broadcast of the concert - couldn't hear the performance because a song and dance troupe played dominoes so loudly. When his teacher moved her chair closer to the television she was told that moving chairs was forbidden. At the end of the saga Kissin received a letter from an official expressing the hope that he would become a good citizen of the motherland. Last year, he received another special "invitation" and played at Prince Charles's 50th birthday party. Kissin says he has no recollection of things getting any more serious as he began to undertake more major engagements. "Things were serious from the beginning, I was in a school that trained professional musicians." But he was increasingly aware of expectations. "My teacher was always making me conscious of that to motivate me to work harder," he says. "She kept telling me that the higher I was getting the more was being expected from me, and I had to fulfil those expectations." While this sounds like one of those horror stories in which gifted children are worked to the bone, in this case his mother and teacher were already beginning effectively to manage the pressures put on him. He only recently found out that the reason the family went to a small town outside Moscow for a few weeks following the Chopin recital was to protect him from "all the fuss that would follow such a major debut". His first appearances outside the Soviet Union were in 1985 when he performed in East Berlin and Budapest. He toured Japan in October 1986 and in 1987 made his debut in western Europe at the Berlin Festival. But the race to record him in the west was by now seriously underway. In December 1987 Dan Gorgolione heard that he would be playing in London the following May with the London Symphony Orchestra. "So I booked the orchestra for the following day. I asked who the conductor of the concert was and I was told, 'some nobody'. It was Valery Gergiev." Because Kissin was under 18, his affairs were handled by the ministry of education in Moscow. Gorgolione sent telexes enquiring about recording him but received no reply. "So there I was with an orchestra booked and no confirmation," he recalls. "Then I saw he was playing in Madrid so I got on the plane and went. After the concert, which he played like God himself, I was taken backstage and introduced by a mutual friend. Genya pointed his finger right at my face and said, 'I make record for you'. Apparently the telexes had got through but they just hadn't bothered to reply." The recording, in Walthamstow, was of Rachmaninoff's second concerto. Kissin was nervous, it was his first studio recording, and they only had six hours studio time. It is usual to have twice that. "But, to his enormous credit, Gergiev got him through", says Gorgolione. "He talked to him like he would to a baby brother and he nurtured him along." As Kissin's career increasingly spread westward he came under the wing of Charles Hamlen at the International Management Group agency. "I first heard him play live in this empty, dilapidated ballroom in a hotel in Germany on a dilapidated baby grand piano. He completely brought to life the Liszt Spanish Rhapsody. It was one the most transfixing moments of my entire musical life. Then he did this incredible pastiche of everything from Bach to Mozart to ragtime, all running into each other. It was hilarious." By the time of his American debut in 1990 there was already a huge buzz about him in New York. He first played four concerts with the New York Philharmonic and then 10 days later sold out Carnegie Hall on the opening night of its centenary season. "I remember people waving $100 bills begging for tickets," remembers Hamlen. "You just knew from the first note that this was something you would talk about 50 years later." His triumph whipped up a New York media storm. Every television talk show wanted the young Russian genius but, as Dan Gorgolione recalls, Kissin had little idea what a talk show was and certainly no idea of how to play the game. "He didn't know how to schmooze, and thought an interview was like an exam where he had to give correct answers. He went on Good Morning America and was charming but we turned down the Johnny Carson show; we didn't want to push our luck." Kissin left Russia in 1991, which meant he avoided conscription, and didn't return until 1997, when he was awarded the Triumph Prize, the highest cultural honour in the Russian republic. He shows little sentiment about the place but expresses some disappointment at political developments. "I left at the time of the collapse of the Soviet Union, just after the failure of the communist coup. I was optimistic then and I couldn't imagine at that time that things would develop the way they have." He is equally clear-eyed about his place in the much vaunted Russian music tradition ("loud and fast", Gergiev has joked). "I never thought much about it when I was living and studying in Russia, because it was an integral part of my personality. It was the press who made me think about it. I wouldn't say I'm much interested in it. I think music is above that." Since he emigrated he has enjoyed remarkable success. He played at the 1992 Grammy award ceremony to a television audience of 1.5 billion, and has issued a steady stream of highly acclaimed recordings. When Nicholas Kenyon was looking for someone for a special Prom concert Kissin was an obvious choice. The piano was placed in the middle of the vast arena in the Albert Hall. "I really wanted someone who could sustain a whole solo recital and the thing about Kissin is he just has this unmistakable star quality the moment you hear him play. There was a sense of risk that one instrument in the vast space wouldn't communicate. But from the very beginning people were held by it. The impact was partly due to people standing just a few feet from the piano. There was an extraordinary feeling of intimacy despite having 6,000 people in the hall. He has been back every year since, and will be back again this year." This month sees his seventh Chopin recording and the start of a British tour. He complains that the lead times for such events are increasingly restrictive. "I would prefer not to have to decide upon programmes so early. In the first half of the last century concerts were planned no longer than a few months in advance. Now concerts are planned two or three years ahead and all the managers and promoters demand programmes at least a year in advance. Maybe if I become more famous I will be able to tell the promoters to just say 'programme to be announced'." He plays about 60 concerts a year and makes the point that while he learns a new piece in rehearsal, there is no substitute for playing it in front of an audience. "Rostropovich told me to always start performing a piece before it is completely ready. I find that it can't be completely ready anyway until you have played it several times in public. Rostropovich added that it improves the nervous system as well," he smiles. But having now performed professionally for almost two decades, does he ever feel the need to have a break? "I once took a four-month break," he says, "and I'd like to take a longer break at some stage - not from music but from performing music. It would give me more time to learn new repertoire, read books, perhaps to visit places I didn't have the opportunity to explore when touring. And to make new friends." He is godfather to Olivia Flatto's six year old daughter Julia. "It's the best thing we did," says Flatto, who met him on a cultural cruise. "He's a wonderful godfather. Both our children love him. He even sits at the piano with them and they play Twinkle Twinkle, Little Star. But their enthusiasm can sometimes be a little embarrassing. We have other friends who are musicians and Julia says things like 'you are a pianist, but you are not as good as my godfather'." "I've been out with him until two and three in the morning in New York," reports Toby Hoffman. "Not doing anything wild or crazy but just having dinner or visiting friends. He's not kept in a cage. We've been out with women and he's been involved with a number of women. They are often a bit older than him because I think women of his age are not usually so developed and mature." Kissin now has homes in London (a flat in Victoria), and New York (an apartment on the Upper West Side within walking distance of the Lincoln Centre and Carnegie hall; former residents of the block have included Stravinsky, Mahler and Yehudi Menuhin). Kissin says he wouldn't get married for the sake of getting married but doesn't want to remain single all his life. It sounds as if the career comes first, but Marina Bower doesn't see it in quite those terms. "First of all he is truthful to himself, and music is the major part of his life. He didn't choose it as a career. He does it because it is an urge and that's why at each concert he gives the utmost of himself without thinking of what effect it will have on his career." Gorgolione is genuinely proud about the way he has matured. personally and professionally. "His only intention is to make the best music. The hype, the career, the adulation don't mean much. He is out there to face the bull, but the bull isn't the public, it's the music itself and he is there to serve the composer. He's probably the highest-paid pianist in the world, but the money and celebrity don't mean anything to him." Just before Christmas he played a benefit concert for a charity run by Charles Hamlen that raises funds for Aids research through classical concerts. "He raised nearly $90,000," says Hamlen. "It was a private house, albeit a glorious house, and he was playing to just 100 people, but he took it every bit as seriously as he would playing Carnegie Hall." It is this attitude that will see him through to the long term, contends Toby Hoffman. "You occasionally hear people say that his music has never been as beautiful as when he was a child. I just don't think that's true. I hear a lot of development. A life in music is just that, a life. The great masters of the piano earn their reputations over 50 or 60 years. It's a continual exploration. There's no question that he's a genius. But he's a 28-year-old genius. As he matures as a person so will his understanding of the music. He understands what he wants to do and I can't see it getting anything but better." Some critics have noted a lack of emotionalism and occasional over-reliance of his phenomenal technique. His recording of Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata didn't receive universal acclaim and Kissin has acknowledged that he was not happy with that recording. "There is more to Beethoven's music than I managed to bring out," he said. "I thought I'd brought it to a higher level in some of my recitals." He is duly respectful about the roll call of 20th-century greats with whom he has played. "But while it is always a thrill to meet these great people, it is also a thrill to work on and perform great music. When that ceases the musician is finished. In our profession the feeling of awe is vital. It is something that cannot be faked." Life at a glance: Evgeny Kissin Born: Moscow, October 10 1971. Education: Moscow Gnessin school of music for gifted children. Ongoing work with Anna Pavlovna Kantor. Key concerts: 1982 debut playing Mozart's piano concerto K466 with the Orchestra of Ulyanovska; 1984 two Chopin concertos with the Moscow State Philharmonic; 1988 Tchaikovsky's first concerto with Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan; 1990 North American debut with New York Philharmonic and Zubin Mehta; Opened Carnegie Hall's centennial season; 1997 first piano recital in the BBC Proms. Key recordings: Rachmaninov piano concerto no. 2, London Symphony Orchestra, Gergiev; The Legendary 1984 Moscow Concert; Chopin Live at Carnegie Hall; Rachmaninov piano concerto no. 3, Boston Symphony, Ozawa; Beethoven concertos nos 2 and 5, Philharmonia Orchestra, Levine.  Chopin Recital by Evgeny Kissin is on RCA Red Seal records. Tour dates: March 15, Glasgow, Royal Concert Hall; 19, Manchester, Bridgewater Hall; 26, Dublin, National Concert Hall ; 28, Birmingham, Symphony Hall; April 14, Birmingham; 15, London, Festival Hall.

fields.headline: Rail passengers rival 1947 demob
fields.trailText: It is a case of letting the train take the strain. Official figures released yesterday by the department of transport show that 35.1bn passenger kilometres were travelled last year, the highest total since the 1947 figure of 37 bn.
fields.body:
It is a case of letting the train take the strain. Official figures released yesterday by the department of transport show that 35.1bn passenger kilometres were travelled last year, the highest total since the 1947 figure of 37 bn.

Then, masses of soldiers demobilised from war service were reunited with their loved ones on railway platforms.

Today's rail passengers are travelling to work and avoiding the country's clogged motorways. The department said reasons for the increase included changing work patterns and rising congestion on the roads, particularly between London, Birmingham and the north-west.

In 1947 there were 1,140m passenger journeys; the total last year was 892m. The public are now travelling further. Commuters to London think nothing of travelling up to 100 miles in each direction.

The figures show that there has been a consistent upward trend in rail patronage since privatisation. Since 1995 the number of passenger journeys has risen by 131m.

The rail statistics show a 5% increase in passenger journeys and passenger kilometres for the third quarter of last year.

With no sign that the trend is abating, more than 1,000 extra trains a day have been put into service. Plans to double and even quadruple line capacity are being drawn up by Railtrack and the shadow strategic rail authority.

Several new stations are under construction, including one near Leamington Spa and another on the midland main line between Nottingham and Leicester.

The most remarkable increase in usage is the London Underground, which is completely full during long periods of the day. There were 8.7bn passenger kilometres travelled on the tube - the highest level since records began in 1934.

They will rise further this year due to the opening of the Jubilee line extension to the Millennium dome in Greenwich. The tube system may be under stress but it is the most convenient way to travel around the capital.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: KLM in deal to auction seats
fields.body:
KLM in deal to auction seats

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that it had signed a deal with online auctioneer QXL.com on internet seat auctions for flights to cities including London, Rome, Madrid and Geneva.

KLM auctions will start on Monday for two weeks and alliance partner Alitalia will auction seats for three weeks. Seats are for flights to 14 destinations including Amsterdam, Paris and London.

In a separate statement, QXL.com said it expected to be auctioning some 100 seats a day in Holland and 300 in Italy.

US economy takes a break

The pace of job creation in the American economy slowed in February and the jobless rate inched up, the government said yesterday in a report set to reduce the pressure for aggressive interest rate rises in months ahead.

The booming economy created a mere 43,000 jobs outside the farm sector in February, the labour department said - a sharp drop from January's 384,000 gain. That figure had been boosted by "unseasonably mild winter weather", the report said.

The unemployment rate, meanwhile, ticked up to 4.1% from a 30-year low of 4% in January. Markets greeted the figures as a welcome sign.

Losses soar at net health firm

Healtheon-WebMD, the fast-growing internet healthcare company, has seen its fourth-quarter losses before charges more than triple - even though it doubled its revenues.

The firm reported an fourth-quarter operating loss before charges of $49.3m (£31m), compared with $13.1m a year ago. Revenue for the fourth quarter rose 113%, however, to $33.2m from $15.6m a year ago.

Unions protest EC inquiry

Swedish trade unions protested yesterday against what they feared would be the European commission's rejection of a planned truck merger between Volvo and Scania.

A EU source said: "On the basis of the submissions they have made so far approval is very unlikely", describing as "good reports" media suggestions the deal would be prohibited.

Swedish metal workers, worried about their jobs, complained in a letter to Brussels about the way the commission was handling its inquiry into competition aspects of the move. The civil engineers' association said a veto would be a slap in the face for Sweden and would harden anti-EU sentiment there.

Goodison steps down at Lloyds

Sir Nicholas Goodison, a senior City figure and one of the instigators of the merger between Lloyds Bank and the TSB, will retire from the bank's board at the annual general meeting next month.

He is the former chairman of TSB and former head of the London stock exchange. His colleagues Peter Nicholson and Dame Bridget Ogilvie will also leave the board at that time.

webTitle: Staff profit as Schroders breaks up

fields.headline: Staff profit as Schroders breaks up
fields.trailText: Schroders, which is merging its investment banking arm with Salomon Smith Barney of the US next month, plans to reward its employees with shares in its remaining fund management operation in an attempt to boost performance.
fields.body:
Schroders, which is merging its investment banking arm with Salomon Smith Barney of the US next month, plans to reward its employees with shares in its remaining fund management operation in an attempt to boost performance.

The group, which yesterday reported its last profits before being broken up, admitted investors in the UK had taken away £7.4bn of its business during the year because of the poor performance of the funds. However, the group received new investment from overseas of £5.2bn.

When Schroders begins operations after the investment bank has been sold, it will have almost £1bn of excess capital which it has not yet decided how to use. Peter Sedgwick, deputy chairman, said the separate asset management operation would use "progressive compensation schemes" which would see fund managers and employees holding a combined stake in the company of between 10% and 20%. "If our clients do well, our employees do well. That has to be a specific motivation," the group said.

It has put $40m into an "e-incubator" fund to allow it to take stakes in internet related companies.

Schroders also intends to roll out a private bank, aimed at wealthy individuals, as well as changing the emphasis in its fund management operation from traditional pension fund management to more specialist products.

Overall, Schroders reported record pre-tax profits of £324m for 1999, its last as a combined investment bank and asset management operation. Overall funds under management rose by 20% to £143m and the asset management business made a pre-tax profit of £162m.

Wim Bischoff, the chairman, who earned £1.7m last year, admitted that the overlap in the US operations of the combined Schroder investment bank and Salomon Smith Barney might result in 500 job losses.

He played down redundancies in the UK, however, where he said "the businesses are largely complementary".

The final dividend is 13p, making a total of 18.5p which will be paid on October 28. The shares rose 68p to £13.

webTitle: GMG and Sky eye stakes in arts channel

fields.headline: GMG and Sky eye stakes in arts channel
fields.trailText: Guardian Media Group and British Sky Broadcasting are in talks to take stakes in an arts pay-television channel fronted by former Royal Opera House chief Sir Jeremy Isaacs.
fields.body:
Guardian Media Group and British Sky Broadcasting are in talks to take stakes in an arts pay-television channel fronted by former Royal Opera House chief Sir Jeremy Isaacs.

GMG, which publishes the Guardian newspaper, is understood to be negotiating a 20% stake in the channel in return for around £3m backing. The digital station, Artsworld, will feature programming on subjects ranging from dance to design and architecture.

BSkyB is understood to have taken a 20% stake in the channel and agreed a carriage deal on Sky Digital, which reaches more than 2m homes.

Mr Isaacs first approached GMG last summer but the company is understood to have warmed to the investment because of the rapid take-up of digital services.

The station will not use the Guardian brand although there is expected to be some, informal, cross-promotion.

Sir Jeremy was at the helm of Channel 4 when it launched and his credits as a television producer include the landmark World at War series in the 1970s, All Our Yesterdays, Cold War and Millennium.

GMG sold its 15% stake in GMTV, the breakfast television group, at the turn of the year for £18.3m. Scottish Media, Carlton and Granada each took the opportunity to lift their shareholdings in GMTV to 25%.

GMG still has interests in TV production through Endemol Entertainment, a joint venture with the Dutch company Endemol. Its programmes include Changing Rooms, Ground Force, Ready Steady Cook and The Pepsi Chart.

Artsworld will pitch itself against two existing channels. Performance, an arts-based channel owned by Harmsworth Media, a unit of the Daily Mail & General Trust, has been on cable since 1992 and is available in 1.4m homes.

UK Arena, a joint venture between the BBC and Flextech, also offers arts programming and reaches 1.2m homes.

Artsworld is thought to be planning an announcement on securing investors later this month and aims to get on air by the end of the year. The company, as well as BSkyB and GMG, declined to comment.

 Unilever, the consumer and foods group, is buying Columbia TriStar's film library as an innovative way of securing airtime advertising slots on Channel 5. The deal is believed to have cost Unilever about £6m although the company declined to comment officially.

Unilever is Britain's biggest advertiser with a TV budget of £144m. It is understood the company will either barter the rights to Columbia films with Channel 5 in exchange for advertising airtime or will sell on the library for cash.

UK Arena, a joint venture between the BBC and Flextech, also offers arts programming and reaches 1.2m homes. The company, as well as BSkyB and GMG, declined to comment.  Unilever, the consumer and foods group, is buying Columbia TriStar's film library as an innovative way of securing airtime advertising slots on Channel 5. The deal is believed to have cost Unilever about £6m although the company declined to comment officially. Unilever is Britain's biggest advertiser with a TV budget of £144m. It is understood the company will either barter the rights to Columbia films with Channel 5 in exchange for advertising airtime or will sell on the library for cash.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: With shares on Wall Street flying higher once again - this time on the back of benign jobs data - shares in London simply followed suit.
fields.body:
With shares on Wall Street flying higher once again - this time on the back of benign jobs data - shares in London simply followed suit.

By the close, the FTSE 100 was showing a gain of 55.4 points at 6487.5 - its best level since mid-January. The TechMark 100 shot up another 151 points to 5604, responding to a 4% surge on the Nasdaq 100 in New York.

The British technology indicator has put on 40% in the space of a month.

Among the leaders, telecom stocks stood out once again, with Colt Telecom up 141p at £40.48 (now up 30% over the past four weeks), Vodafone Airtouch rising from 355p to 369p and British Telecom jumping another 129p to £13.03.

Those Footsie stocks which look in danger of falling out of the Top 100 when the constituents committee meets next week were under heavy pressure. Whitbread , for example, shed 25p to 513p, Scottish & Newcastle dropped from 421p to 409p and Hanson gave up 9p to 397p. Elsewhere, Pearson added 112p to £23.03 ahead of Monday's figures, when Marjorie Scardino is expected to give more detail on the group's internet plans.

The action in the biotechnology sector remained white hot. While this week's wonder stock, Cambridge Antibody , paused for breath at £38.75, Oxford Glycosciences jumped 157p to £28.05 and Phytopharm , which is looking to develop herbal remedies as regulated drugs, soared 130p to 590p. Dealers reported heavy interest after an investor presentation organised by Charterhouse Securities. Also, Xenova , working on cancer cures, rose 35p to 370p and vaccine group Cantab Pharmaceuticals put on 81p to 702p.

And while Alizyme pushed out a statement saying it knew of no reason for the sudden jump in its shares, the quote still closed 91p higher at 227p.

The move followed a news report saying it was about to update followers on the progress of its various drug developments, including one for treating irritable bowel syndrome.

Meanwhile, NMT - probably best described as a struggling safety syringes maker - jumped 11p to 92p. A vague story was doing the rounds suggesting a bid might be on the way from US group Becton Dickinson, which also makes safety syringes but isn't struggling.

fields.headline: Qwest turns out new team
fields.standfirst: New executive appointments seen as an attempt to quell Deutsche Telekom takeover rumours
fields.trailText: Qwest Communications International yesterday unveiled a new executive team to spearhead its merger with US West, but analysts viewed the announcement as an attempt to head off growing concerns of a spoiling bid from Deutsche Telekom.
fields.body:
Qwest Communications International yesterday unveiled a new executive team to spearhead its merger with US West, but analysts viewed the announcement as an attempt to head off growing concerns of a spoiling bid from Deutsche Telekom.

Rumours that Ron Sommer, the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, was preparing to meet with Qwest executives next week to propose a merger continued yesterday.

There was also talk that Deutsche Telekom had the backing of Qwest's largest shareholder, Philip Anschutz, who owns 39% of the company, to make a bid.

A spokesman for Deutsche Telekom said: "We do not speak about what we might or might not do or are planning."

It remained unclear yesterday that if Deutsche Telekom were to prepare a bid whether it would only takeover Qwest or bid for the $36bn (£23bn) deal that will combine Qwest and US West.

Qwest would not comment yesterday. But US West demanded that Qwest disclose any talks with Deutsche Telekom. In a letter, US West said: "We are extremely concerned that these discussions are ongoing with no information being provided to us. Such discussions would appear to be a clear violation of our merger agreement."

Joseph Nacchio, chief executive of Qwest, said the firm's new team would work with executives of both companies. "The new Qwest will have the speed, energy and winning attitude of an entrepreneurial internet business," he said. "We will combine the best qualities of both companies with a focus on our future, not our past."

Earlier this week Qwest and US West issued statements to say they were committed to finalising the deal, while Solomon Trujillo, US West chief executive, also said on Tuesday he would not join Qwest once the merger is completed around June.

Analysts argue the benefits of a bid by Deutsche Telekom for Qwest are clear as it would give the German telecoms operator a substantial presence in the US long-distance market and a 16,000 mile network of high speed fibre optic lines for the internet market.

Qwest also owns about 44% of KPN Qwest, a pan-European data communications joint venture, that would give Deutsche Telekom a significant foothold in that market.

Some estimates have suggested that the Deutsche Telekom could raise as much as €100bn (£61bn) to fund a bid. Mr Sommer last week hinted that the company was on the prowl for acquisitions in the US and Europe, saying the that Deutsche Telekom needed to grow.

The sale by the German government of a further tranche of its shareholding in Deutsche Telekom later this year is seen as putting pressure on the group to a deal before it loses that protection.

webTitle: Shire shares surge on approval of drug

fields.headline: Shire shares surge on approval of drug
fields.trailText: Shire Pharmaceuticals saw its market value surge £390m yesterday after winning its first regulatory approval for a new Alzheimer's disease treatment, originally developed from snowdrops.
fields.body:
Shire Pharmaceuticals saw its market value surge £390m yesterday after winning its first regulatory approval for a new Alzheimer's disease treatment, originally developed from snowdrops.

Medical authorities in Sweden approved the drug, Reminyl, which could command annual sales of more than £250m. Other European Union countries are likely to follow suit, under a "mutual recognition" procedure.

The news sent Shire shares rocketing 160p to a record high of £12.68. Shire's research and development director Wilson Totten said the decision "represents good news for everyone involved in providing care for people with Alzheimer's disease".

In clinical trials, Reminyl was shown to improve the short-term memory of Alzheimer's sufferers, and reduce the likelihood of erratic behaviour. It works by stimulating production of acetylcholine - tiny chemical messengers which help brain cells communicate with each other.

The active ingredient in Reminyl was originally discovered in the bulbs of snowdrops, by an American scientist. It could also be extracted from daffodils, but Shire now produces it synthetically.

Reminyl will be marketed on the continent by Belgian company Janssen, which will pay royalties to Shire of between 10% and 15% of sales. Shire will distribute Reminyl in Britain and Ireland. US approval is expected later this year.

fields.headline: 19 accused after $40m stock fraud
fields.trailText: US prosecutors accused several men of being involved in a money laundering and stock fraud operation run by Russian and New York mafiosi in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday. Nineteen defendants were indicted on charges of taking more than $40m from investors, following a police investigation which highlights the growth of "pump and dump" operations on Wall Street.
fields.body:
US prosecutors accused several men of being involved in a money laundering and stock fraud operation run by Russian and New York mafiosi in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday. Nineteen defendants were indicted on charges of taking more than $40m from investors, following a police investigation which highlights the growth of "pump and dump" operations on Wall Street.

Share prices are artificially inflated by fraudulent promises to investors before they are "dumped" and the proceeds pocketed. Several men with alleged ties to four of the five organised crime families in New York were accused of providing a protection service.

Members of the Russian mafia were accused of laundering the gains, the subject of several popular film and television shows in the US at present including the Sopranos, the award-winning soap based on New Jersey mobsters, and the Boiler Room, starring Ben Affleck.

Howard Safir, the New York police commissioner, said his department had launched Operation Street Cleaner in an effort to stop the growth in financial market crime. Referring to the popularity of fictional mobsters, Mr Safir added that the operation "could just as well have been titled 'GoodFellas Meet the Boiler Room'. "

Fraudulent share schemes are often called boiler room operations because of the hot, crowded conditions in the offices from which the villains call their unwitting victims.

Mr Safir said yesterday: "The mob goes where the money is." The defendants face racketeering and money laundering charges which carry sentences of up to 20 years in prison, as well as securities fraud charges. One defendant, Edward Garafola, is alleged to be the brother-in-law of Salvatore "Sammy Bull" Gravano, the mob turncoat. Another is a suspected Russian mobster.

The alleged fraud was uncovered at State Street Capital Markets and White Rock Partners, two now-defunct Wall Street firms. The arrests follow a four-year investigation which has led to other arrests. Last June, some 85 people were indicted in Brooklyn in the largest boiler-room scam ever discovered.

webTitle: Monotub aims to clean up with Titan

fields.headline: Monotub aims to clean up with Titan
fields.trailText: A revolutionary washing machine, tipped to be as influential as the Dyson bag-free vacuum cleaner, will be on sale in the high street this autumn under a deal struck yesterday by Aim-listed Monotub Industries.
fields.body:
A revolutionary washing machine, tipped to be as influential as the Dyson bag-free vacuum cleaner, will be on sale in the high street this autumn under a deal struck yesterday by Aim-listed Monotub Industries.

Monotub's Titan washing machine will be sold exclusively by Currys, the electrical retailer, for the first four months from its launch. The news sent Monotub's shares surging 77.5p to 425p, valuing the business at £52m.

The Titan machine can take 40% more clothes than traditional models and uses 75% less water. It has a unique tilted drum, which makes access easier and allows the cycle to be stopped at any point without water spilling out.

Monotub's chief executive Brian Austin said: "It's a novel type of washing machine just like the Dyson vacuum cleaner was novel. The success of the Dyson could help us."

To fund increased manufacturing capacity, Monotub is placing 610,000 shares at 330p, raising £1.97m.The machines will cost between £500 and £600 each.

fields.headline: Falling fortunes
fields.standfirst: John Lewis bonuses on the decline
fields.trailText: The 40,000 employees or partners in stores group John Lewis have been warned to expect another drop in their annual profit sharing bonus even though the company has been one of the strongest high street performers, writes Lisa Buckingham.
fields.body:
The 40,000 employees or partners in stores group John Lewis have been warned to expect another drop in their annual profit sharing bonus even though the company has been one of the strongest high street performers, writes Lisa Buckingham.

The chief executive, Stuart Hampson will announce the size of staff bonus on Thursday when the group's annual results will be published. Employees are likely to see the scale of their bonus shrink for the second year in a row after reaching a peak in 1998.

The latest edition of the company's in-house newspaper, the Gazette, reminds staff that trading profit fell 22% in the first half of the year and sales in the second half did not start to pick up strongly until October.

The 19% bonus the group was paid last year - on the group's salary bill of £467.4m - also benefited from a £34m refund of VAT.

But even if partners see the bonus percentage fall by a similar amount to the shrinkage witnessed last year, someone on an average salary of £13,000 will receive a profit share of £2,000. However, the previous government decided that tax relief on profit related pay should be phased out, and employees will be able to keep only £1,000 of their windfall tax free.

In addition to the tougher trading conditions, the group opened a large new store at the Bluewater shopping complex in Kent as well as one in Glasgow and added several outlets to its Waitrose food chain.

John Lewis has also recently announced plans to buy 11 Somerfield supermarkets and has been investing heavily to build its internet sales operation.

An official for the group said that partners were very aware that 1999 had been a tough year for retailing. "Our partners know what the trading conditions are like and while people made a lot of the fact that the bonus fell from 22% to 19% last year, the partners were thrilled with that," she said.

But John Lewis figures show that the bonus levels of the past three years have been at the upper end of what staff have received in the past 20 years.

fields.headline: Building on a flaky past
fields.standfirst: Brand values Kellogg's
fields.trailText: Battle Creek Sanatorium was a Michigan heath resort set up in the 19th century by the Seventh Day Adventist church. It was also the birthplace of Kellogg's Corn Flakes.
fields.body:
Battle Creek Sanatorium was a Michigan heath resort set up in the 19th century by the Seventh Day Adventist church. It was also the birthplace of Kellogg's Corn Flakes.

Towards the end of the century John Kellogg was the doctor in charge. His brother Will was the book-keeper and manager.

For years they had tried to improve the patients' vegetarian diet. They tried all sorts of experiments, including boiling wheat, in the search for a digestible alternative to bread.

The turning point in their search was an accident in 1894. An experiment was interrupted and a pot of boiled wheat was left to stand for more than a day. The brothers decided to roll it anyway, and the result was large thin flakes rather than the expected single large sheet of wheat.

Will persuaded his brother to try out the flakes on his patients. They liked it immediately. The sanatorium had an international reputation and its rich and famous patients asked for parcels of the flakes to be sent to them after they left.

John Kellogg set up his own food manufacturing company, with Will as general manager. Eventually Will decided to branch out on his own. He formed the Battle Creek Toasted Corn Flake Company, which was renamed Kellogg Company in 1922.

Will Keith Kellogg, born in 1860, was less well educated than his doctor brother. He left school early and spent his late teens first as a stockboy then as a travelling broom salesman, before going to work at the sanatorium as a clerk.

But he was practical, had a salesman's flair and an aptitude for hard work. When he died at the age of 91, he had made a huge fortune and had joined the ranks of America's philanthropists.

He had set up the WK Kellogg Foundation, a non-profit making organisation aimed at helping people, especially children and the vulnerable, to help themselves. In 1934 he gave it $66m (£42m) in Kellogg stock and other shares. Among other charitable donations was help for British children orphaned by the first world war.

He was a modest man, content to live in a two-storey stucco house when other wealthy businessmen were building grandiose homes.

Corn Flakes, the mainstay of the Kellogg's empire, were joined by All-Bran in 1916 and Rice Krispies in 1928. But most of the present brands were introduced after 1955.

The company has successfully promoted its products with the use of cartoon characters, including the three gnomes Snap, Crackle and Pop, reportedly the first animated figures to appear in TV advertising.

Kellogg's, which moved into the cereal market in Britain in 1924, now owns five out of the country's top 10 cereal brands. The Manchester factory can produce about 1.5m packets a day. The company estimates that 1.6bn bowls of Corn Flakes are devoured every year in Britain.

The company is working as retail adviser to the People's Lottery, the Richard Branson-led consortium bidding to take over the national lottery.

But the Kellogg's company is going through a rough patch. Sales have fallen, not least because of competition from cheaper own-label brands in supermarkets. Fewer people now eat breakfast, too.

After nearly 100 years of selling products bearing Will Kellogg's signature, the company last week announced that it was to make own-label breakfast cereals for Germany's Aldi discount supermarket chain. It said it was only a test limited to Germany. But it proves that not even a long established brand name is enough to retain the loyalty of today's cost conscious shoppers.

The directors of today's Kellogg Company inherited a very valuable brand name and are now experiencing the pitfalls of such an inheritance. Today's shoppers are helping themselves by demanding the best value for money. Will Kellogg would have approved.

webTitle: A des res with contrasting views

fields.headline: A des res with contrasting views
fields.standfirst: House prices are hard to read
fields.trailText: The average UK home shot up in value by more than £2,000 last month as the booming housing market motored into top gear with the biggest monthly surge in prices since just before the early-90s property slump.
fields.body:
The average UK home shot up in value by more than £2,000 last month as the booming housing market motored into top gear with the biggest monthly surge in prices since just before the early-90s property slump. Alternatively, the average UK home fell in value by £795 last month in what appears to be the first sign that the housing market is coming off the boil.

These were the two wildly differing scenarios presented this week by Nationwide building society and Halifax respectively, both of which claim to operate the comprehensive, authoritative barometer of monthly house price movement.

So which one got it right and which one is wrong? That is not so easy to answer, partly because the methodology each uses is so complex. "Prices are disaggregated into their constituent parts using multivariate regression analysis," explains Halifax's website helpfully.

On the face of it, Nationwide's prognosis seems the more believable: a fairly chunky fall in prices last month just does not ring true when even the notoriously down-playing officials at the land registry are talking of annual house price inflation exceeding 15%. And a glance at Halifax's data for recent months shows some alarming lurches - prices flat in September, up dramatically in October, a fall in November, up sharply again in December.

But Halifax's stance is backed up to an extent by recent Bank of England figures showing that the number of loans for new house purchases falling, and the economists in the City are certainly taking its words of wisdom seriously.

This isn't the first time the two have differed fundamentally over where they see house prices going. Three months ago, Halifax said the price of a typical house fell by 0.5% in November 1999, while Nationwide said it leapt by 1.9%.

Neither side was prepared to give ground yesterday, both declaring that the other was at fault. What is certain is that any more differences of opinion on this absurd scale and both lenders' indexes risk being left discredited.

Phone numbers

Yesterday was that Friday in the month when the US rolls out the non-farm payroll figures. Usually it is a market-sensitive number, scanned for clues about whether or not the apparently ever growing US economy is at last showing signs of overheating.

Traditionally Europe's markets hold their breath for much of the morning, wait for Wall Street to react to the figures and follow suit.

Not yesterday. Though Wall Street delivered a predictably knee jerk reaction to the better (ie, lower) than expected new jobs number, Europe had made its own decision about the day's market mover: the telecommunications sector. From Madrid to Helsinki, telecoms and related stocks were rising. In some cases the phone connection was a bit crackly. Spanish construction group Actividades de Construccion y Servicios, for example, rose 11% on the back of its involvement in a consortium which might (not will, might) win a mobile phone licence in the latest tender.

In London, BT and Vodafone were moving upwards. In Paris it was Vivendi (part telco, part utility) and Bouygues; France Telecom dipped a touch but after a 25% rise on Thursday who is counting? Deutsche Telekom, SwissCom, Dutch operator KPN and mobile phone maker Nokia showed sharp rises.

Does such a flurry of activity make sense? At the wilder end of the spectrum, almost certainly not. The flurry sparked by the Spanish tender looks more like a lottery than a dispassionate assessment of the likely licence winner.

The rest, however, is tricky to disentangle. France Telecom shot up on Thursday because it is thinking of floating the internet arm Wannadoo. Deutsche Telekom has already played the dot.com card but its reported pursuit of Qwest in the US provided motive force for the shares yesterday. Their prospects certainly look sounder than many of the e-stocks being offered at fabulous prices. Look at some of the projections for the growth of mobile phone use (say 3bn subscribers by 2005) and Nokia hardly looks overrated.

Takeover speculation runs beyond Deutsche Telekom and Qwest. Telcos are looking for partners, allies or acquisitions to give them global reach. The German company tried to buy Telecom Italia last year. Vivendi was prepared to go all the way with Mannesmann well before the Vodafone bid but was rebuffed. Today it is Bouygues, Telefonica, Cable & Wireless, Qwest, Bermuda-based Global Crossing, even BT which find themselves in the bid spotlight.

In the short term, prices can be justified by the premiums demanded in the sector. In the longer term, however, they can only be sustained by heady revenue and profit growth. Rapid growth looks achievable, especially in the mobile sector. Even so, the speed with which prices have risen suggests that expectations are outstripping reality.

webTitle: FSA calls on banks to pay for credit unions

fields.headline: FSA calls on banks to pay for credit unions
fields.trailText: The financial services authority plans to ask banks to cover the cost of regulating credit unions, the local money societies mooted by the government as a way to tackle financial exclusion in poorer communities.
fields.body:
The financial services authority plans to ask banks to cover the cost of regulating credit unions, the local money societies mooted by the government as a way to tackle financial exclusion in poorer communities.

In a speech to the Association of British Credit Unions, Howard Davies, chairman of the FSA, said that depositors in credit unions would be offered the same protection as those in banks or building societies.

In an attempt to boost credit unions, the government is giving the City regulator the power to regulate the mutual cooperatives, but while the government now meets 90% of the £500,000 yearly bill for regulation, the FSA will have to cover the cost from the bodies it regulates.

However, the credit unions, of which there are 670 in Britain, are not expected to be able to cover this cost for some time.

"I am entirely prepared, on your behalf, to ask the banks, on whom the greater part of the burden would certainly fall, to support the cost of regulating credit unions, and I have a reasonable expectation they will be prepared to cooperate," Mr Davies said.

"But it is likely they will only do so if they can be satisfied that we are regulating in a cost-effective way and also if they are assure that credit unions are making reasonable efforts to comply with regulatory obligations in as efficient a way as possible."

The FSA will issue a series of consultative documents in the coming months about its proposed regime for regulating the credit unions.

Mr Davies said that he was likely to require that credit unions had adequate resources to back their business, had robust control systems, the people running the operations are "fit" to do so and that they make "timely" reports to the FSA.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: As the sun beams on the economy, one pocket of SW1 is still under the cloud of the savage cuts of yesteryear: No 11 Downing Street.
fields.body:
As the sun beams on the economy, one pocket of SW1 is still under the cloud of the savage cuts of yesteryear: No 11 Downing Street. The position of doorman, it seems, was axed during a round of ruthless cost-cutting measures by Terence (now Lord) Burns, treasury permanent secretary from grim 1991 through to swinging 1998. Next door, we are happy to report, has kept its doorman, who is quite willing to let visitors in through No 10.

 Now for a heartwarming story that corrects any notion that institutional investment bods don't earn those simply stonking salaries. A company was planning a £10m share issue. Its bank briefed the in-house sales team,which promptly hit the phones. One salesman managed (a) to get the company's name wrong, (b) to fail to explain what it did, and (c) to admit he didn't really know much about it, save that it had some connection with the internet. Our spy waited as the called party put a final question, to which he heard the the salesman reply that, sorry, the company did not want all its shares going to just one buyer.

 After heartwarming comes stomach-wrenching, in the form of an "interview" by BBC News online with Martha Lane Fox, "27-year-old co-founder of Lastminute.com" (a holiday- booking service for those too idle to visit a travel agent), set to be worth £30m on the company's flotation (bubble permitting). "The prospect of such immense riches has already begun to take its toll, not on Lane Fox, but on her contemporaries," gushes the Paxman-style interrogator. "Whether she knows it or not, she is cited as chief victim of the emerging syndrome known as dot.com envy. Put simply, many of Lane Fox's contemporaries are bitterly envious of her success." Happily "she probably remains blissfully unaware of such seething antipathy". Probably? Why not ask her?

 Equally disturbing for those of a queasy disposition is the collapse of comestible standards at Schroders, now liberated from its merchant-banking parent. "Happy face" kiddy-biscuits are de rigeur with the coffee, we hear; part of a new culture of openness (sic) and communication (sic) a spokesman explained, sic, sic, sic...

Meanwhile, it's been a bad week for Sir William Shelton, Lady Thatcher's onetime parliamentary private secretary, who was banned for five years from serving as a company director. His involvement with Lord Moyne's Access to Justice legal-advice outfit proved his downfall, but he was not always this unlucky. Early in 1975, as the Tory leadership ballot closed, Sir William, who was batting for Maggie, bet Sir Timothy Kitson - touting for Ted - a pound that Mrs T would pull more than 110 votes. Sir Timothy bet Sir William £1 that Mr Heath would win more than 130 votes. The result - 130 for the lady, 119 for the ex-PM - was a two-way winner for Sir William.

And not a great week for the international development secretary, Clare Short, what with Mozambique and all. Omens were not good a few days earlier, when, on winging in to the Bangkok Unctad conference, she was invited to a Bahraini do, invite addressed to Britain's "minister for international sales and information". Meanwhile, she was due to lunch delegates from the world's least developed countries, but our embassy managed also to invite/insult Armenia, Argentina, Belgium, and the Czech Republic.

Back home, a mini-beef from what we old codgers call LAP, better known nowadays as Heathrow airport, re: our reference a fortnight back to a failure on the tow-truck front. The Lap-landers point out they operate no trucks and any probs re: towing of aeroplanes are down to individual service companies. Fellas, we grovel. May LAP grow wider still and wider. Onward - to terminal 10!

A splendid response to week one of our wizard comp, with neighbouring Mount Pleasant post office reeling before the avalanche of entries. To recap: you are asked to nominate products, companies, entities, every word of whose name is misleading/inaccurate/a lie. Carl Darby of Huntingdon suggested: "Investor in People", while Devra Wiseman of Leatherhead put forward: "Child Support Agency". Allan Entwistle of Buckhurst Hill in Essex kept it simple: "Microsoft", which is "huge and hard as nails". Simpler still was this week's winner, Mrs A Woodworth, of Radlett, Hertfordshire, who suggested the patchwork of local illness units noted for erratic delivery also known as "National Health Service".

fields.headline: Inside story
fields.standfirst: Playing a 52-year-old tobacco company executive in The Insider is all in a day's work for 35-year-old Russell Crowe; giving up the smokes is not
fields.trailText: Playing a 52-year-old tobacco company executive in The Insider is all in a day's work for 35-year-old Russell Crowe; giving up the smokes is not
fields.body:
New Zealand-born, Australia-based actor Russell Crowe has a way of convincing Americans he's one of them. His explosive performance as a violent but well-meaning cop in LA Confidential got many Yanks wondering why they'd never heard of him before. But now that the US public has vaguely understood that the rough-hewn, 35-year-old Crowe comes from Down There somewhere, they're even more impressed with his latest portrayal of a troubled American anti-hero. He's received a well-deserved Academy Award nomination for The Insider, in which he plays the real-life former tobacco company executive Jeffrey Wigand, whose testimony led to the first government sanctions against powerful cigarette manufacturers, and it's Crowe's performance as the beleaguered, compromised, noble and possibly mad whistle-blower that gives the film its troubling, fascinating soul. Nobody from the Bible belt could have done it better.

You neither look nor sound like a 52-year-old American scientist. What did you think when Michael Mann asked you to play one?

I thought it was a silly mistake. There are many, many 50-year-old actors who are just marvellous, and I knew my co-star was going to be Al Pacino and you couldn't have a kind of paternal thing going on. They had to be peers, two men from different tribes trying really hard to get together and realising that it would be a lot easier if they really liked each other. Anyway, I'm part way through my speech to him about all this when Michael puts his hand on my chest and says, "I'm not talking to you because of your age. I'm talking to you because of what you have in here."

I've met Wigand, and you capture the man's jittery heroism and difficult nature incredibly accurately.

I was lucky that Michael is a very organised man. I had access to the 60 Minutes interview, to all of the different news reports that were run in different places. Still, I've never played a real person before. I operate in a fictional world where, if you make a decision about your character, you can rationalise it any way you want. I realised that this was a real man who suffered a massive emotional impact because of this series of events. This guy's life changed completely, as did his opinion of himself and his self-esteem. So I had a meeting with Jeffrey. I asked a lot of really hard questions and it was a very emotional conversation, but he answered every question straight, looking me dead in the eye. I got up from that table and I thought to myself, I must honour this man.

You have a reputation yourself as a tough guy to get along with sometimes.

I am an intense bastard when I'm doing my job. I don't suffer fools and I don't mess around. I want you to be ready, prepared, let's go mate. Commit heart and soul.

Your parents were film caterers, so you pretty much grew up in the business.

From a very young age I spent the hours after school, weekends and holidays on film sets. I ran around knocking on all the doors and annoying the adults, y'know. It took away that mystery; I knew when something came on television that there was nothing behind that facade.

How, after all of this, can you still smoke?

The fact that I can go through a project like The Insider, and examine things the way I have examined them, and haven't given up cigarettes is an indication of the power of this addictive drug. It's not necessarily that I'm stupid though I will admit to that when I'm lighting up.

fields.standfirst: Family crisis
fields.trailText: Family crisis
fields.body:
It was helpful for Richard Ingrams to remind them that the Holy Family consisted of Mary, Joseph and the baby Jesus (Diary, last week). But had he forgotten that this family, which he puts forward as a role model for children, comprised a mother, a baby and a man who was allegedly not the baby's father?
Henry Feuchtwanger
Cheltenham
Glos

fields.headline: Hanging on to the telephone
fields.standfirst: First Direct is becoming an e-bank but, as Rupert Jones reports, it has vowed to carry on listening to customers
fields.trailText: First Direct took the somewhat dangerous step this week of using a press conference announcing the launch of its new online venture to highlight the dissatisfation many people have with the new breed of internet banks.
fields.body:
First Direct took the somewhat dangerous step this week of using a press conference announcing the launch of its new online venture to highlight the dissatisfation many people have with the new breed of internet banks.

The telephone bank, part of the HSBC group, has declared it is transforming itself into an "e-bank" - the latest in a wave of internet announcements by banks and building societies during recent weeks.

But rather than setting up a separately-branded internet-only venture, it says it will be keeping the phone at the heart of its new operation. In a swipe at rivals such as Egg, it has coined the slogan "the internet bank you can talk to" to highlight the fact that customers will be able to do their banking by PC and by phone, and won't be forced to do everything over the net.

Egg makes customers of some of its products pay a fee if they phone up with a query or request that could have been sorted out online.

The not-so-good news is that, as with so many of the other net bank launches, this is something of a "jam tomorrow" offering. People are able to register for the Firstdirect.com service now, but the products won't be available until the end of June.

In the meantime, it will be hard to avoid the service's new logo - a besuited, squeaky-voiced, computer-generated character called Little Fella who is somewhat reminiscent of the dancing baby on Channel 4's Ally McBeal. He is already appearing on TV screens in ads promoting Firstdirect.com.

Alan Hughes, First Direct's chief executive, says it is determined to ensure that "service remains at the heart of the online experience". He highlighted dissatisfaction in the US with online banks, some of which have been dogged by technical glitches.

In the States, one-third of customers who have opened an online account have closed it within months because of poor web service - things like not being able to get through and pages not being displayed when requested.

Mr Hughes also revealed that, despite the predictions of an explosion in the number of people doing their banking on the net, one survey found that only 17% of those who have internet access feel confident about dealing with their bank online.

Details of products that the service will offer are pretty sketchy. There will be a current account paying at least 4% interest on credit balances - at the moment, First Direct's cheque account pays a measly 0.1%.

This is clearly modelled on the current account offered by the Co-op Bank's recently-launched internet bank Smile, which pays 4.85% gross when the customer is in credit.

It is also promising "very low" credit card rates that will beat its current card offering, which has an introductory annual percentage rate (APR) of 4.9 for six months, increasing after that to 18.5.

However, Mr Hughes hinted that the online operation may not offer savings rates as high as those available from Egg, the Prudential's internet bank. "We don't need to buy custom at unsustainable pricing," he says.

Egg is currently paying 6.3% gross on its internet-only savings account and 6% on its standard net/phone/ post account.

From the autumn, Firstdirect.com customers will be able to access a "wealth management store" offering services such as sharedealing and a portfolio facility allowing them to track the performance of their shares and investment funds.

These portfolio services are becoming very popular - personal finance websites such as Moneyextra (www.moneyextra.com) and Interactive Investor International (www.iii.co.uk) have signed up huge numbers of people to theirs.

This is clearly modelled on the current account offered by the Co-op Bank's recently-launched internet bank Smile, which pays 4.85% gross when the customer is in credit. It is also promising "very low" credit card rates that will beat its current card offering, which has an introductory annual percentage rate (APR) of 4.9 for six months, increasing after that to 18.5. However, Mr Hughes hinted that the online operation may not offer savings rates as high as those available from Egg, the Prudential's internet bank. "We don't need to buy custom at unsustainable pricing," he says. Egg is currently paying 6.3% gross on its internet-only savings account and 6% on its standard net/phone/ post account. From the autumn, Firstdirect.com customers will be able to access a "wealth management store" offering services such as sharedealing and a portfolio facility allowing them to track the performance of their shares and investment funds. These portfolio services are becoming very popular - personal finance websites such as Moneyextra (www.moneyextra.com) and Interactive Investor International (www.iii.co.uk) have signed up huge numbers of people to theirs.

webTitle: What you think about having to pay for your own money

fields.headline: What you think about having to pay for your own money
fields.trailText: Britain's banks will see their already battered reputations take a further dive if they insist on pushing through their decision to impose charges on customers who want to make a cash withdrawal.
fields.body:
Britain's banks will see their already battered reputations take a further dive if they insist on pushing through their decision to impose charges on customers who want to make a cash withdrawal.

Cash machine users say this could be last straw in declining bank services. And while they admit they may not be able to find anything better in the short run, they hope that new organisations will move in to fill the gap.

Georgia Shields, 28, from North London, is adamant that NatWest will not keep her account if it lets her down by not protecting her from charges on her cash machine withdrawals.

"I use cash machines daily and I try to keep to NatWest and HSBC to avoid the £1 fee - over a year the cost of convenience would add up to hundreds of pounds."

Georgia, the head of strategy at a design company, believes the banks are swimming against the stream. "Other people are being forced by the internet to reduce costs and improve services. But the banks are doing the exact opposite. Instead of evolving, they're going backwards. The service is generally poor - and as soon as someone comes along with a better proposition, I'll give it serious consideration."

Georgia typically withdraws £100 at a time - partly for work purposes - but would be nervous of tak ing out more to keep costs down.

Cab driver Michael Madden from Islington banks with Girobank but uses machines all over London. Girobank, part of Alliance & Leicester, does not currently impose disloyalty fees on current account customers.

"It's where I am and where you can stop that decides which machine I use," he says. "That freedom is vital in my job."

Michael, 33, uses machines four times a week with typical withdrawals ranging from £10 to £50 so a fee would hit him hard.

He reckons they can't give something free and then take it away. The banks "have a cheek. If they start charging, that's just not nice."

Students and other young people typically take out small sums several times a week - often more than once in a day. Marketing student Stephanie D'Eau from Walthamstow takes out £10 four or five times a week.

She banks with Barclays but believes she will suffer if other banks take reciprocal action against Barclays customers. "If I can't find a Barclays machine or it doesn't work, then it's wrong to make me pay.If this goes through, I'll be losing over £100 a year. But I do have more than one bank account so I'll juggle the cash around to avoid the fees."

Post Office worker Vince Bartolo, 37, from East Ham, banks with Abbey National which imposes a £1.50 charge at most machines. Recently, he had to use Barclays because the Abbey machine was broken. "I went into my branch and demanded the money back. They didn't argue but took 10 minutes over it. I don't understand why they should charge but it puts me off using the machines. "

Visiting professor of den tistry Tetsuya Takamata, 53, faced cash machine charges in his native Tokyo. He uses Girobank. He says: "I'm used to fees but once you have something without paying, it is very hard to turn that around. I'm not at all happy about the proposal although I only use ATMs once a week."

fields.headline: Insurers deny mis-selling
fields.trailText: One of the more fashionable concepts doing the rounds at the moment is that of "denial", a state of affairs in which a person or group simply refuses to face the facts.
fields.body:
One of the more fashionable concepts doing the rounds at the moment is that of "denial", a state of affairs in which a person or group simply refuses to face the facts.

To the sceptical observer, the reaction this week of the assurance business to the Financial Services Authority's review of pension top-up plans would have been a classic example. While welcoming the review, the Association of British Insurers (ABI) insisted that "there's no evidence of mis-selling".

The FSA, meanwhile, estimated compensation costs for this non-existent mis-selling between £90m and £200m, or even higher.

But before packing the ABI off for a spot of psychiatric counselling, it is useful to bear a couple of facts in mind. Firstly, strictly speaking, there is, as yet, no completed case alleging mis-selling of the plans, so-called free-standing additional voluntary contributions (FSAVCs).

Secondly, in the pre-1988 days, when company pensions were stubbornly immobile, the FSAVCs were seen as a thoroughly good thing, an antidote to the horrors of finding oneself with near-worthless bits and pieces of pension from lots of different employers.

Thirdly, the "core" group of FSAVC investors the FSA is ordering companies to review amounts to, at most, 8% of the one million FSAVC customers in Britain, about 80,000 people. This hardly suggests a scandal of pensions-misselling proportions.

But all that said, the life offices could still face a hefty bill once the review is complete. FSAVCs may have been the bee's knees prior to 1988, but the review is concentrating on the years 1988-1999.

Secondly, the 80,000 figure is merely the core population of the FSA review. The authority has a secondary target group that is much larger and not quantified.

FSAVCs are top-up pension schemes that over-arch a person's changes in employment. That's the good news. The bad is that investors have to pay their own administration costs plus the expense of a financial adviser.

In-house schemes offer their own top-up plans, and these tend to be more cost-effective, because the employer usually foots the administration bill and some will also make contributions to their in-house AVC .

Thus, the core group is made up of those who took up an FSAVC when an in-house top-up with various employer subsidies was available as an alternative.

The secondary group include those in the pension schemes of the armed forces and the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

The deadline for the review is June 30, 2002.

By coincidence, this week the FSA reminded anyone sold a pension between 1988 and 1994 has only until March 31 to request a review by their pension company, assuming they have not done so already.

webTitle: Fair trading chief has eye on cash machine charges

fields.headline: Fair trading chief has eye on cash machine charges
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: cash machine charges
fields.trailText: The office of fair trading weighed into the row over cash machine charges yesterday with a warning to banks and building societies that the poor would suffer unfairly by being charged a fee of up to £2.50 for withdrawing money.
fields.body:
The office of fair trading weighed into the row over cash machine charges yesterday with a warning to banks and building societies that the poor would suffer unfairly by being charged a fee of up to £2.50 for withdrawing money.

John Bridgeman, director general of fair trading, said in a letter to the Link machine network's chief executive that he would "not hesitate" to investigate if he suspected the banks were acting uncompetitively. "I have a strong personal concern about the effects on lower income consumers and those with a restricted choice of ATMs," he wrote.

He was asking for confirmation of Link members' charges, and said "double charging" - a surcharge by the cash ma chine owner and a disloyalty fee imposed by the card issuer - would be "impossible to justify to consumers".

He urged banks and building societies to start notifying customers of any charges at "the earliest possible date" on cash machine screens, as he issued a warning that he would be "vigilant" as to any charges being set in concert.

The Cooperative Bank, one of those that offers free access to cash, said there was no commercial need for machine charges to be levied.

The issue caused concern at the highest level of government this week after Link members backed moves to introduce surcharges next year.

Barclays proposed a £1 charge, which would come on top of a disloyalty fee of up to £1.50 if someone used a Bar clays machine but was not a Barclays customer.

John Hardy, chief executive of the 34-member Link network, has written to Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, to play down the possibility of doubled charging, but the minister's office said last night he remained concerned.

Mr Byers, who will meet Mr Hardy next week, is particularly worried about flat fees being charged for cash withdrawals regardless of the amount, and on the impact on customers in areas with few banks.

Barclays, Abbey National and Lloyds TSB intend to drop disloyalty fees in favour of surcharging. Barclays set £1 as a "stake in the ground", 70p more than the level recommended by Don Cruickshank, who is investigating banks for the treasury.

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.standfirst: Two employees at either end of the scale share their experiences of working at Lloyds TSB
fields.trailText: Two employees at either end of the scale share their experiences of working at Lloyds TSB
fields.body:
Jacey Graham
Aged 39
Head of executive succession
Lloyds TSB

Jacey Graham plays a vital role at Lloyds TSB talent-spotting the bank's future leaders. "My job is to identify the high potential people who, in their 20s and 30s, show the capability of being an MD. I then ensure that they get the work experiences and devlopment opportunities to fulfill that potential," she says.

"And we would expect the graduates recruited each year (more than 70) in the Fast Track and other schemes to form part of that pool of talent."

Jacey joined the bank in 1982 after graduating in history (Exeter). She was a branch manager's assistant before moving into electronic payments and then into training.

Facts and stats: Lloyds TSB, the world's fifth largest bank, employs 75,000 staff and serves 5m customers.

The buzz? "It's working for a successful fast-moving company. There's always variety, always a challenge and human resources is a leading edge."

Must-have qualities: Leadership (taking people with you), knowledge of the hinterland (breadth of view) and being on the ball (keeping ahead of change).

Final tip: "Be pro-active about your career and seize every opportunity coming your way."

Nadia Chughtai
Aged 22
Management trainee
Lloyds TSB

By the time Nadia Chughtai started her final year at Nottingham she had made up her mind to join a blue-chip financial services company.

"I chose Lloyds TSB because of its human resources scheme - an area I was interested in," she says.

So, after completing a rigorous recruitment process (interview and assessment centre) she joined the bank in October 1998 armed with a 2:1 in history. Graduates are recruited each year to an eight month stint in specific areas of the business such as retail banking, marketing or HR.

Training: Over 18 months Nadia has had three HR placements in personnel, training and strategy. In-house workshops to develop managerial skills are supplemented by courses - and eight exams - aimed at gaining the Institute of Personnel Development professional qualification.

Progress is measured by appraisals and reviews with line managers plus an end-of-placement review. As well as having a mentor, trainees are assigned a buddy - a former graduate.

Work culture? "The atmosphere is one of encouragement - it's open and helpful."

Next move: "After my training I would like a generalist role in HR."
