fields.headline: Nasdaq and NYSE discuss merger
fields.trailText: America's two largest stock exchanges have discussed a merger of their operations in an attempt to head off increased competition and complaints from some of their largest members.
fields.body:
America's two largest stock exchanges have discussed a merger of their operations in an attempt to head off increased competition and complaints from some of their largest members.

The talks between the New York stock exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the technology-based Nasdaq market, were revealed in a document drawn up as part of a planned share offering in Nasdaq.

The document, intended for the association's 5,000 member firms, reveals that Nasd officials have held talks with several rival stock markets, including the NYSE, about "joint ventures, market affiliations and combinations".

It notes: "The rapid evolution of the worldwide securities markets requires the Nasd and Nasdaq to be proactive."

In recent weeks, Wall Street investment banks have stepped up their calls for a centralised securities market and unified regulation. The growth of electronic trading networks has led to a proliferation of exchanges and increased competition for stock markets around the world, not just those in New York. Any deal is likely to be some way off, however.

The Wall Street Journal reported that the most recent talks had broken down after the NYSE failed to table a deal. The possibility of a partnership had also failed to win much support among the Nasd board members, it said.

Analysts believe that the different trading methods and ownership structures of the two exchanges could also complicate negotiations. The NYSE still operates an open outcry system while Nasdaq is the world's biggest electronic exchange. The two compete against each other vigorously for new listings.

A Nasd spokesman said there were no negotiations between the association and the NYSE yesterday but added: "We talk to everybody all the time." Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the securities and exchange commission, is reported to be keen on the two exchanges merging although he has refused to comment.

The Nasd spokesman stressed that the association was pressing ahead with its plans to offer up to 49% of the Nasdaq market in a private placement. The document which revealed the talks with the NYSE has been drawn up in preparation for the membership vote on the private placement plans.

Nasdaq's listing, which could lead to the Nasd owning only 22% of the separate company, is seen as a way for the association to attract funds and become more competitive.

fields.headline: Empathy the hard way
fields.standfirst:
Brad Mehldau/Fleurine
Pizza Express, Dean Street, London
****
fields.trailText: The pairing of the young Dutch vocalist Fleurine and American pianist Brad Mehldau (the most acclaimed jazz pianist of the last decade) seemed an unlikely one when the former's new Verve disc Close Enough For Love was announced. But the disc has proved they don't have to exist in parallel universes, and so did this London gig.
fields.body:
Vocalist/pianist jazz duets play hard music the hard way. There isn't the sonorously reassuring tread of a double bass, or the insistent bustle of drums to give momentum - and on top of all that, the singer has the taxing task of figuring out something to do while the pianist is playing a solo, other than a little undulating, finger-snapping and shy smiling. It's a sport for the brave, the foolhardy, or the resourceful.

The pairing of the young Dutch vocalist Fleurine and American pianist Brad Mehldau (the most acclaimed jazz pianist of the last decade) seemed an unlikely one when the former's new Verve disc Close Enough For Love was announced. Mehldau was the quintessential contemporary jazz heavyweight, a meditative chamber musician of immense sophistication. Fleurine was the photogenic, standards-singing, multilingual, smooth-jazz singer. But the disc has proved they don't have to exist in parallel universes, and so did this London gig.

Fleurine sang tunes by Thelonious Monk, Curtis Fuller, Thad Jones and other classic jazz composers on her last disc, so the new mixture of Jobim, Legrand and Johnny Mandel undoubtedly sounds like a dinner-jazz move. But if she rarely raises the volume, Fleurine's work remains full of subtle impact and deft timing. If she treated Hendrix's Up From the Skies a little cautiously (as she also does on the CD), Mehldau immediately lifted it with a solo of typically awesome ambiguities and surprise turns, the swing constantly stretched and diverted by a left hand that sometimes suggests the presence of another pianist entirely.

Supertramp's The Logical Song suits Fleurine's fine timing and deceptive simplicity well, and the Mehldau solo on this theme had a character quite different from his earlier exploits, a purposeful meditation of short, explosive phrases. A Jobim episode brought out the daintier and more lyrical side of Mehldau that appeals to Keith Jarrett fans, and his rising cadence to meet Fleurine's returning thematic line (he began it when he spotted her rising from the unobtrusive backstage crouch she often adopted when out of the spotlight) was an exquisite piece of anticipation and empathy. The singer effortlessly ran her jazz credentials past the audience on the bop evergreen Anthropology (she sometimes recalls the instrument-like agility and light, glancing sound of vintage Annie Ross), and Mehldau brought the house down with his break on it, intertwining lines of such clamorous clarity and drive as to suggest a studio sample of half a dozen scalding jazz solos rather than a single one orchestrated by an improvising giant on the fly.

fields.headline: Ravishing Rosalind
fields.standfirst:
As You Like It
Lyric, Hammersmith
*****
fields.trailText: Sheffield Theatre's utterly irresistible production sets the standard for As You Like Its for the next decade, and Victoria Hamilton shoots straight to the top of the roster of great Rosalinds. Director Michael Grandage has cracked this most difficult egg, Shakespeare's 1599 romantic satire that so seldom lives up to expectations.
fields.body:
Sheffield Theatre's utterly irresistible production sets the standard for As You Like Its for the next decade, and Victoria Hamilton shoots straight to the top of the roster of great Rosalinds. Director Michael Grandage has cracked this most difficult egg, Shakespeare's 1599 romantic satire that so seldom lives up to expectations.

In theory it is a wonderfully rich psychological and social exploration of the liberating possibilities of love and of new ways to organise society. In production it often comes across as formal and schematic, the banter between the lovers dry and archaic, Orlando an immature boy and Rosalind an irritating know-it-all. As for the plot, has anyone ever really got to grips with its meanderings?

From the opening court scene played out in a grey, high-windowed state room to a Forest of Arden symbolised just by three tall trees, Grandage's production has a grave simplicity as it charts, with a flurry of snowflakes or the flutter of leaves, the journey from emotional winter to the joyous arrival of spring and the blossoming of true love.

While always visually arresting, the triumph of this production is in its clarity of storytelling. There is never a dull moment, but there is also none of that extraneous funny business that directors so often feel obliged to insert. The other key to Grandage's production is its glorious emotional spontaneity and the depth of the characterisations. Every single role, even the very smallest, has its own distinct and fiercely beating heart. Hamilton makes every line sound as if its has just formed like a bubble in her brain.

But it is not just this Rosalind who supplies new perspectives. Samantha Spiro is an unusually spirited Celia, quite Rosalind's equal and prepared to show her friend her disapproval; Lucy Briers and Martin Hutson's Phebe and Sylvius are not the usual stock country bumpkins but lovers for whom love and hate are near cousins, and Nicholas Le Prevost's Jaques is a man whose dry, donnish approach to life keeps him at arm's length from humanity.

But the heart, mind, and soul of this production belongs to the would-be lovers, Orlando and Rosalind. Ben Daniels as the disinherited younger son develops from loose-limbed, hot-headed adolescent into radical new man. The sexual electricity between him and Hamilton's Rosalind is so great that you actually long for them to fall upon and ravish each other to relieve the tension.

What is there to say about Hamilton's Rosalind except that she is mercurial, full of heart and so touchingly confused when smitten by love that it is almost as if all the skin has been stripped away from her and she is a walking wound. She makes love seem hilarious, excruciatingly painful and so absolutely necessary for both the individual and society.

Till March 25. Box office: 0171-741 2311.

webTitle: Get in training for those tricky internal interviews

fields.headline: Get in training for those tricky internal interviews
fields.standfirst: Taking the inside track should put you in front
fields.trailText: There are too many office casualties out there nursing wounded pride and damaged prospects because they failed to take an internal interview seriously. Make sure you don't fall into the same trap
fields.body:
Inside information is often the key to landing a better job, but there are plenty of office casualties out there nursing wounded pride and damaged prospects because they failed to take an internal interview seriously.

It's unlikely that your employer will hand you promotion on a plate. You'll probably have to sweat it out with the external applicants. The internal interview is only a different twist on the traditional job interview. But there are some major differences - both to your advantage and to your disadvantage - which you need to consider, and some steps to take to make sure your internal interview is a success.

On the plus side, you know the turf. Being interviewed internally means that you will be talking to your potential employer on familiar territory. For you, this makes the process less stressful in terms of research, mental preparation, and the logistics of scheduling the interview. You also have an advantage over outsiders because you are already familiar with your company's culture, its needs and goals and its structure.

Recruiting an insider can also be advantageous for your employer. Hopefully they will see you as a natural fit because you are a known quantity, and therefore less risky. Also, hiring from within is very good for morale - a boost for employees to see that advancement within the company is possible and that you're not slaving away with the risk of having no return.

However, sometimes employers think that the only solution to a slump or the poor performance of a department is to bring in some "fresh blood". Unfortunately, that's a tough battle to fight - regardless of how innovative or enthusiastic you are.

The fact that you are a known quantity can also work against you. Office politics or any slight against a colleague could, for example come back to haunt you, no matter how stellar your track record is. Even your reputation in general may influence decisions and damage your chances of success.

Therefore, don't take internal interviews any less seriously than external ones. Prepare and build your case and strategy as you would for an interview with an unfamiliar company.

Don't skip the research phase. Just because you think you know your company inside and out doesn't mean you do, especially with regard to a new position. Speak to key people in the department you'd be working in to find out what's going on and try to learn as much about concerns, objectives and goals of upper management.

Pay attention to your image - paticularly important if you are trying to move to a higher level or a different functional area. Don't forget that you are known in a certain role at a particular level, so you face the task of trying to get the interviewer to see you in a new light. Make sure that your attire, attitude and demeanour fit the new role.

There are also a few things to remember if you are likely to be interviewed by your current boss. Increase your visibility by making sure your boss knows what you are working on and accomplishing. It may be beneficial to strengthen the relationship you have with your boss, but keep a respectable distance.

Be careful about getting too chummy with your boss - there is a fine line between what is appropriate and inappropriate. Some managers consider an occasional after-work drink or weekend golf game appropriate and a great way to solidify a work relationship. Others draw the line at business lunches.

It works both ways. Too much personal information gleaned about you could work against you at interview.

It may also be time for you and your boss to bury the hatchet on any previous disputes you may have had. There is a fine line between sticking up for yourself and being a stubborn mule. Even if your boss is an incompetent idiot, he or she is still your boss and controls the next step of your career.

webTitle: How to ... flirt to get what you want

fields.headline: How to ... flirt to get what you want
fields.standfirst: Is it harmless banter or a misuse of office time?
fields.trailText: Flirting can be a highly useful skill in the workplace - just make sure you know exactly what you're doing before you employ it.
fields.body:
"Moneypenny, what giveshh?" purred Jameshh Bond. "Me, given an ounce of encouragement," replied M's faithful PA.

Thus, in Dr No circa 1962, began the longest and most successful flirtatious relationship in workplace - and film - history. Miss Moneypenny never did get her man, but guess what ... after four decades, 19 films, four Bonds, and a change of actress or two, she's still in her job at MI5. As for squeezes Ursula Andress, Honor Blackman, Barbara Bach et al? They're Bond history.

There's no doubt about it, flirting can be a highly useful skill in the workplace, a way to win over clients, get your boss on side and ease your way up the promotion ladder. Just ask Mrs Thatcher. According to members of her cabinet, she was a master of the art (and you thought it was just her iron will). Marilyn Monroe and Princess Diana were pretty good at it, too.

So what is flirting? If you have to ask, perhaps you shouldn't try it.

Business consultant and author, Judi James, says it's got little to do with sex. "People often think flirting is foreplay between people thinking of having sexual relations. But real flirting is non-sexual, a combination of body language and verbal communication.

"Flirting is effective because it has humour in it: no-one takes it seriously and everyone enjoys it. It's harmless, jokey flattery. A good flirt will have their tongue firmly planted in their cheek at all times. The best flirts may not be the most attractive people and will flirt with everyone, even members of their own sex."

Judi says accomplished flirts will:

1. "Get people's names right and use them a lot."

2. "Remember you, even if your original meeting was only fleeting."

3. "Remember things about you, like the name of your cat or the fact that you don't eat shellfish."

4. "Listen when you speak - immensely flattering."

5. "Pay subtle, jokey compliments."

6. "Laugh when you are funny."

7. "Subtly monitor your body language and mirror it."

If you flirt with someone, it will make them feel powerful and special. That's why members of the royal family learn a few details about each of their guests before greeting them. No-one really believes that the Queen shares their interest in ornothology or has read their latest book, but being asked about it is flattering.

It's the same in the workplace.

"Flirting makes it nice to be at work," says Judi. "Nobody wants to work with human beings who resemble computers."

But Angela Baron, adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development, believes flirting at work is a risky business: "I wouldn't advocate flirting as a way of getting on," she says. "It reinforces sexual stereotypes and leaves you open to being bullied. It's all too easy for it to backfire on you - you might not be taken seriously and you could become pigeon-holed and passed over for promotion.

"There's a subtle difference between batting your eyelids at someone and being charming and having good networking and inter-personal skills. I think people who flirt put equality in the workplace back years."

Judi James disagrees. She says a good flirt is a natural communicator who will always know when to stop. "You can feel when it's not appropriate, when the situation isn't relaxed or when the other person feels you're just trying to flatter them," she says. "Don't flirt with someone if they're about to hit a deadline or if they're obviously stressed. Always start with the lightest possible flirting and if you're not getting anywhere, or they're picking up the wrong signals, stop immediately. If flirting is done in a respectful way, it won't inhibit a business relationship. It's important to show your boss or client that you have a serious side too."

The key to good flirting is never allowing it to become sleazy. "There is a fine line between flirting and sexual harassment, so it's essential not to get your styles muddled up," states Judi.

"Don't touch - bottom patting is not flirting. Don't let your eyes stray to their cleavage, crotch or legs: always look them in the eye. And never be too personal with your comments.

"Some people would say Miss Moneypenny should have taken Bond to court by now. But she hasn't. Why? Because their flirtatious relationship is a shared joke."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

"Clumsy flirts are better off not flirting at all," says Judi. "If every fibre of your being says you're not a natural flirt, don't do it. It is something you can learn how to do, but it's not something you should practice."

webTitle: E-file your tax return and get a discount

fields.headline: E-file your tax return and get a discount
fields.standfirst: David Brodie looks behind the Revenue's thinking in calling on us to pay tax via the internet - but don't rush to your PC yet
fields.trailText: The Revenue's call for us to file this year's form via the internet could not be more timely. E-filing will eliminate the foibles of human processing and there is a £10 tax-free discount on offer. So how will it work?
fields.body:
The National Audit Office's latest annual report on the Inland Revenue makes the disturbing disclosure that 6% of tax returns may have been entered incorrectly on its computers last year, resulting in 500,000 erroneous tax demands.

So the Revenue's call for us to file this year's form via the internet could not be more timely. E-filing will eliminate the foibles of human processing and there is a £10 tax-free discount on offer. So how will it work?

To start, you will need a PC with internet access and a browser capable of supporting Secure Socket Layer such as Netscape 4 or Internet Explorer 4. Because of the need for security, you must first visit the Revenue's website (www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk) to register for the new service, then wait for a secret user ID which comes by post. You will then be ready to complete your return, using forms and software available on the website. The revenue's software is not compatible with Apple Macs.

After completion, submit your form giving your user ID and a password of your choice. The return will be encrypted, which, the taxman says, provides security and confidentiality. Upon receipt by the Revenue, the form will be checked immediately and you will be sent an acknowledgement of receipt or notice of rejection. (There will also be a dedicated telephone helpline.)

But don't rush to your PC quite yet; you cannot register before April 3. Also, the "supplementary pages" required to report certain types of income - such as rents and income from abroad - will not be available until later in the year. But if you are employed or self-employed, and your affairs are straightforward, you should have no problem filing after April 5.

E-filing offers other advantages apart from reducing Revenue mistakes. In particular, it automatically calculates your tax bill which means you can file four months later - by January 31 rather than September 30.

And then there is the £10 discount. This "special offer" for this year only is available only if you file your return and you pay your tax electronically, and both are done on time. (Electronic payment may be by Bacs, Chaps or debit card.) The discount will be credited automatically to your Revenue statement on January 31, allowing you to reduce the payment due on that date by £10.

The e-discount will be welcomed by recipients, but has been criticised by organisations representing groups with less easy access to the internet as an unnecessary and unfair diversion of funds to the better-off. John Andrews of the Low Incomes Tax Reform Group says: "The Inland Revenue tell me that they cannot afford to give older people on low incomes postage-paid envelopes or local telephone call rates to distant tax offices. I smell double standards."

While the scheme still has much to commend it, there are limitations. You cannot attach documents to the e-return to provide additional information or clarify areas of doubt. These would have to be sent by post. (It may be possible to provide short narrative explanations on the form itself, but only if the Revenue can sort out the nec essary technology within the next few weeks.)

Also, e-filing will not be open to partnerships, trusts or "some taxpayers with particularly complex affairs", although the Revenue has yet to define who will fall into the last group. Nor can accountants use it to file their clients' returns, although they may continue to use the electronic lodgement system introduced in 1997. But this is not very popular and offers no discounts.

E-filing will reduce tax office work, but the Revenue says it will not be firing the staff - they will be deployed elsewhere. You need not fear a sudden rise in tax investigations, as the officers involved are not trained to do that kind of work.

 David Brodie is director of TaxAid, a charity which provides free tax advice to people who cannot afford professional fees. Phone 0171 624 3768 between 10 am and 12 noon, Mondays to Thursdays.

webTitle: Economy risks boiling over, IMF warns Brown

fields.headline: Economy risks boiling over, IMF warns Brown
fields.standfirst: More rate rises needed to prevent overheating
fields.trailText: The world's top financial authority said last night that the Bank of England will need to raise interest rates again this year to prevent the British economy overheating.
fields.body:
The world's top financial authority said last night that the Bank of England will need to raise interest rates again this year to prevent the British economy overheating.

The International Monetary Fund also urged Gordon Brown to keep a tight rein on the public finances to prevent borrowing costs rising too much. "Some directors went further to suggest that a strengthening of the real exchange rate would warant a discretionary tightening of fical policy," said the IMF's executive board.

The conclusions were published for the first time by the British government late last night. They will put pressure on the chancellor to cut public spending or raise taxes - the former would infuriate the unions and the latter would enrage "middle England".

webTitle: Help: I've screwed up my future already!

fields.headline: Help: I've screwed up my future already!
fields.trailText:
I'm in my final year and realise I've chosen the wrong degree - I can't afford to start again.
Kate L, chemical engineering student, Leeds
fields.body:
I'm in my final year and realise I've chosen the wrong degree - I can't afford to start again.
Kate L, chemical engineering student, Leeds

If this feeling of having made the wrong choice has come on suddenly, it could be last-minute panic induced by the prospect of exams or the spectre of leaving education and having to find work. If it's something you've been aware of but blotting out for some time, then maybe chemical engineering isn't for you.

Either way it's no disaster. See your degree as an open-ended ticket; having one helps get you into a variety of professions. Around 40% of graduates go into work unrelated to the subject of their degree, so you're not alone in reassessing your options at this seemingly late stage.

For now, concentrate on two things: getting as good a degree as you can and finding the right work area for yourself. Don't be tempted to give up studying because chemical engineering is not what you want long-term. Employers will be more interested in the class rather than the subject of your degree. Showing you were not defeated by your mistakes will impress them and provide proof of the self-reliance and resilience they are looking for.

The components of your degree will be recyclable for use in a range of jobs. If you can't think how or where, pay a visit to the university's careers centre. It's well worth developing a relationship with these people: never again will you have such easy access to free information and help. Poor choices are usually the result of poor information. Exploit the riches on offer for this limited period.

Showing you were not defeated by your mistakes will impress them and provide proof of the self-reliance and resilience they are looking for. The components of your degree will be recyclable for use in a range of jobs. If you can't think how or where, pay a visit to the university's careers centre. It's well worth developing a relationship with these people: never again will you have such easy access to free information and help. Poor choices are usually the result of poor information. Exploit the riches on offer for this limited period.

fields.headline: Daylight robbery by hole-in-the-wall gang
fields.standfirst: With the banks' decision to charge for use of Link machines, Rupert Jones and Tony Levene look at the best ways to avoid the rip-off fees
fields.trailText: Britain's banks this week gave the green light to what critics say is high street robbery when they decided that millions of customers will have to pay potentially exorbitant charges for withdrawing their own money from cash machines. The decision could see people paying up to £2 just to take out a tenner.
fields.body:
Britain's banks this week gave the green light to what critics say is high street robbery when they decided that millions of customers will have to pay potentially exorbitant charges for withdrawing their own money from cash machines. The decision could see people paying up to £2 just to take out a tenner.

Members of the Link network of 27,000 cash machines this week decided to go ahead with "direct charging," which means that from January next year banks and building societies will be able to charge non-customers for using their cash machines. They will be free to set the size of this penalty fee, and Barclays has proposed it should be £1. These charges may come on top of the "disloyalty fees" that some banks and building societies already impose on their own customers for using other in stitutions' ATMs.

Things have moved on at quite a lick since the decision was announced on Tuesday afternoon. Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has fired off a stern letter to Link, warning that the charging proposals could contravene the new Competition Act, and even Tony Blair has spoken of his concern, saying the impact on pensioners, students, lower-income customers and those in rural areas has to be taken into account by the banks.

Clearly this one is going to run and run, but while we wait for the cavalry to ride in, Jobs & Money highlights the "good" and "bad" players on the fees front, and offers some self-defence tips on how to avoid rip-off fees.

One of the first banks to confirm fee charging from January 1 next year is Abbey National, which said on Thursday that non-customers will pay a "small fee". At the same time it will drop its £1.50 disloyalty fee. It is not saying yet what the "small fee" will be, but indicates it is likely to be more than 30p.

This would put it on a collision course with Don Cruickshank, the man appointed by the government to scrutinise the banks, who says fees should be no more than 30p.

Meanwhile, the fight-back has begun. Yorkshire building society says it will be lobbying the government and putting anti-charges petitions in branches. If those institutions pushing for surcharges of around £1 win the war, that is likely to spell the end of the current situation whereby a customer can choose to bank with an institution that allows free access to all UK cash machines.

The new fees will probably make it impossible for any bank or building society to offer free access to all UK ATMs, as customers will be charged directly by the bank owning the machine, says the Consumers' Association. The only way institutions that currently offer free access to all Britain's cash machines could continue to do this is if they refund their customers every time they are "fined" by another bank - potentially a costly exercise.

There seems to be little logic to the current highly confusing charging system with charges in one direction not matching those in the other. Royal Bank of Scotland, Nationwide building society, the Co-operative Bank and Bank of Scotland are among the big names that don't charge their own customers anything. However, things could obviously change dramatically under the planned new charging regime.

Nationwide is one of the only players to indicate it may refund any charges that its customers face for using rival institutions' machines. However, it says that if the charges are set too high - say £1 - this simply may not be viable. Bank of Scotland announced it will not be imposing any charges on either its own customers who use other people's cash machines, or non-customers who use its machines.

Sainsbury's Bank, a joint venture between Bank of Scotland and the supermarket giant will also not levy any charges. Meanwhile, Royal Bank of Scotland last year issued a guarantee that it wouldn't introduce disloyalty fees, but this runs out in November. With regard to surcharges, it says it has no current plans to introduce them. Co-op Bank says it will not charge a disloyalty fee and also has no plans to charge customers of other banks using its ATMs.

So what can you do to avoid fees for cash withdrawal and generally show your displeasure?

Open accounts with all the banks whose machines you are likely to use. This should cost nothing providing you keep them in credit. That way, you should avoid fees whatever happens.

Alternatively, move your account to one of the non-charging banks or building societies. However, the picture regarding future charges is still unclear.

Make use of the cashback facility available at the checkouts of most major supermarkets and Marks & Spencer. A growing number of pubs also offer the service. There is currently a £50 limit on the amount of cashback you can withdraw but the Don Cruickshank inquiry may recommend this ceiling is scrapped.

Guardian reader Paul Dodd, of Gloucestershire, says people who want to avoid being ripped off by ATMs should consider signing up for the Alliance current account from Alliance & Leicester, a phone banking account that also offers free cash withdrawals and deposits over almost 20,000 post office counters. "They can then get their cash from thousands of small post offices, helping these survive at the same time," he says.

Get friendly with local shopkeepers and publicans. Once they know you, they'll be willing to cash cheques.

Kick up a fuss. Write expressing your indignation to your bank/building society. Here are some postal and email addresses.

NatWest: Gordon Pell, Chief Executive UK Banking, 41 Lothbury, London EC2P 2BP, or Jeff Hartley, Head of Customer Relations, 4 Eastcheap, London EC3M 1AH. Email: customer.relations@natwest.com

Barclays: Head of Customer Service Unit, 55 Lombard Street, London EC3 3AH. Website: www.personal.barclays.co.uk

HSBC: Carole Gibbs, Head of Customer Relations, HSBC Bank, 27-32 Poultry, London EC2P 2BX. Email: carole.d.gibbs@hsbc.com

Abbey National: Lord Tugendhat, c/o Chairman's Office, Abbey National, Abbey House, Baker St, London NW1 6XL or email via www.abbeynational.co.uk.

For an organisation whose machines are on every high street and are used over 750m times a year, Link is remarkably quiet about itself.

It humbly describes itself as a "computer services company". It has a constitution but this is kept secret: "It's just a private document," it says. It is a limited company, set up in 1998, formed out of a company called Linsec (506). The website does carry some details of the accounts but does not disclose how much chief executive John Hardy earns.

Equally secret is how many votes each Link member has. It depends on the number of ATMs and the length of time of membership. The Nationwide has 6% and its allies who voted against charges - Alliance & Leicester, Co-op Bank, Coventry Building Society and Yorkshire Building Society - have a further 8% between them. But most other banks refuse to disclose their voting strength.

The Consumers' Association has challenged Link to reveal the contents of recent reports by consultants Edgar Dunn & Co and Frontier Economics. "As Link has a monopoly, there is a public interest argument in openness," says Neil Walkling at CA.

"They rubbish whatever we say but, because of their secrecy, we cannot see if their challenges are justified because outsiders do not get access to the facts. We do not know even if these reports were adopted or binned."

fields.headline: Banks and societies raise rates
fields.trailText: Several more banks and building societies have digested the last base rate hike on February 10 and begun to adjust interest rates on their savings accounts.
fields.body:
Several more banks and building societies have digested the last base rate hike on February 10 and begun to adjust interest rates on their savings accounts.

Halifax has raised investment rates by a corresponding 0.25%, its Instant Saver account now returns 5% gross (4% net) on a minimum deposit of £500. Its Premium Savings Direct now pays an extra 0.25% at 5.5% gross (4.4%net) on investments of at least £10,000 and 6.25% gross on balances of £100,000.

The bank is rewarding savers with at least £5,000 by raising the gross rates by 0.55% from 3.45% to 4% gross (3.2%net).

Abbey National has also raised its savings rates by 0.25%, Its Direct Saver account now returns 6.55% before tax, 5.24% net, on a minimum deposit of £2,000. Interest rates on its 90-Day Notice account now start from 3.65% gross (2.92% net) on a minimum deposit of £2,000, rising on a sliding scale to return 5.53% gross (4.42% net) on balances of at least £200,000.

Its smaller rival, the Portman Building Society has revamped its 90-Day Notice Account as Premier Account paying 5% gross, 4% after tax, on a minimum deposit of £2,500 with the top tier returning 6.5% gross (5.2% net) on an investment of at least £50,000.

For investors who prefer constant rates of returns, the Nationwide Building Society has launched a two-year fixed-rate deal paying 7% gross (5.6%net) on a deposit of just £1.

National Savings, the state-controlled bank, has raised investment rates on many of its accounts. New rates on the third issue of its two-year index-linked savings certificate, which go on sale on March 9, are set at 3.15% tax-free in addition to index-linking. Tiered rates on its investment account will rise by between 0.35 and 0.4 of a point from March 9.

fields.headline: After the dead crow
fields.standfirst:
Slipknot
Rock City, Nottingham
***
fields.trailText: Slipknot, straight out of metal's midwestern heartland, are both big and gross, though not gross enough, disappointingly, to send you home with the satisfyingly queasy feeling of a Manson show. The Iowa ninepiece have toned down just when, on the verge of international recognition, they should be maximising the shock tactics.
fields.body:
It's no longer enough for extreme metal bands to terrorise their fans with decibels alone. Ever since Marilyn Manson raised the stakes by turning gigs into elaborate cabarets complete with fetishism and nudity, groups have strived to make their shows even bigger and grosser.

Slipknot, straight out of metal's midwestern heartland, are both big and gross, though not gross enough, disappointingly, to send you home with the satisfyingly queasy feeling of a Manson show. The Iowa ninepiece have toned down just when, on the verge of international recognition, they should be maximising the shock tactics. One former party piece has been removed from the show: Corey Taylor's dead crow. The singer kept his decomposing feathered friend in a jar, and the legendary highlight of gigs was the moment when he'd open it, take a whiff and throw up over the front row. The man has style, so what a bore that neither the bird nor the mummified goat that took its place are currently part of the proceedings.

Slipknot still make every effort to offend, though. They create an undeniable sense of unease by cramming on to the tiny stage in home-made horror masks that, to their credit, are America Psycho-scary. Taylor's freshly exhumed corpse hood allows his dread locks to poke through like twisted tubers, while the bass player's leather pig-face shouldn't be observed by anyone on drugs. But the effect is spoiled somewhat by black boilersuits that accentuate waistlines girthier than most doom-metallers'. The night before, one of them put a Wolverhampton fan in hospital by falling on her from a balcony.

"Wake da fuck up, Notting-ham," Taylor roars. "Let me see your fists in the air or I'll piss on this guy here." A real Iowa greeting for you, but we wait in vain. Go on, outrage us. But he just straddles the microphone and storms into the first of a dozen murderous thrash numbers with titles like Wait and Bleed.

Apart from an Adam-and-the-Ants-style tribal drums finale, the music is dire, but that's irrelevant - this isn't a gig but a spleen-venting operation. Like their adolescent audience, Slipknot are miserable for reasons they can't begin to articulate. "The only thing that's real is pain," Taylor screams as he leaves the stage. Too bad he hasn't got around to working out why. It would have made an entertaining gig a memorable one.

webTitle: Judges open way for bank's loan victims

fields.headline: Judges open way for bank's loan victims
fields.trailText: The court of appeal last month criticised the Bank of Scotland mortgage conditions in the strongest terms. Lord Justice Laws said of its Stabilised Mortgage Plan: "The bank's documentation is disgracefully sloppy. It is scandalous that a major lending institution should foist this jigsaw puzzle of a contract on the borrowing public." The court's eventual ruling could reduce many borrowers' payments under these mortgages.
fields.body:
The court of appeal last month criticised the Bank of Scotland mortgage conditions in the strongest terms. Lord Justice Laws said of its Stabilised Mortgage Plan: "The bank's documentation is disgracefully sloppy. It is scandalous that a major lending institution should foist this jigsaw puzzle of a contract on the borrowing public." The court's eventual ruling could reduce many borrowers' payments under these mortgages.

Lamir Ladjadj of Acton took out a loan in 1990, but soon fell behind with his payments. In the 1990s the bank made several possession claims which were staved off by 11th-hour payments.

The idea behind the mortgage plan was that a fixed monthly amount was paid. If interest rates went up, the amount of the loan would increase; conversely, if rates went down it would decrease.

It seemed relatively simple, but the bank's documents created such confusion that it was unclear whether the arrears by 1999 were £81,000 or £40,000. The bank had decided it was entitled to compound interest although the terms did not seem to give it that right. While in the first instance the judge found for the bank, the appeal court held that the ambiguities arising from the bank's documentation needed further consideration.

Lord Justice Walker was equally unimpressed with the bank: "It is deplorable that the couple's right to their home should depend on the interpretation of four documents, which do not use a clear and consistent terminology," he said.

It wasn't just the bank's drafting that offended the court. Ladjadj said the bank had refused to negotiate with him. The court said such a refusal would be "lamentable".

The judges could not calculate how much was actually owing, but the bank's right to possession was suspended. The parties were told to use the court's alternative dispute resolution service. The bank was ordered to pay the legal costs of the appeal - with the implicit threat that there would be more such orders unless it negotiated reasonably. Ladjadj has to pay monthly instalments until matters are resolved.

The bank's spokeswoman said that this "product" was withdrawn in 1994. The bank's standard documentation has since been revised, but no one had identified these terms as being a particular problem until this decision.

Anyone holding one of these mortgages should ask the bank to show how it justifies its charges. If anything is unclear, the bank will probably give way. It is unlikely to risk running more judicial ire by going to court.

Those who have been charged compound interest will have the strongest claim for a refund. During periods of high interest rates in the early 90s the bank may have substantially overcharged many customers, even if few arguments will concern as much as Mr Ladjadj's £41,000 discrepancy.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Eagle lays a golden egg for amateur investors

fields.headline: Eagle lays a golden egg for amateur investors
fields.trailText: The best performing technology fund in the City chalked up a gain of 220% in 1999. But that's peanuts compared to the 2,439% gain achieved by a group of 13 workers in an investment club at a factory in North Yorkshire.
fields.body:
The best performing technology fund in the City chalked up a gain of 220% in 1999. But that's peanuts compared to the 2,439% gain achieved by a group of 13 workers in an investment club at a factory in North Yorkshire.

The Golden Eagle Nest invested £2,000 during the year but by the end of 1999 was sitting on a cash pile of £16,000. What's more, since January 1, the £16,000 has nearly doubled again, to hit just over £30,000 this week. Yesterday, it was named the Proshare Most Successful Investment Club of the Year, beating the UK's other 6,000 clubs to notch up the biggest gain in 12 months.

The club wasn't a one-off; 115 clubs earned their members more than 100% in gains during 1999, with five making 500% or more.

Investing in high-technology and internet stocks was the key to Golden Eagle Nest's success. Formed in December 1998, the club's first investment was in Infobank, which specialises in e-commerce software. The stock was bought at 77p in January last year, but by December it had leapt to £18.35. It hasn't stopped there. Infobank were this week trading at £38 and the club believes there is more to come.

Investment clubs work by a group of friends or work colleagues pooling together a small amount of money each month, typically £25-£50 each, to buy shares. The group then meets monthly in a member's home, or in a pub or a club, to discuss which shares to invest in.

The idea is that everyone gets an opportunity to research particular shares and express an opinion then a vote is held on which shares should be bought. The clubs have soared in popularity, with the number doubling from 3,000 to 6,000 during 1999.

Golden Eagle Nest was started by Garry Morgan, a technical supervisor at Ward Building Components, which produces cold-rolled metal components at a factory near Malton. "I've seen people forming lottery clubs, but you'll never see that money again. I thought we could learn from each other and spread the risk, so I put up notices around the organisation. Thirteen people came forward, and we agreed to start with just £10 per month each.

"One of the guys came up with Infobank, and we decided to go for it because we believe e-commerce is going to be big business in future. We also thought it had the potential to make a lot of money, so we were happy with it being high-risk. We thought we'd be lucky if it tripled in value."

Halfway through the year the club diversified into something closer to home, a construction company called Breedon. But it failed to take off. The shares were sold and more money was put into Infobank, now at £7 a share, plus another internet stock, Kewill. Bought at £12.30, it rose to £15.60 by the year end and is now trading at £25.

"We are only thinking about taking profits because of tax considerations," says Mr Morgan. "We still believe in Infobank. But at some point this year we hope to move back into a construction stock or a blue chip."

One sign of the club's success is that another investment club started at the factory this week with 14 members.

webTitle: Bowled over by the joys of freedom in retirement

fields.headline: Bowled over by the joys of freedom in retirement
fields.standfirst: The government is considering a new plan to give people the opportunity to enjoy their money however they want in their old age. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: People will have much more control over the way they can use their pension fund when they retire if new proposals from an influential group of experts are taken on board by the government.
fields.body:
People will have much more control over the way they can use their pension fund when they retire if new proposals from an influential group of experts are taken on board by the government.

If adopted, their plans would mean some people being freed altogether from the shackles of having to buy an annuity. Many others would only have to use a small part of their pension fund to purchase one, leaving them free to use the rest of the money in other ways.

The group's ideas will be cheered by those approaching retirement who are dreading the moment they will have to buy an annuity - the financial product that will provide them with a guaranteed regular income for the rest of their life.

Annuity rates have plummeted in recent years because of falling interest rates and people living longer, resulting in steadily shrinking retirement incomes. So it's no wonder there have been many calls for an end to the current system, where all those with a personal pension or who belong to a money purchase company scheme are forced to use most of their pension fund to buy an annuity. But the government fears if people can do whatever they want with their pension fund money, they'll squander it and then fall back on the state for support.

The Retirement Income Working Party, a group of academics and representatives of pension companies, has been wrestling with this knotty problem and has come up with what it reckons is the solution. In a report published this week, it says that when people retire, they should not have to use all their pension pot to buy an annuity.

Instead, an individual's only obligation should be to ensure an income that will keep him or her above state support for the rest of their life. The group says this "minimum retirement income" should be £140 a week. It would include the basic state pension, so if someone gets the full basic pension of £66.70 a week currently, they would require another £73.30 to hit the target.

The group proposes that any shortfall would have to be met by the individual buying an index-linked annuity. So if the person only has the basic state pension, they would have to buy an annuity that would provide an income of just over £70 a week - at current prices such an annuity would take around £55,000 of a 65-year-old man's pension pot and £62,000 of a 65-year-old woman's. But if they have other guaranteed income on top of the basic state pension, that will reduce the size of the annuity that has to be bought.

Those people who can guarantee they have a regular income equating to £140-plus a week which will last for the rest of their life would escape having to buy an annuity. Someone getting the basic state pension plus, say, £20 a week out of the state earnings-related pension (Serps), and who was also in a final salary pension scheme for a while, may find that all that adds up to £140 or even more. He or she wouldn't have to purchase an annuity because they would be judged to have met the minimum retirement income requirement.

Meanwhile, many of the people who would have to buy an annuity will only have to use part of their pension pot to do so, and may well end up with quite a bit left over. The working party suggests that people should have "the maximum freedom" to invest the rest of their fund in a range of ways. An individual might wish to invest the money in something like a unit trust in order to provide them with a regular income plus capital growth.

So how might all this work in practice? The report gives the example of John Smith, 65, who has worked all his life and has decided to retire. For a few years he was a member of a final salary company scheme. However, for quite a while he didn't have access to a company pension scheme, and so he paid into a personal pension.

He has the following pension entitlements and assets: a basic state pension of £3,471; a final salary company scheme entitlement of £1,000 a year (not index-linked); and a personal pension plan with assets of £150,000. The minimum retirement income (MRI) target figure is £7,280 a year (52 x £140). John can take up to 25% of the £150,000 in the personal pension plan as a tax-free lump sum - that's a maximum of £37,500. He's decided to take the full amount.

John begins by deducting the basic state pension from the MRI target figure. The amount left is £3,809. The next stage is to consider any other pension entitlements. John's final salary company pension will provide a fixed income of £1,000 a year. Suppose this is treated as equivalent to an index-linked income of £779. Take this away from the £3,809 and that leaves £3,030. As he doesn't have any other bits of pension knocking about, John must use some of the money in his personal pension plan to buy an annuity paying £3,030. The current market price for this sort of annuity is £45,866.

Once you've knocked off the £37,500 that John is taking as a lump sum, and then deducted the £45,866, that means he's left with £66,634 of the original £150,000, which he can then perhaps invest in a unit trust or similar vehicle.

webTitle:
Revenue puts 
 
pressure on husband and wife businesses

fields.headline:
Revenue puts 
 
pressure on husband and wife businesses
fields.trailText: Husband and wife partnerships of the fiscal rather than the emotional variety could be nearing their end if the government pushes through its proposals on "service companies" in the budget later this month.
fields.body:
Husband and wife partnerships of the fiscal rather than the emotional variety could be nearing their end if the government pushes through its proposals on "service companies" in the budget later this month.

"It's all part of the Inland Revenue attack on service companies - the one person outfits that do the same job as an employee but end up with a far better tax deal," says Martin Donn at accoun tants Blick Rothenberg. "But it's not just companies. Partnerships where one spouse pays the other a small sum to avoid tax and national insurance will also be hit.

"They will now have to show that expenses are 'necessary' as well as being 'wholly and exclusively' for the business - and that's a far more difficult task."

So far, the combined brains of the accountancy profession have not come up with an immediate answer other than to make hay while the present rules last - probably until the end of this tax year on April 5. Depending on the new rules, they say, husband and wife partnerships may have to split or change the terms and conditions with which they deal with others.

But while those with service contracts will be concentrating on how to make the best of a bad job, there are still plenty of tax planning opportunities which must be taken over the next month if they are not to be lost forever.

Individuals, say accountants Mazars Neville Russell, should check they have claimed all their allowances such as the married person's allowance and the additional personal allowance paid to single parents with children in full time education.

You can claim back six years so the earliest year to apply for a rebate is 1993-94.

Many people including the self-employed and those who are directors of their own companies can either defer or advance income. It is worthwhile putting off a pay cheque until after April 5 if your earnings are going to fall next year - you could end up in a lower tax bracket.

The opposite applies if you expect next year to be better paid. Deferring income could also reduce self assessment payments for 2000-01.

Investors in high flying shares should consider selling just enough to use up their £7,100 capital gains tax allowance. Few bother, but once the tax year is passed, the CGT free slice is gone for all time. It could save £2,840. Spouses each have their own allowance.

Tax on the company car perk - if you have one - depends on how far you drive each year on business. The two key points are 2,500 and 18,000 miles. If you are near either threshold then getting out and seeing business contacts could be a good idea.

But tax inspectors will not buy the idea of consecutive days in Land's End and John O'Groats without a lot of persuasion and proof.

Mazars says not to forget pensions - one of few remaining areas where a top rate taxpayer can obtain a full rebate. Personal pension contributions have the great advantage that they can be offset against earnings in a previous tax year should you wish - so you could pay in more than one year's earnings would justify.

Finally, structured payments through gift aid or "give as you earn" payroll schemes offer big tax reliefs to charities - and that does not apply to the cash you put in collecting boxes.
